Title: Stuck at home? Rustle up some healthy road-side snacks
Content:

How to make it

The joy of eating out, especially from a popular road-side vendor, is indescribable. There is something about digging into a plate of piping hot gobi manchurian or trying one of the 99 varieties of dosas, etc. Eating at a road-side outlet is when we, most often, overlook hygiene and give in to cravings. But now is not a good time for that, what with Bengaluru battling cholera and COVID-19 scares simultaneously.In the last two weeks, Bruhat Bengaluru Mahangara Palike officials have been cracking down on street vendors who have not been following basic hygiene norms, following a surge in gastro-intestinal disease cases in the city. And now, with the city on temporary lockdown and everyone left with spare time at hand, how about making sure that you are not missing out on your favourite road-side delicacy, but with a healthy twist? Try these recipes at home. What's best is that you can even make a family activity out of it. Here’s to healthy munching...2 medium sized sweet potatoes (with skin on)2 tbsp avocado or coconut oil (optional)1 tsp chaat masala2 tbsp lime juicePreheat oven to 190 C. Cut potatoes in half lengthwise and transfer to a baking sheet. Drizzle with a little oil and massage to coat. Place cut side down on the baking sheet.Bake for 25-35 minutes, or until caramelised on the edges. When you press on the top of the potatoes they need to have a little give.Enjoy as is, or top it with chaat masala and lime juice.Calories: 120Carbs: 35 gramsProtein: 4 gramsFat: 0.3 gramsFibre: 6.6 grams1 green apple peeled and sliced1 cucumber peeled and sliced1 radish peeled and sliced4 green chillies1 tsp salt½ tsp black salt1 tsp lime juice2 tbsp chopped coriander leavesGrind the green chillies with salt, black salt and lime juice. Rub this on the slices of apples, cucumber and radish. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Calories: 85Protein: 0.3 gramsCarbs: 31.8 gramsFibre: 7 gramsFat: 2.2 grams½ cup muesli¼ cup roasted peanuts½ diced boiled potato2 tbsp boiled sweet corn2 tbsp chopped tomatoes2 tbsp lemon juice1 tbsp chaat masala2 tbsp chopped coriander½ tsp chopped green chilli¼ tsp saltIn a bowl, add the muesli and peanuts. Mix together the chaat masala and lemon juice in a small bowl and keep it aside.In another bowl, add the potatoes, tomatoes and corn and mix gently.Now, add the chopped green chillies and coriander.To this, add chaat masala mixture and mix well.Taste the mixture and accordingly add lemon juice and salt. Serve immediately, else it will get soggy.Calories: 280Protein: 10 gramsCarbs: 40 gramsFibre: 7 gramsFat: 11 grams250 grams minced chicken2 eggs3 tbsp edible oil2 big onions finely chopped2 medium sized tomatoes finely chopped1 tsp garlic paste1 tsp ginger paste1/2 tsp cumin powder1 tsp red chilli powder1/2 tsp turmeric powder1/2 tsp chaat masala1 cup whole wheat flour1 and 1/2 cabbage finely chopped1 beetroot (medium size) (finely chopped)To prepare the dough for parathas, in a bowl, takewholewheat flour, add salt and one tablespoon edible oil. Make the dough adding adequate water. Make two thin parathas and half cook them on the pan.Break an egg into a bowl and beat it, adding salt and pepper powder. Add half a tsp of oil on tawa and pour in the egg mixture. Place the paratha on top of the egg mixture and cook for a few seconds. Then, remove from heat.— chop vegetables thinly lengthwise. Keep aside until chicken is ready. In a bowl, add red chilli powder and turmeric powder. Mix it well with the minced chicken. Add one tablespoon of salt and two ablespoons of chaat masala. Mix it well. Add a cup of water to it and cook until the chicken is tender. Add chopped coriander leaves to it and keep it aside., add chicken mixture to the side with egg, add on green chutney (optional) and sprinkle sliced vegetables over it. Take a pinch of chaat masala and sprinkle over the onions. Wrap/roll the paratha and cook for a minute.Calories: 267(per frankie)Protein: 4.6 gramsCarbs: 36.1 gramsFibre: 3 grams2 cups finely chopped coriander leaves1 green chilli (optional)½ inch ginger finely chopped¼ to ½ tsp lime juice (as per taste)½ tsp cumin powder½ tsp salt (as per taste)1 to 2 tsp water for grindingWash coriander leaves well in warm water and chop themroughly. Add chopped green chilli, ginger, cumin powder, chaat masala, lemon juice and salt in a small blender jar. Add water and grind to a smooth chutney.1 cup cashew nuts1 cup almondsSalt to tastePowdered jaggery to taste4 tsp Coconut oilDry roast the nuts till crisp. Grind in a mixer along with salt, jaggery and coconut oil, until you get a paste with theconsistency of a dip.Store in a glass jar in the fridge.(*All measurements are in tbsp-tablespoon, tsp -teaspoon quantities)(Recipes by wellness coach Kuhoo Gupta and nutritionist Preety Tyagi)

Title: When my friend dumped me
Content: I have often spoken about cutting out people from my life, and actively support this form of cleansing. I believe it’s cutting out toxicity. However, I did not think I would be the person who would be at the receiving end of this.I have sat down with friends and told them exactly who has been holding them back in life, who is bringing inthe toxicity and who needs to go.I have done this for myself as well.I was always that reliable person to whom people came for sound advice, especially when it came to relationships.I felt I had gone through a lot pretty early in life and had a very practical, empathetic and mature outlook. But I did not know everything. No one does, and that isthe learning curve in life that everyone talks about – the things we accept we don’t know.I was pretty fond of this school friend of mine. She was cool, witty and caring, all at the same time. I was in love with her. Since life takes an unknown turn every now and then, I couldn’t maintain my closeness with her. We still met a handful of times a year. On birthdays, important dates and festive holidays.I thought everything was okay. Once college got over and both of us started working, we had time to take out for each other. However, everytime we met, she would comment on how I was intrusive and had a strong opinion on other people’s lives. Maybe I did, I didn’t make much of it.Then those comments just became two words: Aunty Acid.I don’t even know what she meant and a Google search of what it meant was of no help. I did get offended but would choose not to react. I let it all pass, until one day both of us got into a huge fight, in the middle of a buffet breakfast at a hotel.I thought things would fall into place in time. It’s been two years since that fight and I haven’t heard from her. She, just like me, spoke about letting go of people who did not “feed the soul”. I just didn’t think I was one of them. She removed me from her social media, and till date avoids events where she knows I might show up.She’s blocked me off WhatsApp too. I was over that fight after a week or so and tried to get her to talk to me, but clearly life is not a wish granting machine.She thought that I was overbearing and annoying because of my habit of telling people what to do. Now that I think of it, she had her reasons to dislike me. I was trying too hard to hold on to that last straw of our friendship. She wanted out and she took the first option she got.Was I hurt? Yes. Did I forgive her? Yes. Did I understand her reason? No.Friendships can’t be forced and I should have known. I did not need a wake up call, it was more like... this happens to people around you, you have done this to your own friends, so you are at as much risk as anyone else to be cut out. I was toxic and I still cannot come around to the fact that it happened to me. I hold my friend in high regard, wherever she is. But I too now do not wish for her to be a part of my life anymore.“This happens to people around you, you have done this to your own friends, so you are at as much risk as anyone else to be cut out. I was toxic and I still cannot come around to the fact that it happened to me”By: Yashi Marwaha

Title: Celebrities taking up WHO’s ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ irk water conservationists
Content: Over the past few days, a number of celebrities took up the World Health Organization (WHO’s) ‘Safe Hands Challenge’, in a bid to encourage people to maintain personal hygiene amid the viral disease outbreak. While many have lauded the initiative shown by Sachin Tendulkar, Deepika Padukone, PV Sindhu, Dia Mirza and Shilpa Shetty among others, these videos on social media have certainly irked a lot more, as concerns are being raised over them wasting water. So much so that the clips shared by Dwyane Johnson and Kusal Mendis were even trolled online. As we observe World Water Day today and pledge to work towards a greener and a more sustainable future, Bangalore Times speaks to experts to understand why water conservation needs to be taken more seriously…“Bringing down the usage of water for sanitation has always been a challenge. According to international standards, every person requires only 135 litres of water per day for sanitation, but many are using water way beyond this amount. What we need keep in mind here is that hygiene is not about using too much water, but it is about how effectively use it. And the WHO challenge has once again triggered concerns over the urgent need to reduce water wastage,” says Kshithij Urs, Additional Professor of Public Policy at National Law School of India University.“Wasting water is a crime, and one needs to be more thoughtful while conveying the message of hygiene amid the COVID-19 outbreak. We need more effective ways to handle it, keeping water conservation in mind,” says water expert Sushmita Sengupta, who is also the Programme Manager at Centre For Science and Environment (CSE).According to her, these are tough times and, hence, we need to come up sustainable solutions. “Almost 80% of the freshwater we use is converted into wastewater. Thus, when we flush 100 litres of freshwater, 80 litres of it go into the sewer as wastewater. Freshwater is converted to greywater (coming out of kitchen and bathroom) and blackwater coming out of toilets. And, treating that wastewater is costlier than treating drinking water,” she explains, adding, “Water-efficient fixtures can be a solution to water wastage.”Speaking about solutions, Kshithij also points out the need for a pubic programme to support people to buy taps that are frugal. “The ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ needs to go beyond social media opportunities for celebrities. They should look at conveying the message in a more socially-equitable and environmentally-sustainable manner,” he adds.is an urgent necessityThe average water availability in India is just 100 litres per person a day (lpcd), as opposed to the prescribed standard of 135 lpcd. Of this, nearly 30% water is used for flushing and about 50% is used for bathing, washing and cleaning.Taps: 10-18 litres/minute depending onthe pressureShowers: 10-25 litres/minuteToilets: Single-flush toilets use 10-13 litres/flush(Source: Parryware Roca)In her ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ video, though, actress Anushka Sharma was seen urging her fans not keep the tap open while scrubbing their hands. She says, “Try to save water. While washing your hands, don’t let the tap on, that’s also not good. You will be wasting a lot of unnecessary water which is also not required. (sic)”

Title: Celebrities taking up WHO’s ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ irk water conservationists
Content:
Over the past few days, a number of celebrities took up the World Health Organization (WHO’s) ‘Safe Hands Challenge’, in a bid to encourage people to maintain personal hygiene amid the viral disease outbreak. While many have lauded the initiative shown by Sachin Tendulkar , Deepika Padukone, PV Sindhu, Dia Mirza and Shilpa Shetty among others, these videos on social media have certainly irked a lot more, as concerns are being raised over them wasting water. So much so that the clips shared by Dwyane Johnson and Kusal Mendis were even trolled online. As we observe World Water Day today and pledge to work towards a greener and a more sustainable future, Bangalore Times speaks to experts to understand why water conservation needs to be taken more seriously…

‘Reducing water for sanitation has been a challenge for a long time’

“Bringing down the usage of water for sanitation has always been a challenge. According to international standards, every person requires only 135 litres of water per day for sanitation, but many are using water way beyond this amount. What we need keep in mind here is that hygiene is not about using too much water, but it is about how effectively use it. And the WHO challenge has once again triggered concerns over the urgent need to reduce water wastage,” says Kshithij Urs, Additional Professor of Public Policy at National Law School of India University .

‘Water-efficient fixtures can help limit water wastage’

“Wasting water is a crime, and one needs to be more thoughtful while conveying the message of hygiene amid the COVID-19 outbreak. We need more effective ways to handle it, keeping water conservation in mind,” says water expert Sushmita Sengupta, who is also the Programme Manager at Centre For Science and Environment (CSE).

According to her, these are tough times and, hence, we need to come up sustainable solutions. “Almost 80% of the freshwater we use is converted into wastewater. Thus, when we flush 100 litres of freshwater, 80 litres of it go into the sewer as wastewater. Freshwater is converted to greywater (coming out of kitchen and bathroom) and blackwater coming out of toilets. And, treating that wastewater is costlier than treating drinking water,” she explains, adding, “Water-efficient fixtures can be a solution to water wastage.”

Speaking about solutions, Kshithij also points out the need for a pubic programme to support people to buy taps that are frugal. “The ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ needs to go beyond social media opportunities for celebrities. They should look at conveying the message in a more socially-equitable and environmentally-sustainable manner,” he adds.

Why water conservation

is an urgent necessity

The average water availability in India is just 100 litres per person a day (lpcd), as opposed to the prescribed standard of 135 lpcd. Of this, nearly 30% water is used for flushing and about 50% is used for bathing, washing and cleaning.

The amount of water used in standard fixtures

Taps: 10-18 litres/minute depending on

the pressure

Showers: 10-25 litres/minute

Toilets: Single-flush toilets use 10-13 litres/flush

(Source: Parryware Roca)

Meanwhile, what Anushka said...

In her ‘Safe Hands Challenge’ video, though, actress Anushka Sharma was seen urging her fans not keep the tap open while scrubbing their hands. She says, “Try to save water. While washing your hands, don’t let the tap on, that’s also not good. You will be wasting a lot of unnecessary water which is also not required. (sic)”

Title: The lure of chikankari
Content: If spring-summer had a fashion avatar it would probably be a chikankari kurta. The lightweight, delicate — usually floral embroidery — in white thread on a light airy pastel-hued fabric is what summer dreams are made of. As the temperature soars, chic chikans come marching out. And this year it goes beyond the kurta. From sarees to festivewear and bustier tops to pants – chikan is everywhere. Designers are constantly adding new stitches and fabrics to keep the age-old embroidery up-to-date. Creative director of House of Kotwara, Sama Ali, says that chikankari originated to ease the hot summer of India and it was traditionally done on fine cotton for a variety of silhouettes. “Now with modernisations of various ethnic crafts, one can find chikankari on swimwear cover ups,” she says. Its soft and subtle tone-on-tone embroidery translates well on easy-breezy ensembles.MANISH MALHOTRA; INSTAGRAM@KANIKAKAPOOR_HOUSEOFCHIKANKARIChikan literally translates to embroidery, and is typical to Lucknow, so much so that Geographical Indication Registry has accorded the craft Geographical Indication (GI) status in December 2008. Ali feels that it’s because of cooperatives like Sewa and Mijwan, chikankari continues to be relevant. “There’s constant innovation of the craft itself as seen in our collections and works by Abu Jani-Sandeep Khosla and Rahul Mishra. Over the years, chikan has moved beyond cotton to other fabrics such as organza, georgette, silk and has also been utilised in bridal outfits and western silhouettes. The possibilities are endless, as we see a fusion of different motifs and techniques,” she adds.ANJUL BHANDARIDesigner Anjul Bhandari who has been working with chikankari extensively and uses it to create a heavily embellished festivewear calls it elegant and graceful. “It works very well on pastels and light fabrics like muslin, linen, georgette, chiffon and cotton which are the ideal fabrics for this weather,” she notes. Bhandari has developed new motifs which are feminine, modern and even geometric. Using signature highlights like Japanese baby pearls, baby mirrors and sequins and zardozi and gold and silver beads, the ensembles are made to look bride ready.Chikankari’s core technique works well with modern or western silhouettes from gowns to skirts and capes. Bhandari suggests adding elements to make the embroidery stand out more. For Ali, it’s the constant dilution and wrong representation of chikankari that has affected the craft negatively.NOORKARI CHIKANKARIChikankari consists of 32 techniques and what we see is mostly keel or jaali work – and it’s more intricate and versatile than that. Ali says that the original handmade chikan is a long and laborious process. “Being a price sensitive market, people are now focusing on the cost than the quality that has a detrimental effect on the authenticity of contemporary chikankari,” she notes. Bhandari insists on buying from a verified genuine source and thanks to being geo-tagged, only chikankari from Lucknow or the Awadh region is authentic. She adds, “If you can buy chikankari, think about it as an investment rather than just any purchase. You are investing in heritage.”1. PRAMA BY PRATIMAA PANDEY2. Kareena Kapoor Khan in a Manish Malhotra lehenga;3. Deepika Padukone in a Rahul Mishra saree;4. Sonali Bendre wears a heavy Abu-Sandeep creation5. Jhanvi Kapoor keeps it simple;6. Sara Ali Khan likes her easy-breezy kurtas

Title: Change of diet or mindset?
Content: Which one will you choose? Mindset 1: This food will make me fat and sick.Mindset 2: Whatever I eat is healing and nourishing for my body.Mindset matters. Your mind is a powerful tool and it can either be your best asset or your worst enemy. There is continuous communication between your body and your mind. What your mind thinks, envisions and sees, it accordingly sends an indication to your body and your body responds to the indication by manifesting every one of those thoughts.If you are the one with Mindset 1, and label a particular food as “fattening”, then that is exactly how it is going to be for you. On the contrary, if you are the one with Mindset 2, label it as “healing” or “nourishing”, then it will behave that way.When clients come to us with their health concerns, even before getting them started with our protocol, the first thing we ask them is whether they believe they will be fine or not. If the answer is yes, then we know they are on right path. However, if they say “no”, we know a lot of time and effort has to be spent on coaching the client’s mindset.A mindset change came come in the form of ‘hope’ too. Today, people spend so much money around cancer treatment, fly across the world, get hold of top doctors, nutritionists for dietary changes, change water filters, include superfoods, new treatments like immunology, immunotherapy and do every single thing needed but do not practice and give HOPE to people with cancer affirming that cancer doesn’t mean the end of life and that there is a possibility of living life undeniably normally.Take another example. While so many people going through chemotherapy and radiation experience side effects that they dread, many don’t even know what these side effects are and walk out of hospitals with zero side effects, full of energy and some even resuming work right after a radiation of chemo session. Same drug, same cancer but different outcomes. Of course, everyone is different (in terms of their state of mind, genes, stage of disease), but keeping a strong mindset is key. What you believe, so shall it be. The moment a person starts to give up from the mind, the body soon starts giving up too. Without the right mindset, we cannot heal. Instead, we lock our own success with poor mindsets.Having said that, it isn’t realistic to have a positive mindset always. We are humans and it’s natural to go through negative feelings. Real freedom is when you can take yourself away from your own prison and trap of self-limiting beliefs and mistaken mindsets. Your body achieves what your mind believes.There are more than 60,000 thoughts that pass our mind every single day, but we can at least try to be more aware of when our mind starts to slip towards negative thoughts and use certain techniques like positive visualisations, positive affirmations, meditation, praying and practicing hope.

Title: The mystery around Amala Paul’s ‘marriage’
Content: During the promotions of her film Aadai, Amala Paul has revealed that she was in a relationship, but did not disclose the identity of her partner. Industry insiders speculated that the actress was in a live-in relationship with Mumbai-based singer Bhavninder Singh . Adding weight to these speculations, the singer had come on board as a co-producer for Cadaver, a film that marks the actress’ debut as a producer, and had also begun to handle her work commitments. The two were also frequently posting pictures of each other on their Instagram pages as well.On Friday, a few pictures that showed the two taking part in a marriage ceremony were posted on Bhavninder’s Instagram account. The singer had captioned the pictures with the hashtag #throwback. Another Instagram profile, named Brian Siddhartha Ingle, too, had uploaded these pictures and posted, “Some beautiful wedding pics of my friends Amala & Bhuvi during these difficult times.”The pics soon went viral, with many speculating that Amala had married Bhavninder in a private ceremony some time ago. But interestingly, as soon as the pics started trending, Bhavninder, who had a public profile, deleted his post and a few hours later, also made his profile a private one. Brian, too, has deleted them from his page.While we tried reaching out to Amala to get her version of this story, her publicists stated that they weren’t aware of a wedding. Another source told us that Amala and Bhavninder had met through a common friend, and had dated each other, but have now broken up. Lending credibility to this version is the fact that the actress has unfollowed the singer on her Instagram page.

Title: #CoronaCrisis: A treat to beat #JantaCurfew from artiste fraternity
Content: The Carnatic musicians’ and the performing artistes’ communities have come out in support at this hour of #CoronaCrisis in a unique manner, to make Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s #JantaCurfew a success, and to urge people to stay at home all through today. They will be coming together under an online umbrella of #JanathaCurfewOnlineFestival, and live-streaming concerts, as well as sharing, recorded concerts of eminent artistes. They will keep this going from 8am to 5pm, the time when the PM has urged everyone to come out on their balconies and make some noise.“This will keep everyone interested in arts and music , young and old alike, engaged, and will help kill boredom. People can sing along from their homes, with their families,” says Carnatic pianist, Anil Srinivasan, who’s spearheading this on his Facebook page and is currently busy collating a list and schedules of about 130 participants who’ve already given their consent.Among them is Carnatic vocalist Sudha Raghunathan. “We are living in denial. Let’s lace-up, be responsible and stay put. Let’s learn self-control and understand the seriousness of the situation,” says Sudha, and adds, “I have a live-streaming of my own music from 8.30am to 9am — I have chosen this time as many Indians in the US indicated they would love to be a part of this initiative, and said this is a comfortable timeframe for them.” She intends to start her FB live with a message on ‘What we should do and what we shouldn’t be doing’.“I’ve named this session Sowkiyam — it means ‘all is well’ in English. I wish all is well soon,” says Sudha, who will also share her recorded concerts and messages for the #JanathaCurfewOnlineFestival all through the day.“I am doing my live-streaming at 9am,” informs Anil, “And again, maybe, in the afternoon at around 3pm. I must slot all those who’ve agreed to be a part of this — already around 130 musicians, well-known and upcoming, have said they want to participate. It would be a great platform for upcoming talent to be seen and heard as well. If we can create multiple engagement opportunities for people on that day, we’re hoping they’d stay at home — we’re readily giving you 100 to 150-odd performances to listen to on your phone from where you are sitting. Isn’t it a great incentive?” asks Anil.“It’s just that all of us will be at home, so I wanted to spread some love through music and support for humanity,” says singer Srinivas, also a participant, “I will come live at some point of time and sing some songs, say some good things. All of us will be solo. It’s not right to get anyone to travel, so there are no accompanists.”The list includes well-known names such as Bombay Jayashri, Rajhesh Vaidhya and Anita Ratnam, who’ll be sending recorded pieces, “and an ever-growing list of live participants,” adds Anil. “Many artistes have experienced disturbances in their concert schedules because of this Coronavirus pandemic. So, a lot of creative energy is sitting worried and idle. This can be a good outlet for them, too. Participation needs only filling up an online form,” he says.“This doesn’t require a lot of tech support — even amateurs can join us. The intent is to keep this going till 5pm. I am not an organiser or anything; we are all participants, all I am going to do is cross post everything that the participants put up on their own FB or Insta pages and tag us. Tag and share are the keywords here. Yes, like for every initiative, there are naysayers, too. But our priority is health — let’s allow the process to happen, let’s spread love; it not the time for fights, political, or otherwise,” concludes Anil.

Title: Column: Tongue in Check
Content: Want the latest buzz on the gossip front? A peep into the lives of the rich and famous? A wind of Chennai’s best-kept secrets? Writer, activist, anchor, and queen bee Apsara Reddy fills you in ...From sacred chants to parenting tips, Lakshmi Manchu and her daughter Nirvana are going viral with the little girl’s new YouTube channel. But guess what! K-Town stars are amongst the first who have rang up Lakshmi to wish her well. Lakshmi, the daughter of Tollywood veteran Mohan Babu, even received a call from Superstar Rajinikanth, who is her dad’s best friend, to congratulate her daughter on being so creative. Buzz is some Kollywood directors are planning to cast Nirvana as a child star in their films.Benny Dayal has a firm friendship with his old pal Salwin Alfred and seeks advice on life and music from this young man, who is an expert at putting gigs together. Salwin was heard sharing with friends about how Benny helps people in the most unusual ways. The singer is known to visit the homes of friends in distress or those going through rough times and offers his talent and music to lift them up, and sometimes, helps out even financially.This not-so-liked but well-known filmi couple who came together just a few months ago are having trouble in paradise. It seems the cousins of the girl have started talking about how the husband refuses to get cracking on his career and is putting pressure on the wife to “just let him be” and “plan his entry into films”. She, on the other hand, is keen to prove to her family that her husband is serious about making his own money through their business.In a bid to seem like Good Samaritans, a well-known socialite and her husband visited a medical shop, bought all the sanitisers available and distributed it to their domestic staff and watchmen. And she posted about how they donated sanitisers to the poor on her WhatsApp groups!

Title: Vikram & Akanksha have lucky escape from COVID-19
Content: Earlier this year, when the world was just waking up to the Coronavirus outbreak in China and its slow but steady spread to other parts of the globe, director HS Sahana Murthy was in Thailand with his team of Trivikrama. Along with the lead pair of Vikram Ravichandran and Akanksha Sharma , he was shooting a song and stunt sequence in the island nation. “We shot a song featuring the lead pair in Bangkok, followed by another sequence in a jungle a few hours away from the city. This was around the time that the COVID-19 pandemic was on the rise in China. It was only a few days after we returned home that we got to know that even Thailand was in the grip of the virus pandemic,” says the filmmaker. Vikram adds, “I think we had a very lucky escape. When we headed to Thailand, we had no idea about the coronavirus. In fact, the initial plan was to shoot the song as a montage. But Bhushan master, of Chuttu Chuttu fame, decided to shoot for it across picturesque locations in Thailand, because it is a peppy track, while also making sure that the narrative goes forward with the song.”

Title: Divya Uruduga’s next is with Vijay Raghavendra
Content: Actress Divya Uruduga has signed up for a film opposite Vijay Raghavendra . This film is being directed by the duo, Ravi and Chethan. Divya says, “I play Vijay sir’s wife in the film, which follows a newly-married couple, and the strange experiences they have in an apartment. There are no evil forces at play in this, but there will be enough elements to keep audiences on the edge of their seats. The narrative seemed very engaging, which is what excited me about being a part of the film. I am looking forward to working with Vijay sir, who is one of the finest actors in the Kannada film industry. The film will go on floors as soon as the coronavirus pandemic is contained.”

Title: Mineral watch : Potassium
Content: Considering potassium is the third most abundant mineral in our body, it is worth knowing its role in human health and the food sources through which we can consume it.A diet adequate in potassium can help reduce water retention and bloating by lowering sodium levels. By helping the body remove excess sodium, potassium plays a vital role in reducing blood pressure. Messages between your brain and the body are delivered in the form of nerve impulses. These impulses regulate your heartbeat, muscle contractions, reflexes and many other physiological functions. Potassium, by virtue of being classified as an electrolyte, plays a significant role in the activation of these nerve impulses throughout our nervous system. Additionally, it also helps protect against stroke, osteoporosis, kidney stones and helps regulate fluid balance in the body.Natural, unprocessed salt as compared to white or refined salt. Coconut water , bananas, sweet potatoes are great sources of potassium as well. Processed, industrialised foods are high in sodium and low in potassium. Eat minimally processed foods to optimise your body’s sodium-potassium ratio. — Munmun Ganeriwal, nutritionist & lifestyle consultant

Title: The rise of fashion DIY 2.0
Content: Everyone has a signature style, and it hasn’t been more evident as it’s right now. Courtesy social media, bloggers, influencers, celebs, flaunting innumerable looks — from ramps, Insta profiles to airports — Gen Now has grown up looking at fashion as a way to display their signature style. About a few decades ago, people spent a significant amount of time — say the whole of their 20s — trying to figure out what their personal style was; now, you have teens, young adults as well as adults, flaunting their style with panache.Look around you. Almost everyone is personalising sarees and salwar kameez, westernwear and every attire in between. We’ve moved past the fast fashion overdose of the ’90s, when you either found people choosing either Western or Indian. Those were the days where fashion designers and glossies, not to forget Bollywood, dictated style choices.(Left to right: Fashion influencer Nilu Yuleena Thapa wears a sheer organza jacket with a tiger-print skirt, Influencer & YouTuber Roshni Bhatia flaunts her lilac turban and dress)Today, everyone is his or her own brand. Designer Raghavendra Rathore believes style these days is “all about curating an experience” for yourself, all the while collectively pushing the frontier of fashion towards a slow movement. Hence, we are seeing youngsters coupling their mother’s old saree with an uber chic tee, and making the look rock.Fashion brands have globally become aware of this trend. A study by Deloitte finds that though the one-size-fits-all approach by luxury brands worked for a few decades, such a strategy does not resonate with the changing consumer base. About 45 per cent of respondents actually preferred personalised products and services.Gucci has recently preselected a section in many stores, where DIY-ers can choose to put their desired patch, initials or embroidery. Says fashion designer Shivan Bhatiya of Shivan & Narresh, “People, in general, love the concept of owning something exclusively. Millennials reflect their true personality with the way they style themselves. For instance, hand-painted denim jackets and customised T-shirts are currently a raging trend. It’s this idea of being able to express yourself in your attire that has popularised fashion DIY 2.0.”Rathore adds, “Social media is the new consciousness, and the platform where new trends emerge from. The runways and glossies are passe. The ability to tap into anybody’s style universe via social media — with an insight into their thought pattern — is changing fashion as we knew it.”(Left to right: Fashion blogger Mamta Sharma Das displays a knotted saree look, YouTuber Komal Pandey makes a statement with a choker, floral top and a side-slit skirt, Lawyer-turned-influencer Karron S Dhinggra belts up his suit to make a personal style statement)Personalisation has been a growing phenomenon for a while now in the West, with brands from Ralph Lauren to Burberry to Nike and Fendi, offering customised tweaking for patrons. It’s happening in India too for a while now. Fashion blogger Mamta Sharma Das (@thebohobaalika on Insta) loves experimenting with clothes. She says, “People now want to follow people with realistic fashion sense, someone they can relate to. I analysed what made me different and focused on that rather than copying others. I think it’s vital to let your personality shine through and keep the style breezy – looks that will work both casually and at work. The style should be easy to achieve too.”(Artist blogger Neha Sahai wears a bralet blouse with her saree)This is the Age of Assertiveness led by a very confident generation. For them, creativity doesn’t begin and end with the established industry trends. This generation is guiding itself to new heights of fashion, wearing their own ideas with confidence. Says designer Ritu Beri, “Personalisation is always the key when it comes to styling. Today, trends and brands showcasing one design in several colour schemes is boring.” The era of designer dictating terms may not be completely over, but the designer needs to understand their clients’ tastes more intimately to be relevant.”Adds Beri, “Blogging is dynamically changing how people choose their style and clothes. I have seen how they can actually wear a plain basic tee in 10 different ways and drape a simple saree in different styles – which I think is amazing.”The future of fashion lies in personalisation. We live in a world where individuals are increasingly encouraged to take charge of their own fate; they are challenging established sartorial trends and creating their own every day. Says artist and styleblogger Neha Sahai (@wildflowernehasahai on Insta) “As an artist, I like to define the clothes I wear. I personalise my fashion with exciting personal patterns and embroideries. I also dress-it-up with 15 bangles, 3 rings, a pair of earrings, a nose pin, a bindi and kajal. I find it exciting to wear a saree with a funky T-shirt, with my artwork. I think personalising fashion makes it dymanic and very bohemian.”Designer Sunil Mehra agrees. He says, “These days, a luxury client begins his fashion journey with the designer by sitting and discussing his or her personal dos and don’ts. Personalisation is definitely the new trend. And it’s evolving continuously. It’s going to have a strong influence in the fashion industry in the coming years.”Style, these days, is all about curating an experience for yourself, all the while collectively pushing the frontier of fashion towards a slow movement.— Raghavendra Rathore, designer“Personalisation takes art of craftsmanship back to its glory days”There is an upside to individual expression. The idea of personalisation also takes the art of craftsmanship back to its glory days, where products were made for the customer on a one-to-one basis.— Shivan Bhatiya, designerThere was a fatigue with designer and brand labels, when I started blogging. People now want to follow people with realistic fashion sense, someone they can relate to...—Mamta Sharma Das, fashion influencer.

Title: How I Start My Day
Content: The first few minutes of your morning are crucial for your entire day, and can set the tone for positivity and productivity. Developing an excellent morning routine gets you off to a good start.Create time for yourself. The mental energy you save will astound you. Use this energy for creative thinking.Decide what you’re going to wear, what you should eat. I start my mornings with a good lemon ginger honey tea and sitting for my prayer. This is followed with OM chanting and going ahead with on spot running or ‘engine daud’ with yoga poses. A good ‘engine daud’ releases serotonin which helps as a mood enhancer. Lemon ginger honey tea hydrates your brain without making you feel full and bloated.This practice teaches you to surrender, restart from a neutral, empowered place.List your to-dos, place them priority wise. Positive thoughts, activities, feelings release feel-good hormones (endorphins).Prepare your mind for the every situation. Have complete trust that every incident beyond your immediate control, is simply a small part of the larger picture, which eventually gets unfolded only for your well-being.Shruti ChaturlalWellness coach & Yoga Expert(As told to Nona Walia)

Title: How to make a happier home?
Content: Mood-boosting decor is on the rise right now. To reduce stress and anxiety, infuse your homes with things that promote peace and positive energy – and most of the time, those items are all-natural. Here’s how to build your home into a safe haven.If you haven’t seen agate or amethyst accessories in your nearest retail store yet, expect them to rule the shelves soon. For centuries, different cultures have displayed crystals in their homes, believing them to carry therapeutic energies harnessed from the earth. From supermodel Miranda Kerr to the pop crooner Sam Smith, healing crystals are having a moment in Hollywood. Kylie Jenner, who’s been spotted crystal shopping with Jaden Smith did a tutorial on crystal healing. They work beautifully as home decor, as they are sculptural and provide a “grounded, earthy energy” that helps to balance a space. Create zones for different crystal energies. For instance, quartz is used to amplify intentions while amethyst is used for protection.Rooms featuring curvature are rated as more pleasurable and may activate the brain’s emotional and motivation centres. According to research from environmental psychology, natural materials used in homes uplift our minds. Our homes should be designed to make our nervous system healthier. People feel less stress and fatigue in wood-filled spaces, which also benefit the respiratory and nervous systems. Psychology Today reports how spending time in rooms constructed with a moderate balance of wooden surfaces has been linked to decreasing diastolic blood pressure and to a general sensation of comfort. Greenery too reduces BP and production of stress hormones.The height of your ceiling impacts your behaviour. In a low ceiling room, people feel cramped and lose their temper more. Researchers believe this response derives from our evolutionary preference for spaces, the ability to see foes (or food sources) before they see us. A sense of being enclosed, seems to stimulate our fight-or-flight response.Much like plants, different woods have different benefits. For example, willow carries salicin for headaches. When you bring live-edge pieces into your home, you enjoy good vibes that come with the material. Invite natural beauty and energy into your home by displaying different woods.Reset the energy in your home by opening the windows, smoking the air with sage herb. It is a beautiful way of cleansing the space. Allow only positive vibes to come in.Be the sanctuary maker of your home. Create a comfortable atmosphere. That doesn’t just mean filling your space with blankets and pillows. It’s the small details that add a personal touch and make all the difference. Pick and place anything that lifts your energy, no matter how small. Think: crystals, plants, glass, feathers, art, photographs, family heirlooms, and other handmade items.Big windows overlooking a balcony garden offer emotional support. Just being able to see how the weather is and knowing what’s out there relaxes people and makes them feel more in control.People are craving raw and organic in their decor as much as in their diets

Title: Stuck at home? Rustle up some healthy road-side snacks
Content:
Roasted Sweet Potato Chaat

Cucumber, radish and green apple chaat

Muesli Bhel

Healthy Tawa Chicken Frankie

Nutty Vegan Dip

The joy of eating out, especially from a popular road-side vendor, is indescribable. There is something about digging into a plate of piping hot gobi manchurian or trying one of the 99 varieties of dosas, etc. Eating at a road-side outlet is when we, most often, overlook hygiene and give in to cravings. But now is not a good time for that, what with Bengaluru battling cholera and COVID-19 scares simultaneously. In the last two weeks, Bruhat Bengaluru Mahangara Palike officials have been cracking down on street vendors who have not been following basic hygiene norms, following a surge in gastro-intestinal disease cases in the city. And now, with the city on temporary lockdown and everyone left with spare time at hand, how about making sure that you are not missing out on your favourite road-side delicacy, but with a healthy twist? Try these recipes at home. What's best is that you can even make a family activity out of it. Here’s to healthy munching...2 medium sized sweet potatoes (with skin on) 2 tbsp avocado or coconut oil (optional)1 tsp chaat masala2 tbsp lime juicePreheat oven to 190 C. Cut potatoes in half lengthwise and transfer to a baking sheet. Drizzle with a little oil and massage to coat. Place cut side down on the baking sheet.Bake for 25-35 minutes, or until caramelised on the edges. When you press on the top of the potatoes they need to have a little give.Enjoy as is, or top it with chaat masala and lime juice.Calories: 120Carbs: 35 gramsProtein: 4 gramsFat: 0.3 gramsFibre: 6.6 grams1 green apple peeled and sliced1 cucumber peeled and sliced1 radish peeled and sliced4 green chillies1 tsp salt½ tsp black salt1 tsp lime juice2 tbsp chopped coriander leavesGrind the green chillies with salt, black salt and lime juice. Rub this on the slices of apples, cucumber and radish. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Calories: 85Protein: 0.3 gramsCarbs: 31.8 gramsFibre: 7 gramsFat: 2.2 grams½ cup muesli¼ cup roasted peanuts½ diced boiled potato2 tbsp boiled sweet corn2 tbsp chopped tomatoes2 tbsp lemon juice1 tbsp chaat masala2 tbsp chopped coriander½ tsp chopped green chilli¼ tsp saltIn a bowl, add the muesli and peanuts. Mix together the chaat masala and lemon juice in a small bowl and keep it aside.In another bowl, add the potatoes, tomatoes and corn and mix gently.Now, add the chopped green chillies and coriander.To this, add chaat masala mixture and mix well.Taste the mixture and accordingly add lemon juice and salt. Serve immediately, else it will get soggy.Calories: 280Protein: 10 gramsCarbs: 40 gramsFibre: 7 gramsFat: 11 grams250 grams minced chicken2 eggs3 tbsp edible oil2 big onions finely chopped2 medium sized tomatoes finely chopped1 tsp garlic paste1 tsp ginger paste1/2 tsp cumin powder1 tsp red chilli powder1/2 tsp turmeric powder1/2 tsp chaat masala1 cup whole wheat flour1 and 1/2 cabbage finely chopped1 beetroot (medium size) (finely chopped)To prepare the dough for parathas, in a bowl, takewholewheat flour, add salt and one tablespoon edible oil. Make the dough adding adequate water. Make two thin parathas and half cook them on the pan.Break an egg into a bowl and beat it, adding salt and pepper powder. Add half a tsp of oil on tawa and pour in the egg mixture. Place the paratha on top of the egg mixture and cook for a few seconds. Then, remove from heat.— chop vegetables thinly lengthwise. Keep aside until chicken is ready. In a bowl, add red chilli powder and turmeric powder. Mix it well with the minced chicken. Add one tablespoon of salt and two ablespoons of chaat masala. Mix it well. Add a cup of water to it and cook until the chicken is tender. Add chopped coriander leaves to it and keep it aside., add chicken mixture to the side with egg, add on green chutney (optional) and sprinkle sliced vegetables over it. Take a pinch of chaat masala and sprinkle over the onions. Wrap/roll the paratha and cook for a minute.Calories: 267(per frankie)Protein: 4.6 gramsCarbs: 36.1 gramsFibre: 3 grams2 cups finely chopped coriander leaves1 green chilli (optional)½ inch ginger finely chopped¼ to ½ tsp lime juice (as per taste)½ tsp cumin powder½ tsp salt (as per taste)1 to 2 tsp water for grindingWash coriander leaves well in warm water and chop themroughly. Add chopped green chilli, ginger, cumin powder, chaat masala, lemon juice and salt in a small blender jar. Add water and grind to a smooth chutney.1 cup cashew nuts1 cup almondsSalt to tastePowdered jaggery to taste4 tsp Coconut oilDry roast the nuts till crisp. Grind in a mixer along with salt, jaggery and coconut oil, until you get a paste with theconsistency of a dip.Store in a glass jar in the fridge.(*All measurements are in tbsp-tablespoon, tsp -teaspoon quantities)(Recipes by wellness coach Kuhoo Gupta and nutritionist Preety Tyagi)

Title: Beat the quarantine boredom the way your fave celebs do
Content: Showbiz is all about working away from home at remote locations, for days together, with lengthy hours as well. So, working from home during a shutdown, as the one all of us are in now, isn’t exactly something that ‘works’ for the industry. If you have been watching pictures and videos of Hollywood celebrities trying to keep themselves entertained during this ‘break’ and wondered what your fave stars in Bollywood and Sandalwood are doing, here’s the lowdown…Actor Ganesh shared a video on social media, in which he was seen turning his dining table at home into a sports arena. He was seen playing table tennis with his wife Shilpa and kids Charithriya and Vihaan. “When quarantined......dining table becomes tennis table??. Be safe, stay home vth family ??”, he captioned the video.Actress Katrina Kaif shared a muted video of her learning to play the guitar. The effort was “Work in progress. Sound coming soon in a few days, hopefully,” she said. Seems like musician Ankur Tewari is her guru, as Katrina ended the caption with: “can’t let down @ankurtewari.”“The way we dress, it’s perhaps the best thing our culture has ever done,” says Salman Khan in the video that he posted on social media, as he went about sketching two figures. In the video clip, he also seemed to be humming a tune that sounded like the title track of Kaho Na... Pyaar Hai.I am truly working from home. I was shooting for Kabza when the shutdown happened. So, I decided to use this time off to concentrate on the editing of Buddhivanta 2. Of course, I’m also happy to spend extra time with the kids and Priyanka.For Deepika Padukone, it’s all about being productive during the quarantine period. The first picture the actress posted on social media was of clothes and cloth hangers, captioning it: “Season 1; Episode 1. Productivity in the time of COVID-19! #cleaning #wardrobe.” This was followed by a photograph of her massaging her face. “Season 1: Episode 2”, she wrote, using the hashtags #selflove #selfcare.Feeling all artsy, are we? Comedian Kenny Sebastian shared pictures of his painting sessions at home with his friends.I’ve been doing some reading and writing. In fact, I’ve got a script ready and am stoked with the way it’s turned out. I’m also binge watching shows and listening to a lot of classical music. My lifestyle has been pretty much the same, the only thing I’ve done away with is traveling, especially on flights.I went to be with my parents back home at our village, and have been meeting my friends almost every day. We catch up at each other’s homes and avoid public places. It feels like the good old times when things were simpler.I am a fitness freak and just cannot spend endless hours doing nothing. I'm using this time to pursue my favourite sport —cycling. I have mapped out 100 km each day for the next 10 days and intend to cover 1,000 km by the end of this month. I'm only doing solo rides and loving the minimal traffic on the roads.I had been traveling a lot on work, so this comes as a welcome break. I vacuumed my balcony; it’s never looked so sparkling clean before. I have also been watching a lot of shows and catching up on movies. I’m also going for long walks and will go cycling to Bannerghatta National Park and back this week.We were supposed to head to Kashmir and Rajasthan for the song shoot of Raymo, after which I was set to rejoin the Madagaja set. I was looking forward to all the travel. This unexpected break is the longest I have had in a while. I have been enjoying the pampering back home and all the good food. I also hung out at home with my old school friends. I miss going to the gym, so I’ve been doing a lot of yoga at home.

Title: Common health mistakes
Content:
Vaccination, deworming



“Sometimes, adult food is fed to puppies, which leads to indigestion. They suffer from vomiting and diarrhoea,” says Dr Sarkar.Quantity matters. “If they are fed lesser than the normal quantity or in big gaps/intervals, they are bound to remain hungry all the time and gorge on any dirt lying around,” adds Dr Sarkar.Dr Natasha Couto says most dogs are over-fed, and sometimes, eat as much as the pet parents. “Adult dogs should be ideally fed just twice a day with a well balanced diet. Also, make it a habit to feed your pet well before your meals to discourage your dog from begging at the table for scraps,” she says.Some people who are vegetarian feed vegetarian food to their dogs. “They have the feeling that if they start feeding vegetarian food to their dogs at an early stage, their dog will become a vegetarian ignoring the fact that dog is a carnivorous animal,” says Dr Sarkar.This kind of mistakes are usually made to miniature breeds, who most spend their time mostly with children and eat whatever the child eats. These habit later causes kidneyfailure, haemorrhagic gastroenteritis and food poisoning.Dr Natsha says chocolates can cause chocolate toxicity and prove to be fatal. Feeding dogs sweets, chocolates and buffalo milk (rich in fat) makes pets overweight. Obese dogs are at high risk for arthritis and other orthopedic issues and cardiac problems. Let your vet recommend a specific food schedule.“Gum disease is more common in dogs on soft food diet. Teeth and gum diseases can eventually lead to various organ diseases,” shares Dr Natasha.“Not following vaccination, deworming schedules leads to health issues,” warns Dr Sarkar. “Pets who are not vaccinated regularly on time could succumb to fatal diseases like gastroenteritis, leptospirosis and distemper. Also regular deworming can prevent anaemia, diarrhoea and other problems. Please follow the vaccination schedules as provided by your veterinarian,” adds Dr Natasha.“Medicating your pet without consulting your vet can cause severe adverse reactions. For example: Crocin given to cats for fever/pain can be fatal while Brufen/Combiflam in dogs can cause severe gastritis,” shares Dr Natasha.“Any minor deviation from routine pattern should be noted and consulted with the veterinarian,” tells Dr Natasha.“Most dogs are not walked and are at home all day leading to overgrown nails, obesity and unsocial behaviour owing to being locked up all day indoors. Dogs need to be walked at least twice- thrice a day for a min of 15-30 minutes,” tells Dr Natasha.Not neutering/spaying your pet can lead to incidence of pyometra/mammary tumours in females and prostrate enlargement in males later in life. “Neutering your pet also prevents indiscriminate breeding, makes your pet more controllable and will also curb the progression of genetically transmitted diseases, such as hip dysplasia, cryptochidism, etc,” advises Dr Natasha.www.dogsandpupsmagazine.com; www.facebook.com/DogsandpupsmagAre you a proud pet parent? Have a cute cat story to share? Maybe your guinea pig is giving you trouble? Whatever is your creature companion, we are here to listen to you. Send your photos, queries and stories to timeslife@timesgroup.com

Title: SGPGI’s advice to Kanika: ‘Behave like a patient, not star’
Content: LUCKNOW: Rebutting bollywood singer Kanika Kapoor ’s claim that she was not being attend well at Sanjay Gandhi Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences - where she has been quarantined since she tested positive to coronavirus infection on Friday – the institute authorities advised the patient ‘not to throw tantrums ’.In an official statement, director, Dr RK Dhiman said: “Kanika Kapoor has been provided the best that is possible in a hospital. She must co-operate as a patient and not throw tantrums of a star. She is being provided Gluten Free Diet from the Hospital Kitchen. She has to co-operate with us to help herself.”Kanika has been criticising the facilities at SGPGI from her social media handle besides giving statements to a section of media. “It appears I am in jail,” she told a website. She also said that when she asked the doctors to get the room cleaned, he told her that she was not in a five star hotel.Denying the allegations, Dr Dhiman stated that utmost care is being extended to her and she must first start behaving like a patient and not a star. “The facility provided to her is an isolated room with a toilet, patient-bed, and a television. The ventilation of her room is air conditioned with a separate Air Handling Unit (AHU) for the COVID 19 unit. She should start behaving like a patient in the hospital and not a star,” the director advised.

Title: Kanika Kapoor: Boots on the ground: A thousand in search of Kanika’s footprints
Content: LUCKNOW: Over 100 teams, comprising around 1,000 members of the local administration and the UP health department, have been tasked to track down all possible contacts of singer Kanika Kapoor during her stay in the city since March 11. She tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday.The teams are trying to reach out to all who were present in social gatherings attended by Kanika by conducting a boots-on-the-ground exercise to reach out to people living in the vicinity of her house in Mahanagar and also each one who was present at the places Kanika went.“The combing exercise is being done as per Union health & family welfare ministry’s standard operating procedure on containment of coronavirus . Anyone who disrupts the scanning or doesn’t cooperate with the teams will face police action,” additional DM Amar Pal Singh , who is supervising the teams, told TOI.On Saturday, the team scanned nearly 22,000 residents living near Kanika’s house. “The houses of Adil Ahmed and Adesh Seth, who hosted two parties attended by her, have been sanitised. Residents have been told not to move out nor let anyone come in for the next 48 hours,” said an officer helping the UP health department put together Kanika’s contact list.Another team of experts is scanning video footages and CCTV records of the five-star hotel where Kanika stayed between March 14 and 16. “There are reports that she dined in the hotel’s buffet and also attended several guests in the lobby. She was living there at a time when the South African team was staying in the hotel for the ODI match, which eventually was called off. There is information that Kanika was seen briefly attending a news channel’s annual conclave held at the hotel. Therefore, it is important to scan the CCTV footage and list those came in contact with her,” said an officer engaged in surveillance.“She flouted instructions on home isolation despite being a potential case of Covid-19… Instead of staying at home, she went socialising. Now after having tested positive, she has now put everyone who came in contact with her at risk,” said Dr Narendra Agarwal, Lucknow’s chief medical officer, who also lodged an FIR against the singer.In Kanpur, where Kanika went to meet her maternal grandmother, the DM has ordered sealing of the apartment. Police have been deputed to ensure that no one enters or leaves the building, which houses more than 35 families, for the next 48 hours. Health officials have also alerted Kanika’s kids and caretakers in London Lucknow police commissioner Sujeet Pandey said that he had got in touch with his counterpart in Mumbai. “We have also written to the police commissioner of Mumbai to find out if Kanika was properly screened at the international airport or not. Details of the places where she stayed have also been sought,” he told TOI.

Title: Amid coronavirus lockdown, Kangana Ranaut catches up on reading Sadguru’s book ‘Death’
Content: With the country under lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus , actress Kangana Ranaut has been putting her time to good use.The actress shared a photo of herself catching up on some reading and it so happened to be author Sadguru ’s book titled, ‘Death’.Kangana was clicked enjoying a sunny day out in her garden, engrossed in the book that she also highly recommended to her fans. Giving out her list of some other good reads, she recommended, ' Inner Engineering ' and 'Mystic's Musings' to make the most out of this self-quarantine period.Kangana is currently in Manali, enjoying some free time with family, considering that the film industry has been brought to a standstill and work on her next, ‘ Thalaivi ’ has been halted.

Title: #CoronaConcerns: 'Too far' or prudent choice? Hazmat suits face demand-supply gap in Delhi
Content: By now, almost everyone knows the steps to protect themselves from being infected with the coronavirus . Washing your hands for 20 seconds, maintaining distance from other people, self-isolation, wearing a mask etc. The rules are fairly clear. But recently, when Naomi Campbell posted her airport look wearing a hazmat suit, a mask, protective eye-gear and gloves, netizens thought she was "taking it too far".In an interview to an American daily, Naomi explained, "When I heard about the virus on February 22, I was talking with Linda [Evangelista], and she told me about these hazmat suits. So I purchased the suits a month before. I had them not knowing this was going to happen, but just wanting to be safe." Naomi is known to be a trendsetter, but this new trend is more than just about fashion. Hazmat suits have made their way to Delhi's markets. And while you might think this is a good way to keep those working in hospitals and clinics safe, a plot twist awaits. These suits are not for them, but are now the hottest trend of the season for some Delhiites. Why? Well, because they can afford it and one can never be too safe these days.Going by the number of people buying these suits in NCR, don't be surprised if you see someone walking their dog in a hazmat suit. Sellers say that last week, the demand for these suits has shot up in the city. Jai Dhar, who is selling hazmat suits at his Khan Market store, says, "We are getting orders of approximately 200-400 hazmat suits every day. After it was launched 12 days ago at our store, the demand has only gone up. If it continues like this, it will get difficult to meet the demand."Sellers say that as of this weekend, the demand for hazmat suits at stores and online has increased by eight-ten times as compared to last week. Shiv Bansal, who works at a medical store near Safdarjung Hospital in South Ex, says, "My junior staff had alerted me last month to place more orders of these suits, but I told them, "People in Delhi care a lot about how they look and what they wear. Dilli mein hazmat suit pehen kar kaun ghoomega?" Abb tak toh kisi ko dekha nahi hai, lekin jitne log inquiry karne aa rahe hai, unko dekh ke toh abb lag raha hai ki stock pehle mangwa lena tha." He adds that they went out of stock in three days.For the rich and affluent in Delhi, the hazmat suit is a better investment than sticking with the humble mask. The motto seems to be: when in the middle of a pandemic, do as doctors do. So if you are also planning to buy a hazmat suit, you can order online. While the average price is around Rs 2000, some websites are also selling them for as cheap as Rs 200. However, the effectiveness of those is as good as anyone's guess.Sumedha Chaudhary, a shopper at South-Ex, says, "What option do we have? Doctors are saying masks are of no use. Still, we have bought the most expensive masks in the market. We have spent Rs 25,000 only on masks. But doctors around the world are wearing hazmat suits. People who cant stay at home should be buying these." Not just these suits, but Delhiites are stocking up on gloves, eye-gears and masks in bulk and the sellers are concerned that soon it won't be easy to re-stock. But there is no need to panic. If you are following health advisories and practicing social distancing, you probably don't need to go to such extremes.

Title: An impressive guest list at this reception in Lucknow
Content:
Luv Bhargava and Kirti Sharma (L) and Ritika Silas (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

George Figg and Husain Ehtisham and Asma Husain (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Jamal and Rafat Khan and Lisa Nilles (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Manjuli and Nalin Phillips and Sana Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Rajiv and Rahab Soni and Renu and Kush Bhargava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Seemaab & Sheekha Khan and Shehla Amjad Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Shadaab and Rumana and Shivam (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Shuchi and Ashok Sur and Zohra Chatterjee (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Zarine Viccajee (L) Rudi Kapoor and Ahlam and Zafar Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Afzal Ansari and Bushra and Ghassan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Chander and Sudha Prakash and Daniela and Martin (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Luv Bhargava and Kirti Sharma (L) and Ritika Silas (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)The wedding reception of Gibran Hussain and Ameera Ali Soni was a lavish affair. Organized at a prominent five-star hotel, the guest list included the who’s who of the city who came to bless the newly married couple. The bride looked ethereal in a pink sharara while the groom looked dapper in blue formals. The parents of the groom, Husain Ehtisham and Asma were seen welcoming the guests and also taking care of the arrangements.George Figg and Husain Ehtisham and Asma Husain (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Jamal and Rafat Khan and Lisa Nilles (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Manjuli and Nalin Phillips and Sana Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Rajiv and Rahab Soni and Renu and Kush Bhargava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Seemaab & Sheekha Khan and Shehla Amjad Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Shadaab and Rumana and Shivam (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Shuchi and Ashok Sur and Zohra Chatterjee (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Zarine Viccajee (L) Rudi Kapoor and Ahlam and Zafar Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Afzal Ansari and Bushra and Ghassan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Chander and Sudha Prakash and Daniela and Martin (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)People from all walks of life including governance and administration, advocacy, politics, police, judges and businessmen were spotted at the wedding. Family members of late veteran star Amjad Khan too were spotted at the wedding. Bollywood actor and Lucknow lad Shivam Bhaargava was also a part of the celebrations.The guests were seen enjoying several retro melodies played on a saxophone by George Figg.— Prachi Arya andFarhan Ahmad Siddiqui

Title: #CoronaConcerns: 'Too far' or prudent choice? Hazmat suits face demand-supply gap in Delhi
Content: By now, almost everyone knows the steps to protect themselves from being infected with the coronavirus . Washing your hands for 20 seconds, maintaining distance from other people, self-isolation, wearing a mask etc. The rules are fairly clear. But recently, when Naomi Campbell posted her airport look wearing a hazmat suit, a mask, protective eye-gear and gloves, netizens thought she was "taking it too far".In an interview to an American daily, Naomi explained, "When I heard about the virus on February 22, I was talking with Linda [Evangelista], and she told me about these hazmat suits. So I purchased the suits a month before. I had them not knowing this was going to happen, but just wanting to be safe." Naomi is known to be a trendsetter, but this new trend is more than just about fashion. Hazmat suits have made their way to Delhi's markets. And while you might think this is a good way to keep those working in hospitals and clinics safe, a plot twist awaits. These suits are not for them, but are now the hottest trend of the season for some Delhiites. Why? Well, because they can afford it and one can never be too safe these days.Going by the number of people buying these suits in NCR, don't be surprised if you see someone walking their dog in a hazmat suit. Sellers say that last week, the demand for these suits has shot up in the city. Jai Dhar, who is selling hazmat suits at his Khan Market store, says, "We are getting orders of approximately 200-400 hazmat suits every day. After it was launched 12 days ago at our store, the demand has only gone up. If it continues like this, it will get difficult to meet the demand."Sellers say that as of this weekend, the demand for hazmat suits at stores and online has increased by eight-ten times as compared to last week. Shiv Bansal, who works at a medical store near Safdarjung Hospital in South Ex, says, "My junior staff had alerted me last month to place more orders of these suits, but I told them, "People in Delhi care a lot about how they look and what they wear. Dilli mein hazmat suit pehen kar kaun ghoomega?" Abb tak toh kisi ko dekha nahi hai, lekin jitne log inquiry karne aa rahe hai, unko dekh ke toh abb lag raha hai ki stock pehle mangwa lena tha." He adds that they went out of stock in three days.For the rich and affluent in Delhi, the hazmat suit is a better investment than sticking with the humble mask. The motto seems to be: when in the middle of a pandemic, do as doctors do. So if you are also planning to buy a hazmat suit, you can order online. While the average price is around Rs 2000, some websites are also selling them for as cheap as Rs 200. However, the effectiveness of those is as good as anyone's guess.Sumedha Chaudhary, a shopper at South-Ex, says, "What option do we have? Doctors are saying masks are of no use. Still, we have bought the most expensive masks in the market. We have spent Rs 25,000 only on masks. But doctors around the world are wearing hazmat suits. People who cant stay at home should be buying these." Not just these suits, but Delhiites are stocking up on gloves, eye-gears and masks in bulk and the sellers are concerned that soon it won't be easy to re-stock. But there is no need to panic. If you are following health advisories and practicing social distancing, you probably don't need to go to such extremes.

Title: An impressive guest list at this reception in Lucknow
Content: Luv Bhargava and Kirti Sharma (L) and Ritika Silas (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)The wedding reception of Gibran Hussain and Ameera Ali Soni was a lavish affair. Organized at a prominent five-star hotel, the guest list included the who’s who of the city who came to bless the newly married couple. The bride looked ethereal in a pink sharara while the groom looked dapper in blue formals. The parents of the groom, Husain Ehtisham and Asma were seen welcoming the guests and also taking care of the arrangements.George Figg and Husain Ehtisham and Asma Husain (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Jamal and Rafat Khan and Lisa Nilles (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Manjuli and Nalin Phillips and Sana Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Rajiv and Rahab Soni and Renu and Kush Bhargava (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Seemaab & Sheekha Khan and Shehla Amjad Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Shadaab and Rumana and Shivam (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Shuchi and Ashok Sur and Zohra Chatterjee (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Zarine Viccajee (L) Rudi Kapoor and Ahlam and Zafar Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Afzal Ansari and Bushra and Ghassan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Chander and Sudha Prakash and Daniela and Martin (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)People from all walks of life including governance and administration, advocacy, politics, police, judges and businessmen were spotted at the wedding. Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Man with no travel history tests positive in Bengal
Content:
KOLKATA: A 57-year-old man with no foreign-travel history and a 23-year-old woman who returned from Scotland tested positive to Covid-19 within 24 hours in Bengal, taking the total number of confirmed cases here to four. While three of the patients returned to the city from UK, what has set alarm bells ringing within the medical fraternity and the administration is the case of the fourth patient who has no travel history and did not come in contact with anyone with known foreign-travel history.

The man from Dum Dum was admitted at a private hospital in Salt Lake on Monday. He was suffering from fever and dry cough for four days prior to hospitalisation . His symptoms worsened on Thursday to acute respiratory syndrome and he has been on ventilation since.

More on Covid-19

Coronavirus pandemic: Complete coverage Coronavirus: What are the symptoms 52 testing sites for coronavirus in India Helpline numbers for states and UTs Do fever and cough mean you need Covid-19 test? How to stay safe How to quarantine yourself at home

The patient’s swab samples were first sent to SSKM Hospital , where it came out positive. It was then sent for reconfirmation to ICMR-NICED, the nodal diagnostic lab for the entire eastern region, where it again tested positive, Swasthya Bhawan officials said.

Sources at the private hospital where the patient is admitted said the 57-year-old was treated as a suspected Covid-19 patient right from day one and kept in an isolation ward. “The hospital had taken proper protective measures for its doctors and frontline healthcare workers who were dealing with the patient. He is s currently in isolation ICU. His condition is serious” said a hospital source.

The health officials said they are trying to identify family members who had come in direct contact with the patient.

The other patient who tested positive late on Friday night is a 23-year-old resident of Habra in North 24 Parganas. The young woman had recently returned from Scotland, where she is pursuing an MBA course. She followed the instruction at the airport and headed straight to the Beliaghata ID Hospital, unlike the first two city patients who had sought hospitalization after several days at their respective homes raising a scare of transmission.

Now under treatment, doctors said her condition is stable. His father, a friend and the family driver have been kept in home isolation. The two other Covid-19 patients in the same hospital are also stable.

Title: Thalapathy 65: Vijay and AR Murgadoss's next film to start rolling from April end?
Content: Actor Vijay has completed the work for his upcoming film 'Master', that is slated for an April release. Previously, Vijay was expected to join hands with director Sudha Kongara , but he reportedly changed his mind since the film needed long pre-production time. A few days back, reports stated that AR Murgadoss will be directing Vijay's 65th film, and it will mark the director's fourth collaboration with the star. Now, the latest buzz on the internet is that the actor-director duo will start work on the film by April end.While some fans were excited about this collaboration, others reportedly felt disappointed, considering that the director's last film 'Darbar' with Rajinikanth didn 't perform as well as expected.Vijay's 65th, is expected to start rolling after the release of 'Master', but, an official announcement about the same is still awaited.On the other side, fans of Vijay have been enjoying the 'Master' songs, which are composed by Anirudh Ravichander . Directed by Lokesh Kanagaraj , the film has an ensemble star cast that includes Vijay, Vijay Sethupathi Andrea Jeremiah , and others.

Title: Mumbai Local Train Status: General public not allowed in Mumbai local trains from Sunday
Content: MUMBAI: In order to decongest local railway stations, the Konkan divisional commissioner will be starting a drive from Sunday in which only personnel who are a part of emergency services with valid I-cards and people who are in medical emergency will only be allowed to travel in local trains. This will continue till March 31Konkan Divisional Commissioner Shivaji Daund said that there will be two teams and in each team there will be 5 personnel one from GRP, RPF, health official and two from the revenue department. These fleets will be stationed at the northbound and southbound entry points of the railways stations and will not allow passengers who are found to be travelling unnecessarily on the platform.There are nearly 150 railway stations under the Konkan division –From CST- Khopoli, CST-Panvel and Churchgate to Dahanu. “All these stations will be covered under our decision. The idea is to not let any passenger without an emergency reason to travel. We will send passengers home if they are found to be travelling unnecessarily. Mostly, passengers with a medical emergency –personal or in the family will only be allowed that too after verification by the health personnels on the team,” Daund told TOI. He added that people who want to board a long distance train, their valid tickets will be checked and only then allowed on the platform.He said that under the epidemic disease act, 1897 the state government has empowered all municipal commissioners, divisional commissioners and even collectors to take action to reduce crowding. If people do not cooperate then action can be initiated against them under IPC section 188 and even section 144 IPC for unlawful assembly, said Daund.He said that the revenue department staff should maintain a diary in which the details of the passengers allowed should be noted. He added that the team will be provided with adequate masks and thermal scanners.“On certain stations where there are multiple entry points, some will be blocked and only entry and exit will be allowed from the main gates so that each passenger can be checked,” said Daund. He also said that the idea is to discourage non-essential travel and ensure that there is a sense of responsibility amongst the people during the crisis situation.Also if people who are supposed to be in home quarantine are found then they will be sent to institutional quarantine, said Daund. The government has made the facility of institutional quarantine with the capacity of 7,000-8,000 and 4,000-odd rooms at non-occupied government and SRA buildings at Mumbai suburban area and Panvel respectively,” said Daund.

Title: 'Jail' director Vasanthabalan to conduct a painting competition for children
Content: Cinemas, educational institutions, and malls have been shut down due to the coronavirus outbreak. Many children and adults are confined to their home to prevent a spread of the virus.Prime Minister Narendra Modi also asked the citizens of the country to observe Janta Curfew on March 22 from 7 AM to 9 PM.Director Vasanthabalan , known for his movies like 'Veyil', ' Angadi Theru ', and 'Kaaviya Thalaivan ', is currently working with GV Prakash Kumar for 'Jail'. Now, the latest report is that the director will be conducting a painting competition for children.Stating that the isolation is hard on children, he has decided to conduct a painting competition for kids under 12 years of age. The director asked the children to make their artwork on A4 white paper at their homes and send it to his email address. Mails from March 22nd, 10 AM to the next day 10 AM will be only taken for the competition. The director has also decided to award the best paintings.Meanwhile, fans and celebrities have been praising the director Vasanthabalan for his innovative idea to brighten up peoples' mood.

Title: Coronavirus Vaccine: French researcher reports successful drug trial
Content:
More on Covid-19

PARIS: Amid the novel coronavirus scare around the world, a French researcher has reported successful trial of a new treatment line for Covid-19, with early tests suggesting it can stop the virus from becoming contagious in just six days.According to connexionfrance.com , Professor Didier Raoult from hospital l'Institut Hospitalo-Universitaire ( IHU Mediterranee ), put up a video to explain the trials held earlier this week.Raoult, an infectious diseases specialist, was tasked by the French government to research possible treatment for the novel coronavirus.According to the professor, the first Covid-19 patients he treated with drug chloroquine saw rapid and effective speeding of their healing process, and a sharp decrease in the amount of time they remained contagious.Chloroquine -- which is normally used to prevent and treat malaria -- was administered via drug Plaquenil."We included everyone who was in agreement to be treated, which was almost everyone. Two towns in the protocol, Nice and Avignon, gave us infected patients who had not yet received treatment," Raoult was quoted as saying by connexionfrance.com.According to the media report, the treatment was offered to 24 patients, who were among the first to become infected in the southeast of France, and who had voluntarily admitted themselves to hospital for the process.Patients were given 600mcg per day for 10 days.
