They were closely monitored, as the drug can interact with other medication, and cause severe side effects in some cases, it added."We were able to ascertain that patients who had not received Plaquenil (drug containing hydroxychloroquine ) were still contagious after six days, but of those who received Plaquenil, only 25 per cent were still contagious after the given period," he added.Chloroquine phosphate and hydroxychloroquine have previously been used to treat coronavirus patients in China, in ongoing Covid-19 clinical trials.Kaletra, a US-based antiviral drug used to treat HIV, is another medicine that is being tested in the fight against the deadly virus.

Title: Coronavirus Cases in India: 40% of cases in India recorded in last 2 days
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The Covid-19 count continued to surge across the country with at least 78 new cases reported from the states on Saturday, surpassing Friday’s figure of 57 as the highest for a single day and taking total number of cases in the country to 333.Kerala (12), Maharashtra (11) and Punjab (10) reported new cases in double digits even as the national count in the past two days alone stood at 133, accounting for 40% of all cases since the first one was confirmed on January 30.While Maharashtra and Kerala together account for more than a third of all cases, government data shows new hotspots are emerging, such as Bhilwara in Rajasthan , where 11 new cases have been reported in the past 48 hours. Punjab and Gujarat have also witnessed significant spike in Covid-19 cases.Meanwhile, Assam may become the 22nd state in the country to report a Covid-19 case. A four-and-a-half-year-old girl, who had recently travelled from Bihar, tested positive for the infection in Jorhat. Her sample has been sent for re-confirmation to an ICMR lab in Dibrugarh.In all, fresh cases were reported from 13 states, indicating the spread of the infection across the country. The Union health ministry confirmed 283 cases, including 23 who have recovered.The ministry’s count of Covid-19 cases includes 39 foreign nationals, one patient who has migrated and four persons who have died.The government admitted that Covid-19 infections were spreading but said there was no evidence yet of community transmission, which happens in Stage III of an outbreak. Joint secretary (health) Lav Aggarwal said on Saturday that more cases have been found in some locations. “Yesterday (Friday), there were 6,700 contacts (of Covid-19 positive cases) and now it is 7,000. This number is going up and if factual information shows there is community transmission, we will tell the nation about it,” he said.Also, the government is sending a special flight to bring in 262 Indians stuck in Rome in Italy where the Covid-19 outbreak has taken a dreadful shape claiming over 4.000 lives.On Sunday, PM Narendra Modi has appealed to people to observe a “janata curfew”. All cops using police vehicles in Delhi will blow siren at 5 pm for a minute and the PM has urged people to express their appreciation for the work being done by those in hospitals, airports, by banging utensils or by clapping for five minutes during the curfew.Meanwhile, the central government on Saturday held a video conference for training of hospital staff across states for critical care management in case of need for more hospitalisation with surging Covid-19 cases.Further, all states have been asked to conduct mock drills on Sunday on how to manage OPD, IPD, patient transfer in ambulances and infection control measures in case of a crisis, officials said.Gujarat seems to emerging as a new hotspot for the virus. Between March 19 and March 21, the number of Covid-19 cases in the state has risen from two to 14. While 13 positives had a history of foreign travel, the state also recorded its first Covid-19 patient, a 67-year-old Surat man, who had no international travel history but had visited Delhi and Jaipur recently for work.To contain a Covid-19 outbreak in the state, the health department now stares at the challenging task of tracking 47,000 people with a history of foreign travel. Some 100 people, who have come in contact with the positive cases, are also under the scanner.Bhilwara, meanwhile, could be sitting on a ticking bomb as 11 cases have been reported from there in the past two days. All of those infected are doctors and nursing staff with no recent travel history abroad. Since Friday evening, the entire city is under curfew.In Odisha, where two Covid-19 cases have been confirmed, CM Naveen Patnaik announced complete lockdown of five districts and eight major towns, including Bhubaneshwar and Puri, for a week to control disease spread. These are the places where more than 70% of the 3200 foreign returnees belong to. The lockdown will start at 7am on Sunday and continue till 9pm on March.

Title: Rajasthan Lockdown: 4 states seal borders, Rajasthan orders lockdown
Content:
More on Covid-19

We don’t want tourists coming to Goa until situation settles: Health minister

Maharashtra, Goa, Bihar and West Bengal have sealed their borders for buses from March 22 to March 31. Mizoram suspended issuing inner line permits with immediate effect to stop people from outside from entering the state.In Maharashtra, restrictions on entry and exit of MSRTC buses, those owned by other state transport undertakings and private tourist buses were imposed. Goa sealed its borders with Maharashtra and Karnataka from Saturday midnight. All passenger vehicles will be denied entry and only bona fide residents of Goa will be permitted to enter. Bengal won’t let buses enter or exit till March 31.Bihar has suspended all interstate bus services till March 31. Rajasthan has ordered a lockdown till March 31 while Odisha will lock down five districts till March 29. tnnMore than 3,500 tourist buses, specially luxury AC sleeper coaches, which arrive and leave Mumbai daily, will be hit by Maharashtra sealing its borders. However, the restrictions do not apply to private cars, tourist cabs, trucks and other heavy goods vehicles.“Transport operators are requested not to send any contract carriage bus from Maharashtra for interstate operations. Also no bus should leave any station outside Maharashtra to reach the state boundary after Saturday midnight. These instructions have been brought to the notice of all bus operators within and outside state and will be strictly enforced,” said Maharashtra transport commissioner Shekhar Channe.Even though there has not been a single positive case in Goa, “considering the critical phase the country is going through, it is necessary to be more vigilant and take all preventive measures that are required to prevent the community transmission of the virus,” chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Saturday. Goa issued the transport ban a day after the Karnataka government barred entry of passenger vehicles from Goa and Maharashtra. “We don’t want tourists coming to Goa until the situation settles,” health minister Vishwajit Rane said. He also said interstate movement of private vehicles would be restricted.

Title: Coronavirus Test Kit: Pvt labs with USFDA-approved kits can start testing for Covid-19
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The government has decided that private laboratories with Covid-19 testing kits approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (US FDA ) can start testing suspected cases, significantly adding to the scope and numbers of persons who are being tested. The cost of such tests will also be specified.So far, government labs had carried out the tests and even this number has risen to 111, an increase from some 70-odd that were involved in testing for Covid-19 till a few days ago. Allowing private labs — around 50 initially — will also help address criticism that too few tests are being carried out.The government has broadened the criteria for testing to all hospitalised cases of pneumonia beyond the random testing of ICU patients. The testing had been restricted to persons complaining of Covid-19 symptoms with a history of foreign travel of those who came in contact with such persons.Meanwhile, ICMR maintained that community transmission of the disease has not been documented as yet. It added that testing strategy would be changed further if there is evidence of a community spread.While allowing private labs to test, the Centre on Saturday said they can do so based on a prescription from a registered physician and as per testing guidelines and protocols issued by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). The US FDA approval for kits is the key criteria apart from SOPs for bio-safety of samples and collection procedures.“We have arrived at a decision on allowing private labs. The order detailing eligibility to participate in the programme and the cost of such tests done by private labs will be issued by evening,” a senior official told TOI. The government has ramped up its network with 111 public sector laboratories now offering Covid-19 tests across the country.“Private labs will be guided by testing protocols and criteria fixed by ICMR,” health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal said, emphasising that testing should not be “out of fashion” or as “a confidence-building exercise”.Meanwhile, testing protocols were also revised on Friday to include all hospitalised patients with severe acute respiratory illness (fever and cough and/or shortness of breath). It also said that “asymptomatic direct and high-risk contacts” of a confirmed case should be tested once between day 5 and day 14 of coming in contact.According to the advisory, direct and high risk contacts include those who live in the same household with a confirmed case and healthcare workers who examined a confirmed case without adequate protection.The government maintained most Covid-19 cases in India so far are related to travel and local transmission from imported cases to their immediate contacts. “The testing protocol is based on a response according to the evolving situation. Public health experts take note of the evolving situation, discuss it and then accordingly take decisions,” Agarwal said.Ramping up preparedness for a possible influx of patients, the government also initiated training for critical care management at 1,000 locations through video conference, and said it would conduct a nationwide mock drill on Sunday for emergency response to handle coronavirus cases.The government has also instructed states to augment production and supply of masks and sanitisers by doing away with permissions for capacity augmentation for existing sanitiser manufacturing units. Similarly, deodorant manufacturers have been asked to produce sanitisers to meet the increasing demand. Alcohol manufacturers have also been asked to supply the raw material, and also set up units on their own if possible.The government has also fixed the prices of masks and sanitisers under the Essential Commodities Act to avoid overpricing of these products. While the 2-ply and 3-ply masks carry a maximum retail price of Rs 8 and Rs 10 per piece respectively, the price of a 200 ml sanitiser unit has been fixed at Rs 100.

Title: 'Social distancing is here to stay, and it’s going to change our lives'
Content:
An

as social media influencer sounds strange, right? But not when the man behind the handle is

, a mathematician and epidemiologist who has closely studied how contagions spread. He’s also the author of a very timely book — an incredibly strange coincidence, he says — titled The Rules of Contagion. He tells

how maths can help contain the pandemic

You have studied how maths can help in understanding the spread of infectious diseases. Can it help us contain Covid-19?

You say that we have to live with social distancing for a year. What will that do to the economy and our lives?

Epidemics, pandemics lead us to an ‘us vs them’ situation. Why do stigma and segregation travel as fast as the pathogen?

You also question existing notions of how outbreaks happen and can be controlled. What’s the new wisdom on infectious diseases?

There’s a growing demand for countries to share DNA sequencing data of patients to study Covid-19. But how does this stack up against concerns for privacy and ethics?

How do you feel about your new social media stardom?

Maths can give us an idea of the scale of a problem and what we will be able to do about it. In the early stages, a person infected with coronavirus will pass it on to 2-3 people. Generally, there’s a five-day gap between one getting the infection and showing symptoms. You infect 2-3 people, after 5 days they give it to another bunch of people. So, with this kind of growth after a month or so you are going to be looking at hundreds of infections. If we implement really good social distancing, then instead of infecting 2-3 people, a patient will infect just over one. If you halve the amount of transmission, then you are potentially looking at a difference between hundreds of cases and a handful. Maths can be useful in giving us a sense that we don’t need to reduce our interactions by 99% — an average 50-60% would give us a huge difference in the outcome.It’s difficult to answer as we are really in unprecedented territory. The challenge we have got is that we know these intense social distancing measures can reduce transmission, but we don’t know the impact it will have on our daily lives, on our economy. But people need to be thinking about these measures on longer time scales. Some countries are claiming it’s a two-week change and we’ll be back to normal. This is going to be a long period of time. On the economic side we have seen people make efforts to look after their workers. I think it’s time to put people before profit. How we deal with our workers now will have a huge social impact in the coming months.With every outbreak, we see spread of fear and information. Fear, disgust, anger are fundamental survival emotions. Knowing what is bad for us has an evolutionary advantage because it prevents us from putting ourselves at risk. During an epidemic, we like to have a simple narrative of whose fault it is. That also combines with our tendency to put a story around these outbreaks. The Spanish flu, for example. Post-WWI a lot of countries had put censorship in place but not Spain. It was the only country that reported widely on the pandemic giving an illusion that Spain had many more cases. We are seeing the same with Covid-19. A lot of countries haven’t reported cases. That doesn’t mean they don’t have an outbreak. In the beginning everyone said it emerged from Asia. But new reports suggest that in Africa it’s being blamed on Europe.In the current corona outbreak, some people are taking more cosmetic measures. For example, temperature screening at airports. The problem with this is that the virus has a five-day incubation period. If someone has not been picked up while they are leaving a country, then it’s very unlikely that they will develop symptoms during a flight or when they arrive. You miss a vast majority of cases. It’s far more effective, as some countries are now doing, to quarantine all incoming people. Or, have clear information that all people flying in from certain countries need to isolate themselves.While data is a valuable resource in understanding how outbreaks spread, how we extract relevant components without compromising privacy remains a challenge. During the last stages of Ebola epidemic, there were cases of sexual transmission. Not many people were willing to come forward and share sequencing data as it was sensitive information. We need to create technology to respect boundaries.We scientists use Twitter to bounce around ideas, get a grip of the new science. With this outbreak many of us are getting more attention on what we are saying and doing. It’s common to see people make mistakes and misinterpret data during a pandemic. Through social media we can guide them towards things that are relevant. And with social distancing in place, it’s a platform to shout from and tell people that we need to take this thing very seriously.

Title: UP first to roll out aid scheme for Covid-hit daily wagers
Content:
More on Covid-19

LUCKNOW: The Uttar Pradesh government on Saturday announced financial assistance through direct bank transfers to daily wage workers in the state, who stand to lose employment during the current coronavirus-linked slowdown. This makes UP the first state to implement a policy for lakhs of people in the unorganised sector in this time of the Covid-19 outbreak.No sooner was this announced, the Karnataka government told its labour department to identify the modalities of a similar state-funded scheme and the extent of assistance for daily wage labourers in the state.UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced Rs 1,000 monthly allowance each for around 35 lakh labourers, hawkers and vendors and free ration to 1.65 crore daily wagers. An estimated Rs 420 crore will be spent on the entire exercise.Over the next 15 days, each district administration will launch a mammoth exercise to identify beneficiaries and collect bank account details. Those without bank accounts or ration cards will get them on priority.“As a precaution, we directed several institutions to shut down or reduce staff. Lakhs of poor people will lose their jobs, so the UP government has come up with a proposal to pay them Rs 1,000 per month and provide free ration till the crisis ends,” the CM said.He said, 20.37 lakh people are registered with the labour department, but bank details of only 5.97 lakh are available. Those without accounts will get help from the district administration and funds from labour cess will be used for the allowance. A budget of Rs 203 crore has been set aside for this.Unorganised workforce of 15 lakh people like hawkers, vendors, rickshaw and cart pullers will also be identified by the district administration and Rs 1,000 will also be transferred to each of them through DBT entailing an expenditure of Rs 150 crore. The urban development department will prepare their database in 15 days.Also, the government will provide 20kg wheat and 15kg rice to about 1,65,31,000 construction workers and daily wagers like cart-pullers registered under Antyodaya Scheme, MNREGA and labour department. The disbursal will be undertaken in April. An expenditure of Rs 64.5 crore will be incurred on this process. “MNREGA workers who have not been paid till now will get dues cleared in March,” the CM said.Quarterly pension to 83.83 lakh beneficiaries of old age, disability and widow pensions will be given two months in advance, in April.The Karnataka government too is all set to take a leaf out of the UP initiative and provide direct cash transfer to daily wagers and construction labourers, whose livelihood has been severely hit by the Covid-19 pandemic.Soon after Yogi made the announcement, the labour department was told to identify the modalities and the extent of assistance provided to daily wage labourers.Labour minister Shivram Hebbar will meet his officers on Monday to lay out the scheme and later meet chief minister BS Yediyurappa for his approval.

Title: Rlys: At least 12 coronavirus-infected took trains in 4 days
Content:
Railways tweaks

rules to avoid crowding

NEW DELHI: At least 12 Covid-19 infected people have travelled in trains between March 13 and 16, the railways said on Saturday. In a tweet, the ministry said, “Railways has found some cases of coronavirus-infected passengers in trains which makes train travel risky. Avoid train travel as you may also get infected if your co-passenger has coronavirus. Postpone all journeys & keep yourself and your loved ones safe.”The railways also announced a change of refund rules to avoid crowding at stations. Railways said passengers can claim refund up to 90 days from the date of journey across counters instead of the current practice of three days in case a train is cancelled. This will be applicable for trains cancelled by the railways between March 21 and June 21. This even as the railway board ordered the closure of all rail museums, railways heritage parks and galleries till April 15.The railways said that eight people who travelled on the AP Sampark Kranti train on March 13 have tested positive for coronavirus. “We have appealed people not to rush and avoid travelling. Trains that are already running before Sunday but are due to reach their destinations will not be stopped,” said an official.He added that as per the relaxed refund rule, passengers will be fully refunded if they cancel their tickets for journeys till June 21 and for a refund for counter generated tickets passengers can approach any counter across the railway network.The norms have also been relaxed for refund in case the passenger doesn’t want to travel even as the train has not been cancelled. Passengers can file ticket deposit receipt within 90 days from the date of journey.Passengers who want to cancel their tickets through 139 service, will get refunds within 90 days from the date of journey instead of the rule of up to scheduled departure of the train.

Title: Coronavirus curbs trigger prison riot in Kolkata; 1 killed, 8 hurt
Content: KOLKATA: One person was killed in police firing and at least eight prisoners, jail staffers and policemen were injured after inmates of Dum Dum Central Correctional Home rioted on Saturday. Undertrial prisoners set fire to prison property and engaged security personnel in several rounds of pitched battles using bricks and axes and other sharp-edged weapons, forcing cops to open fire.Several prisoners tried to scale the 20-foot-plus walls of West Bengal ’s largest prison facility during the riot, which continued for over eight hours in the middle of a crowded Dum Dum neighbourhood; three others were caught trying to sneak out of the prison gates, officials said.The arsenal used by the prisoners indicated it was a “planned” jailbreak attempt, officials said, but there were three immediate sparks, all linked to Covid-19 fears and several steps implemented by the government over the last one week to control its spread.One of the immediate causes was a decision by prison authorities on Friday to suspend till March 31 the bi-weekly prisoner “interviews” with family members; this would have significantly reduced the number of jail visitors. Another trigger was a government proposal for a 15-day special parole for lifers who had already spent 10 years in prison with certified “good conduct”; this would have led to the release of 500 lifers and freed up several cells for use as isolation wards.The third issue that Saturday’s rioters mentioned was delayed court production of undertrials (courts are taking up only urgent matters and encouraging more video-conferencing).The first inkling of trouble came around 10.30am on Saturday when a section of undertrials, demanding hand sanitisers and masks, “started getting agitated”, officials said. This soon led to the demand that they be allowed their weekend “interviews” with family members. This was followed by slogans against parole applications being turned down (even as lifers’ applications “were being allowed”).

Title: Rs 41,000 crore stimulus for desi mobile makers
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The government has approved a mega Rs 41,000 crore booster for local manufacturing of mobile phones and their components , giving out incentives between 4-6% towards specified Make in India initiatives, apart from announcing a near Rs 7,000 crore scheme for manufacturing of electronics components, and for setting up manufacturing clusters.

Telecom and IT minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said that the approval to the schemes, given by the Union Cabinet , is aimed at boosting investments in the critical electronics segment while positioning India as a global manufacturing hub.

TOI was the first to report on the development in its edition dated March 3, giving details about the mega plan towards boosting local electronics manufacturing and positioning India as a credible counter to countries like China and Vietnam .

“Two long-term policy decisions have been taken to make India a hub of electronics manufacturing in new directions and medical electronics. Cabinet has approved production linked-incentive for electronics companies. We will give Rs 40,995 crore in the coming five years for production linked-incentive in mobile phone manufacturing and specified electronic components, including assembly, testing, marking and packaging units,” Prasad said.

Incentives will be linked to incremental sales and capital investment of the companies, he added. “ ... because of these schemes, we hope to generate manufacturing revenue potential of Rs 10 lakh crore by 2025.” With the scheme, the government expects the domestic value addition in mobile phones to rise to 35-40% by 2025 from the current level of 20-25%.

Apart from this, the Cabinet cleared a Rs 3,285 crore scheme for promotion of manufacturing of electronics components and semiconductors. The scheme will provide financial incentive of 25% on capital expenditure for the identified list of electronic goods that comprise downstream value chain of electronic products such as electronic components, semiconductor/ display fabrication units, among others. The scheme is expected to create around 6 lakh (direct and indirect) jobs, he said.

On electronics manufacturing clusters, the Cabinet approved a budgetary outlay of Rs 3,762 crore, to be given over a period of 8 years. The scheme will provide financial help up to 50% of the project cost, subject to ceiling of Rs 70 crore per 100 acres of land for setting up of electronics manufacturing cluster projects.

Title: 2 land in Gaya with Covid-19 symptoms
Content: GAYA: Two passengers reportedly showing Covid-19 symptoms landed at the Gaya airport on Saturday afternoon sparking panic and a flurry of activities among the airport staff. The flyers, said to be residents of Gorakhpur in UP, arrived from Thailand in a Bangkok-Gaya flight belonging to Thai Smile Airways, airport officials said.Prompt crew members had alerted the airport officials about the health condition of the two flyers on board and on arrival, they were immediately segregated and taken out of the airport through a separate gate. “The two travellers have been sent to the isolation ward of ANMMCH in Muzaffarpur. Samples of blood and throat swab of the suspects would be sent for proper testing,” Gaya DM Abhishek Singh said, adding, “Initial reports had put the number of Covid-19 suspects on board at five.”Altogether 12 passengers arrived by the Thai Smile Airways flight from Bangkok. The other 10 passengers have been advised home isolation by the medical team attending at the airport. They have been asked to strictly follow the social distancing protocol.Though the ANMMCH superintendent Dr Vijay Krishna Prasad could not be reached despite several calls made at his official number, sources said the two isolated flyers are suffering from high fever and respiratory problems.Airport Director Dilip Kumar said, “The Thai Smile plane was thoroughly disinfected and it subsequently took off for Bangkok with 120 passengers, all of them foreign nationals.”

Title: Courts in state conduct trials through videoconferencing
Content: PATNA: Covid-19 pandemic has forced the prisons directorate in Bihar to ensure the production of undertrial prisoners in respective courts through videoconferencing only. It has, however, not affected the ongoing trial proceedings in courts. A Jamui court on Saturday awarded three years’ imprisonment and imposed a penalty of Rs10,000 in a case under Arms Act.The case pertains to recovery of a country-made pistol and two live cartridges from the possession of Jitendra Thakur alias Jitu from Lachhuar turning under Sikandara police station in Jamui district on July 28 last year.Judicial magistrate Manish Pandey pronounced the quantum of punishment through videoconferencing. While the accused deposed before the trial court from Jamui district jail, defence lawyer Ravindra Kumar Yadav and assistant public prosecutor Jitendra Kumar Singh presented their arguments through videoconferencing.Jamui jail superintendent Arun Paswan said, “For the first time the quantum of punishment has been pronounced by a trial court through videoconferencing in Jamui. All the undertrial prisoners are being produced before the respective courts from jail through videoconferencing following the prisons directorate advisory.”Earlier, Singh said the accused was held guilty and convicted by the court within six months under speedy trial. The charges were framed against him on September 25, 2019. Altogether five prosecution witnesses were examined during trial in the case, he revealed.There were 400 prisoners lodged in Jamui district jail against the sanctioned capacity of only 187 inmates. Similarly, the inmates of the Beur central jail in Patna were being deposed before the respective courts through videoconferencing. At present, 4600 prisoners were lodged in Beur jail against the sanctioned strength of 4100.Beur jail superintendent Jawahar Lal Prabhakar said altogether 150 inmates were shifted to Phulwari jail and Bhagalpur central jail recently. “We have distributed masks among the prisoners and their wards were being sanitized. Besides, they have been asked to follow the advisory strictly,” he added.Meanwhile, IG (Prisons) Mithilesh Mishra visited the Beur jail on Saturday to assess the preventive measures in the wake of lurking threat of coronavirus . “Instructions have been issued to all jail superintendents to ensure production of prisoners in respective courts through videoconferencing system only,” he said.There are over 40,000 prisoners lodged in 59 jails, including eight central jails, in the state. However, the fear of coronavirus has not affected the trial proceedings in the courts across the state, thanks to the videoconferencing facility available both in courts as well as jails.

Title: Admn to allow minimum movement on roads today
Content:
PATNA: In view of PM Narendra Modi’s call of ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday, the district administration has sensitized its officers for making efforts that least number of people come out on road from 7am to 9pm.

Patna DM Kumar Ravi and SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma had a meeting with SDOs, SDPOs and other officers on Saturday to take stock of the situation and steps required to ensure that people themselves remain indoors.

Ravi told TOI over phone that the officers have been sensitized for making appeal to people to remain indoors for their well-being as well as of the society at large. “Minimum movement would be allowed on roads. The administration would ensure smooth operation of essential services like electricity supply and ambulance services on Sunday,” he said, adding that common people are already aware about the present situation.

Ravi also said the administration would also ensure that people stuck in any emergency situation are provided required assistance as roads would remain empty. He said Patna Municipal Corporation has been instructed to get garbage lifted from all the locations before 7am at any cost.

“We have requested the organizers of Chhath and Ram Navami processions not to make gathering this time. We have directed NDRF and SDRF to request Chhath devotees through associations during meeting for celebrating the festival indoors this time,” he said, adding the administration would appeal to people to abide by law and not to gather more than 50 persons anywhere at a time. “Police patrolling would be intensified on Sunday,” he said.

Meanwhile, SSP Sharma said directions had been issued that all four-wheelers in police stations be used for intensive patrolling with an attempt to persuade people that they remain indoors. “All quick mobile personnel on bikes would roam on the main roads and bylanes and appeal to the residents to remain inside for their own well-being,” he said, adding that no additional force had been requisitioned from outside the district.

He said police patrolling parties would also persuade people spotted on road to go back home for their own benefits.

Title: Buses not to ply till March 31
Content: PATNA: The state government on Saturday suspended all bus services in the state, including interstate buses, till March 31 as a preventive measure against Covid-19 pandemic.The state transport department has decided to stop the operations of city buses with immediate effect, whereas the services of interstate buses would remain suspended from Sunday (March 22) till March 31. However, inter-district buses would continue to operate for the time being though only 50% of them will be allowed to run.Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the decision to stop interstate and city buses till March 31 has been taken as preventive measure and to follow the guideline of social distancing. “Buses operated by Bihar State Road Transport Corporation Limited (BSRTC) as well as private operators have been stopped with immediate effect. The interstate buses would also stop plying from Sunday onwards,” he said.“The instruction to ban bus services till March 31 has been issued to all the operators. The suspension order would be revoked only after the situation improves,” he said.On being asked how the department would ensure restriction on bus operators, Agarwal said district magistrates will monitor and take action against violators. “The salary of bus drivers and conductors will not be deducted for this period. Meanwhile, the passengers, who booked the bus tickets in advance from travel websites for interstate buses will get full refund for cancellation,” Agarwal said.There are about 125 city buses of BSRTC and 250 by private operators in Patna. BSRTC operates 20 interstate buses on Delhi and Jharkhand routes and private operators run more than 100 buses on Kolkata, Lucknow, Delhi, Agra and Jharkhand routes.Earlier, an order was issued on March 15 to suspend operation of buses from Patna and Gaya to Kathmandu and Janakpur till March 31. The district transport officers, motor vehicle inspectors and enforcement sub-inspectors of the respective districts have been instructed to ensure that public transport vehicles are being sanitized.

Title: Kandla port to strengthen infra, take on private players
Content: Rajkot: With an eye on future growth and to compete with private players, Deendayal Port Trust (DPT), formerly known as Kandla Port, has envisaged an investment of Rs 9,757 crore for sprucing up its infrastructure facilities.One of the 12 major ports in India, DPT has already submitted its infrastructure development plan to the Union ministry of shipping.The port has set a target to handle annually 137 million metric tonnes (MMT) cargo and increase revenue to Rs 1,967 by 2024.The port has handled 102 MMT cargo till January this fiscal and hopes to complete the year with 119 MMT cargo handling. The port’s vision is to achieve 200 MMT by 2029.“To realize our vision, DPT’s infrastructure facilities are being spruced up. The port intends to pump Rs 1,671 crore for augmenting its liquid cargo handling capacity from 8 million metric tonnes per annum (MMTPA) to 23 MMTPA. The capacity expansion projects will be executed on public-private-partnership basis,” said S K Mehta, chairman, DPT.To upgrade its infrastructure facilities, an investment plan involving Rs 8,086 crore has been chalked out for the port situated at Kandla in Kutch. The investment will be made towards mechanization of fertilizer berth, revamping of berth structures, construction of roads and godowns, creation of new storage areas and improving rail connectivity.In order to take on private port operators, DPT has decided not to increase tariff in the new Scale of Rates (SoR) for three years. It has already implemented this decision from November 2019. It will also maintain the lowest tariffs amongst neighbouring ports. The port authorities will also provide discounts to foreign vessels.The port is going to start a marketing division and rope in marketing talents from premier institutes like IIM Ahmedabad and others.

Title: 17 more trains cancelled: ECR
Content: PATNA: The Covid-19 pandemic has forced the railways to cancel 17 more passenger trains originating from different stations under the jurisdiction of the East Central Railway (ECR). With this, the total number of cancelled trains due to poor occupancy rate has gone up to 35.ECR chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar told this newspaper on Saturday that the railways had cancelled the Saharsa-Patliputra Junction Express (13205/13206) from March 21 to 31. “The Muzaffarpur-Raxaul MEMU (63311/63312), Saharsa-Supaul passenger (55503/55504), Samastipur-Darbhanga passenger (75209/75210) and Samastipur-Saharsa passenger (63343/63344) will remain cancelled till Sunday,” the CPRO said.Similarly, the Anand Vihar-Madhupur Express (22459/22460) will be cancelled from Anand Vihar-end on March 23 and 30 from Madhupur-side on March 24 and 31.“Other trains like the Anand Vihar-Madhupur Express (22465/22466) will be cancelled on March 25 and 26. The New Delhi-Dibrugarh Rajdhani Express (20506) will not run from New Delhi-side on March 29 and the Dibrugarh-New Delhi Rajdhani Express (20503) will be cancelled on March 26,” the CPRO said.The Ranchi-New Delhi Rajdhani Express (12453/12454) will not run on March 21, 22, 24, 26, 28 and 29 due to poor occupancy, while the Lucknow-Pt Deendayal Upadhyay Junction Express (14261/14262) will be cancelled on March 24, 26 and 31. “The Delhi-Dibrugarh Brahmaputra Mail (15956) will be cancelled from March 23 to April 3 and the Patliputra Junction-Lucknow Express (12529/12530) from March 21 to 31,” Kumar said,” adding that the Barauni-Ambala Hariharnath Express (14523/14524) would be cancelled from March 21 to April 2.Special trains: The railways is running four special trains from Mumbai and Pune, including the Mumbai-Patna special (01101) and Pune-Danapur special (01499, 01401 and 01139), to bring back people stranded there due to lockdown in Mumbai and Pune.“These special trains will reach Patna and Danapur on Sunday morning. The railways has made arrangements for proper screening of passengers at the stations,” the CPRO said.

Title: In view of coronavirus outbreak, West Bengal government postpones HS exams; new dates to be declared after April 15
Content:
Delay in completing the examinations by a month will, however, have a ripple effect on the academic sessions a... Read More

KOLKATA: The West Bengal government has decided to postpone the ongoing higher secondary (Class XII) examinations and called off the Class XI exam, which are conducted by the schools based on question papers provided by the West Bengal Higher Secondary Council. All the exams will be rescheduled after April 15.

After the announcement by chief minister Mamata Banerjee, the same was explained by education minister Partha Chatterjee. He also lashed out at some private schools, alleging parents had complained that they were kept flouting the advisories.

Three more days of exams remain now. These will be rescheduled. “The decision was taken in the wake of the ongoing crisis and the immediate need to prohibit movement. The pandemic may flare up with the number of affected persons multiplying in no time,” Chatterjee said.

Among the examinations, which are left includes physics, nutrition, education, accountancy, chemistry, economics, journalism & mass communication, Sanskrit, Persian, Arabic, French, statistics, geography, costing and taxation, home management and family resource management.

Earlier, the Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations (CISCE) and the CBSE had decided to reschedule all Class X and Class XII Board examinations till March 31.

Delay in completing the examinations by a month will, however, have a ripple effect on the academic sessions as well the publication of results, alerted the educationists.

Angshuman Guha, an HS science student said, “There are a series of national entrance tests lined up from April. These are yet to be postponed. If those are not rescheduled, I may have to skip them.”

The Class XI examinations conducted by the schools will be held later.

Title: PMC approves Rs 119 crore surplus budget with focus on infra development
Content:
Patna Municipal Corporation

PATNA: The board of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) on Saturday passed Rs 119.11 crore surplus budget. Keeping in mind coronavirus threat, the board members and officials of PMC sat in four different halls of a hotel here to ensure social distancing.

The budget, tabled by mayor Sita Sahu, envisages an estimated income of Rs 3,863.57 crore and an estimated expenditure of Rs 3,744.46 crore. As per the budget, maximum expenditure will be on infrastructure development, for which Rs 2,726.23 crore has been allocated.

In the budget, the PMC has mentioned construction of toilets, colony roads and drainage system as its flagship programmes. The civic body has targeted to spend Rs 5 crore each in construction of modular and community toilets and Rs 2,806 crore in construction of smart roads in colonies and drains.

“The aim is to provide all civic facilities to the people of the city. We have focused on construction of colony roads and drains. The target of solid waste management will also be achieved,” the mayor said.

The PMC has allocated Rs 12.05 crore for solid waste management. Under this project, plastic waste processing units will be set up to convert plastic waste into granule and fuel. Construction of six garbage transfer stations is also under this programme – two at Gardanibagh and four at Agamkuan.

The budget has made provisions for four mega commercial complexes to be constructed at an expenditure of Rs 256.63 crore. These commercial complexes will come up near Saidpur, Machhua Toli, beside Khetan Market and near Meena Bazaar in Patna City.

Title: Number of coronavirus tests to be increased in Bihar
Content: PATNA: Bihar is likely to increase the number of tests for Covid-19 in adherence to fresh guidelines issued by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). Only 79 samples have so far been collected in the state and sent to laboratories for test against 520 travellers enrolled for observation.State nodal officer Dr Ragini Mishra said they were following the guidelines of ICMR. Till Friday, only those coming from affected countries were being tested in the state.“According to the fresh ICMR guidelines, those having severe acute respiratory illness will also be tested henceforth,” she said.The ICMR has made some changes in the guidelines for conducting tests for Covid-19 in the country after World Health Organisation (WHO) asked all countries to increase the number of tests.After changes in the guidelines, even asymptomatic direct contact with positive case and high risk contacts of confirmed case will be tested. Besides, those hospitalized with symptoms of coronavirus, like respiratory illness, shortness of breath, cough and fever will be tested.Bihar has so far received 1,500 kits from National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune for conducting tests for Covid-19. While 1,000 kits are in Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences, the remaining 500 kits are with Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital (DMCH).Asked whether 1,500 kits were enough for a populous state like Bihar, Dr Sunil Singh, a member of Bihar Medical Council, said the state was following the protocol of the Centre for tests and these kits were sufficient for the time being.No protective gears for doctors at isolation wards: Health workers at isolation wards of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH), including doctors, nurses and other staff, were on Saturday seen working without wearing protective gears like eye shield, shoe cover, gown and gloves.World Health Organisation (WHO) has asked all the medical institutes to ensure that health service providers, who are at high risk, work with personal protective equipment (PPE). But at PMCH, this was not the case. The health service providers were only wearing N95 mask.PMCH superintendent Dr Bimal Karak, however, said the hospital has sufficient quantity of PPE. Health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar also said that 31,000 PPE are in stock but there was some scarcity of N95 masks.

Title: Mahabodhi Temple shut
Content:
GAYA: The Mahabodhi temple, which attracts visitors from across the globe, will remain shut on Sunday. Gaya DM Abhishek Singh issued an order on Saturday to close the Mahabodhi Mahavihara in view of the PM’s call for a ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday.

The Bodh Gaya Temple Management Committee issued a notification suspending religious activities such as meditation, chanting of mantras, flower offerings and group prayers at the Mahabodhi Mahavihara, the seat of Gautama Buddha’s enlightenment, as a preventive measure to contain the spread of Covid-19.

As per the notification issued by committee secretary N Dorje, several other regulatory measures have been taken, which include restricting the number of people entering the temple by issuing a token. Only 50 visitors would be allowed inside the shrine premises at a time and entry into the sanctum sanctorum will only be in batches of three.

Devotees meditate at various points on the shrine premises for long hours, such sessions stand suspended. According to the Gaya DM, visitors are being allowed inside only after thermal scanning and two Bodh Gaya hotels have also been kept in readiness to quarantine coronavirus suspects.

Tourist attractions such as the 80 ft high Great Buddha Statue, Diajokiyo Temple, Srilankan monastery and Thai temple, called ‘Navlakha Mandir’ by local residents have also been closed. The entire temple township wore a deserted look on Saturday.

In a related development, the management committee of the White House Compound Mosque, on Friday evening held an emergency meet to approve regulated entry into the mosque.

According to Tanveer Usmani, secretary of the Mosque Committee the ‘Wazoo Khana (pre prayer wash facility)’ has been closed and carpets have been removed. “Elders have been advised to pray at home and only the ‘farz’ (mandatory) prayers would be held in the mosque. The mosque will be properly disinfected after each prayer and mosque doors would be closed immediately after prayers,” Usmani said.

As per reports, some devotees visiting Vishnupad temple for darshan have objected to the use of sanitizers in the shrine as devotees cannot offer obeisance with alcohol-soaked hands. As per custom, devotees have to touch Lord Vishnu’s foot print.

Confirming the reluctance of devotees to use alcohol-based sanitisers, senior priest Mahesh Guput said honouring the sentiments of the devotees, soaps have been placed at the temple entrance. No compromise with the preventive protocol was being allowed at the Vishnupad Temple, said the priest, a leading Gayawal Panda.

Title: Most Kashi temples closed for devotees
Content:
A priest waits for customers on a deserted ghat on Saturday

Varanasi: Residents of Kashi offered prayers at home as most of the temples were closed for devotees from Saturday as a preventive measure to the check spread of coronavirus.

While Kashi Vishwanath, Durgakund and Annapurna temples will remain closed till March 24, Sankat Mochan Temple has been shut till March 25. Besides, other local temples also remain closed.

Announcing closure of the temple from Saturday, Mahant of Sankat Mochan Temple Prof Vishwambhar Nath Mishra said, “The decision has been taken in the larger interest of people who visit the temple in large numbers, particularly on Saturdays and Tuesdays.”

“Though we were adopting all precautionary measures to prevent spread of virus and keep devotees safe, it became essential to close the temple in view of the prevalent situation,” he said.

“Next week is very crucial and people should keep themselves safe,” he added.

Mishra said normal routine of the temple and activities like ‘bhog’ and ‘aarti’ would continue as usual. “The temple has been closed for devotees only. Temple priests will continue daily religious rituals. The situation will be reviewed later and the decision to reopen the temple will be taken after consultation with the district administration,” he added.

District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said the decision to close Kashi Vishwanath temple for all devotees was taken in a meeting of temple trust on Friday evening. “The temple will remain closed while all routine rituals and ‘aartis’ will continue as usual,” he added.

Earlier, Kashi Vishwanath temple administration had stopped the entry of devotees inside sanctum sanctorum and made washing and sanitization of hands mandatory before entry.

Title: Janta curfew: 80 trains to be cancelled today
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PATNA: Altogether 80 long-distance trains originating from different places under the jurisdiction of the East Central Railway (ECR) have been cancelled due to the ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday. These include premier Delhi-bound trains like the Rajdhani Express, Sampoorna Kranti Express, Shramjeevi Express and Magadh Express.

ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar told this newspaper, “All long-distance trains, which left their originating stations on Saturday night, will be allowed to reach their destinations on Sunday. However, those, which were supposed to originate from their respective stations between 4am and 10pm on Sunday, have been cancelled due to the ‘janata curfew’.”

Several pairs of local passenger trains will also not run on Sunday, bringing the entire traffic movement to a halt for about 18 hours.

Title: Patna college gets ISO certification
Content:
Patna University

PATNA: Magadh Mahila College , a constituent unit of Patna University, on Saturday received a certification from the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), following a rigorous assessment.

College principal Shashi Sharma claimed that the 74-year-old college, which has recently been accredited by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council in the second cycle with grade ‘B+’ and accorded the status of ‘College with Potential for Excellence’ by the University Grants Commission, happens to be the first public institution of higher education in the state to get ISO certification.

Sharma told this newspaper that the process of certification was a weeklong affair when a team visited and assessed the institution on various parameters in February. The institution was evaluated on the criteria laid down by the United Accreditation Foundation (UAF)-USA and it was found in accordance with the requirements of the management system standards.

The college received ISO certification in four different categories — Certification for Educational Organization Management System, Certificate for Occupational Health and Safety Management System, Certificate for Quality Management System and Certificate for Environmental Management System.

“UAF representatives Raj Summerbar and Aashiqali Asharfi applauded the college management in maintaining its standards beyond the international standards. The certification is valid till March 2023,” the principal said.

Magadh Mahila College got the ‘Best College Award’ from chief minister Nitish Kumar in 2014 and the ‘Excellent Institution of Higher Education for Girls in Bihar’ award by the then governor and present President Ram Nath Kovind in 2016.

Title: Patna: Experts for access to safe drinking water
Content: PATNA: Even as one-third of the world’s population is clamouring for safe drinking water, the issue of hand washing is likely to dominate this year’s celebration of World Water Day on Sunday.Experts are of the view that the availability of fresh water is vital in the fight against coronavirus . They say that without running water for everyone, fighting the new disease is impossible. Patna University (PU) geology department head Ramesh Shukla says, “Over-exploitation of groundwater — the only source of water supply in Patna — through deep tube wells has led its reservoir to deplete faster. For a city of nearly 25 lakh people already facing a major water crisis, the rapid depletion of groundwater will spell doom. The underground watertable in the state capital has gone down by more than 15 feet in recent years.”Environmentalist Mehta Nagendra Singh claims that many shallow tube wells have dried up in the last couple of years, leading to their complete breakdown.“Although the average annual rainfall over Patna is fairly high (about 1,000mm per annum), the bulk of the rainwater is lost through surface run-off. Things have come to such a pass due to the gradual disappearance of ponds and other open surface water bodies that helped recharge the groundwater reservoir through slow seepage,” he adds.PU environmental science and management course coordinator D K Paul points out, “Clean drinking water is a human right. People should not have to worry about the fact that their water is unsafe to drink or wash hands. We need funds to keep our water systems up-to-date and affordable.”He adds, “The corona crisis has made it clear once and for all that access to safe water, hygiene and health are inextricably linked.”

Title: Bihar CM reviews preparations for ‘janata curfew’ today
Content:
Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar and his deputy Sushil Kumar Modi on Saturday appealed to the people of Bihar to make the PM’s call of ‘ janata curfew ’ on Sunday a grand success. The CM also held a meeting with top state officials to review the government’s preparations to meet the challenges posed by coronavirus.

“PM Narendra Modi has given a call for janata curfew on March 22. We appeal to all residents of Bihar to stay at home between 7am and 9pm on Sunday,” Nitish and SuMo said in a statement released on Saturday.

Nitish also called for maintaining social distancing. “Social distancing is the best solution for putting an effective check on spread of coronavirus,” Nitish said.

Besides SuMo, health minister Mangal Pandey, chief secretary Deepak Kumar , DGP Gupteshwar Pandey and Patna divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal attended the meeting, held at the CM’s residence.

The CM asked the officials to ensure comprehensive screening of all people coming to Bihar either by flights, trains or buses.

Later in the evening, the CM spoke to the DMs and SPs of all districts through videoconferencing and reviewed the preparations being made by them for janata curfew. He also issued certain instructions to the DMs and SPs, an official told TOI.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: SHO, 2 other cops suspended over Kheri liqour deaths
Content:
BAREILLY: Days after two persons died and five were taken ill after consuming spurious liquor at Pahadpur village in Lakhimpur Kheri district, the SHO of Mailani police station and two other policemen were suspended for negligence in preventing manufacturing and sale of the deadly brew in their area.

Poonam, SSP, Kheri suspended SHO, Mailani, Rajveer Singh , Kukra police outpost in charge Ajay Sharma and constable Naresh Kumar for the liquor related deaths. She has ordered a departmental inquiry into the matter. She has also written to the government seeking suspension of the excise inspector concerned of the circle.

The manufacturing of spurious liquor is rampant in the villages adjacent to the Dudhwa forests in Mailani area, where the residents do not have much agricultural land.

On Friday evening, the SSP met the families of the people who fell ill after consuming spurious liquor and also visited Pahadpur village to take stock of the situation.

Following investigations, two liquor mafia, Satish and Ravindra, were arrested at the village. A huge consignment of spurious liquor brewed by them in the forest area was also seized.

Circle officer Ravindra Kumar Verma , who is probing the matter, told TOI, “We found that SHO Mailani, Kukra police outpost in charge and the SHO’s driver guilty of negligence. All three of them have been suspended by the SSP. We have found that many people are involved in manufacturing illicit liquor in Pahadpur and nearby villages. We are identifying them and action will be taken against them.”

Asked about the ailing victims, Verma said, “The condition of all the people admitted to hospital after consuming spurious liquor is stable now. We have arrested the duo involved in making and selling the liquour and booked them under the Excise Act and IPC sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) and 272 (adulteration of food or drink).”

Title: 10 more pigs found dead in Bhagalpur
Content:
BHAGALPUR: Fresh cases of pig deaths in different localities of the town have alarmed the district administration and the Bhagalpur Municipal Corporation (BMC) amid coronavirus threat.

After “unexpected” death of 78 pigs in different localities of the town on March 19, another 10 pigs were found dead on Friday. Bhagalpur DM Pranav Kumar had said attributed the death of 78 pigs to swine “fever”, which is different from swine flu.

Following the sudden death of pigs, Bhagalpur district administration has asked BMC to sanitize all 51 wards and remove garbage and filth within the municipal corporation area. Instructions have also been issued to quarantine the areas from where most pig death cases have been reported.

The animal husbandry department has also been advised to collect viscera samples from the dead pigs and probe the cause of sudden death of pigs.

Deputy municipal commissioner Satyendra Prasad Verma said the civic body was disposing the carcasses of dead pigs by burying them 10 feet under soil.

DM Pranav said the animal husbandry department has been asked to depute veterinary doctors in the areas concerned and make medicines available to the people rearing pigs. The DM also ordered a ban on sale of pig meat till March 31.

Stay safe, cops told: Bhagalpur police have taken several initiatives to protect police personnel from Covid-19. Hand wash and sanitizers are being provided to the arrested accused and criminals as well as visitors coming to police stations, traffic police outposts and police department offices.

Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti has asked SHOs of police stations to ensure that visitors and others clean their hands with sanitizers before entering the police stations and other premises.

The SSP said several steps have been taken to protect police personnel and people visiting police stations from coronavirus.

Naugachia police district SP Nidhi Rani has also asked the SHOs to offer hand wash and sanitizers to the people coming to police stations or even those who have been arrested and brought to police station.

Title: ‘Homeopathy can treat Covid-19 but no common medicine for all’
Content: Veteran homeopath Dr Vilas Dangre believes that homeopathy has a combination of medicines with which one can treat a Covid-19 patient and can even get the patient cured, if given a chance. But this combination differs from person to person. Mass distribution of one homeopathic medicine as a cure or prevention of coronavirus is unscientific and against the principle of individuality on which the homeopathy is based on, he claims.In an interview with TOI, Dangre spoke at length about the burning issue which has hit the world in a scary way.Excerpts...Q. Is there any medicine in homeopathy to cure Covid-19?A. My one word answer is yes. That’s because homeopathy can treat Covid-19 symptomatically with a combination of medicines. But if you ask me exactly what that combination is then it would be difficult for any homeopath to tell you. This is because homeopathy is based on a principle of individuality. Every individual is a different case for us. We can’t generalize. Two individuals showing a similar set of symptoms may be prescribed different sets of medicines in homeopathy based on various parameters. So, my final answer is yes. Homeopathy has a medicine for Covid-19, but there is nothing like one common medicine which is applicable to all.Q. Some groups are distributing homeopathic medicines, drops at public places claiming it be preventive vaccines. How reliable are these medicines?A. This virus is new and all systems of medicine are still in the research phase. Presently, no system has discovered a medicine or vaccine to tackle Covid-19. Even doctors practising modern medicine are treating only the symptoms. No doctor of any system can claim to have a vaccine or a medicine for Covid-19. You can have immunity boosters to keep yourself fit and protected from viruses, but it couldn’t be called as Covid-19 vaccine. I also came across some practitioners who claimed in the media that homeopathy has a medicine that can cure Covid-19. I think some of them were over enthusiastic and many wanted instant popularity by issuing such fancy statements in the media. How can they claim their medicine can cure or prevent this disease when there is no evidence to support such a claim? Some practitioners are even distributing proven homeopathic immunity-boosters among masses. Their intentions are good. They could be thinking that their gesture will keep people away from unnecessary panic. But I think that even this exercise should be avoided.Q. Given the scenario, is a little bit of panic good?A. It is because I believe that a little bit of panic for a disease like Covid-19 is a must. We just can’t take it lightly. People may stop observing social distancing and taking other protective measures after getting the so called vaccines. This may put them at risk. Such immunity boosters can keep you fit, but may not protect you from coronavirus entirely. This virus spreads rapidly. It can affect a large population within a short span of time. We have examples of Iran and Italy where thousands have died just because people failed to follow the necessary preventive practices. At the same time, I also suggest avoiding unnecessary panic. Many people are so scared that they have stopped meeting their neighbours. The example of a positive patient’s family in Nagpur is still fresh. Their own neighbours have boycotted them socially. We should avoid this type of misconduct. Be alert, be vigilant, but don’t be terrified of coronavirus. We have no option but to fight it together. The entire world is fighting it.Q. What is the best remedy to ensure safety?A. At present, the only way to protect ourselves is to maintain social distancing practices, hand-hygiene, avoiding visits to public places, parties and marriage functions. We are observing a janata curfew today and I think we need to observe more such curfews in the future. This is the only way we can stop the spread of coronavirus. For those who believe in homeopathy, my only suggestion to them is to not follow a common medicine. It’s against the basic principle of this system. Rather, you can visit your doctor, share all symptoms and get medicines as per your individual condition. This is the most proper way of getting homeopathic treatment.Q. Some theories are claiming that the harsh summer of Vidarbha will end coronavirus. Your thoughts?A. It’s unscientific to say so. In fact, such misconceptions will only complicate the situation. All of us must spontaneously practice social distancing. As far as my knowledge is concerned, the outbreak of coronavirus is not going to stop in a month or two. It’s not even a question of summer or winter or rainy season. It’s at least a year-long fight and we must be prepared for it.

Title: Mystery over death of railway staff found on tracks
Content:
Representative image

AGRA: A 30-year-old welding technician of the carriage and wagon the department of the Indian Railways died under suspicious circumstances on Saturday morning. He was found unconscious and later declared brought dead by hospital staff.

According to GRP, the deceased was identified as Dheeraj Kumar, a resident of Ramveer Nagar Albatia. His colleagues took him to a private hospital, where he was declared brought dead.

Naushad, Agra Fort GRP inspector, said, “At around 4:35 am Dheeraj’s colleagues found him lying in an unconscious state on the railway track of platform number one. They first rushed him to the railway hospital and later, took him to a private one, where he was declared dead. The body has been sent for an autopsy. Based on the post-mortem report, we will lodge an FIR.”

Dheeraj is survived by his wife and two children. His father-in-law Suryaprakash Gaur said, “I suspect my son-in-law was murdered by the husband of the woman with whom Dheeraj was having an affair.”

Title: Suspects being stamped at Patna airport
Content: PATNA: Jayaprakash Narayan International (JPNI) Airport, Patna on Saturday started to ‘stamp’ coronavirus suspects, who are returning to city from abroad.Suspected passengers were marked with inedible ink on their hands after the screening and symptomatic heath check at the airport by the state health officials. The marked passengers are required to be home quarantined as a precaution to contain the potential spread of Covid-19.CISF officials at Patna airport said the coronavirus suspects are being stamped on their left hands with a home quarantined tag.Airport director Bhupesh C H Negi said all the passenger touch points, including chairs, railings, gate knobs, trolleys, washroom, counters and buses are being properly sanitized by the staffs. “We have also started thermal screening of departing passengers in security check area,” he added.

Title: PMCH, NMCH doctors on toes
Content: PATNA: At a time when all public places have been shut and most people are staying indoors, city doctors and paramedical staff are proving their mettle by handling suspected cases of Covid-19 in hospitals. They have even risked their lives as they are likely to contract the virus easily.Those, who are working in the Covid-19 isolation wards, claimed that they were discharging their duties diligently despite being worried about their own family members and friends.Nodal officer of the isolation ward at the Patna Medical College and Hospital PMCH ), Dr Purnanand Jha, told TOI, “I heard about a Lucknow-based doctor, who had tested positive for coronavirus after coming in contact with patients. We do not have any positive case in Bihar so far, but I take a lot of precautions. As soon as I reach home, I immediately take a shower and dump my clothes.”He also thanked his wife and family for standing by him “at a time when I need their support”.Abha Sharma, a nurse on duty in the PMCH, claimed that she was taking all necessary precautions while entering the isolation ward.The hospital’s superintendent, Dr Bimal Karak, said, “My family members are supporting me. They ask me whether I have eaten my food or not.”Associate professor of medicine at the Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH), Dr Ajay Kumar Sinha, hails from a family of doctors.“Although most members of my family are doctors, they are worried about each other. My children keep telling me to wear a mask and be cautious. I, therefore, take all necessary precautions,” said Dr Sinha Sharing an incident of the NMCH isolation ward, he said, “When two Covid-19 suspects were brought to the hospital, many patients ran away. My team of paramedics calmed them down and are working responsibly.”He urged people not to panic and understand that doctors were fulfilling their duties well.

Title: Bihar: Criminal receives gunshot injury in Bihiya encounter
Content:
Representative image

ARA: Notorious criminal Dani Yadav received bullet injury in his right thigh in an exchange of fire with the police near his house at Mahavir Sthan under Bihiya police station in Bhojpur district on Saturday morning. He was admitted to Ara Sadar hospital for treatment.

Bhojpur SP Sushil Kumar said Yadav had been released on bail around two months ago. Since then, the police had received several complaints against him for demanding extortion in Bihiya and the adjoining areas, he said.

The SP said more than a dozen cases were lodged against him in various police stations and Yadav was at present wanted in three recent cases of extortion, sexual harassment and loot of bikes, money and cellphones.

“The police had been conducting raids. On Saturday morning, we got an information about him. When the police surrounded his house, he tried to escape by opening fire. The police returned the fire in which he got injured. A country-made gun and some cartridges were recovered from his house,” Bhojpur SP said.

Meanwhile, police conducted a flag march at Bihiya to instill confidence among the people after the exchange of fire with Yadav.

In another incident, a 36-year-old primary schoolteacher, Abhishek Kumar from Khanani Kala village under Agiyaon Bazar police station in Bhojpur district, was shot at by two unidentified miscreants, when he was moving in the village on Saturday morning. The teacher got gunshot injury in his right hand and was rushed to Ara Sadar hospital.

Agiyaon Bazar police station SHO F Ahmad said prima facie an old dispute with some co-villagers seems to be the reason behind the attack on the teacher.

Title: Patna all for ‘Janta curfew’ to keep virus at bay
Content: PATNA: PM Narendra Modi’s call for a ‘janta curfew’ from 7am to 9pm on Sunday to encourage social distancing has found enthusiastic response from city residents.Several housing societies have issued instructions and requested residents not to go out, others have decided to lock the main gates till the ‘curfew’ ends late in the evening. All domestic help have been given the day off to take part in the social distancing exercise.“Social distancing is the only way to limit the spread of the virus in such a critical situation. Avoiding gatherings and staying at home is very important right now. We have asked all domestic help to take off and stay at home as part of the Janta Curfew,” Abhay Nandan, secretary of Pataliputra Vikas Manch, a residential society, said on Sunday.He added: “In addition to applauding health workers by clapping and ringing bells at 5pm, we have asked residents to unfurl our national flag from their balconies.”Paltliputra Cooperative Society secretary Rai Ajeet Prasad said that announcement has been made in the society for staying indoors during the ‘janta curfew’. “We have asked residents to purchase all necessary items beforehand in order to participate in the Janata curfew ,” he added.Residents of other areas in the city, too, vowed to take part in the initiative. “Roaming outside at this time is like putting everyone’s lives at risk, including my own. I appreciate and support the initiative for which I have decided to stay indoors on Sunday,” said Meenakshi Sinha, a resident of Boring Road.Kadamkuan resident Pritee Prasad said the ‘janta curfew’ is not just an activity but a way to encourage and appreciated doctors and health workers, who are risking their lives and working throughout the day. “My entire society has decided to stand in the balconies and clap hands and ring bells at the scheduled time of 5pm,” Pritee said.Transport services, including buses and auto-rickshaws, will remain affected. Bihar state auto-rickshaw drivers association’s general secretary Rajkumar, said all auto-rickshaw drivers will remain off-duty in order to curb gathering on the roads.Supermarkets and local wholesale shops will be closed. Raju Gupta, owner of a wholesale shop in Kadamkuan said, “There are around 10 grocery shops in this area and all of them will be closed on Sunday. We have informed our regular customers about it.”Petrol pumps, on the other hand, will remain open. Ajit Kumar, owner of Indian Oil petrol pump at Bailey Road said the pump will remain open on Sunday, but the staff will participate in the clapping activity. “In order to follow the ‘janta curfew’ fewer numbers of staff have been asked to be on duty on Sunday,” he said.

Title: Met predicts light rain in parts of Bihar on Sunday
Content:
Weathermen predicted showers along with thunderstorm at a few places in the state on Sunday

PATNA: Skies turned cloudy at Patna and many other parts of the state on Saturday and weathermen have predicted showers along with thunderstorm at a few places in the state on Sunday as well.

The daily weather bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre on Saturday evening stated that rainfall with thunderstorm would occur at one or two places in central and eastern parts of the state on Sunday. The weathermen attributed the showers to a trough line running from southeast Bihar to north-coastal Odisha.

Private weather agency Skymetweather reported that a cyclonic circulation was positioned over Vidarbha and a trough was formed from this system up to north interior Odisha. At the same time, an anti-cyclone had strengthened over north Bay of Bengal. Moisture from this system continued to grip eastern and adjoining central India.

“Due to the persistence of these systems, scattered rain occurred in south Odisha, isolated parts of Jharkhand and adjoining Bihar during the last 24 hours,” it said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: SGPGI, RML declare partial closure of OPDs from tomorrow
Content:
The decision was taken on the state government’s directives to avoid overcrowding and check spread of coronavi... Read More

LUCKNOW: Sanjay Gandhi Post-Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences ( SGPGIMS ) and Ram Manohar Lohia Institute of Medical Sciences (RMLIMS) have decided to suspend several OPD services from Monday till further orders.

Director, SGPGI, Dr RK Dhiman said the decision was taken on the state government’s directives to avoid overcrowding and check spread of coronavirus infection.

“Besides dialysis services, only neonatal and cancer OPDs will run. Stable patients are being discharged and only critical cases will be admitted,” he said.

Director, RMLIMS, Prof AK Tripathi said emergency services in antenatal, neonatal, cancer, cardiology, urology , neurology , gastro-surgery, nephrology, dialysis, urosurgery and cancer departments will operate round the clock.

General emergency will also run. Emergency helplines are 0522-6692000, 6692001 and 6692002. Daily, at least 1,000 patients visit general OPDs of RMLIMS and 6,000 at SGPGIMS. Many come from various parts of the state and are confused if theirs is an emergency case.

Title: As virus grips Italy, anxiety spreads among Malayalis too
Content: Kochi: With Covid-19 fast spreading to southern and central Italy from northern parts of the country, more Malayalis are likely to be affected. It is in central Italy, Rome and southern parts of the country that most of Keralites reside.Many who work part-time as cleaners, salesmen/saleswomen have lost their jobs and are unable to return to Kerala as international flights have been cancelled.Several students are remaining in rented houses after the shutdown of colleges. Many others who have gone as caretakers to help the elderly are also struggling to cope with anxiety as most of the dead so far belong to old age groups.“We can get out of our residences only for going to hospitals or supermarkets,” said Fr Jophy Thottankara, a Keralite priest at a church under Venice diocese.“Italy values individual freedom, and citizens may have some problems when the government restrict their freedoms. They have even roped in the army to control the youths who violate the lockdown,” Thottankara said. Thottankara, who had served as assistant vicar at a church at Thalayolaparmbu, where recently a holy mass was conducted violating the instructions given by the authorities, called upon believers to abide by the government’s instructions.“In Kerala, the health department and the government are doing an excellent service. We have to support them” Thottankara said.He said many of his parishioners, mostly elderly couple, are anxious. “Most of them are widows or widowers and they burst into tears once we start talking. Friends and family members of the dead are sad that they were not even able to see them for one last time,” Thottankara said.“Even the verandas of hospitals are full of patients. Most of the hospital staff, including Malayali nurses, are staying at hospitals,” said Fr Geo Tharakan, another priest who resides in Rome.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 30-year-old man, minor injured in celebratory firing in Budaun; 1 arrested
Content:
BAREILLY: A 30-year-old man and a 12-year-old girl sustained injuries during celebratory firing in Sohra village under Musajhag police station in Budaun district .

Police arrested accused Rajiv on Saturday and also recovered a country-made pistol from him.

The incident took place on Friday night at a wedding ceremony. They were admitted to a hospital on Friday and are undergoing treatment.

Police said during the ceremony, someone started firing and the bullet hit two persons—Jagdish (30) and Manju (12). After the duo was injured, the accused fled the spot.

Station house officer, Musajhag police station, Lalit Bhati, said, “An FIR has been registered against Rajiv under section 307 (attempt to murder) of the Indian Penal Code and under the Arms Act. We have started investigation.”

Title: BCA suspends Bedade for misbehaving with players
Content:
Atul Bedade

Vadodara: Former India player Atul Bedade, who is coach of Baroda senior women’s cricket team, was on Saturday suspended by Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) for allegedly misbehaving with women cricketers. The association said in its letter to Bedade that they had received complaints against him which amount to sexual harassment and public shaming.

Bedade will now face probe by an external inquiry committee that will be formed by BCA soon. “We had complaints against Bedade from some women cricketers. The association heard all the sides and decided to suspend him pending inquiry from an external committee,” said Ajit Lele, BCA secretary. The letter issued to Bedade stated that he passed personal comments on physical to personal issues like menstruation, that discourage the morale of team members. He has also been accused of angry outbursts unbecoming of a women’s team coach and using unparliamentary language that is not accepted of a person in-charge. Bedade has been accused of behaviour oblivious of gender sensitivity.

A BCA official said that 52-year-old Bedade has been accused of passing comments on menstruation for senior woman cricketer and demoralizing some players if they didn’t perform well. The inquiry committee that will probe charges against Bedade will include an external member from a women’s NGO to ensure fair investigation. Bedade wasn’t available for comments.

Sources said that Bedade wasn’t issued any formal showcause notice and suspended after being questioned on Friday.

Bedade was appointed as Baroda women’s cricket team coach last year. He was aiming to climb up the ladder and coach Indian women’s cricket team. Bedade, a level II coach, has also served as the Baroda Ranji team coach in the past. An explosive batsman during his cricketing days, Bedade has played 13 one-day internationals and 64 first-class matches for Baroda. He scored 3,136 runs in 64 first-class games including 10 centuries.

Title: Covid-19 threat: No pilgrim’s progress in Ayodhya on Ram Navami
