She delivered a baby on Saturday morning. The doctors claim that both the woman and her infant are fine but as a precautionary measure, the mother and the baby have been kept in special isolation ward for pregnant women created at the hospital.

Title: Niranjani Akhara closes temples in Haridwar, Rishikesh till March 31
Content:
In the wake of the spread of novel coronavirus, Panchayati Akhara Shree Niranjani has decided to close all its temples, including the famous Mansa Devi and Veer Bhadra temples in Haridwar and Rishikesh respectively, till March 31.

Meanwhile, priests across the state have asked devotees to offer prayers at home and not venture outside.

Mahant Narendra Giri, president of Akhil Bhartiya Akhara Parishad who also belongs to Niranjani Akhara, said, “We have closed all temples of Niranjani Akhara in Haridwar and Rishikesh till March 31 amid coronavirus threat. Further decision will be taken after assessing the situation. We request people to perform Puja at home.”

Earlier, the district administration of Haridwar had prohibited all religious events till March 31.

At present, seven suspected Covid-19 patients have been quarantined in Roorkee and Haridwar and their samples sent for testing. Haridwar CMO Dr Saroj Naithani said, “Five persons have been admitted to the Mela hospital isolation ward and two in Roorkee civil hospital isolation ward. Similarly, three persons, including two French citizens, who recently returned from abroad have been home quarantined at the BHEL guest house.”

Title: Kidnappers kill boy as father fails to pay Rs 8L ransom
Content:
Rampur: The body of a 10-year-old boy kidnapped for ransom in Sambhal was found in Piplee forest reserve area here on Saturday afternoon. The body was lying near the pond in the forest. One of the kidnappers led a Sambhal police team to the spot.

The victim, Yuvraj, was the son of the village development officer Surjeet Golay.

According to police, the boy was kidnapped on Thursday afternoon when he had gone out of his house to play with other children in Hallu Sarai area, Sambhal.

Speaking with TOI, Amit Kumar, SHO of Sambhal Sadar Police station, said, “Yuvraj was kidnapped for ransom allegedly by his neighbour, Rajeev, a historysheeter. He was helped by his sister, Dolly. They demanded Rs 8 lakh as ransom from the boy’s father.”

Amit Kumar said, “With the help of the surveillance team, police tracked Rajeev, a local gangster, his aide Neeraj from Chimaya Wala Tiraha locality and Dolly. During interrogation, they revealed that after kidnapping the boy, they took him to Bilaspur in Rampur. They called Golay and again demanded the ransom after he failed to deliver Rs 8 lakh. Therefore, they took the boy to the forest and strangled him and dumped his body there.”

Police said a local court had sentenced Rajeev to10 years of imprisonment for an attempt to murder and robbery in 2007.”

Title: Home delivery of food, hazard bags
Content:
Ahmedabad: In all till now some 1,159 foreign returned persons living within municipal limits have been screened by Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) for Covid-19 symptoms. Of these, 486 have shown no symptoms in the past 14 days while under home quarantine. At the moment, some 649 foreign-return individuals in the city are under home quarantine.

Senior AMC officials said that there are three patients in SVP Hospital and four at Asarwa civil who are awaiting final lab confirmation. “These people are doing well and are healthy and are under observation,” said the AMC official. The official said till now SVP Hospital in Paldi has attended to 29 Covid-suspected patients of which only two were positive cases. In Asarwa civil hospital 23 of the 29 cases attended to till now have turned negative.

Of the 650-odd foreign returned individuals who are home quarantined, some 449 have opted for food packs. “We are providing them seven days supply of 1 litre tetra pack milk, 1kg chana, family pack noodles, paper napkins, 7-day hazard bag for waste and 14-day dinner and lunch from leading restaurant chain and food delivery platform,” says the AMC official.

Title: Coronavirus: Community transmission stage not reached yet says Gujarat CM
Content: AHMEDABAD: Urging the public to be vigilant and take preventive steps, chief minister Vijay Rupani on Saturday assured that there was no need to panic as the Covid-19 virus spread is yet to reach community transmission stage in which the virus is transmitted rapidly.“We are between stage two and three and have not yet come to community transmission stage,” he said and appealed to citizen to adhere to preventive guidelines and go for social distancing.He added that the people who were tested positive for the virus mostly belong to Ahmedabad, Gandhinagar, Vadodara, Rajkot and Surat. Rupani claimed that he will personally monitor the situation in Ahmedabad-Gandhinagar, deputy chief minister and health minister Nitin Patel will oversee Vadodara region. Education minister Bhupendrasinh Chudasama will monitor the situation in Rajkot while Ganpat Vasava and Kishor Kanani will oversee administration’s Covid-19 preparedness in Surat.CM said that the state government is equipped to fight the virus epidemic. “Government is ready to face the worst situation. We have decided to create special isolation treatment facilities at hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients, one each in Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Rajkot and Surat,” Rupani said and added that the newly built 1,200-bed hospital complex at Ahmedabad Civil Hospital will be dedicated to treat Covid-19 patients.“Government has divided the state into four zones for fighting this epidemic and four senior IAS officers have been given responsibility to oversee preparedness in these zones. Four senior ministers will also oversee the preparedness,” Rupani said.He said that additional chief secretary(ACS) Pankaj Kumar has been given additional responsibility as the nodal officer for Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar, Surat director of municipalities M S Patel for Surat, education secretary Vinod Rao for Vadodara and industries commissioner Rahul Gupta has been given responsibility to monitor preparedness in Rajkot. “All four officers will continue their additional responsibility till further order,” Rupani said.

Title: JP Nadda welcomes Scindia’s 22 into BJP; Tomar is anchor
Content:
Govind Singh Rajput and Imarti Devi after arriving at Bhopal airport on Saturday.

BHOPAL: A day after Kamal Nath resigned as chief minister, the 22 Jyotiraditya Scindia loyalists whose rebellion toppled the Congress government followed their ‘Maharaj’ into BJP in New Delhi on Saturday.

They had sent their resignations on March 11, which was accepted by Speaker N P Prajapati late on Thursday night, ahead of Friday’s floor test. On Saturday, after landing in Delhi, all of them said they would again “go the people of their constituencies”, preparing for bypolls.

They were welcomed into BJP at he residence of BJP president J P Nadda in the presence of Scindia, Union ministers Narendra Singh Tomar and Dharmendra Pradhan, and party national general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya.

Wearing BJP scarves, the Scindia loyalists returned to Bhopal on Saturday night — 12 days after they left for Bengaluru. Pradhuman Singh Tomar said, “Maharaj showed his power and we scarified our posts for development.” They headed for former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan’s residence.

Like the central BJP leadership, state BJP also gave a red carpet welcome to Scindia’s 22. Chouhan said: “Twenty-two new members have joined the BJP family. I welcome them with open heart. They are now members of BJP. Our aim is to work for the development of state. We will work unitedly. People of MP celebrated Holi and Diwali together on Friday (the day Nath resigned as CM) and you all were the medium.”

BJP state president V D Sharma and other senior BJP leaders were present on the occasion.

Former Congress minister Govind Singh Rajput said: “We feel happy after joining BJP and we’ll try to fulfil all expectations. It was not easy to leave Congress, but we were not left with any option. The CM’s job is to link everyone, but despite being a cabinet minister, I hardly got chance talk to the CM (Nath) for 15 minutes on any issue.”

Earlier in the day, all 22 former MLAs were flown to New Delhi on Saturday, escorted by senior BJP leader Narottam Mishra and BJP MLA Arvind Bhadoria. They checked into a hotel where Scindia, Tomar, Pradhan and Vijayvargiya greeted them.

After meeting his loyalists, who toppled the Kamal Nath government, Scindia said they are his family, and he has “come to BJP with his family”. “It was not a fight to win or lose. It was fight of justice for the people of state and now our BJP government will do justice to the people of MP,” he said.

Scindia joined his loyalists on a bus ride to Nadda’s residence. Nadda came out on the lawn to greet them. Tomar — said to be in the running for CM — anchored the membership ceremony.

“It is a happy moment as the BJP family is getting new members. The ones present played an important role in what happened in MP in the past fortnight,” he said.

Former BJP state president Rakesh Singh, who was present at Nadda’s residence, said it is time for the Scindia loyalists to go back to their supporters and family members.

The 22 Scindia loyalists that joined BJP were Bisahulal Singh, Aindal Singh Kansana, Munnalal Goyal, Giriraj Dandotia , Suresh Dhakad, Raksha Sironia, Hardeep Singh Dang, Rajyawardhan Singh, Kamlesh Jatav, Raghuraj Kansana, Brijendra Yadav , Jajpal Singh , Jaswant Jatav, Manoj Choudhary and OPS Bhadauria. And the former ministers were Imarti Devi , Pradyumn Singh Tomar, Govind Singh Rajput, Prabhuram Choudhary, Mahendra Singh Sisodia and Tulsiram Silawat.

They all indicated they are preparing for bypoll. While in Bengaluru, they were in constant touch with Scindia and their family members, they said. Back in Bhopal, Scindia loyalist Prabhuram Choudhary said: “Kamal Nath ignored our leader, Jyotiraditya Scindia.

Title: 3 taxi drivers test negative for corona, hosps shut OPDs
Content:
Doctors, residents and policemen wear masks in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak in the city on Saturday

Prayagraj: The three taxi drivers who were admitted to TB Sapru (Beli) Hospital’s isolation ward on Friday, after they experienced symptoms similar to novel coronavirus (Covid-19), tested negative for the infection in Prayagraj on Saturday.

The three men were friends and worked as taxi drivers in Mumbai. The three were native to Prayagraj, Pratapgarh and Jaunpur and came to the city on Friday morning.

They were admitted to the isolation ward on Friday after they complained respiratory problems.

Beli Hospital’s chief medical superintendent Dr Sushma Srivastava said, “The three were aged between 35 and 42 years and tested negative for Covid-19 on Saturday. The three were discharged from the hospital on Saturday morning. Once they were discharged, the entire isolation ward was sanitised and closed for entry.”

The three were brought to the ward by a team of health department officials, after the latter came to know about their health condition.

Their swab samples were sent to Lucknow’s King George’s Medical University for testing.

The CMS also said that the emergency services are available round the clock at Beli Hospital, but the out-patient departments (OPD) would be closed till further notice.

A senior health official said that OPDs have also been suspended at primary and community health centres in the wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak. He said that emergency services would still be offered at all medical facilities in the city.

Health Officials said that samples of eight persons from the city have been sent to KGMU for testing till now and all of them have tested negative for novel coronavirus till now.

However, a strict watch is being maintained on people returning from aboard or other affected countries.

Meanwhile, city-based traders welcomed Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s announcement of ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday.

President of Allahabad Chemists and Druggists Association Anil Dubey said, “The Janata Curfew would be helpful in checking the spread of the deadly virus which has already claimed four lives and infected more than 200 people in the country.”

Title: Covid-19 affects popularity of Surti saris
Content: Surat: As the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) has taken the country in its grip, the popularity of Surat’s famed saris has faded with the textile traders in the country’s largest man-made fabric (MMF) wholesale market witnessing about 65% glut in the demand.Apart from the high-end designer saris costing over Rs 5,000, Surat is the biggest centre for low-cost saris targeting rural women. It is here in Surat that saris in the range of Rs 200 to Rs 300 are made. These saris have a huge market in the rural areas of several states, including Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, West Bengal, Chennai etc.Industry sources said that buyers from different parts of the country, mainly from Delhi and Mumbai have stopped coming to Surat due to the lockdown and fear of coronavirus spread. As the demand for saris has dipped across the country, the wholesalers in other markets have started cancelling their pre-booked sari orders.The low-cost sari business has been hit hard with the demand dipping by over 80% in the last few days. The buyers, mostly from Delhi, Uttar Pradesh and Bihar have cancelled the orders for cheap saris in the range of Rs 200 to Rs 300, which are sold in the rural areas.According to an estimate, Surat supplies about Rs 60 crore worth of saris per day to different parts of the country, which includes about Rs 20 crore worth of low-cost saris in the rural parts across the country. However, coronavirus outbreak has reduced the business to less than Rs 25 crore per day.There are about 170 textile markets housing more than 75,000 textile shops located at Ring Road and Salabatpura the centre of sari trade.President of Federation of Surat Textile Traders Association (FOSTTA), Manoj Agarwal said, “The coronavirus outbreak has broken the back of the sari traders in Surat. The overall sari trade has declined by almost 65% as the buyers have stopped placing orders fearing huge losses with the customers shying away from the retail stores”The sari traders in the city are also facing payment crisis with the buyers extending the deadlines due to the coronavirus outbreak. According to rough estimate, payments to the tune of over Rs 1,000 crore have been stuck due to the pandemic.Sardar Bitta Singh, a sari trader at JJ market told TOI, “Two days ago, some of our buyers from Delhi cancelled orders for Rs 5 lakh worth of designer and low-cost saris due to coronavirus outbreak. Many buyers are approaching us on phone to cancel their pre-booked orders. There is money crisis as buyers are not making payments on time”Echoing similar sentiments, Rajnish Lilah, a sari trader at Kuberji park textile market at Ring Road said, “Good business was anticipated for the upcoming Akha Trij, wedding season and the summer vacation. However, the coronavirus outbreak has cast a dark shadow on the sari business. We are facing cancellations of pre-booked orders of saris worth Rs 10 lakh in the last few days”

Title: OPDs at 2 premier government hospitals in Dehradun shut
Content:
A completely deserted OPD at Gandhi Shatabdi Eye Hospital

DEHRADUN: In the wake of the rising number of novel coronavirus cases, two major government hospitals in the city — Coronation and Gandhi Shatabdi — have shut their OPD services till further orders to prevent crowding. Officials said that only emergency cases will be handled at these hospitals.

Dr BC Ramola , chief medical superintendent (CMS) of Gandhi Shatabdi and Coronation hospitals, confirmed that no OPD service would be available at these hospitals where 16 suspected Covid-19 cases have been quarantined. He said, “We have a quarantine ward and the suspected cases are increasing now. As doctors come in contact with these persons, we don’t want them to venture out and meet general patients.” He added that emergency cases would be admitted as usual.

According to sources, Gandhi Shatabdi and Coronation hospitals witness a daily footfall of over 1000 patients. As their OPDs are shut, the authorities of the Government District Medical College (GDMC) have now displayed the contact numbers of all doctors on the notice board so that patients can consult them over phone.

GDMC principal Dr Ashutosh Sayana said, “We are treating Covid-19 cases at the hospital. However, shutting the OPD is not an option as people from various villages, who cannot afford treatment at private hospitals, reach our facility in large numbers. We have decided to display the doctors’ numbers to avoid crowding and enable consultation over phone.”

So far, the Uttarakhand health department has quarantined 1,324 patients, out of which 494 have already completed their 28-day observation period. The state has sent 139 samples for Covid-19 testing of which 107 are negative and three positive while the results of the rest are awaited. The government has also received 2195 calls on its state helpline 104 in the last 10 days.

Title: Police team bid to end Roshanbagh protest underway
Content:
Police at the anti-CAA protest in Roshanbagh on Saturday

Prayagraj: Tense moments prevailed at Mansoor Ali park of Roshanbagh locality of the city on Saturday as police and administration tried to end the Anti-CAA protest being held at the park for over two months in view of coronavirus spread and Sunday’s ‘Janata curfew’ called by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

SP (city) along with ADM (city) and other officials arrived at the park on Saturday evening along with a huge posse of police force. They met the protesters and appealed them to end the agitation. They also apprised them about the state government order restricting mass gathering.

“We appealed to the protesters to end their agitation in view of the treat by the virus and state government’s decision aimed at checking its spread,” said SP (city) Brijesh Srivastava.

Heavy police force was present at the park till filing of the report as the dharna was continuing.

Title: 13 hotels sealed for violating norms
Content:
Varanasi: At least 13 hotels on Mall Road were sealed and FIRs lodged for violating government guidelines on coronavirus threat.

Moreover, a megastore was sealed while FIRs were lodged against 36 shopowners on Friday night for violating the orders of district administration for closing all shops and commercial establishments by 8pm. One school was also sealed in Bridge Enclave area.

A team of officials led by additional city magistrate and circle officer checked the hotels on Mall Road and other areas of the city.

“When the hotels on Mall Road were checked, it was found that many had not ensured compliance of guidelines and some had also not completed the formalities of reporting the stay of foreigners to the foreigners’ record registration office of local intelligence unit,” said CO Cantt Mushtaq Ahmed.

Following this, seven hotels were sealed while FIRs were lodged against seven other hotels, he said.

Earlier, on Friday late evening a big band of officials along with heavy police moved in various localities to ensure compliance of the order of closing shops and commercial establishments by 8 pm. Most of the shops in markets were closed on time as per the order of district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma.

Title: NSI makes hand sanitiser,shows the way to sugar units
Content:
NSI director with sanitiser bottles

Kanpur: In wake of Covid-19 scare, National Sugar Institute ( NSI ) has shown a way to the sugar industry how it can address the shortage of hand sanitisers in the country.

National Sugar Institute, Kanpur has prepared alcohol-based sanitisers which are enriched with natural ingredients. The hand sanitisers have been prepared at the experimental sugar factory and alcohol unit situated on the institute's campus. Director, NSI, Narendra Mohan said that the sanitiser, besides containing 80% ethyl alcohol, contains hydrogen peroxide and glycerol as per guidelines of World Health Organization. However, it has been enriched by adding aloe-vera extract and rose water, he said. He further said that this hand sanitiser has been readied using alcohol produced from molasses at the experimental sugar factory on the campus.

"The sanitiser has been developed not for commercial purpose, but to inspire and provide technical know-how to the sugar industry as to how they can produce such good quality sanitisers in distilleries attached to their sugar factories. At this juncture, while this sanitizer will be of immense utility for people, in future the sugar industry may look into venturing into healthcare sector too enhancing their product range", Prof. Mohan explained.

He mentioned that many sugar factories and machinery manufacturers from India and Nepal are already in touch with the institute and such product from the sugar industry would be available in the market soon.

Title: Covid-19 Relief: NMC stops snapping water connections of defaulters
Content:
Municipal commissioner has issued directions not to disconnect water connections till Covid-19 is under contro... Read More

Nagpur: Water supply is crucial to prevent the spread of Covid-19 and hence, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has stopped disconnecting defaulters from Saturday.

The civic body has also stopped attaching properties of tax defaulters to avoid violation of section 144 of CrPC.

In the aftermath of Covid-19, the cash-strapped NMC’s recovery of property tax has dropped. Cases of sale deeds of plots and flats have also come down.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe told TOI that he issued directions on Friday not to disconnect water connections of defaulters till further orders.

Taking serious cognisance of huge arrears of water bills, the NMC has launched a drive to snap water connections of all defaulters. Nearly 1,640 connections were disconnected.

On Thursday and Friday, there was tension in Mankapur and Futala following disconnection of water connections. People requested the NMC team not to disconnect water supply till end of Covid-19.

On Friday, MLA Vikas Thakre rushed to Futala and stopped NMC’s disconnection drive. He lodged a complaint with CP Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay, stating that a team of 20, comprising 15 from NMC and 5 from the police department, started the drive despite enforcement of section 144.

“Already, people are tense due to Coronavirus. They need water to wash hands regularly and also keep their premises clean. Instead of focusing on wealthy defaulters, the NMC is harassing poor people, some of whom have received bills amounting to lakhs of rupees,” he said.

NMC standing committee chairman Vijay Zalke sent a letter to administration directing it to stop the drive. “Disconnection will resume only after the end of Covid-19. People will have to come out of their homes for water and so, the decision has been taken to defer the drive,” he said.

The NMC has also stopped attaching properties of tax defaulters from Saturday. The action requires a team of over 5 people so the civic body stopped it to avoid violation of section 144.

NMC’s property tax recovery has also been affected. Against the daily collection of Rs1.5 crore, the NMC’s revenue dropped to Rs92 lakh on Friday. Generally, towards March end, NMC’s revenue increases but recovery has been hit hard due to the lockdown. The NMC has kept its collection counters open at all the 10 zone offices and the head office as well.

NMC assistant commissioner Milind Meshram said people should pay tax by using NMC’s online system. “Only 15% of the taxpayers are using it. We have provided an online payment facility on NMC’s website. We have also launched a special app. No extra charges are levied if the HDFC payment gateway is used online,” he said.

The stamps and registration department said, “Each of the nine registry offices used to record 25-30 sale deeds daily. Now, the number has come down to 18-20 per day since the last three days. Online facility is available and should be used by all. Only 45% cases are coming through online,” the department said.

IN A NUTSHELL

* NMC stopped disconnection of water connections of defaulters considering that water is crucial to prevent spread of Covid-19

* NMC also stopped attachment of properties of tax defaulters to prevent violation of section 144

* NMC property tax recovery dropped from Rs1.5 crore to Rs92 lakh per day

* Sale deeds of plots and flats also reduced

* There is no impact on water bills recovery

Title: Markets closed, people stay indoors on janata curfew eve
Content:
People wear masks and display placards to garner support for janata curfew in Kanpur on Saturday

Kanpur: A day before ‘janata curfew’ to be held on Sunday, most of the markets in the city remained closed and people remained indoor in view of coronavirus threat.

Most of the shops in prominent markets were closed. Traders claimed they had decided to cooperate with the district administration and had informed they would close the markets on Saturday and Sunday.

However, wholesale grain and grocery market and utility shops were opened, but the customers were missing. Bullion market on Birhana Road, Nayaganj and Saraffa Bazaar was closed and owners assembled outside the shops.

Advocates abstained from judicial work and distributed masks among their colleagues. Office-bearers Kanpur Bar Association and The Lawyers Association said they had decided to avoid gathering of advocates and litigants inside courts.

Kapildeep sachan, general secretary of KBA, said high court had closed all district courts till March 28. Divisional commissioner Sudhir M Bobde said roles of district administration, police, health department and others had been fixed

Title: Showrooms to remain shut for 3 days
Content:
Vadodara: All prominent saree and dress showrooms in posh Alkapuri and other areas of the city will remain closed for the next three days.

Owners and representatives of nearly 70 such showrooms met on Saturday evening and decided to keep their showrooms closed not just on Sunday but till Wednesday.

“The Janta Curfew is on Sunday but to ensure that COVID-19 virus does not spread, we have collectively taken the decision of keeping the showrooms closed on Monday and Tuesday as well,” said Lalabhai Shah, owner of Gauri Sarees RMF, a showroom in Alkapuri area of the city.

“We are also appealing all our customers and traders operating in other sectors to support us in our decision,” he said. tnn

Title: Anti-CAA stir in Mewat put off till Mar 31
Content: GURUGRAM: Thousands of protesters at Mewat’s Badkali Chowk have temporarily called off their agitation till March 31 against the Citizenship (Am endment) Act and National Register of Citizens in view of the Covid-19 outbreak.The decision was taken after the central and the state government stepped up measures to counter the spread of the disease and Prime Minister Narendra Modi appealed to people to observe ‘Janata Curfew” on Sunday.The protesters and the local leaders, however, said that while priorities have dramatically changed in the current scenario, the agitation is not over.“We are just being responsible citizens right now. In such testing times, when the entire human race is under distress, we know that one has to rise above politics. Priorities have changed for the time being, but the motive hasn’t. The safety of all depends on the safety of one. And given the fact that there’s still no cure for the disease and our healthcare system is not robust enough to respond to massive community transmission, it’s wise to stay at home and avoid getting infected,” said Salamuddin, a lawyer and president of Mewat Vikas Sabha.The sit-in protest has been on since the past two months. While initially camps were organised and people screened for flu symptoms, the recent rise in the number of Covid-19 cases in NCR has caused some concern.“This protest was pro-people and meant to preserve the safety of one and all in this country. Now, when we are facing the wrath of the nature that we have been exploiting, it’s time to respond maturely to it. We are going to stay put at home and support the government and health workers in their efforts,” said 25-year-old Yusuf, a resident.A 65-year-old woman, also one of the protesters, said, “This doesn’t mean our fight is over. We’ll return soon.”

Title: NCR cancels 43 trains for ‘janata curfew’
Content:
Prayagraj: North Central Railways cancelled 43 trains during the ‘janata curfew’ slated for Sunday between 7 am and 9pm to check the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19).

The move comes after Indian Railways decided to suspend train operations from Saturday midnight to 10pm on Sunday.

“Earlier, we had cancelled 38 trains and reschedule five others, including the Prayagraj Express. However, later we cancelled the five trains as well,” said NCR general manager Rajiv Chaudhry.

Apart from these, two trains would be terminated midway, he added.

“During te ‘janata curfew’, there would be sudden fall in number of passengers. Hence, we have decided to cancel some trains to stop the infection from spreading. I, therefore, appeal to my fellow countrymen to stay at home and refrain from travelling if it is not essential,” he added.

Following the railways’ decision, all passenger trains originating between midnight and 10pm on March 22 will remain cancelled. Trains plying before 7am on Sunday will be allowed to go up to their respective destinations. However, the division concerned will keep a watch and will terminate trains which are empty.

In Prayagraj, Chauri-Chaura Express would operate from Rambagh while Prayagraj Express would leave at 10.30pm on Sunday. Likewise, Kanpur-Bhiwani Express would leave Kanpur at 10.30pm and Manikpur-Nizamuddin Express would leave from Khajuraho at 11pm. Gwalior-Ahmedabad would start its journey at 10.40pm.

Title: Covid-19 spread wreaks havoc on asset classes; investors tense
Content: Ahmedabad: When the world was already reeling from an economic slowdown, the fast spread of the Covid-19 pandemic, spike in cases and deaths – all with no known medicine or vaccination – is driving countries into lockdown mode, and wreaking havoc on global markets. Indian markets and investors too have not remained immune to this, irrespective of the asset classes they invested in. Several asset classes, be it stocks, mutual funds, crude, or currencies have yielded negative returns.Stock markets free fall erodes investors’ wealthInvestors’ wealth has been drastically eroded with equity markets falling 25% to 35% since February. All major indices like Sensex, Nifty, mid and small caps, bank index have suffered steep fall.“Such sharp decline reminded investors of times in 2008 when in similar fashion all asset classes fell sharply due to global financial crisis,” said Mumukshu Desai, director, Artham FinoMetry Pvt Ltd.“There is further room for correction and high volatility over the next three months. The risk of downside is more than the scope of upside. Investors should wait and watch till March 31. Whenever they start investing again, they should do it in a phased manner,” said Nilesh Kotak, a city-based stock analyst.Mutual Funds yield negative returns up to 33%Volatility of stock markets has impacted mutual funds across various categories, be it equity-based mutual funds or even hybrid ones. Several MFs have yielded negative returns ranging from 30-33% since February.According to financial analysts, the volatility of the equity markets over concerns of fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic on industry and economy has multiplied losses for a number of investors, particularly in the past two weeks.“Mutual funds erosion is directly linked to the share prices of stocks. However, the silver lining is that SIP has not reduced and has remained on the same line. Investors are in wait and watch mode; and thus, while there is no major withdrawal, there are no fresh investments either,” said Jayesh Vithalani, a city-based financial advisor.Gold turns volatileGold and silver prices have remained extremely volatile after the COVID-19 outbreak and spike in cases reported in India. After touching a peak of Rs 46,100 per 10 gram in the Ahmedabad market on March 7, gold price has declined by Rs 3,300 per 10 gram from its peak to close at Rs 42,800. Silver prices have come down from Rs 46,400 per 1 kg on February 1 to Rs 40,500 per kg on Friday.“Investors who lost hefty sums of money in the stock market crash heavily sold gold and silver from their portfolio to maintain liquidity, which led to a sharp fall in the gold and silver prices. However, despite the volatility, gold and silver prices are expected to go up, as globally investors will turn to these commodities as a safe-haven investment,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA)Bank deposit rates declineBank deposits rates have also shown a significant decline with the RBI policy review. Since February, the country’s largest lender SBI has twice cut fixed deposit rates across multiple tenors for general customers as well as senior citizens.“After the RBI reduced its lending rates, the bank’s costs have to be aligned and therefore, the deposit rates have been reduced,” said Vikramaditya Singh Khichi, convener, SLBC – Gujarat. Sources said that in the wake of the the Covid-19 pandemic, if the RBI may further reduce lending rates in the upcoming policy review on April 4, there is further likelihood of decline in deposit rates. “This may be done to infuse more liquidity in the market to help cope with demand slowdown in the country,” said a financial analyst.Real estate investments unaffectedEven as other asset classes have yielded steep negative returns, real estate has emerged as a safer investment option in such a turmoil. “Real estate is unaffected with prices remaining stable, while investment value in other asset classes has gone down,” said Balbirsingh Khalsa, branch director, Ahmedabad, Knight Frank India.“Real estate, however, becomes less liquid as compared to other asset classes in such tumultuous times,” he said.The coronavirus scare has resulted in low footfalls and has temporarily affected sales. Given the current scenario, sentiment will be subdued in the first quarter of the next fiscal.“Given the massive erosion and panic in stock markets, there is a possibility of investors staying away from market for some time.” Nilesh Kotak, a city-based stock analyst“Time and again we have seen that strong Indian fundamentals — demographic dividend, diversified and consumption-based economy-have always helped Indian economy and in turn Indian stock markets have given handsome returns once the crisis gets over.” Mumukshu Desai, director, Artham FinoMetry Pvt Ltd.“Real estate is unaffected with prices remaining stable, while investment value in other asset classes has gone down.” Balbirsingh Khalsa, branch director, Ahmedabad, Knight Frank India“Safe haven investments in gold are expected to continue over looming uncertainty in other asset classes. The prices may remain volatile, but investors internationally will move to gold and silver owing to the ease of liquidity.” Haresh Acharya, director, IBJA

Title: Dehradun: Police to help locals during Janata Curfew
Content:
DEHRADUN: In a noble move, the police officials have announced to extend help to locals during the “Janata Curfew” on Sunday. Senior police officials of the city have assured that they would ensure availability of necessary goods and ambulance services for Doonites on the day. Previously, the district officials had also announced that those who call for help during Janata Curfew will be attended to.

Notably, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call for Janata Curfew this Sunday had raised apprehensions among Doonites that they won’t be able to avail any essential service on the day. However, the assurance by local officials has brought relief for the city residents.

Colonel RP Singh, a resident of Defence Colony , told TOI, “The house owners in the colony are taking every possible measure to stay safe and have self-quarantined ourselves. The help offered by Doon Police is a very welcome step.”

Nalin Rastogi, a resident of Shipra Vihar, said, “The administration is doing the best it can to help us follow the Janata Curfew. We appreciate the assurance given by the officials that they will provide people with necessary commodities on Sunday. The move will greatly help senior citizens.”

Besides government departments, some social organisations have also offered to help the senior citizens during Janata Curfew on Sunday and have issued a helpline number for them. One such organisation Apna Asra Welfare Society has released helpline numbers for different localities — Race Course (9790446512), Premnagar (8630558639), Subhash Nagar (9639144882).

Title: Singer’s uncle, 34 others in isolation, area sanitised
Content:
Security personnel wearing protective masks on guard outside Kalpana Tower, which is under lockdown since sing... Read More

Kanpur: At least 35 people associated with Vipul Tandon, the maternal uncle of singer Kanika Kapoor who tested positive to coronavirus, have been quarantined after preliminary medical tests on Friday.

After returning from London, the singer had visited her uncle’s house in Kalpana Tower in Vishnupuri area of Kanpur on March 13 to attend ‘grah pravesh’ function.

District authorities have sanitised Kalpana Tower and adjacent areas in view of coronavirus threat.

Chief medical officer Dr Ashok Kumar Shukla said, “At least 35 samples, including that of Vipul Tandon, have been sent to Lucknow lab for further testing. We are waiting for the reports.”

District authorities have also directed the residents of Kalpana Tower and Sagar Villa apartments to stay indoors.

“Residents of these two apartments have been asked to stay in their homes. Police have also been deployed in the area. No one will be allowed to enter or exit without permission,” said Kanpur district magistrate Dr Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari.

Kanpur municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi said Tandon’s flat, besides Kalpana Tower building and Sagar Villa apartment in Tilak Nagar had been fully sanitised.

RK Gautam, an officer at Kanpur Municipal Corporation who is monitoring activities of occupants and visitors outside Kalpana Tower, said, “As a precautionary step, we have been deployed here to check that no one can enter or exit the building. A police team has been provided to assist us. All occupants of Kalpana Tower are cooperating with us.”

A resident of Kalpana Tower, who did not wish to be named, said: “We are taking to e-commerce sites for delivery of goods and grocery. We are following the instructions of government officials who are making announcements asking us to stay indoors.”

Title: DM clamps prohibitory orders, all hotels, restaurants to remain shut
Content:
Health officials distributing masks and hand sanitisers to people on Saturday

Kanpur: The district administration on Saturday ordered closure of all restaurants and hotels in the district till next order to counter the spread of coronavirus and make Sunday’s ‘janata curfew’ a success.

District magistrate Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari on Saturday also clamped Section 144 of CrPC in the city.

The DM said since closure of hotels, restaurants and edible item shops was essential to check assembly of people, they had been closed till next order. He also added that shops of raw edible and domestic goods situated inside malls and multiplexes would remain open for public, but not on March 22. Besides, all medical stores would also remain open on all days.

“The order has been enforced with immediate effect and any violation would attract action under Section 88 of the Indian Penal Code,” the DM added.

Meanwhile, Allahabad high court in an order closed all subordinate courts to High Court till March 28. The registrar general of High Hourt of Judicature at Allahabad, in his letter under top priority category, ordered all courts, subordinate to High Court at Allahabad, and all commercial courts, motor accident claim tribunals and land acquisition, rehabilitation and resettlement authorities across the state shall also remain closed till March 28.

However, as regards cases of utmost importance/urgency, the district judge shall decide as to whether urgency exists or not and to take action as per convenience. Remands and bails of the arrested persons shall be done as per holidays practice. In lieu of the closure, the courts during above mentioned period shall work in coming summer vacations accordingly.

In another development, the district administration also closed all revenue courts till April 2. Besides, all educational institutes, coaching institutions, cinema halls, malls, parks, clubs, swimming pools, gyms and multiplexes will also remain close till April 2.

The DM said all programmes which attract mass gathering such as religious, philosophical, social, cultural and sports functions would also be suspended till April 2. During this period, all recovery and auction proceedings would also remain suspended.

Title: No shortage of critical drugs, major pharma cos assure PM
Content:
Mumbai: Major pharma companies assured the Prime Minister on Saturday there would not be any shortage of critical medicines in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, ever after April, with supplies of certain raw materials having resumed from China. Significantly, the industry said there were enough stocks of hydroxychloroquine, a medicine used for rheumatoid arthritis and malaria, in the country, if there was need to use it as a potential treatment for Covid-19, sources told TOI. With a global race to develop effective treatments for the dreaded virus, hydroxychloroquine has emerged reportedly as one of the frontrunners globally.

PM Narendra Modi held a video conference with CEOs of top drug companies like Zydus Cadila, Dr Reddy’s, Sun Pharma and GSK, industry associations IPA, IDMA and OPPI, AiMed, bulk drug manufacturers’ and chemist associations including AIOCD, to assess supplies of key medicines and critical devices like ventilators in view of the rising number of Covid-19 cases. Earlier, the Union Cabinet approved a Rs 9,940 crore incentive package for bulk drugs and Rs 3,820 crore for medical devices.

The drug hydroxychloroquine has shot in limelight recently after US President Trump touted it as a potential treatment, while France has found early evidence that a combination of hydroxychloroquine and antibiotic azithromycin may be effective in treating Covid. Sources said Indian Council of Medical Research may include it in the treatment protocol of Covid-19 patients, but this could not be verified till time of going to press. “India has enough stocks of the drug, and if there is a need, we can also supply 25 lakh dosages in the country,” a company’s CEO who produces the drug, is understood to have conveyed in the meeting.

Main producers of hydroxychloroquine include Zydus, IPCA Laboratories and Cipla, while a majority of the drug is exported to US. Amidst the surge in demand, a shortage of the generic drug in US is being feared reportedly, according to American Society of Health-System Pharmacists. Regarding the stocks of medicines in India, earlier the industry had conveyed that it had an inventory for three to four months till March-April, after which it could face supply disruption. Shortages were feared mostly in key raw materials and APIs (active pharmaceutical ingredients) on which there is complete dependence on China including paracetamol, several antibiotics and vitamins, due to the lockdown in China’s Hubei’s province in the wake of Coronavirus outbreak. This had led to the government to impose export restrictions on 26-odd APIs earlier this month.

“Things are looking better with supplies of critical key raw materials and APIs having resumed. Some APIs have started from China. Also, we have asked the government to ensure a faster and priority clearance at ports, and to look at the option of air-lifting critical APIs, which may be required to ramp up production. We have stocks of three months,” a CEO with a Mumbai-based company said. Pharmaceuticals are fundamental to the healthcare security of the country, and our first priority is the domestic market. With an adequate stock of APIs, finished product formulations and channel availability, we can sustain the supply of medicines for the coming months. We are not aware of any medicines shortage to date,” Sudarshan Jain of Indian Pharmaceutical Alliance told TOI. Rajiv Nath, forum coordinator AiMed, said: “There is no crisis as far as ventilators are concerned as of now. We can ramp up production of critical devices if we get assistance in cargo-lifting of key components.”

Title: All essential civic services to remain unaffected today
Content: Gurgaon: All essential services like sanitation, water, sewerage and streetlights provided by MCG will remain unaffected even as the city is gearing up to observe Janata Curfew on Sunday.Moreover, the district administration on Saturday also clarified that though all private, corporate establishments and factories will be completely shut down, the companies and government agencies providing essential services will be allowed to operate.MCG, however, will suspend all routine work from Saturday till March 31 due to curbs imposed by the government. “We have been directed that the routine work will be carried out after March 31 and that in such a difficult situation, all basic municipal services like sanitation, water, sewage, streetlights will remain uninterrupted,” said a senior MCG official.The official also said the civic body is receiving several queries on its functioning during Janata Curfew. MCG commissioner Vinay Pratap Singh on Saturday directed the joint commissioners of all zones, medical officers and sanitation inspectors to ensure workers are reported for duty only wearing masks and gloves.“MCG staff have been provided protective gear so that they can roll out essential services without risking themselves. The corporation is communicating with residents through social media and the media,” Singh told TOI.The commissioner has also asked officials to be ready for the lockdown on Sunday and ensure that all precautions are taken by the civic body’s staff who are at work without any failure. Medical officer Ashish has been made the nodal officer for providing sanitisers, masks, gloves and other protective gear. The administration issued a new order on Saturday, asking establishments providing essential services like water, banking, telephone, internet, petrol, food to operate.

Title: Bengal’s Covid aid: Free ration for 7.85cr people
Content:
More on Covid-19

KOLKATA: Reaching out to people inconvenienced by the Covid-19 outbreak, the West Bengal government on Friday announced that people getting subsidised rice at Rs 2 a kg and wheat at Rs 3 a kg will now get them free (maximum of five kilos a month). The relief package will directly benefit about 7.85 crore people of the state.The state also mandated a partial work-from-home system for its employees.The two measures were part of a plan announced by chief minister Mamata Banerjee to tackle the spread of the novel coronavirus and mitigate the problems faced by a large section of people staring at a season of hardships because of reduced activity — economic and otherwise — induced by the outbreak of the disease. “The government will to give free rations to the poor till September,” Mamata said.The CM also asked government departments to introduce a duty roster that would enable 50% of their employees to work from home. The new roster will come into force from Monday and continue till March 31. “We have our e-offices ready. I would advise private employers, too, to take appropriate measures,” the CM said.“I am not asking for a complete shutdown. Shops and markets will remain open. Restaurants can operate but with precautions. I will appeal to all of you to avoid gatherings, which should be a strict no-no,” she added.Mamata said government hospitals had 800 beds ready and a new high-rise facility at Rajarhat could accommodate 8,000 people. “But we still we need more infrastructure. We have not got anything from the Centre till date. There is a dearth of testing kits and laboratories in the state. I told PM Narendra Modi about the problem during our video-conference,” she said.“I proposed setting up of at least seven more laboratories. I have also asked for ECMO machines used for clearing patients’ lungs and expensive research equipment needed for laboratories. The PM said these points had been noted,” she added.Mamata mentioned that het government has already set up a Rs-200 crore fund to fight the virus.

Title: Kanpur Bar Association polls on Apr 4
Content:
Kanpur: Kanpur Bar Association’s annual election is likely to be held on April 4, according to member of UP Bar council and observer for KBA election Madhu Sudan Tripathi.

Tripathi convened a meeting on Saturday with candidates and apprised them that election would be held on April 4. He added that the date could be extended if the district administration advised so. Voting will take place on the premises of Kanpur court and members will be allowed to cast their votes only after showing their identity card or certificate. The model code of conduct will be effective from March 23 and will continue till the election process concludes. Candidates may lodge complaints through Bar Council s local members Ankaj Mishra and Yogendra Swarup.

Title: Bhilwara remained isolated and deserted on 2nd day
Content: Ajmer: The second day of curfew in Bhilwara on Saturday went in tense and panic for hoarding eatables. Police found that people were not supporting the noble cause and therefore warning was issued to residents to cooperate with district administration and remain inside houses.The relief in curfew was given on Saturday morning till 11 before noon and there were long queues to purchase groceries, milk and eatables. Police had to forcefully sent back residents after the relief in curfew was over. SHO Kotwali Yashdeep Bhalla said that they have warned people to cooperate with police.There was alarm in the common public and they feared to send their children out of their houses. Pankaj Maheshwari said that the terror is that eatables, vegetables will not available to them and therefore they are storing. Mamta Gupta who came out to take milk said that they are under tension as there are some rumours on social media that Bhilwara will remain close for next 15 days. Ashok Sharma, of Balaji market said that some of the ATM went dry and therefore they are under stress that they cannot able to withdraw their money. Santosh Verma said that her mother is ill and therefore he has to go out to consult doctor and to purchase medicines.But literary low cooperation was seen by the residents of bhilwara with district administration to follow curfew as dozens of people this morning in Subash Nagar area went out for morning walk on roads and in public garden. Police forced them to go back to their houses. At about 11 in the morning, police forced people to obey the orders of curfew at Suchna Kendra market, Balaji market and subji mandi region. Additional SP Rajesh Meena said that there is no crisis of eatables and milk and district administration is helping that everyone will get to eat. Important is people should isolate themselves and not indulged in social gatherings.There was no roadways bus entered into Bhilwara and no passanger was allowed to step down without any reason. Similarly people coming from rural region were restricted to enter the city. The city limits were sealed and on one was allowed to enter inside.Roads were mostly deserted and there was police force everywhere and police personals were threatening as well as requesting people to go back to their houses. The control room was working 24 hours and reporting the situation of the city to high officials.The curfew was imposed in Bhilwara on Friday, 20 March when 6 positive cases of Coronavirus were detected in the city. Administration is trying to find the chain of other infected patients who met with these doctors and medical staff in a private hospital of Bhilwara.

Title: COVID-19: Three test positive in 24 hours, six others await reports
Content:
People wait outside the screening centre at the SSG Hospital on Saturday

Vadodara: The number of positive COVID-19 cases in Vadodara went up to three in just 24 hours by Saturday morning with the sample of one more patient testing positive of the deadly virus. Reports of six others are being awaited.

On Friday, an NRI businessman from Spain and a 62-year-old woman who had recently travelled to Sri Lanka had been confirmed to be infected with the virus, while on Saturday, a 52-year-old male who had co-travelled with the woman was also confirmed to be infected. Sources said that the duo were part of a group of couples from the city which had recently travelled to Sri Lanka.

Sources said that of the three positive patients, one had been kept on ventilator on Friday evening while two others are on oxygen.

The six others whose reports are awaited include a 22-year-old girl who had recently travelled to the United States. She was admitted in the isolation ward of state-run SSG Hospital on Saturday. Two others are relatives of patients who had travelled to Sri Lanka.

“We had screened 140 passengers, of whom 63 have cleared their observation period. Total 77 are still under observation. Reports of six suspect cases are being awaited,” said Dr Uday Tilawat, chief district health officer, Vadodara.

“One patient who was already admitted in our hospital has been shifted to the isolation ward because of new guidelines issued by the government that all those who have serious chest infections should also be screened for COVID-19,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.

This patient does not have any foreign travel history, nor has he travelled outside Vadodara in the recent past. “Reports of all these four patients are being awaited,” he said. By Saturday evening, the government hospital had screened 160 new individuals.

Gujarat’s deputy CM Nitin Patel had also visited the hospital to check its preparedness. Patel asked the authorities to cordon off the entire area surrounding the isolation ward.

Title: 31 patients isolated in Bhilwara hospital
Content: Ajmer: Thirty-one patients suspected to have covid-19 have been isolated in ICU ward of Mahatma Gandhi Hospital in Bhilwara . A person who came recently from Spain was found negative in test. Doctors on Saturday released him from hospital and directed him for 14-day self-quarantine at his residence.District collector Rajendra Bhatt took the meeting of officials and monitored the situation. There is a curfew in the city and police working hard to send people back to their homes. SP Harendra Kumar directed police to take strict action against those who are not obeying the orders.Director of medical and health department said samples of 14 suspects have been sent to Jaipur for test.A survey has been started in the city in which 5,580 people were screened on Saturday. There are five police stations in the jurisdiction of Bhilwara and district administration deputed area magistrate in every police station region.Medical and health department deputed 300 teams in the city who went to house from house. As there are about 80 thousand households in Bhilwara and these survey teams are asking about any patient of fever and cold. These teams specially asking about their recent visit to private hospital in Bhilwara during their survey as there were 3 doctors and 3 medical staff was found Coronavirus positive a day before on Friday.Similarly the nearby towns like Gangapur, Jahajpur, Mandal, Mandalgarh and others have started precaution. Gangapur town remained closed totally while there was spray in the Mandal and Jahajpur towns.

Title: Nagpur: CAMIT seeks government relaxation
Content:
NAGPUR: Chamber of Associations of Maharashtra Industry and Trade (CAMIT) has requested the central government to relax few things for medium and small enterprises following various types of restrictions amid Covid-19.

In a letter sent to finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, Dipen Agrawal, President CAMIT, said, “Trade and industry were already in distress due to the worldwide economic slowdown during the last two years. Now, the world is going to confront the economy collapse due to the Covid-19 pandemic. In these hard times, Indian business enterprises, particularly the Small and Medium Enterprises, will be hard hit in short to mid-term. Besides its worrying effects on human life, this pandemic has the capability to slow down the economy. The impact of the same is clearly visible in trade and business. India is among the 15 most affected economies by COVID-19. Demand of goods is vanishing day by day as the number of affected cases are increasing. The situation will worsen due to lockdowns announced to prevent India from entering stage 3 of pandemic.”

Agrawal added, “Government should consider six points. All EMIs, including those of term-loans, should be extended by 90 days without penal interest or late payment charges and the borrower should be saved from adverse rating by CIBIL. Banks and financial institutions should be directed not to take adverse action and relax the conditions related to maintenance of margin against working capital limits obtained to run businesses for at least 90 days. Payment of Letter of Credit (LC) should be extended by atleast 90 days without any penal interest against Letter of Assurance from beneficiaries to avoid any mischief and chaos so as to protect the interest of banks as well as business entity. All time bound commitments under Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) such as collections from foreign debtors, export commitments, payment to foreign creditors, etc. which fall due between March 15 to April 30 should be extended by 90 days from their due date. Payment of GST for the month of February to April should be extended by 90 days without any penal interest and GSTIN should allow submission of returns without insisting on payment of GST. All regulatory compliances under substantive laws such as Income Tax, GST, PF, ESIC, Registrar of Companies (ROC) etc. and filling of returns should be extended for 90 days without there being any late fee due, he said.

Title: Pune: Fuel pumps count 30 per cent dip in sales over a week
Content: PUNE: The fear over the spread of Covid-19, shut down of establishments like shopping malls, eateries, temples and the resulting decline in traffic on streets has caused over 30% drop in petrol and diesel sales in Pune recently, oil marketing companies and sources from the All India Petrol Dealers Association (AIPDA) told TOI.Meanwhile, the Petrol Dealers Association of Pune has asked fuel pumps in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad to make at least one fuelling unit at pumps operational after 4pm to fuel vehicles that transport essential goods. The appeal follows the association’s earlier decision on petrol pumps in Pune remaining operational from 8am to 4pm from March 21-31.Estimates provided by the association showed that petrol sales in Pune dropped from 30 lakh litres per day to 22-odd lakh litres per day over the last week, while diesel sales dropped to 48-odd lakh litres from the daily figure of 60-lakh litres.AIPDA spokesperson Ali Daruwalla stated that there has been over 30% drop in sales since the Covid-19 scare surfaced. “A lot of vehicles are not seen on the streets. We still see two-wheelers coming in to the pumps. There has also been a decrease in light commercial vehicles, like tempos, trucks, etc, coming into the petrol pumps. This seems to be a pan-India phenomena as it’s happening in cities like Bangalore, Chennai, Delhi too,” said Daruwalla.An oil marketing company official said, “From March 18-19, there was a 25-30% drop in fuel sales at city pumps. The oil companies had dispatched the same amount of petrol and diesel to pumps, but secondary sales have been low, which means sales have dropped at petrol pumps,” the official said.

Title: Lohegaon airport starts screening domestic flyers
Content:
PUNE: The Pune airport started screening domestic flyers with a history of foreign travel from Friday, a senior authority of the facility said.

A state health department official said, “We ask the flyers about their travel history in the last 28 days and on that basis we screen them. We are trusting the information they give us,” the official said, adding the travellers with history of travel abroad are asked which country they visited, following which they are screened.

Pune airport director Kuldeep Singh said the state health department had commissioned two teams to carry out the screenings at the facility.

He said on an average, one passenger takes between 10 and 15 seconds to get screened.

At present, there are 170 flight movements at the airport and 85 domestic flights arrive at the facility. “There has been a drop of around 20 to 25% passengers in most flights,” an airline official said.

The Pune airport recently stopped the two international flights at the facility to Dubai. Over 2,100 passengers coming on the two international flights to Pune were screened from March 5 to 19. Over 5,000 domestic flyers were screened at the airport from Friday.

“Earlier this week, I was on a flight from Goa to Pune and many seats were empty,” a Pune-based passenger said. Many on Twitter expressed concerns about the crowd at the airport’s terminal building. The airport stated on Twitter, “All airlines in Pune have normal operations. Some flights may be combined due to lesser passenger load. Passengers are requested to check flight status from the airline concerned.”

Title: Now, domestic passengers to be screened for Covid-19 too
Content:
Vaishali Nagar Market in Nagpur

Nagpur: After alarming rise in the number of coronavirus cases across India, the district administration has decided to tighten screening norms by now including even domestic passengers coming from cities like Mumbai, Pune and Chennai among others.

“So far, only those arriving from international flights were screened and moved to isolation centre at MLA hostel. Now, even those arriving from domestic flights would be screened as many of them arrive from abroad and then take domestic flights to the city. The virus is spreading from the passengers coming from other countries,” guardian minister Nitin Raut said.

He was speaking after a joint meeting convened by divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar and collector Ravindra Thakare, which was attended by public representatives, including MPs and MLAs, along with municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe and police commissioner Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay.

Later, while addressing the media, the minister talked about various measures taken by the district administration to contain the spread of the virus. “The citizens should understand that this is an unprecedented medical emergency and they should cooperate with the administration. We request all to close their establishments, else we would be forced to take strict action,” Raut, who was accompanied by animal husbandry minister Sunil Kedar, said.

Acknowledging that poor and daily wagers would be suffering the most in the lockdown, Raut said the state cabinet had discussed the issue and would come out with a solution to help them out after March 31. “We’ve directed the NMC to restore all water connections of citizens which were snapped for defaulting on bills. We’re also taking help of NGOs and public representatives to spread awareness about the disease. We’ve advised flat schemes and townships to screen the visitors and keep sanitizers at the gates.”

On the alleged leak of list of quarantined persons, Kumar said, “There was nothing secret in that list, which contained information of those who travelled abroad in this period and were advised home quarantine.”

Munde said that they found two suspects who weren’t cooperating and one of them was later forced to go into quarantine at MLA hostel. “The citizens should report presence of foreign nationals in their localities if found,” he said.

On screening at railway station, Raut said they had advised railway officials to monitor passengers and on Saturday, they detained a couple of them who were suspects. “Those coming from outside in their private vehicles had to give a certificate that they hadn’t travelled abroad in the last 14 days,” he added.

Title: Cases filed against 50 businesses
Content:
Pune: The city and rural police on Saturday filed cases against 50 establishments, mostly hotels, shops and private workplaces, for violating Pune district collector’s order banning assembly of five or more people at one place in view of the novel coronavirus scare.

The city police filed 38 cases, while the Pune rural police filed 12 cases. Additional commissioner of Pune police (crime) Ashok Morale said that fewer cases were registered on Saturday as compared to 120 cases on Friday. “Due to action in the last two days, eateries, hotels and other businesses remained shut on Saturday,” he said.

The Pune rural police registered 12 FIRs against hoteliers and shopowners for violating the order. The cases were registered at Baramati, Shirur, Junnar and Lonavala.

Title: Matri Sadan head continues hunger strike to save Ganga
Content:
DEHRADUN: Head of Matri Sadan Shivanand Saraswati, who is on a hunger strike since March 10 to save Ganga, refused to end his fast on Saturday, while lamenting that Sadhvi Padmavati, another seer of the ashram who is also on a fast to protect the river, was not getting any support from the residents of Haridwar.

“In Haridwar, everyone is earning money through Ganga, be it in the name of religion or tourism. Sadhvi Padmavati who is fighting to protect the river is not getting any support from residents of Haridwar. And now Ganga aarti and temples in the city have shut down. This is an indication from mother nature to stop exploitation of Ganga,” he told reporters.

To recall, Ganga aarti at Har-ki-Pauri and temples in the holy city have been closed to public in the wake of coronavirus threat.

Title: Pune: Rural cops check travellers on expressway, old highway
Content:
Screening: A team of doctors in the presence of a policeman check the occupants of a car at a toll plaza on Sa... Read More

PUNE: The Pune rural police have started checking travellers heading towards the city from Mumbai since the last two days in a bid to curb the spread of coronavirus. They have set up two ‘nakabandi points’ at Kusgaon toll plaza on old Pune-Mumbai highway and Urse toll plaza on Pune-Mumbai expressway.

A team, including doctors from the district administration, state revenue officials and police officers, checks vehicles at these locations 24X7.

“We collect information about each traveller. If s/he has arrived from a abroad, the doctors examine them. If someone is suffering from cold, cough, or fever, they will be shifted to a designated hospital where they will be treated or quarantined, as needed,” said Sandeep Patil, superintendent of police, Pune rural.

The district administration has made required manpower available from the revenue department while 17 policemen, including two officers, are present at each location. “We verified documents of over 3,000 commuters on Friday while on Saturday we checked about 2,000 travellers,” said inspector Suresh Nimbalkar of Wadgaon Maval police station.

“So far, we found only a couple, who returned from a tour to Singapore on Saturday morning. Our doctors checked them before allowing travel to their native place in Aurangabad. We have shared the couple’s information with the Aurangabad district authorities so that they can monitor their health status for the next fortnight,” added Nimbalkar.

Title: Fair price shops get grain stock for April, May
Content:
Pune: Minister for Food Civil Supplies and Consumer Protection Chhagan Bhujbal has assured that there is enough foodgrain stock for at least seven to eight months and beneficiaries of fair price shops can avail stock for two months without biometric identification in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

At the same time, Bhujbal warned against hoarding and threatened to invoke the Essential Commodities Act against persons involved in hoarding. If found guilty, the person will have to pay a fine and face imprisonment for up to seven years.

Officials of the state Food and Civil Supplies Department stated that an emergency meeting was held with large traders and sellers in the wholesale markets in Mumbai, Pune, Thane and Navi Mumbai and they were advised to check for black marketing and hoarding.

“We are prepared at all levels and we have already provided stocks in advance for April and May to fair price shops. In order to curb the spread of Covid-19, which could also infect beneficiaries of the public distribution system (PDS), we have directed shopkeepers to not carry out biometric verification,” said Bhujbal.

Meanwhile, officials have also been directed to search large godowns and ensure no hoarding was carried out in key cities across the state. Officials from the department said that they were closely monitoring all vehicles moving in and out of markets as part of preventive measures and the home department has been directed to take necessary action.

Senior department officials said advisories have been issued warning people against indulging in panic buying. “The PDS facility is being made available on e-POS equipment for the period of the shutdown. There is no need to rush to shops for now. We have stock to last for the next seven months,” said a government official.

Title: NDA cancels lectures till March 28
Content:
Pune: The National Defence Academy (NDA) on Saturday cancelled all the remaining lectures for its six courses till March 28 in view of the coronavirus outbreak in the city.

“We have taken this step as a precautionary measure. Further decisions would be taken after assessing the situation here,” a senior officer told TOI on Saturday.

“In view of the coronavirus pandemic, all group training activities have been reduced to a minimum and are being undertaken with due precaution. All avoidable exposure to the persons from outside have been completely curtailed. Cadets and staff are being monitored for Covid-19 symptoms at all times and in places,” a statement issued by the NDA on Saturday read.

Title: NMC begins to clear debris lying on roads
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has started lifting debris and construction material dumped on main and internal roads. The move is a result of the lockdown in the city to control Covid-19.

Due to the lockdown, many main and internal roads hardly have any traffic. A lot of debris and construction material was lying abandoned on roads. The NMC could not lift it due to traffic.

During one of his rounds, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe saw debris and constructions material lying on roads. Mundhe directed the NMC engineers to lift and dump it in low lying areas where rainwater has accumulated. Such places are ideal mosquito breeding grounds.

Accordingly, NMC superintending engineer Manoj Talewar directed the engineers of five of total ten zones—Laxminagar, Dharampeth, Hanuman Nagar, Dhantoli and Mangalwari zones to start the drive. The drive kicked-off on Monday.

Title: Nagpur police’s witty tweet spreads smiles, gives hope
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur police are ready to fight the coronavirus outbreak and stay with the people right till the battle is won. ‘Jab tak ye khel khatam nahi hota apun idharich hain’ (until the game ends, we’ll stay here), a witty post by Nagpur Police on its official Twitter handle is winning over the internet and also spreading smiles amid corona scare.

The outbreak, which has forced countless people to work from the confines of their homes, hasn’t prevented cops from turning up at their workplace. Making it evident, the police department on Friday posted a picture of uniform-clad officials wearing face masks along with a caption: Jab tak yeh khel khatam nahi hota, apun idharich hai #WorkingFromPoliceStation #NagpurPolice #AlwaysThere4U. The line has been taken from popular web series ‘Sacred Games’.

The image also has ‘sacred duty’ written over it. The tweet was posted on Nagpur police’s official social media accounts on Friday afternoon. Within a few hours it got close to 2,000 likes, 400 retweets on Twitter and 1,000 likes and 100 shares on Facebook. It is also being covered by various meme pages.

The tweet was created by 20-year-old Tahauddin, a law student. “While many have been asked to stay indoors, police are working on the field even in such difficult times. To highlight their dedication to their job, I created this tweet which will also bring smile on faces of people who are currently isolated at home,” said Tahauddin.

Tahauddin’s earlier tweet on Vikram Lander, which was also posted on official twitter handle of Nagpur police, too had garnered a lot of praise.

Title: Janta Curfew: Market Yard shut today, but Pune retailers have enough stock
Content:
People throng a supermarket to stock up on essentials ahead of Sunday

PUNE: Wholesalers and commission agents at the Gultekdi Market Yard have announced a-daylong closure on Sunday.

Retailers in the city, however, said they have enough stock of vegetables and fruits to meet the needs of local markets. “On Thursday, we recorded a significant supply of vegetables and fruits to traders in the Market Yard. The retailers had stocked up on the supplies considering the three-day shutdown. Local markets in the city are unlikely to face any shortage on Sunday,” Vilas Bhujbal, head of the association of commission agents at APMC, said.

The shutdown is a part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's appeal for a “Janata Curfew” on Sunday, where he asked people to remain indoors from 7am to 9pm.

Sunday will be the third consecutive day that the Market Yard will be shut. On Friday, traders had shut their businesses to enable the Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) to conduct a disinfection drive in the facility. The market remained shut on Saturday on account of the regular weekly holiday.

Manoj Kande, a vegetable retailer from Shivajinagar, said, “I am not sure if I will keep my shop open on Sunday, even though I have adequate stock.”

BJ Deshmukh, administrator at APMC Pune, said, “We had a meeting of the members of the traders’ body on Saturday. They were informed of the decision to keep the market closed on Sunday. We have all the machinery in place to assist the farmers for unloading the farm produce and assisting the local vendors in purchasing vegetables from the farmers. But, it is unlikely that the market would record any transactions on Sunday.”

Deshmukh said the farmers were likely to arrive to the market after 9pm on Sunday. “We are making arrangements to open the market from around 3am on Monday,” he added.

Title: FOLLOW THE LAW OR FACE POLICE ACTION
Content:
Nagpur: Even though the lockdown due to the coronavirus came into effect in city early on Saturday, citizens were openly defying the rules forcing municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe to issue a stern warning. After random visits to a few of the crowded areas like Sitabuldi and Badkas Square, the civic chief forced many establishments to close their shutters.

Till 9pm, the city police detained 908 persons who were found wandering on roads despite Section 144 being invoked which prevents the assembly of more than four persons. Around 148 cases were registered for various offenses like keeping their shops open, etc. Total 82 calls were received on police helpline till 4pm.

Admitting that the citizens and industrial units had flouted rules, guardian minister Nitin Raut said about 90% citizens followed the directives and stayed at home. “We will take action against industries for defying the orders,” he said after being told that some units in Butibori and Mihan were operating.

In Amravati, collector Shailesh Naval ordered all commercial establishments to close their shutters till March 25, while in Akola, collector Jitendra Papalkar called for a total lock down between March 22 and 24. In Chandrapur, 1,085 students and citizens, who returned from Pune, were stamped with indelible ink and were directed to undergo home quarantine.

On Friday, Mundhe invoked Section 10 of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, to clamp total lock down within city limits as per the instructions of the Maharashtra government, till March 31. He was followed by collector who imposed similar restrictions under Disaster Management Act, 2005, in entire Nagpur district that included industrial estates in Butibori, Hingna, Kalmeshwar and Mihan.

Earlier, chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had imposed a lockdown in Mumbai and Pune, which are witnessing a jump in the Covid-19 positive cases.

As per the restrictions, all the commercial establishments should have been shut except essential ones like medicine and groceries, and also all vehicular traffic, including the cab services of Ola and Uber would be suspended. However, when the civic chief visited Seminary Hills, Katol Road, Futala, Timki, and Mominpura, it was like any other day.

During his visit to Sitabuldi at 11am, Munde took action against a popular photo shop as it was operating and seized its standees kept on display. “Lockdown means people are supposed to strictly stay indoors, but they were seen venturing out. Even local markets in many areas were seen functioning. If citizens don’t adhere to the law, NMC and city police will be forced take stringent action,” he warned.

The west and central Nagpur areas wore a deserted look as major markets like Dharampeth and Khamla were closed, except medicine and vegetables shops, and people preferred to stay indoors. However, places like Old Bhandara Road and Itwari market were congested as usual. Prominent markets, like at Cotton Market, Kamal Chowk, Mahal, Sakkardara, Jaripatka and Gokulpeth, were mostly deserted with only vegetable and fruit vendors present. Grocery shops, including the ones selling milk, witnessed walk-in crowd for most part of the day.

The corporation operated 75 of its over 400 buses on prime routes like Dhantoli and Sitabuldi. “As the number of vehicles on city roads was significantly reduced, Nagpur traffic police turned many traffic signals at busy squares into blinkers," said deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Vikram Sali.

The NMC is using electric rickshaws, garbage collecting vehicles to create awareness staying indoors till March 31. “We’re also using the 52 public address systems installed at various busy intersections in the city,” said Munde.

In the morning, CP Upadhyay broadcast a message to his force to initiate strict action if anyone is found violating the lockdown orders. Later, the cops visited different areas and booked several shops and kiosk owners under Section 188 of IPC for keeping establishments open. They also used public address system fitted on vehicles to make announcements regarding the orders of lockdown and dispersed motley crowds at different places.

Public transports at Ganeshpeth inter-district bus stop and railway station premises were spotted but their numbers were restricted.
