Even the crowd of the outstation passengers at Ganeshpeth bus stop was much lesser. The railway station too, was wearing a deserted look in afternoon, as many trains were cancelled.

The civic officials and NMC’s nuisance detection squads also had to shut down some shrines at Itwari issuing warning to the trustees. NMC’s assistant municipal commissioners, deputy engineer and other senior officials from all 10 zones too were on their toes entire day to enforce the lockdown. At Variety Square, assistant commissioner Prakash Warade was seen intercepting private vehicles and appealing drivers not to venture out unless medical emergency. Assistant commissioner Vijay Humne too, was seen vacating a temple in Jagnath Budhwari in Central Nagpur.

Street side vendors and cart owners faced actions and were also rounded up at Bharatmata Chowk by Tehsil police after they were found present on the roads. Tehsil police also rounded around 35 persons and registered offence against two shop owners. Koradi police too had pulled up a pan kiosk for clandestinely operating the outlet and also rounded up another 45 for their reasonless presence at the public places.

Auto-rickshaws and e-rickshaws, despite less in numbers, were found plying on the road. The pre-paid autorickshaw services at railway station was found operating. Rickshaws were seen plying outside the Ganeshpeth and other bus stops.

Title: Efforts on to make janata curfew a hit
Content:
Nagpur: The district administration in leaving no stone unturned to make Sunday’s ‘janata curfew’ a grand success.

Even citizens are excited over Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call to observe it in the wake of the growing threat from coronavirus. Social media was abuzz with PM’s call with citizens exhorting each other to make it a success. The curfew would start from 7am and would end at 9pm.

Even public representatives cutting across party lines have lauded the PM’s initiative stating that it was launched with a view that people should maintain social distancing and prevent themselves from contracting the deadly disease that has so far claimed over 6,000 lives across the globe.

“The janta curfew is meant for adopting social policing by citizens. This is a deadly virus which could take form of an epidemic if proper care is not taken,” animal husbandry minister Sunil Kedar said.

Endorsing him, energy minister Nitin Raut said citizens cutting across party lines should follow the janta curfew. “It’s high time everyone strictly followed the administration’s orders by staying at home. This is not the time to think on party lines, but to come together and fight this menace,” he said.

Meanwhile, commissioner of police Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay has cancelled leave of all senior police personnel up to inspector level in the wake of the ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday where they would be deployed at various places to ensure that the public strictly follows the prohibitory orders.

Even transport services would be completely shut off to follow the PM’s call of Janta curfew, which many are terming as a ‘mock drill’ to face more such conditions in the future, in case the country faces an epidemic like in China, Italy, Iran and other European nations.

While MahaMetro won’t operate train services on Sunday, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) will keep its Aapli Buses off the roads.

Title: Digital platforms come in handy for students
Content: Puducherry: Digital platforms of the consortium for education communication (CEC) have come in handy for students of universities and colleges to keep abreast with academic commitments after institutions suspended classes until March 31 to prevent the incidence and spread of Covid-19 infection The students can access the content of 87 undergraduate courses on the consortium’s website. The consortium also offers 11 subject-based DTH channels on DD free dish, Dish TV and Reliance Jio mobile application. These channels offer live lectures in various higher education subjects, including humanities, science, management, professional courses, computer science and Indian and classical music. These channels are free to air and can also be accessed through local cable operators, said Radhika Khanna, Pondicherry University’s Educational multimedia research centre head (in-charge).The undergraduate and postgraduate massive open online courses (MOOCs) that have been archived can be accessed by learners even if they have not registered for the courses at http://ugcmoocs.inflibnet.ac.in/ugcmoocs/moocs_courses.php.The consortium offers more than 150 undergraduate and postgraduate MOOCs in the current semester.The students can also make use of CEC-UGC YouTube channel to access unlimited curriculum-based lectures that could help them keep pace with academics in the hour of distress. More details can be obtained from http://cec.nic.in/. TNN

Title: APMCs told to ensure supply of veggies, foodgrain
Content:
Pune: The state marketing commissioner has directed APMCs across Maharashtra to make arrangements for adequate sale of vegetables and foodgrains to ensure supply to local markets.

In a circular, the commissionerate has directed Agriculture Produce Market Committees (APMCs) to not halt the functioning of markets for cleaning activities. “The cleaning should be carried out at night or after daily transactions are completed without disrupting the unloading and sale of vegetables, fruits and foodgrains,” the circular stated.

The circular further stated that the purchase-sale and supply of essential commodities like wheat, jowar, rice, grains, vegetables including onion and potato should not be disrupted and that the farmers should be able sell without hurdles.

APMC traders in Pune had shut shop on Friday, demanding the sanitization of the wholesale market’s premises. The traders announced that they plan to continue with the closure every Wednesday till the end of March.

“In Pune, there are more than three sub-markets that hold daily unloading and sale of vegetables and fruits. All these sub-markets should also function without disruption,” an official said.

The government has already clarified that trade and supply of essential commodities will continue during the shutdown. “APMCs are the main source of essential commodities for the local retail markets. Non-functioning of these wholesale markets may lead to shortage of vegetables,” a senior official said.

Title: Daily wagers struggle to find regular work
Content:
People leave for their villages by the horde

Pune: Daily wager Siddappa Khude was unable to find work for five consecutive days this week despite knowing several odd jobs.

Khude claimed that he could do different types of works, including gardening, cleaning and carrying loads. He said he could also be a helper in plumbing jobs. Still, he has been jobless over the week because of the Covid-19 scare.

The job search forced Khude to spend two hours at the “mazoor adda” in Budhwar Peth every day. “I am a regular at the ‘mazoor adda’ and never faced such difficulties in finding some work in the recent past. The past two weeks have been very tough. The demand for workers has gone down because of the ongoing Covid-19 scare,” he lamented.

Like Khude, many daily wagers are finding work hard to come by. Nagesh Misal, another daily wager, said he was recently offered a painting job, but this week he was told to stop coming to work. “When I checked with the managers, they told me that they did not want too many people at the site,” Misal said.

Vikas Hole, a contractor who engages daily wagers, said the jobs were either cancelled, postponed or put on hold. “There is almost a total shutdown in the market. People have postponed their work to avoid social contact,” he said, adding that “mazoor addas” at other places like Warje and Hadapsar were also experiencing dearth of demand for workers.

Ramesh Kenjale, a contract worker, said, “We take up furniture and painting related work in the area. But for the past three days, the furniture and hardware shops are shut. We don’t know if we shall be able to find a new work after completing the ongoing job.”

Title: Pune: Volunteers sign up to help seniors, dependants access meals & medicines
Content: PUNE: Hundreds of citizens have joined hands to help senior citizens or anyone in need as the city remains on a near lockdown due to the coronavirus scare. From delivering essentials and medicines to providing food to those relying on messes, Punekars are doing their bit to ensure no one suffers from difficulties during the troubled times.City-based NGO Action for Pune Development (APD) has launched an initiative to provide all necessary help to senior citizens, especially those over 70 years old. “Whether they need groceries, other essentials or medicines, we will try to deliver them. Either senior citizens themselves or their acquaintance can connect with us and our volunteers will try to deliver the requested items. We have also provided masks and gloves to our volunteers for their safety. We have also requested people, who have extra essentials stored at home, to send us a list of such items so that we can easily obtain some things when required,” explained Aakash Shah from the NGO.Ninebee, a citizens group in the city, has already distributed over 1,000 packets, each consisting face masks, sanitizers and information leaflets. “We are now focusing on assisting people with other important needs including grocery, medicines and others. Many shops are on the verge of closure as most things are out of stock due to panic buying. We are trying to help with whatever we can,” explained Guneet Kaur from Ninebee.Many others are trying to help in their individual capacity as well. City-based youth Kiran Pawar has taken to social media to offer help to the elderly or differently-abled. Pawar said, “Elderly persons are at a greater risk of getting infected. Many senior citizens live alone, have restricted mobility and need care and support in this period. So, I decided to help out anyone in need.”Nearly 750 persons from the city also registered with the Annapurna Group to provide meals to those dependent on messes, tiffin services or restaurants for meals. Nandu Phadke, who started the initiative, said, “We started accepting registrations for people to provide food and those who needed meals. About 750 people registered with us and said that they would provide food either for one person or multiple persons. We had 400 people reach out to us for food. We even delivered food to about 75 persons on Saturday upon request,” Phadke explained.

Title: Pune: Call for phase-wise closure
Content:
PUNE: Divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar has called for a phase-wise closure of non-essential industries in the coming days in the wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak in the city.

Mhaisekar and Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram held a meeting with industrial bodies as well as the labour commissioner and issued instructions on classification of essential and non-essential units so that a staggered closure can be carried out.

"If the industries are not able to follow the instructions to work from home and reduce staff, we have to go as per classification and issue closure orders accordingly. We cannot issue a direct closure for all as it will impact the economy,'' he said. Ram said that instructions have been issued to establishments to work with 25 per cent staff and they should be adhered to.

“Pune is an IT hub and around 70% services across the country depend on these companies. We will give the companies time to reduce staff,'' he added.

Title: Eight more test positive for Covid-19 in state, total cases rise to 25
Content: Jaipur: Eight more people tested positive for Covid-19 in Rajasthan on Saturday. While Bhilwara registered five fresh cases, Jaipur, Pali and Pratapgarh recorded one case each.With this, the total number of people infected with the virus in the state touched 25, including the three who were cured in Jaipur. Of the two Italian tourists cured, one died of cardiac arrest on Friday.Bhilwara has become the epicentre of the pandemic in the state with 11 cases reported in the past two days. All of them are doctors and nursing staff members with no recent travel history. Since Friday evening, the entire city is under curfew.The fresh cases in Bhilwara were reported from the same private hospital where six people were diagnosed with the disease on Friday. The entire city is under lockdown as the district administration is not allowing any outward and inward movement of people.The administration has created a containment zone to screen people. As a precautionary step, the hospital has been sealed after disinfecting it. “All five new cases of Bhilwara are hospital staff,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.Since all the cases have been reported from a private hospital, the health department is taking it as a major challenge to contain the spread of the disease. A massive campaign has been launched in Bhilwara to check all patients who had undergone treatment at the private hospital.Since February, 658 people have undergone tests for the virus. Test reports of 42 samples are still awaited.Concerned over the increasing number of cases in the state, the health department has issued directions to all the district collectors to remain prepared to deal with the situation.

Title: SSC paper put off, fresh dates likely in April
Content:
Nagpur: The final SSC paper for geography scheduled for Monday has now been postponed with new dates to be announced in April. This was announced by school education minister Varsha Gaikwad on Saturday afternoon, barely 24 hours after declaring that the exams will be held as per schedule.

The administration, however, conducted the Saturday’s SSC paper successfully as per timetable albeit with extra precautions from both students and schools’ side.

Schools said the state education department has remained indecisive right from the time the crisis started. A principal, whose family also owns a school, said, “Maharashtra state board should have announced this much earlier. It has been two steps behind CBSE and ICSE. It has been slow to react to every development and seem to be perpetually confused on what is to be done next.”

Another principal said lack of clarity is a typical style of functioning by the state education department. “First, the department announced holidays for students, which was good but there was no clarity about teachers. When we petitioned, the minister did the department talk about work-from-home concept. On Friday, it said the SSC exams as per schedule, on Saturday it said it’s not,” said the principal.

A school trustee said that the government would have been better off going ahead with the Monday paper. “It has waited for so many days, despite other boards shutting schools and even government announcing a lockdown. There was just one paper remaining and board exam is a major logistical challenge for all those who are involved in it. So may be it could have completed the exam and got things over with,” he felt.

Another school trustee however said it would have been a mistake to continue with the examinations “The dangers of having 15 lakh-plus students come out, commute on streets, gather in clusters in small rooms is a potential risk when the country is facing an epidemic threat.

Adarsh Vidya Mandir principal Ashnarayan Tiwari said, “All SSC candidates were provided with hand sanitizers before they entered the examination centre on Saturday. Our teaching and non-teaching staff was wearing masks, with some also wearing gloves as required.”

Title: Cops to trace people with travel history
Content:
Vadodara: City police are tracking down all persons who have returned from abroad in March and are currently living in the city. Teams of crime branch and local police stations are preparing a list of such people and also of those with whom they came in contact with, so that they all can be advised to stay under self-quarantine.

Police officials said that this exercise is being done so that if anyone who has come in contact with a virus-affected person, the citizen does not spread the virus further.

“This is solely being done so that people remain in isolation. There are instances where people are hiding their travel history without realizing that they are not only harming themselves but also all those who are around them,” said deputy commissioner of police Jaydeepsinh Jadeja.

Police are in process of taking details of all such passengers from the Airports Authority of India.

Jadeja added that cops will go to every household once they have enough details and ensure that such people keep themselves in self-quarantine. “It is a tough task but we will try to ensure that we reach out to as many people as possible,” Jadeja said.

He added that their task will become easy if people will themselves come forward to declare that they have returned from a foreign country and get into self-quarantine.

Senior police officials also said that if anyone will hide any information or give false information about their travel history then a criminal offence will be registered against them.

Title: Pune: Covid-19 positive woman’s four kin home quarantined
Content: PUNE: Four family members of the 41-year-old woman, admitted at Bharati hospital and testing positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection, have been home quarantined and their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) to rule out the infection.“The woman's son, daughter, niece and mother have been home quarantined, and their swabs have been sent to the NIV for testing. They have flu like symptoms. Their reports are awaited,” said a health official of Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC).On Friday, the woman's throat swab sample sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) to rule out swine flu (H1N1), had turned out to be positive for Covid-19 and negative for H1N1.The woman, a resident of Sihagad Road, did not give any history of foreign travel or any known contact with foreign travellers or with a person found infected with the Covid-19 infection.The health authorities, however, dismissed it to be a classic case of community spread of the Covid-19 in India, underlining the likelihood that the woman might have come in contact with a person with recent history of international travel or any close contact of such travellers of which she might be ignorant.The woman attended a marriage in Vashi (Navi Mumbai) on March 3. She developed symptoms like sore throat and was unwell since March 8."Her symptoms initially started with sore throat and dry cough. She developed fever two days later, following which she visited local general practitioner, who gave symptomatic treatment. But her symptoms were not relieved with the medicationsHer fever and cough persisted, and she gradually developed shortness of breath," said Bharati hospital's infectious diseases expert Sujata Rege.On March 16 morning, the woman was admitted to a private hospital on Sihagad Road, where she was found to have pneumonia. In view of her worsening respiratory status, she was shifted to Bharati hospital around 11.45pm on March 16.

Title: Suspected patients test -ve for Covid-19: Jipmer
Content: Puducherry: Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research ( Jipmer ) has appealed to people to ignore fake messages being circulated on social media platforms that patients with Covid-19 infection have been admitted at the institute.Jipmer director Rakesh Aggarwal on Saturday clarified that the messages circulating on social media platforms on Covid-19 cases are ‘incorrect’. He said all the suspected patients tested by the institute till March 20 evening were found to be negative . He regretted that some of the messages on social media carried suspected patients’ names, their addresses and photographs.“Everyone is hereby reminded that privacy is a basic right of every individual. Even more importantly, patient confidentiality is an important principle in medical ethics and is considered as a sacrosanct right. The institute and its staff are committed to ensuring that the identity of the patients and their test results are not made available to anyone other than the treating medical team. Others are also requested to respect these principles,” he said.The institute has been equipped with necessary facilities and trained healthcare personnel as per the standards prescribed by the Union government to test for Covid-19 infection and extend treatment if the patients test positive. The institute has undertaken several measures and imposed restrictions to avoid overcrowding and spread of infection adhering to the Union government’s guidelines.Meanwhile, Puducherry restaurants’ association (PRA) has extended support to the ‘janata curfew’ called by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and has decided to close restaurants and eateries on March 22.“We take this opportunity to extend our sincere gratitude and heartfelt thanks to all doctors, nurses, healthcare workers and government authorities for their selfless service during these testing times,” said PRA president Abdul Subhan.Lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi, while outlining the importance of the ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday said the curfew will prevent transmission of the virus from human-to-human for 14 hours. The curfew will reduce the risk of people contracting virus in open public places and ensure the natural death of the virus.Moreover, the 14-hour curfew will help people familiarise themselves with self-isolation and prepare them to face hardships, if any, in the future. It will also make people pledge to follow safe, healthy and hygienic practices and adhere to instructions of authorities to prevent the incidence and spread of the Covid-19 infection.Above all, the curfew is to recognise and appreciate those who have been tirelessly working to combat the disease.

Title: Why we need to thank docs, health workers today
Content:
Nagpur: Apart from practising self isolation for 14 hours, the janata curfew on Sunday is also the best opportunity to thank doctors, nurses, paramedical staff, lab technicians and everyone from the city who are engaged in diagnosis and treatment of Covid-19.

The experiences shared by some young doctors working in isolation wards regarding crisis management will make us all realize why we need to thank them.

According to a resident doctor posted in the isolation ward at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), the treatment for Covid-19 includes continuous monitoring of vital health parameters of patients who are in isolation. “Only doctors can enter their rooms wearing all protective gears. We are only people to whom these patients can interact directly and share their feelings,” the resident said.

Isolation is challenging for anyone, but these doctors are trying to make it comfortable for the patients. Paramedical staff and sanitary workers in both GMCH and Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) are working with limited number of protective gears and ensuring that the entire ward is sanitized.

Lab technicians in IGGMCH are working 24X7 and conducting tests of as many samples as they can batch-wise every day. Many suspects visit these hospitals daily and counselling them is another challenge for doctors.

“I have seen suspects right from one year to 78 years of age. During the last 10 days, I have personally counselled IT professionals as well as a housemaid who don’t know English. It’s challenging, but fulfilling also,” said another doctor.

A junior doctor from IGGMCH, who was present when four suspected patients left the hospital without permission, said that she tried hard to stop them. “The suspects are already under pressure. They can’t believe they could be diagnosed with Covid-19. The entire team tried to stop the four suspects but we can’t force them beyond a certain level,” she said.

Still, doctors successfully convince most of the suspects to get tested and stay home quarantined. Many doctors are also following the quarantine practices voluntarily.

Residents living in hostels are staying in separate rooms. They also undergo regular check-ups. Till date, two of the doctors treating Covid-19 patients have developed symptoms. They have been tested negative. Many senior doctors are living in separate rooms at their own houses.

“I live in a separate room where any member of my family hardly drops in. After a hectic day in hospital, it’s difficult to stay lonely. But it’s important for their safety,” said a senior doctor.

Doctors have appealed citizens to stay at home during the curfew on Sunday. At GMCH, a team of doctors, led by GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra and superintendent Dr Avinash Gawande issued an emotional appeal that reads — ‘We stay here for you. Please stay home for us’.

A doctor from Nagpur Dr Yash Avinash Banait is posted at the Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport, Mumbai. He is heading a team of 30 other doctors who are working dedicatedly to screen all the incoming passengers.

THANK YOU, DOCTORS

Deans, superintendents, civil surgeon, DDHS are working 24X7

Many resident doctors are working in back-to-back long shifts

Both GMCs in city are managing in limited resources

Doctors managing the work despite shortage of masks, PPE suits

They are also treating all regular and emergency patients, conducting all surgeries

NMC doctors and paramedical staff are providing door-to-door assistance to all

Nurses, paramedical staff, sanitary workers risking their lives to keep wards sanitized

Title: Doc didn’t inform about Dubai visit, joins duty
Content:
Alwar: A doctor of a private hospital in Bhiwadi , who came back from Dubai on March 14, did not inform anyone about his travel and joined the hospital the very next day of arrival.

Dr Ravindra Singh, CHMO, Bhiwadi said, “After the administration got to know about the doctor of a private hospital who travelled with his family abroad and did not undergo the necessary screening after returning home, we immediately got him screened along with others who came in contact with his since his return. He along with others has been put under 14 days of home isolation.”

According to sources, the said doctor who runs his own private hospital went there on March 15 and took an inspection. During this time, he also dealt with patients but did not inform anyone that he had returned from abroad just a day before.

After the incident came to light, the authorities took immediate action and not only put the doctor under two weeks of home isolation but also closed down the hospital till further notice. Officials will also look at the reports of the patients that the doctor came in contact with during the week since he got back from Dubai.

“At present the hospital will remain closed as we cannot take the risk of exposing so many people to the chance of possible infection. The hospital will be closed till we know for certainty that there were no positive cases of COVID–19.We will take the call following that,” added the official.

Title: At home, a little more of good time together
Content:
PUNE: Schools and other establishments shut, several professionals working from home are using the shutdown as an opportunity to spend quality time with families.

From playing games to cooking together, this social distancing period has turned into a staycation at home for several families. Arunima Athalye, a home chef, says, “This phase has been a boon for us to connect as a family. We have been catching up on how much our son has grown and learnt. He is using this time at home to learn cooking skills. Once his father’s work from home hours are over, they play chess. We go for walks in the evening. This does feel like a home staycation.”

According to Aniruddha Patil, the founder of Pune Eat Outs, this period is a little more of everything that his family does normally. “There is a little more of eating and sleeping. Moreover, it is a little more of getting surprised with what a three-year-old knows. That little is almost 24 hours. So, the stay at home is pretty good. Now I know what animal offsprings are called, almost 30 of them. Also, it is surprising that there is no Netflix or phone use, at least not as much as normal days,” he quips.

City resident Purvi Dhanuka says, “The social distancing is taking us back to our roots and making children see fun in simple everyday activities, including helping at home, cooking and exercising.”

Entrepreneur Shamal Pitale says, “We have got a chance to spend time at home for ourselves, especially for our children, because of coronavirus. Schools, colleges, malls and almost everything are closed. We are spending quality time at home. I taught my child a few games I played when I was of her age. She likes drawing, so I taught her finger painting, spray painting and other forms of art. I have been cooking her favourite meals with her help. All in all, it’s a good time that we are enjoying.”

Working mother Gayatri Ganyarpwar Rudrakantwar says, “My husband and I are both working from home and we have divided time to play with our child in a way that it doesn’t affect work. In the first half of the day, my husband takes care of our son. After lunch, I take an hour off to play with him. From around 4pm to 6pm, he gets to watch little television. Then my husband takes a break for an hour and takes him out for a while. Then we all enjoy the rest of the day together.”

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: PCMC home quarantines eight doctors concealing travel history
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The civic body on Saturday home quarantined eight doctors, who returned from Uzbekistan but did not inform the authorities about their travel history.

Confirming the move, Pimpri Chinchwad municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar said, “We home quarantined the doctors soon after getting information about them.”

An official of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) said 40 doctors, including the eight residents of Pimpri Chinchwad, had gone to Tashkent in Uzbekistan for a conference. According to initial reports, these doctors did not inform the PCMC authorities about their travel history after returning to the city.

“The government as well as others have appealed to people returning from abroad to inform local authorities and undergo strict home quarantine to prevent the spread of Covid-19. People returning from abroad are screened at airports and information of those returning to our city is given to us,” said Hardikar.

On Friday, a home quarantined person and one of his family members were sent to the isolation ward in New Bhosari Hospital after the former was found going around in a car with his wife and father.

The civic body has made arrangements to start institutional quarantine at Balewadi, where it can accommodate 450 to 500 people coming from abroad. It also has created facilities to start a 100-bed isolation ward at Jijamata Hospital and a 30-bed isolation ward at an eye hospital in Pimpri.

A senior civic official said nobody tested positive for Covid-19 on Saturday. A total of 613 people has been home quarantined in the Pimpri Chinchwad limits.

Title: Maharashtra: Chhagan Bhujbal for ramping up production of sanitisers
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: State minister for food, civil supplies and consumer protection, Chhagan Bhujbal , has directed 500 manufacturing units in Nashik , Pune and Mumbai to increase production of sanitisers to address the shortage in the state.

“I have asked the sanitiser-producing units to ramp up production. These will be available in the market soon,” he told TOI.

In a notification issued on Thursday, the Union ministry of consumer affairs, food and public distribution asked all state governments to enhance production of sanitisers and ensure their availability to consumers.

Bhujbal said that the self-help groups have also been requested to increase the production of face masks as these would be required in the days to come. “While the local authorities have been directed to use funds and buy these locally and not wait for funds to arrive, we are making sure that there is no dearth of masks and sanitisers,” he said.

Title: No masks at hand, they slog at city’s construction sites
Content: GURUGRAM: In the wake of the coronavirus scare, the business and service class is either working from home or taking leaves and limiting their work-related activities. Getting the short end of the stick are the city’s daily wagers, construction workers and roadside vendors , for whom these options aren’t possible.The situation of construction workers, in particular, is precarious, as they are already exposed to excessive dust and conditions unfavourable to respiratory well-being.At many construction sites, scores of workers continue to work without masks and other safety measures advised by the health ministry and state government. While NHAI and GMDA claimed to have asked contractors to provide masks and sanitisers, the shoddy implementation of these advisories has stoked concerns.A visit to several such sites showed that only a few workers are wearing masks, while the majority of them have hardly any access to dispensable handwash or sanitisers. Covered in dust all day, many of them cough incessantly. But neither do they have the time to visit a government hospital and get tested, nor do they have access to any thermal screening camps, which labour unions feel should be provided by the administration.“A friend of mine told me that I should go to Civil Hospital and get tested. I’m taking tulsi and haldi (turmeric) daily for my cough and will think of seeing a doctor if time permits,” a worker said.NHAI claimed that all the contractors have been advised to strictly follow the advisory issued by the Union health ministry. “We have asked all contractors to ensure that masks and sanitisers are present at their sites. We also have onsite staffers who keep a close watch on the implementation of these guidelines,” a senior NHAI official said.The situation of daily wagers, roadside vendors, dealers at wholesale vegetable markets, and small-scale shopkeepers of local markets, isn’t any better. For them, choosing between their livelihoods and safety is a dilemma.A daily wager squatting at Labour Chowk near Sikanderpur metro station was visibly worried about the coming days. Like several others, he hasn’t gotten any work in the past two days, meaning no income at hand. The local grocery shop where he deposited money in advance for daily ration needs has been closed since Thursday.With all local markets and grocery shops either shutting down or limiting their operating hours, these workers are finding it hard to get daily essentials. They complained about their inability to stock food and medicine supplies for 2-3 weeks, unlike those in gated societies with stable sources of income. They ideally want to go home, but that will involve travelling in crowded trains or buses for many, which they want to avoid.The labour union feels that the response towards the pandemic has once again highlighted how the working class, especially those at the lower rungs, is easily left out from the policy vision.“Daily wagers are starving. They don’t have the income or the capacity to hoard essential items. Construction workers are working like slaves, with nobody even bothered about their safety. If anyone of them gets infected, it will affect the entire city. Ideally, the labour department should facilitate testing camps at all major work sites,” said Rohit Ruhella of Inquilabi Mazdoor Kendra, a workers’ union.“Like Kerala, the state government must utilise its labour welfare funds to provide all the daily essentials for these workers so that they can stay at home, quarantine themselves and not fret about sleeping with empty stomachs at night,” he added.Not surprisingly, the state’s labour ministry has no plans or answers to all these concerns. Asked if the labour department is doing anything for them or is planning to, a senior official said, “I don’t want to comment on anything at the moment.”

Title: Amid shortage, medical stores overcharge for masks, sanitizers
Content:
Nagpur: Medical shops in the city were found selling premium N95 and simple masks and sanitizers at 150% profit margins, making them quite expensive.

Authorities from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and legal metrology department could only check sanitizer pricing but couldn’t stop them from overcharging of masks in the absence of specific rules. Both the products have been in huge demand in the wake of Covid-19 scare. On Saturday, these were in severe shortage at most stores leading to others exploiting the situation.

A special squad comprising two inspectors each from metrology department and FDA set up by the district collector took mild action against four medical shops at Ramdaspeth and Sadar.

Metrology inspector Anil Nalawade said Sagar Medical and Jayant Medical at Janata Square have been issued show cause notice after they were found selling a 670ml sanitizer bottle for Rs670. “They were charging Rs250 above MRP as per the new central government guidelines. Whatever be the purchase date, the retailer can’t sell it for more than 50 paise per ml now,” he said.

In the same area, the squad later inspected Prince Medical was selling N95, which is prescribed mask for Covid-19 confirmed and suspect cases, at Rs250. “We couldn’t make a case as they were selling it as per MRP, though exorbitantantly, but it was booked for other lapses,” he said.

In Sadar, the squad inspected Cash Chemists where again it found that sanitizers and substandard N95 masks were sold at exorbitant rates. “Action for not mentioning the customer care number and e-mail id on the N95 product has been initiated. There are severe penalties for this. The central government’s notification doesn’t fix pricing for N95 mask,” Nalawade said.

FDA Nagpur drug inspector Neeraj Lohakare, who was accompanying the squad, said violations under Section 65 of the Drugs and Cosmetic Act were noticed. “But we can’t take or prevent overpricing as it doesn’t fall under our purview,” he said.

Nagpur FDA joint commissioner Prakash Shende said, “Mask is not covered under our department and we have no control on its sale. But due to Covid-19 spread due to which masks should be available, FDA had decided to make prescription must for N95. We can’t stop them from selling or seize the goods as people need them right now,” Shende said.

Shahid Sharif, executive member of Consumer Protection Council Nagpur at district collector office, accused the squad of not taking coronavirus outbreak seriously. “A crisis is facing humanity and here, the authorities are passing the buck in reining in the syndicate. The company shown on paper as manufacturer of masks by these shops doesn’t make it. Beside masks and sanitizer, there is a similar issue with gloves. When I informed Mr Shende, he refused to take any action,” said Sharif, who is also chairman of anti-adulteration and consumer society.

Title: Janta curfew: Milk booths, grocers may shut shop today in Mumbai
Content: MUMBAI: Localized shortage of essential items such as milk, bread, eggs and restaurant food marked the first day of the city’s Covid-19 lockdown. A complete closure is expected on Sunday due to the Prime Minister’s ‘Janata Curfew’ followed by a period of dormancy over the next few days until March 31.On Saturday, vegetable markets, grocers, chemists, petrol pumps and milk booths in Borivli, Mulund and Thane functioned normally. Yet, Mumbaikars were in stockpiling mode. Milk, bread and eggs ran out in parts of the city and Thane.Most milk booths are likely to be closed on Sunday despite being an essential service. Prakash Nayakal of the dealers’ association said, “Households have already made exigency purchases since they cannot head out after 7am on Sunday.”Tushar Jadhav of Navnath Dairy, Kurla, said there was no use opening shop for there will be no buyers on Sunday. BMC and police have asked milk dealers to close so as “not to attract crowds”.On Saturday, Kokilaben Ambani Hospital’s pharmacy in Andheri ran out of sanitizers and masks, but these were available at local chemists. Certain chemist shops may remain open on Sunday though most are shut. J S Shinde of the AIOCD (All India Organisation of Chemists and Druggists) said, “We are urging all emergency or 24/7 drugstores to remain functional so that people in each locality can at least avail of emergency medication. Anyway most will ply half day on Sunday or are closed.”Taxi and auto drivers sat idle for want of passengers on Saturday. Drivers of Ola and Uber chose to not log in, with one union sayjng they will stay away till March 31. BEST spokesperson Manoj Varade said buses ran to schedule and will do so Sunday.Greengrocers in Andheri, Goregaon, Malad, Borivli, Mulund and Thane had adequate supplies and yet footfalls were anaemic. Raja Patil, a vendor at the commonly crowded Khar Matket, said, “There are simply no buyers. Daily wagers have no money in hand. Sunday is a full shutdown. Police have asked us to close Monday too. Moreover, mathadi loaders of APMC have threatened to strike work that day, so it seems doubtful.” Prices rose marginally on Saturday.Restaurants chose to roll down shutters. Khalid Qureshi, a restaurateur from Mahim said, “People are avoiding outside food, particularly non-vegetarian items.”On Saturday, D’Mart Mulund reported long lines with a waiting time of up to 45 minutes. The store chain reportedly handed out tokens asking customers to come back later. Although exempt, several grocery shops, including Nature’s Basket, are likely to stay shut on Sunday.During Sunday’s curfew, petrol pumps will function with skeletal staff, said Ravi Shinde, head of the petrol dealers’ association.Both Western and Central railway will run 40% fewer services while Metro and Monorail will shut. A WR spokesman said, “Only 801 services will ply on the suburban section against 1,278 on regular days.” CR will run 1,100 services out of 1,425.Domestic help, drivers, attendants and garbage collectors across the city and Nalasopara will avoid work.Mutton supplies may trickle down as Deonar abattoir is under lockdown.Shops selling non-essentials in Palghar have been closed. The farther suburbs reported a drop in train passenger traffic on Saturday.

Title: No room for social distancing in Pune’s thickly-populated slums
Content:
The city has 426 slums with 1.40 lakh huts

PUNE: Kamlibai, who works as a maid and lives in a dense slum in Pashan, does not know what social distancing is.

“I live in a small room in Lamhan Tanda slum with four adults and two children. My next-door neighbours live just a few inches away,” she said.

“There are many people in my neighbourhood with fever and cough. Does that mean they have the disease?” she asked, fear writ large on her face.

For many of the city’s slum dwellers, who live cheek-by-jowl in small tenements with other family members, social distancing – the much bandied-about term in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak -- is a tough task.

“There are 426 slums in Pune city with 1.40 lakh hutments. Even if we consider that an average of 5 people live in each hut, it means there are about 7 lakh people who live in these slums alone and this is a conservative number as there can be more people living in each of these homes,” said Avinash Sakpal, deputy commissioner, slum eradication and rehabilitation.

A slum dweller in Mumbai recently tested positive for Covid 19. Though no such case has been reported from Pune yet, the authorities are worried.

Apart from the sheer number of people who live in proximity with each other, lack of personal toilets, narrow and dingy lanes and unclean surroundings pose a health risk to the slum dwellers.

Shahrukh Qureshi, a resident of Patil Estate slum in Shivajinagar, said, “Some PMC staff had come a few day ago and fumigated the entire area. But the condition of community toilets is deplorable as they are not cleaned regularly. As hundreds of people use the same toilet, better hygiene is a must here,” he said.

The problem is the same in Sanjay Gandhi Vasahat and Lamhan Tanda slums in Pashan. Overflowing garbage and stagnation of putrid water in dingy alleys are a common sight in these areas.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, deputy commissioner, PMC, said, “We are taking care of the cleanliness in slum areas. The ward offices are fumigating them. Waste pickers have also been asked to clean the slums regularly. We will provide soaps in community toilets and ask the staff to clean them regularly.”

Title: Auto drivers ferry labourers to MP after lockdown in city
Content:
Nagpur: Even as most auto drivers in the city are worried about incurring losses due to the lockdown, Asad (name changed) is going the extra mile to double his daily income. On Saturday, he was among the few autorickshaw drivers who earned a Rs3600 through a 130km single trip to Seoni in neighbouring Madhya Pradesh which has sealed its border for public and private buses from Maharashtra due to coronavirus outbreak.

Even Chhattisgarh has closed its border for public and private buses from Maharashtra, creating problems for labourers who come from these states to find work in Nagpur. Some of the auto drivers who were stationed near Madhya Pradesh Parivahan Bus Stand saw an opportunity in this.

Some of the auto drivers at the stand told TOI that since morning five-six auto drivers have boarded passengers, mostly labourers who want to go to their hometowns in Seoni and Chhindwara following the lockdown.

“We are charging Rs600 per person for a trip to Seoni and Chhindwara. In a single trip, we take around six persons. There are no passengers during the return trip,” an auto driver said.

A one-way trip to Seoni or Chhindwara by bus costs around Rs200 to Rs250. But now passengers have no option but to agree with the fare charged by the auto drivers.

According to deputy RTO Atul Adey, auto drivers are not allowed to leave the district limit. “If any autorickshaw is found overloaded and out of the district limits, action will be taken. The transport commissioner has also issued an order prohibiting shared auto rickshaws from plying due to coronavirus outbreak,” he said.

Title: Homoeo docs offer fake med for Covid-19, flee
Content:
Salem: Two homoeopathy doctors are likely to face legal action for misleading the public stating that that have preventive medicine for Covid-19. The two had deployed a staff member at Uzhavar Shandy in Hasthampatty area on Saturday morning to lure the public. However, when TOI tried to talk to him, he fled.

The pamphlet had contact details of doctors - Dr P Elango and Dr E Indrakumar - who were practicing homoeopathy at a clinic on Gandhi road. TOI alerted deputy director of health services Dr J Nirmalson, who tried to reach the two on their mobile phones. “No one picked up the calls. They managed to escape and the clinic was found closed when our team went there,” the officer said.

He has lodged a complaint with the Hasthampatty police, seeking action against the errant homoeopathic consultants for trying to cheat people. TOI also couldn’t reach the doctors and their mobile phones were switched off since 11am on Saturday.

Title: Home quarantine list that went viral upsets many
Content:
A citizen distributes masks among personnel deployed to enforce the lockdown in the city on Saturday

Nagpur: On Friday, a list with names of quarantined people in Nagpur went viral on social media leading to debates in various groups about the utility of such information being made public. Later, the authorities clarified that the list had been put up on their portal with a view of seeking community’s help to keep tabs on those who are under home quarantine.

Though there were talks about registering an offence against those forwarding it on social media, no official action had been taken till the time of going to press. There were almost 400 names there with some of them being prominent citizens of the city, or their immediate family members .

A senior doctor couple, whose name figured in the list, felt that this amounted to breach of privacy. “I appreciate the intention of the authorities and they are doing a fantastic job, but the list should not have been made public. It caused a lot of embarrassment to our family. Many friends and families started calling up and it took some time to take control of the situation,” said the doctor.

Later in some groups, message from family members of a person named in the list started circulating. The message expressed thanks “for the concern shown” and assured that the person is not simply in home quarantine and not a patient.

In another WhatsApp group, friend of one such person named in the list said that it was very upsetting for the family. Speaking to TOI, he said “The person is my classmate and he is being contacted on phone and WhatsApp by well wishers. In our school group, thankfully nobody is discussing it, though they do the same in private chat. But I feel this invades their privacy and people will stay away from them.”

The list also included directors of Centre Point group of schools, Arun and Aruna Upadhyaya, who insisted that TOI mention their names in the article. “We had returned from London as based on travel history, we were advised home quarantine. I am actually happy that the list was made public because this leads to an automatic social distancing with friends and family,” said Upadhyaya.

“This way, people know that they should not come to meet us for a few days more. And authorities have been fantastic with one Dr Khan from NMC calling me everyday to check on health status and even cops coming to inquire regularly. So, I feel that authorities are doing the best to make home quarantine work and the list going public has not upset us at all,” Upadhyaya added.

There was commotion at a nationalized bank’s branch on Saturday morning after a staffer claimed that a customer had breached home quarantine guidelines. The rest of the customers panicked and the branch was soon evacuated.

The man claimed that it was his uncle who had been put in home quarantine, and he was merely depositing a cheque on his behalf. Police said that they were investigating the statements of the person.

Title: Congress MLAs want Kamal Nath to lead them into bypoll battle
Content:
On Friday, when Congress MLAs had met the outgoing CM following his resignation, Nath asked them not to be ups... Read More

BHOPAL: A day after Kamal Nath resigned as chief minister, Congress workers put up a ‘we will be back’ banner outside the state party HQ, even as party MLAs demanded Nath be made leader of opposition and lead the fight against BJP .

“After the bypolls, we will be ready to serve Madhya Pradesh again,” said the poster, put up by PCC spokesman Sharyar Khan and state party vice-president Nagendra Tripathi .

On Friday, when Congress MLAs had met the outgoing CM following his resignation, Nath asked them not to be upset and assured that the government will be back after the bypolls.

Twenty-four assembly seats will go for by-election within six months — including the 22 Scindia loyalists who resigned and the two seats vacated after the death of Congress MLA from Jaura, Banwarilal Sharma, and BJP MLA from Agar Manohar Untwal.

The Congress poster thanked people of Madhya Pradesh and quoted the CM’s Friday tweet, “The hopes and trust of Madhya Pradesh have been defeated. The greedy and the enticer have won.” The billboard claims more than 400 promises have been fulfilled in 15 months of the Kamal Nath government, and says: “In the bypolls, people will teach a lesson to the Vibhishan who went against the feelings and wishes of the people of Madhya Pradesh and sold people’s mandate to BJP.” The poster ends with the slogan, ‘ Jai Jai Kamal Nath ’.

State Congress leaders believe the bypolls will be contested on the issue of development work undertaken by the Nath government during its short tenure, and schemes like Indira Griha Jyoti Yojana of subsidized electricity bills and farm loan waiver will give Congress the edge — and the seats needed to return to power.

P C Sharma, who was minister for law in the Nath government, told reporters, “Congress had secured maximum number of seats in the 2018 assembly elections. The bypolls will now prove who is in majority and expose those who secured power through horse-trading.” He called the breakaway Congress MLAs the “greedy persons group.”

Party MLAs have demanded that Nath be made leader of opposition and retain his position as state party president, Sharma said, adding: “The legislative party wants to fight BJP under Kamal Nath’s leadership.”

On Friday night, the state Congress tweeted, Preserve this tweet. On August 15, 2020, Kamal Nath will hoist the flag as chief minister of Madhya Pradesh and take salute of the parade. This is a very short interval.”

Title: Newly-weds commit suicide in Bharatpur
Content:
Jaipur: A couple who got married less than a month ago committed suicide in Bharatpur ’s Deeg police station area.

The duo had married on February 28 and the family claimed that they were not facing any marital issues. The bodies were found by the family on Saturday morning and cops did not find any suicide note.

The deceased were Upendra Kumar and his wife Jyoti Devi. The couple was in their 20s and the incident is of Khera Brahman village.

“When the couple did not come out of their room on Saturday morning, the family members went to check on them. When the door was not opened despite repeated knocking, they tried to see through the window and saw the two bodies hanging from the ceiling,” said an official of Deeg police station.

According to the family members, the duo had no marital issue and were happy in their marriage. Police have also not found any possible reason behind the suicide and the official added, “At present, we do not know the possible reason that the couple decided to end their own life. The family is also unable to give us much details and claim that there was no reason which would make the duo kill themselves together. On Friday night, the family claimed that the two deceased had gone to their room without any outward incident and the other members had no reason to think that the newly-weds were thinking along these lines.”

Cops will also check the phone call details of both the victims to find any possible leads. The bodies were handed over to the family after the post-mortem on Saturday as mystery continued to shroud the double suicide

Title: Shops down shutters ahead of curfew
Content:
Vijayawada/Tirupati: Large crowds gathered at rythu bazaars and vegetable markets in the city on Saturday as buyers lined up for essential commodities ahead of the janata curfew on Sunday.

Rythu bazaars were crowded from the early hours of Saturday morning even as officials made arrangements to bring in supplies from nearby farms. “As markets are likely to close on Sunday, we have witnessed huge crowds today. We have kept maximum efforts to maintain stocks. The market will reopen on Monday as per the instructions of the government,” said Chandra Mohan, estate officer at Swaraj Maidan rythu bazaar.

Supplies at some rythu bazaars ran out by 3 pm and officials procured stocks from neighbouring markets.

Vijaya, Sangam Dairy and other cooperative dairies put in place arrangements for uninterrupted supply of milk and other dairy products. In some places, agricultural marketing authorities made public announcements urging against panic buying as rumours were floated over the scarcity of vegetables and other essential commodities.

Motorists queued up at filling stations throughout the day after petrol bunk owners announced that they would remain closed on Sunday.

All private hospitals in the city have decided to admit only emergency cases till March 31.

Meanwhile, the state government has announced that bus services will remain suspended on Sunday. Shops and other commercial establishments in the city have supported the Prime Minister’s call for a janata curfew and will remain closed. Some emergency services, however, will remain operational.

In Tirumala, shops and other business establishments closed ahead of the janata curfew. All temples in Tirupati have already been closed to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

At supermarkets, rythu bazaars and vegetable markets in Tirupati and across the Rayalaseema districts of Chittoor, Kadapa, Kurnool and Anantapur, however, people queued up to purchase essential goods. Panic buyig was also reported from some parts of Tirupati and Kadapa and Anantapur districts.

Several flights to the temple city will remain suspended on Sunday in view of the janata curfew and the TTD’s decision to suspend pilgrim worship at the Tirumala temple.

Director general of police (DGP) D Gautam Sawang called for people’s participation in the janata curfew and said police will be on duty to ensure the safety of people. ‘Dial-100’ services will be available round-the-clock and police will be monitoring the situation from control rooms, he said.

Title: NGT serves notice in Bhendi Bazaar redevelopment project
Content:
NGT directed the applicant to furnish requisites in a week

MUMBAI: The National Green Tribunal ( NGT ), Pune, on Friday issued a notice in Saifee Burhani Upliftment Trust (SBUT)’s Bhendi Bazaar redevelopment project and directed that a committee be set up to inspect and verify factual aspects of a complaint of alleged infringement of environmental clearance.

The committee is to comprise State Level Environment Impact Assessment Authority (SEIAA), Maharashtra, State Pollution Control Board, Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai and Mumbai suburban collector. They will nspect and verify the project and submit a report via email to NGT before the next hearing on April 30. The order, passed ex-parte, was on a complaint filed by one Sayyed Usman that 25% recreation ground spaces have not been provided on “virgin land” and have been provided on a podium with “no scientific disposal of construction waste”. NGT directed the applicant to furnish requisites in a week.

“These are baseless allegations. We are glad the court has asked the petitioner to submit facts,” said an SBUT spokesperson, adding the project complies with Development Control Regulations. NGT panel of Justices S P Wangdi, S K Singh and expert members Dr S S Garbyal and Siddhanta Das in the order said, “In the event allegations are found to be correct, appropriate action in accordance with law will be taken against the project for mitigation, which may include rectification of infractions as well as assessment and payment compensation for damage.”

Title: Janta curfew: No public transport today, essential services to run
Content:
Balcony ovation

NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: Life is set to come to a standstill, for all practical purposes, as residents and administrations gear up to respond to Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call for a ‘ janata curfew ’ from 7am to 9pm on Sunday.In Noida, all public transport, including metro and bus services, will remain suspended. The Aqua Line will not run from 10am to 4pm on Monday either and frequency of trains will be reduced to 20 minutes from 6am to 8am.All public and private companies, offices, factories and industrial units will remain mandatorily closed on Sunday during the ‘people’s curfew’. However, this will not be applicable to the units producing hand sanitisers.Restaurants, cafes, sweet shops and salons will keep their shutters down too.All liquor shops will be closed as well. Exemptions include hospitals, pharmacies, pathology centres and those dealing with items covered under the Essential Commodities Act , like groceries, milk, cooking gas, ration, vegetables and fruits.“We are not asking any of the stores with essential commodities to remain shut. All emergency services of health, police, fire and ambulance will work normally,” said B N Singh, district magistrate, Gautam Budh Nagar.Similarly in Ghaziabad, all commercial, industrial, private institutions, restaurants and salons will be shut. Only essential services like medical stores and grocery shops will be open, district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey said, adding that anyone found violating the directive will be booked under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code.Many highrise societies said that they will enforce complete lockdown , except for emergency services, and residents’ movements will be restricted. “All residents in our society have granted paid leave to domestic helps and the size of the security staff has been scaled down to a minimum,” said Sanjay Jha, secretary, Gaur Global Village, in Ghaziabad. “Only one gate will be opened. Residents have been asked to discourage guests but we will allow movement only during emergencies,” he added.Alok Kumar, a resident of Arihant Harmony in Ghaziabad, said domestic helps, masons and plumbers had been asked not to come and assured that their wages would not be deducted.“We are prohibiting entry of helps, delivery boys, external vendors and car cleaners. We have also asked residents to come out and applaud the brave health workers at 5pm,” said Amit Gupta, the RWA president of Prateek Wisteria in Noida’s Sector 77.Meanwhile, residents of scores of housing societies in the city stepped out on balconies on Saturday evening to carry out a ‘dry run’ of the ‘people’s curfew’. To laud the efforts of doctors, policemen, administrative and government officials involved with the prevention and treatment of Covid-19 , around 5pm, many came out on their balconies with steel plates and utensils. Interestingly, residents of two societies in sectors 78 and 74 where cases have been confirmed showed a lot of enthusiasm.A resident of a Sector 78 society, Biswajit Sarkar, said, “Some friends had shared a message on an internal WhatsApp group to practise and create awareness about the ‘janata curfew’. Other group members also showed inclination to join in and gathered on their balconies.”A resident of Sector 74 society, Prashant Yadav, said, “People remained on their balcony for nearly an hour. Some were also blowing conch shells. The atmosphere was electrifying and we expect to see a huge response on Sunday evening.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Fellow train travellers under scanner now
Content: JABALPUR: Railways and health department are tracing all the passengers who had travelled in B1 coach of Govardhan Express, in which the three positive patients had travelled from Mumbai to Jabalpur.District collector Bharat Yadav said, “Of the four patients, three had reached Delhi from Dubai and then arrived in Jabalpur by Govardhan Express, on March 16. Similarly the other patient who is a student had arrived in the city by a domestic flight after coming from Germany. All the passengers who were travelling with these patients are being identified and their screening would be done as per prescribed protocols.”Central public relations officer of the West Central Railway (WCR) Priyanka Dixit said, “List of passengers who were travelling in that particular coach, in which the corona-positive patients were travelling, has been sent to the concerned railway zone by the board. It has been instructed that the passengers travelling in the coach should be informed.”DRM, Jabalpur, Sanjay Biswas, said, “Three passengers who were found positive had alighted from the said train on March 16 at Jabalpur. As a precaution, we have also declared the area outside the railway station as ticket zone, thus, people gathering there also need to purchase platform tickets worth Rs 50, this has been done to ensure there is no unnecessary gathering there. Several other measures are also being taken to contain the spread of coronavirus .”

Title: ‘No disruption of milk supply today’
Content:
Salem: There will not be any disruption in milk supply on Sunday, said C Vijay Babu, general manager of Aavin, Salem district. Citing the direction of chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswamy , Vijay Babu said milk comes under essential commodities. “Tankers trucks were asked to be at the Aavin premises on Saturday night. The tankers will be filled with milk and be out of the premises around 2am on Sunday.

Milk will be be available at the designated parlours, stalls and shops from 3am,” he said. He warned that police action will be initiated against people who try to disrupt the milk distribution. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Bavdhan resident tests positive, Maharashtra tally rises to 64 cases
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: A 25-year-old resident of Bavdhan tested positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection on Saturday, taking the Covid-19 positive case tally in Pune district to 23.

The number of positive cases in the state rose to 64 on Saturday.

Of the 23 positive cases in Pune since March 9, a total of 11 patients are residents of the areas within the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) limits and the 12 others are residents of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC).

“The Bavdhan man hails from Ichalkanranji and was temporarily staying at his friend's place in Bavdhan after he returned from Ireland on Friday (March 20). He self-reported after he developed flu-like symptoms, following which he was isolated at Naidu Hospital the same day (March 20). His throat swab sample tested positive at the National Institute of Virology (NIV) on early Saturday (March 21) morning,” a civic health official said.

The man's close contacts, mainly his nine friends, have been quarantined at Naidu Hospital, and their throat swab samples have been sent to the NIV for testing. “Their reports are awaited,” an official said.

Title: Poultry farm owner booked for dumping 1,500 birds in river
Content:
Nagpur: Sewagram police from Wardha district recently arrested a poultry farm owner and his employee for allegedly dumping around 1 ,500 birds, including some dead ones, in Dham river near Waghala village.

The accused, Rashtrapal Dhale, and his employee were later released on bail. The tehsildar office of Seloo along with the other government machinery removed the dead birds from the river and buried them in a big pit.

The accused were booked under section 269 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and 108 of the Maharashtra Police Act for putting people’s health at risk.

According to sources, due to the Coronavirus scare, the sale of chicken had decreased drastically. The owner of the poultry farm was depressed after suffering losses.

Unable to cope with the disturbing situation, the owner, along with his employee, took nearly 1500 birds to the Dham river at night and dumped them.

The dumping of the birds, which eventually led to their deaths, contaminated the water. The incident came to light the next day when some residents spotted dead birds floating in the river. After gram panchayat officials were informed, the government machinery was summoned and the dead birds were taken out from the river.

“We cleared the water which was contaminated due to the dead birds. We also filed a complaint with Sewagram police who took further action. Due to the Coronavirus scare, we are already on our toes. The incident did create a bit of a panic like situation, but we brought it under control. Now, everything is OK. We have also instructed the other poultry farmers to refrain from taking such drastic steps,” said Seloo tehsildar Mahendra Sonone.

Water from Dham River is supplied to many nearby villages.

“We swung into action after the incident was reported. We tracked down the poultry farm owner and arrested him. He dumped his birds into the river which is illegal. Due to the contaminated water, he also put the health of villagers at risk. He should have buried the birds in a pit rather than dumping them in the river,” said Kanchan Pande, PI of Sewagram police station.

Title: The Bengaluru CONNECTION
Content: BENGALURU: The past few months can be termed ‘innovative’ when describing drug smuggling in and out of Bengaluru city. Smuggling has always involved ingenuity. One of the earliest documented examples of smuggling – that of silkworm cocoons from out of China into Europe – involved a two year operation, culminating in a pair of monks smuggling the cocoons in the hollows of their bamboo staffs.Smugglers out of Bengaluru have smuggled contraband worth over Rs 18 crore including cocaine, ephedrine and hashish this financial year. The most recent attempt involved a fake wedding for which invitation cards were printed and a bogus designer whose garment spools were being exported — with drugs hidden in ingenious fashion.The Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) and its cargo section are where most of these drug smuggling activities come to light. The Customs authorities have noticed a significant uptick in attempts to smuggle drugs out of Bengaluru this year. On February 18, sleuths of the Customs Intelligence Unit at the air cargo section of the Bangalore Customs spotted a unique cargo — 45 spools of embroidery lace for garments. “The consignment of the spools as part of shipment of designer clothes was booked to Australia from Madurai by a Chennai-based exporter. We felt that there was something amiss about the shipment and opened out the garment laces to find tiny tubes of plastic with a white powdered rolled inside. Tests later determined it as ephedrine, a banned drug,” said an investigating officer with the Customs at KIA Cargo.The ephedrine that was discovered weighed a total of 5.11kg - worth a whopping Rs 5 crore in the international market. An investigation into the Chennai-based exporter showed that it was a bogus company. Why the Bengaluru cargo terminal was chosen for the smuggling is being examined.Fake weddingShockingly, before the drug smuggling investigation could make headway, the same KIA cargo unit received another suspicious consignment on February 22. This time, many wedding invitations–along with clothes and other items – was part of a consignment for an Australian destination. “This was within a week of the first case and what we did was immediately check if the wedding mentioned in the cards scheduled to be held on April 30, 2020 in Chennai was true. It turned out to be fake and we opened all the 43 fancy invites and were stunned to find powdered ephedrine smartly hidden. We haven’t found anything like this before,” said another officer who dealt the case.The ephedrine drugs, this time worth Rs. 5.05 crore, was also sent from Chennai. Customs sleuths believe that both these attempts to smuggle ephedrine were part of a larger operation. A thorough probe is under-way into the source of the drugs but progress has not been speedy.Salahuddin (name changed), from Kozhikode in Kerala, has links here with gold smuggling rackets operating between the Bengaluru and the Gulf. He claims to have helped recruit mules to smuggle gold into Bengaluru for a fee, apart from free tickets for the journey. “The drug game is big and murky involving big players who are literally invincible and invisible to the lower ranks. These consignments are booked using fake addresses and people moving them often don’t have a clue on who gives them the orders as they are directed through the cellphone. So it becomes difficult for investigators to find the links,” he said.Inside players hint at extremely innovative methods of drug and gold smuggling to avoid detection from the eyes of Customs authorities at KIA. “Bengaluru is dubbed as an easy spot for smuggling activity as the rackets are well aware that the city airport is huge and enforcement agencies inside are severely short staffed,” revealed Shaji, another Kerala-native who used to be a carrier. He refused to identify himself beyond the name citing pending investigations against him.Big fishes, drugs in padsThe sleuths of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) who are also a key enforcement agency monitoring drug and gold smuggling through Bengaluru airport had nabbed what they called a ‘big fish’ in the recent months. February again witnessed the arrest of notorious Kerala-based gold smuggler Shihabudheen Thadathil who runs a big racket smuggling gold between Bengaluru and the Gulf. His carriers use methods like body pouches and gold as paste stuck to the body. “The 46-year-old smuggling kingpin, as per our investigation, had managed to smuggle in 200 kgs of gold between June and October 2018 alone. He has been operating for over a decade and we had a look out circular issued against his passport which ultimately resulted in his arrest at Bengaluru airport on February 7th,” said a senior DRI investigator.The DRI also busted a gang with their mule who attempted to smuggle out hashish worth over Rs 30 lakh inside cereal boxes meticulously hidden inside his check-in luggage.However, the most novel method of them all was a drug smuggling attempt inside sanitary napkins and the carrier was a woman to avoid detection by authorities. Last year, the Bengaluru unit of the Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB), busted the connecting gang operating from Austin Town who used to recruit women to smuggle hard drugs by air into the Gulf and seized 510gm of methamphetamine and 572 Lyrica, a sedative capsule, hidden in sanitary pads.“The enforcement agencies remain vigilant and items for export and luggage items are meticulously scanned for every possible clue. But these smart smuggling methods like the wedding cards and clothes spools are drastic steps taken by the racketeers trying to smuggle crores of rupees worth of contraband from Bengaluru. We too have some innovative mechanics to tackle the smuggling and will continue to clamp down the perpetrators,” added a senior Customs officer at KIA.Major drug busts at Bengaluru AirportFinancial year - Drugs seized - Value in Rs2016-17 - Methaquolane, Ephedrine - 14cr2017-18 - Ephedrine, Ketamine - 2cr2018-19 - Methaquolane - 6.45cr2019-20 - Ephedrine, Cocaine - 18crSneaking throughMarch 2, 2020: Cocaine worth Rs 8.30cr in 150 capsules swallowed by Guatemalan woman, lands in city, travelling from Brazil.Feb 22, 2020: Ephedrine worth Rs 5.05cr inside 43 wedding cards in a shipment to Australia. Wedding known to be fake.Feb 18, 2020: Ephedrine worth Rs 5cr inside 46 spools with garment laces as part of designer Indian clothing to AustraliaSept 14, 2019: Hashish worth Rs 30lakh inside cereal boxes bound for Qatar via a male passenger.June 17. 2019: Methamphetamine and Lyrica capsules worth Rs 3cr inside sanitary pads of a woman passenger to the Gulf.

Title: Buses off roads as RTC suspends services
Content:
Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation ( APSRTC ) has cancelled all bus services for Sunday in view of the countrywide janata curfew to contain the spread of coronavirus.

Transport minister Perni Venkatramaiah (Nani) announced that all bus services will be suspended from 7 am to 9 pm on Sunday. All long-distance services will be suspended from Saturday night and resume on Sunday night, the minister said.

Nani also appealed to private travel operators to suspend all bus services. “The measure is being taken for the wellbeing of society and to contain the spread of virus,” he said and requested private travel operators support the cause. Drivers and owners of taxis and autorickshaws were also requested to suspend operations on Sunday.

The APSRTC has already removed the 25% concession given to senior citizens to discourage elderly persons, more at risk of contracting Covid-19, from using public transport.

Workers’ unions have demanded that managements consider Sunday as special casual leave as most bus services have been suspended. General secretary of APSRTC employees union Palisetti Damodar said on Saturday that as there is no clarity when services will be resumed, the management should give special casual leave to staff scheduled to be on duty in the cancelled services.

Title: 4 pvt hospitals allowed to treat Covid-19 patients
Content:
Coimbatore: The district health department has allowed four private multispeciality hospitals in the city to set up 50-bed isolation facilities to treat patients with Covid-19 symptoms.

Collector K Rajamani on Saturday said the government has decided to allow Kovai Medical Center and Hospital, PSG Hospitals, Royal Care Hospital and Abhinand Hospital to admit and treat patients suspected of having Covid-19 and those tested positive.

“The hospitals have been asked to keep ready isolation wards that have 50 to 60 beds,” he said.

While the hospitals can admit and treat patients, the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital will be the authorized centre to do the test.

The health department is asking all those who were travelling and have Covid-19 symptoms to undergo the test, unlike earlier, when they were only testing people with specific symptoms so as to not overburden test centres and waste testing kits.

The collector also oversaw screening activities at the Walayar check post and Anaikatti. “All vehicles carrying essential commodities and patients with medical emergencies are allowed to enter the state,” said the collector. “We are also planning to establish another makeshift corona observation centre at Othakkalmandapam.”

Seven people who were tested at the Covid-19 test centre in CMCH have tested negative and so have four people tested on Thursday, health department sources said. This includes a 77-year-old man who visited Mumbai, a couple from Mettupalayam who returned from Sweden and a girl who returned from Spain.

Three patients were isolated at the CMCH and ESIC Hospital on Saturday include a three-year-old boy who has cold and fever. The boy and his family had recently returned from Rajasthan. The others are a 45-year-old man who returned from Odisha and a 35-year-old man who had been to Germany.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Narsinghpur goes into 2-week shutdown
Content: BHOPAL: After Jabalpur issued a lockdown on Saturday, following four positive Coronavirus cases a day earlier, local administration in several districts imposed restrictions on its borders.While in Satna, administration advised people to avoid unnecessary travel to neighbouring districts, in Narsinghpur, district collector ordered complete shutdown in the district for the next 14 days. In Chhindwara, check posts were put up in bordering areas and transport between Chhindwara and Jabalpur was banned.Narsinghpur collector Deepak Saxena ordered that there will be complete lockdown for 14 days in the district, from March 21 onwards.During this period, no person will be allowed to travel in and out of the district. Apart from grocery stores and chemists, all other stores would remain closedIn Satna district , collector advised people to avoid unnecessary travel to prevent spread of Coronavirus. tnn

Title: Coronavirus scare: Gujaratis among 50-odd Indians stranded in UK
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: More than 50 Indians including a few from the state are stranded in London as they were unable to leave the United Kingdom despite having booked their tickets.

While the group that includes mostly students believed that they would be able to leave as flights to India would stop on March 22, they had to return from the airport after being told that they could not fly to India due to restrictions.

The group had bought tickets after India made the announcement that passengers of international flights could not disembark in the country after 1.31am on March 23.
