While this was true, another advisory issued by the Indian High Commission in London on March 19 had stated that the travel of Indian citizens including Indian students in the UK would remain restricted till March 31. It posted the information on its website and also tweeted it.

Believing that they would be able to fly to India till March 22, a group of students booked their tickets and even reached the airport. They were to travel to Dubai and then to India. But on reaching the airport, they were asked to return citing restrictions on travel for Indian citizens.

The students and a few others then reached the Indian embassy seeking help. “We booked tickets after the announcement of restrictions on fights after March 22. When we reached the airport, we were told that we could not fly. We are now stranded. We booked costly tickets and will get refunds only after two weeks. Till then we do not know how to survive as many do not have enough money. The situation here is serious,” said Itishree Yashesh Pradhan from Godhra who is staying there on a dependent visa.

Dhruv Patel, a resident of Vadodara, said that there were several Gujaratis amongst the group of 54. “Some people have shifted to a hotel arranged for them by the embassy. We booked the tickets on March 20. We did so fearing that we may not be able to leave later,” he said.

The high commission has been trying to convince the students to move to hotels. It has also tweeted steps taken to help Indians in the UK. But till Saturday evening, students were in no mood to leave the embassy and had even spent a night there.

Title: Koradi plant gets notice for green violations
Content:
KTPS has failed to instal flue gas desulphurizers (FGDs) despite repeated directives from Union ministry of en... Read More

Nagpur: Union ministry of environment, forests and climate change (MoEFCC) has issued a showcause notice to Mahagenco’s Koradi thermal power station (KTPS) for violating environmental norms.

The major violations by KTPS are failure to install flue gas desulphurizers (FGDs) despite repeated directives, effluent treatment plant (ETP) not functioning properly, etc

Mahagenco’s director (projects) V Thangapandian has submitted a reply to MoEFCC and sought a personal hearing in this regard. Mahagenco has submitted an application seeking terms of reference (TOR) for environmental clearance for two new 660MW units in Koradi. Any adverse development can affect the issue of TOR. A meeting on issuance of TOR was held on March 19.

Thangapandian has stated the reasons for delay in installation of the FGDs in the reply. Mahagenco at first sought a waiver on installation of the FGD but was unsuccessful. It then filed a petition in National Green Tribunal (NGT) seeking extension of deadline for installation of the equipment but later decided to withdraw the plea.

Mahagenco then floated an expression of interest (EoI) for installation of the FGD on one of the 660MW units (Unit 10) in July 2016 on built operate and transfer (BOT) basis. However, no response was received. It then floated a bid for this work on engineering procurement contract (EPC) basis in May 2017.

Later the top officials changed their mind and cancelled the tender. They floated a tender for installation of the FGDs on all three 660MW units of Koradi plant in March 2019. Due to ambiguities in the tender, it was cancelled again. A fresh tender was floated in September 2019 which had a provision of the successful bidder operating and maintaining the FGD for 10 years.

Techno-commercial bids were opened in October 2019 and financial bids were opened in November 2019. Meanwhile, permission was sought from Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC) for installing these equipments.

Letter of agreement (LoA) for installation of FGDs will be put up before board of directors for approval and the equipments will be installed as per timeline of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), Mahagenco has assured MoEFCC.

The MoEFCC team that had visited Koradi had raised objections on ETP not working properly. Thangapandian has stated that it was working partially due to O & M issues. However, soon these were addressed and now the plant is working at full capacity.

The generation company has submitted the figures of various pollutants measured at chimneys of the three 660MW units and claimed that all of them were within stipulated limits.

Title: Kota collector orders 72 hours shutdown from Sunday
Content: Kota: In a major preventive measure against spread of Corona virus, Kota district collector Om Kasera on Saturday issued order for shut down of all business and non business establishments in the district for 72 hours from 6 am on Sunday to 6 am on Wednesday, however, establishments with emergency services have been exempted from the 72 hours long shut down.The district collector ordered for a complete shutdown of all establishments for 72 hours except that of the establishments of commodities listed in Rajasthan Essential Commodities Act and empowered with Epidemic Disease Act and Rajasthan Epidemic Act. The order, however, will not apply to those providing home delivery to railway station, bus stands and students in hostels.The district collector urged the people not to step out of homes unnecessarily and to avoid visiting crowded places from 6 AM on March 22 to 6 AM on March 25.Medical stores, ration shops, milk, vegetables, LPG gas, petrol pumps, retail outlets, water supply, banks, ATM, will continue to function unaffected from the shutdown while other establishments and shops that include business activities, sweets, Namkeen, Kachori shops and other edible items will remain completely closed.

Title: No relief for maids, cooks and drivers
Content:
Jaipur: Amidst the pandemic which has gripped the world, people in Jaipur are claiming to stay inside the houses and maintaining appropriate social distancing to avoid being exposed to Covid-19, the threat still looms as locals are unwilling to let go of support staff including maids, cooks and drivers.

While, a few townships have imposed restrictions on the entry of domestic helps, there are independent house owners who call them for household works.

Bina Devi, who works in eight houses in Adarsh Nagar, says, “On Saturday, I worked in all the households. None of the owner asked me to take leave, apart from Sunday. I feel it’s justified too as most of the houses where I work have elderly or working class people. Elderly cannot afford cleaning and cooking on their own.”

There are several instances that people are sending their help to markets without realising they could become a carrier of the virus.

Title: Covid-19 drama over delayed funeral leads to panic
Content:
Nagpur: There was a panic-like situation in Lonara village on the outskirts of the city after residents started feeling tizzy after a 53-year-old woman’s body was kept in Nagpal Colony.

The funeral, which finally took place on Friday, was delayed by 72 hours as the deceased’s son was held up at MLA hostel’s quarantine facility after landing at Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar international airport from Paris.

It’s learnt that the woman, after suffering for a prolonged period, had expired at a leading hospital in Pune on March 16.

In the death certificate, the reason behind her cause of death was mentioned as pneumonia and related complications.

The drama started after the woman’s body was shifted to her brother’s residence in Lonara’s Nagpal Colony, a day after her death.

After learning about his mother’s death, the son rushed to the city to perform the last rites. He landed in the city from Paris on March 17 but was quarantined at MLA Hostel for the mandatory 48-hour screening.

Meanwhile, a resident raised objections regarding the body of the women being kept in the freezer. He was doubting her cause of death. He had also shared his concern about the woman’s possible cause of death due to corona-like symptoms.

After the objections were raised verbally and via social media, local residents approached cops. They even questioned the delay of the funeral.

Senior PI Vazeer Shaikh of Koradi police station said he was flooded by calls from Nagpal Colony regarding the funeral. “We had to contact the doctor of the primary health centre of Gumthala who accompanied me to the house of the concerned person in Nagpal Colony on Thursday (March 19) to scrutinize the death certificate and other documents of the deceased. She did not die due to corona,” he said.

Shaikh said the reports of the medical history of the deceased was revealed to the residents after summoning them at a prominent place in the village. “We convinced the local population that there was no reason to panic or fear as her death had not taken place due to corona. At the same time, we also summoned the person who was rumour mongering and warned him,” said the PI.

He added the person, who was contacting everyone stating that there was a corona-related death in the village, was also served a warning notice.

It’s also learnt that the police had sent a team to MLA Hostel to check the health status of the woman’s son after the rumour was spreading in Lonara and adjoining places. Police and government agencies had also conducted a check at the residence of the woman’s brother to ascertain whether there was a home quarantine facility, if required.

As there were no symptoms, the woman’s son was discharged from MLA Hostel as the cops and other government personnel helped him reach home on March 20 to perform the last rites at a local crematorium.

Title: 150 medicos stuck in Philippines, seek govt help
Content: Alwar: Over 150 medical students, who are stuck in Philippines after Covid-19 spread, took to social media to request the Indian government to airlift them at the earliest as they have been stuck at the Manila airport and are even running out of food.The appeal made through a video made by Sunil Kumar Meena who is the head of the International Indian Medical Association and hails from Behror said that they have been stuck at the Manila airport as curfew has been imposed and they are unable to get out.Manila has been down on a lockdown from March 17 to April 14 and the country’s government had asked the foreigners to return home if they wished within 72 hours. According to Meena’s video there have been 230 cases which have tested positive for Covid-19 and 18 fatalities.“As soon as we were informed about the lockdown, we booked our tickets but in the meantime the Indian government closed down the flights from Philippines from landing in India and since then we have been stranded. After India cancelled the flights, our boarding passes were immediately cancelled,” said Meena in the video. After the video was uploaded many state leaders including Hanuman Beniwal and Satish Poonia assured the students of all the help.According to officials, all flights have been banned till March 31 and the concerned authorities have been asked to ensure that they reach their accommodations in Manila safely till can leave the country. The officials will also be monitoring the situation regularly.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Essential Commodities Act imposed on masks, sanitisers
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

BHOPAL: In a bid to check hoarding of masks and hand sanitizers, Madhya Pradesh government has imposed Essential Commodities Act on masks and hand sanitizers and framed the Madhya Pradesh Mask (2ply and 3 ply surgical mask and N 95 mask) and Hand Sanitizer Control Order 2020.

As per the order, traders are now required to exhibit ‘available stock of masks and sanitizers and also display their prices on boards.

Food inspectors will have the right to inspect records and stock of any shop. It could not be sold above the prices prescribed as per the notification of the union government which specified that the cost of 2 ply masks will not be more than Rs 8 and cost of 3 ply masks will not be more than Rs 10 per piece and retail prices of the sanitizers shall not be more than Rs 100 per 200 ml bottle.

The state government order reads, “The trader shall display information of available stock and the sale price of mask (2ply and 3 ply surgical mask, N95 mask) and hand sanitizer on a board fixed at a conspicuous place in its transaction premise daily. The trader shall not refuse to sale the essential commodities mentioned in clause 3 to any consumer. The trader shall not commit any act for the purpose of profiteering which creates and artificial shortage of the said essential commodity.”

It also makes it mandatory for the traders to submit the purchase and sale record before the food and drug administration department every fortnight. Besides the order also specifies that officers not below the rank of food inspector could inspect and conduct seizure of the commodities (masks and sanitizers) to ensure that provisions of this order are not violated.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Pink City goes into self ‘lockdown’ mode
Content:
JAIPUR: The increasing threat of Covid-19 seemed to have compelled people in the city to go into a self-imposed curfew on Saturday. A day prior to the Janata Curfew proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the markets, shops and malls remained closed in the city.

Likewise, the roads wore an empty look even in the evening. At some places, the police were seen using their powers of CrPC and asking tea stalls, fruit sellers, sweet shops etc to close their shops or to ensure that there was no over-crowding at their shops. The only ones that were seen open were grocery shops or diagnostic centres.

Coronavirus in India live updates

TOI on Saturday visited various parts of the city including the Walled City and found that the traders were closing their shops on their own. “Ab khatra badh raha hai, hum to kuch din band rakhenge (Now, the danger seems to be increasing, we will keep our shops shut for some days),” said Hukum Chand Tekwani , a wholesale trader of clothes at Chandpole Bazaar.

Similarly, the small vendors selling ice-cream, snacks and other roadside eateries, were also seen closed. “If it is better to be at home, then so be it. I will not open it for next couple of days or may be for a week,” said Raju Chahar, who sells paranthas near Polo victory area in the city. The roads also wore an empty look in the afternoon and evening, as people confined themselves to their homes and offices.

Areas including Raja Park, Jawahar Nagar, Aadarsh Nagar, MD Road, Janta Store, Gopalpura, Jagatpura, Mansarovar , Sikar Road, Jhotwara, Murlipura, Kardhani and others witnessed almost 70 per cent closure of shops. At some of the shops, traders pasted a notice saying, “Due to the danger of Covid-19, the shop will remain closed.”

However, in many areas, the police teams were appealing to the public to close their shops and to ensure no overcrowding takes places. “Using CrPC powers, we are not allowing any gathering of public. At the sweet shops, tea stalls, ice cream parlours, coffee shops, where we see gathering, we are asking the traders either to ensure no overcrowding takes place or are asking them to shut down,” said a senior officer of Jaipur police commissionerate.

Title: Protesters change tack in Amaravati
Content: Vijayawada: Farmers protesting the three-capital move for the last 96 days, on Saturday, said they will continue the stir but change their approach considering the coronavirus outbreak.Puvvada Sudhakar, member of Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee (JAC), announced, “ Given the prevailing situation, we have decided to limit the number of people to 10 at a given time in the protest venues. Children below 10 and the aged above 60 will not participate in the protests.” Besides, farmers have also decided to light a candle at 7pm every day in their homes as a mark of protest.The JAC also announced that they will participate in the Janata Curfew called by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Meanwhile, police issued notices to the farmers to leave the protest venues in view of the spread of virus. Police have imposed restrictions on all kinds of gatherings and processions.

Title: Automatic signalling in Nagpur-Khapri section
Content:
The Rs20-crore automatic signalling system will help ease out bunching of trains

Nagpur: In a major move, the Nagpur division of Central Railway on Thursday commissioned automatic signalling system between Nagpur and Khapri (12.41km). The Rs20-crore project will help ease out bunching of trains.

This is the first automatic signalling system in Nagpur-Ajni-Khapri section. Automatic signalling is the most advanced system where several trains can be run between sections. Nagpur-Ajni-Khapri is a busy section where trains from both Itarsi and Howrah side run frequently.

In the present signalling system, only one train runs between two stations at a time. However, automatic signalling provides a feature to run multiple trains between two stations. Thus, with the new system in place more trains will depart and arrive at Nagpur and Ajni stations.

For the first time across Central Railway, live train movement with signal position can be viewed at stations and also by divisional control office.

Besides, the level crossing gate between Ajni and Khapri has also been provided with automatic approach warning of train. “Now gate man will get an audio buzzer when a train is about 2km away. This will help him close the gate on time. This is the first such system in Nagpur division,” said officials.

On Thursday afternoon, Jaipur-Mysore Express was the first train to run on automatic signalling system in the section.

“Now congestion of trains at Nagpur and Ajni stations will be reduced and waiting time for trains outside the station will also be less. The system will control movement of trains between the blocks using automatic signals. The new system consists of six automatic signals and four semi-automatic signals with axle counters along auto generation of SMS,” said DRM Somesh Kumar.

Kumar lauded the signal and telecom department for achieving the major milestone in providing the first automatic signalling system in Nagpur-Khapri section.

The commissioning took place in presence of ADRMs Manoj Tiwari and Jay Singh. Senior officials Ashutosh Shrivastav, Alok Kumar, YT Barapatre, NM Jambulkar, RS Kawde, MK Awadhi, SB Chawde, Ashay Dixit and P Ravikumar Rao.

What It Means?

*In automatic block working system movement of trains is controlled by automatic stop signals. These signals are operated automatically by passage of trains of automatic signalling sections

* The line is track circuited throughout its length and divided into a series of automatic signalling sections each of which is governed by an automatic stop signal

* The movement of trains is controlled by stop signals, which are operated automatically by the passage of trains past the signals

* No automatic signal goes ‘off’ unless the line is clear not only up to the stop signal ahead, but also an adequate distance beyond it

Title: Spl postal numismatic cover released
Content:
Coimbatore: The city postal division in collaboration with philatelist and numismatist C Selvaraj released a special cover to mark the International Day of Forests on Saturday. Priced at Rs 350, this numismatic cover comes with a commemorative coin, a golden cancellation, a real wood veneer and a philately cancellation of a stamp released on the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi.

The colourfully designed cover has the potential to become a rare philately collectible for more than one reason. Sudhir Kumar Jakhere, senior superintendent of post offices, Coimbatore, said, “It contains an extremely rare 25 paisa commemorative coin that was released in 1985 with the lettering “forestry for development”. These coins are extremely rare and are sourced by Selvaraj. It also has real mahogany veneer of hardly 600-micron glued on to the cover, a golden cancellation of a postage stamp on the zoological survey of India and a cancelled stamp that was released on the 150th birth anniversary of Gandhiji.”

The postal department has decided to print only 500 special covers for now and they will be available for sale at the philatelic bureau. While the cover alone is priced at Rs 350, the same is available in a special folder with Mahatma Gandhi’s quotes at Rs 700.

In addition, the postal department has also released a special pack of postcards with pictures of rare species of plants in the Western Ghats. The postcards are affixed with QR codes, which if scanned would tell us the exact location where the plant was photographed. “The postcards come in plain packs, cancelled packs and elite packs. The elite packs have a special green cancellation designed by INTACH,” Jakhere said.

The Coimbatore division is the only division in the state to release special covers with coins within a short period. “The concept behind this cover is Gandhian environmentalism, which focuses on minimalism, and not overexploitation of forests and natural resources. He advocated development with sustainable usage of natural resources, which was way ahead of his time,” Jakhere said.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: Sunni leaders seek suspension of prayers at Mumbai mosques
Content: MUMBAI: Alarmed by the number of Sunni Muslims coming out of their homes for Friday and congregational prayers five times a day, a section of community leaders and commentators have demanded immediate suspension of all congregational prayers at mosques till Covid-19 dies down.While Haji Ali and Mahim Dargah are closed and Shia mosques have suspended congregational prayers in compliance with WHO guidelines in the fight against the virus, Sunnis continue to hold prayers in their mosques, though the duration has been curtailed.“Daily congregational prayers at holy mosques in Mecca and Medina have been stopped. Mosques in Kuwait are telling worshippers not to visit mosques but pray at home. But here, in India, some Sunni mosques continue to hold congregational prayers,” said senior Urdu columnist Hasan Kamal.Several Sunni clerics have asked people to visit mosques only for the mandatory prayers. “When health guidelines say that we must maintain a distance of at least one metre to avoid contracting this contagious disease, there are chances that an infected person at congregational prayers may transmit the virus to the non-infected,” said M A Khalid of All India Milli Council.Islamic scholar Zeenat Shaukat Ali referred to a saying of the Prophet. He said if there is a plague, no one from the plague-affected area should go out and no person from a non-affected area should visit.UK-based, Indian-origin pediatrician Dr Nadeem Jilani said on Facebook he offered prayers at home this past Friday. Senior cleric Maulana Mahmood Daryabadi said the lockdown has reduced worshippers at daily prayers at mosques.

Title: Photos: Pali administration creating awareness with caricatures
Content:
Video: Pali administration is circulating cartoons and caricatures with messages and slogans on prevention of Covid… https://t.co/RSsGn5GDLG — TOI Jaipur (@TOIJaipurNews) 1584849842000

JAIPUR: Amid the scare of Covid-19, the district administration of Pali has come up with an innovative idea to spread awareness about the pandemic. The administration is circulating cartoons and caricatures with messages and slogans on prevention of the infection, on various social networking groups in the city, and are also putting up posters and banners with these caricatures on them.A caricature artiste has also been hired to design and pen a series guiding the people on how cleanliness and hygiene, washing of hands, no hand shakes and no socializing, can prevent the outbreak of Covid-19. In one of the series, the caricature artist has also taken a jibe on the Kanika Kapoor episode.“In the era of social networking, these messages hit you harder. Today, when we have people using smartphones in the rural interiors of Rajasthan, we thought of doing something different. In one of our caricature series, there are three men standing and a Covid-19 cartoon is trying to shake hands. Responding to this, the three men are saying namaste, satshreakal and aadaab. Thus, the message comes across loud and clear,” said Dinesh Chand Jain, district collector, Pali while talking to TOI. “We want them to be interactive,” Jain added.These messages are being circulated in various social networking groups. “I first send it to my subordinate staff including the sub-divisional magistrates (SDM) and later I appeal them to circulate in their groups,” Jain added.In past one week, these caricatures are popular to an extent that they have gone beyond Pali and have been received by people living in Jaisalmer, Barmer, Jalore, Sirohi and Jodhpur districts of the state. “Our aim is to educate people, thus we came up with this idea,” he said.In these messages, the district administration is also circulating the control room numbers. “Our hospitals are on standby mode and everyday, we are appealing to the public to avoid visiting the places which are overcrowded, wash their hands regularly, and are also disinfecting public places,” he said.

Title: Train to Tambaram will benefit region, say railway users
Content:
Coimbatore: Several rail passengers associations in the Pollachi to Udumalpet belt are demanding an overnight train from Mettupalayam till Tambaram.

Representatives of the associations said they had wrote to Coimbatore MP P R Natarajan and Southern Railway general manager demanding a train from Mettupalayam or Coimbatore to Tambaram or Chennai. “We want more rail connectivity between Coimbatore and the delta regions via Pollachi and Dindigul,” said secretary of the Welfare Association of Rail Passengers in Pollachi Mohan Kumar, who is also a businessman.

“Many Udumalpet industries and farmers buy banana leaves and betel nuts and leaves from the delta region and vegetable traders can easily travel between Mettupalayam and Dindigul for buying and selling vegetables,” he said.

Such a train will fill a large void in the tourism and pilgrimage sector, said Kumar. “This train should pass through Palani and Kumbakonam, both of which are popular destinations for pilgrims and start and end at Mettupalayam, giving travellers in delta region easy connectivity to NMR and Ooty,” said Mohan Kumar.

President of the Thanjavur District Rail Users Association P K T Shanmugam agreed. “Every day, at least six government buses operate between Palani and Chidambaram. As many buses operate between Palani and Mayiladuthai, and Thanjavur. A special fare train will help the passengers because it is more convenient. Moreover, the railway will earn more revenue,” he said.

The train will also benefit the students of Annamalai University in Chidambaram based in Palani and Pollachi.

Title: Covid-19 in Rajasthan: Worried patients with flu symptoms flood hospital
Content: JAIPUR: While 23 persons have already been tested positive for Covid-19 in the state till Saturday, worried patients having symptoms of cold, cough and fever are rushing to the SMS Hospital for getting the Covid-19 test done.However, the SMS hospital authorities faced difficulties in handling these patients. Immediately, the SMS hospital made arrangement to deploy six doctors outside emergency unit and also a team of six doctors at out patient department to conduct screening of the patients.Anticipating that Covid-19 cases may increase in numbers, health department issued directions to all the private hospitals, having capacity of 100 beds, to reserve 25% of the beds for such patients. Since, Covid-19 cases have reported from city’s Adarsh Nagar, Rangoli Garden, Jagatpura and Gopalpura area, the health department is conducting intense screening of the area. They are identifying those patients who have cold, cough and fever and advising them to see doctor and remain in isolation. Over 5,000 such cases have already been identified from these areas.Concerned over the increasing pressure of patients, SMS medical college principal and controller Dr Sudhir Bhandari held a meeting and issued most urgent out and action immediately directions. He constituted eight member screening team including doctors Dheeraj Saxena, Lokesh Sharma, Dr SK Singhal, Dr Kapil Gupta, two resident doctors and one nursing staff and one consultant in respiratory medicine.The SMS Medical College has decided to put big hoardings for proper identification of place in front of emergency (garage of ambulance) for screening for Covid-19. Dr Vinay Malhotra will ensure implementation of ICMR testing protocol. Dr SM Sharma, will coordinate with rapid response teams for their movement. He will ensure availability of kits for testing. Dr Bharti Malhotra will provide help for meeting ICMR testing protocol requirements.

Title: First case of Covid-19 from Jodhpur division has history of travelling to Dubai
Content: Jodhpur: A person who had been admitted to the isolation ward in Pali ’s Bangar Hospital was found positive for coronavirus on Saturday. His entire family has been quarantined at home. The medical and health department has been trying to identify all those in his village, who had come into contact with him.According to joint director (medical and health) Yudhveer Singh Rathore, a youth from village Dhola in Pali district had returned from Dubai on March 18. In spite of the symptomatic indicators, he did not visit the hospital.“On the information about a foreign visit by him, our team went to his home and took him to the hospital for isolation. His samples were sent for examination, which tested positive for Covid-19,” said Rathore adding that his treatment has started. He, however, expressed relief that none of his family members has tested positive, but they have been still kept under observation for conclusive results.Meanwhile, about 62 samples of suspects have been taken in all the six districts of Jodhpur division and except the one from Pali, none has been tested positive for Covid-19. In the given scenario, all those persons coming from abroad have emerged as a major threat for other people.According to Rathore, there have been multiple cases, where such persons have escaped reporting to the medical department for screening despite having symptomatic indicators.“Such negligent persons, god forbid, if carried virus, could be potential threat to the rest of the population including their families,” said Rathore, adding that India was on the verge of 3rd stage and it was only the citizens’ awareness, which could hold it from getting worse.In a similar case, two suspects, who had returned from Italy to their village in Osian, three days back, refused to get themselves screened and shifted to isolation facility in Jodhpur. The SDM had to contact them but still adamant, they had to be isolated at their respective homes.This negligence of foreign visitors has been taking the team of Jodhpur Municipal Corporation also to task and the teams have to resort to hard convincing.Commissioner (JMC) Suresh Kumar Ola said that close to 200 foreign visitors have been stamped on their hands so far and counting, following the information received from the people about arrival of such persons in the city.He admitted that there have been 2-3 instances of resistance by such persons for screening to their teams. “We convinced them into home quarantine, warning them of legal action against them, if they did not cooperate,” said Ola.

Title: Covid-19 household survey: Nearly 94% of homes covered
Content: Vijayawada: The ongoing household survey to track all foreign returnees has so far covered about 1.33 crore households out of the targeted 1.41 crore households. The state government leveraged its huge network of ward/village volunteers, ward/village secretaries, Anganwadi workers, Asha workers and other field-level staff to conduct the extensive household survey.About 12,400 foreign returnees have been identified and mapped with the local primary health care team, comprising Asha workers, ANMs and medical officers, to monitor their health condition twice a day. Among these 12,400 persons, who returned to Andhra Pradesh in the last 40 days, nearly 7,000 people are yet to complete the 14-day home isolation period.Special chief secretary (medical and health and family welfare) KS Jawahar Reddy has asked foreign returnees to remain under self-home isolation for 14 days from the date of the arrival and not to have any contact with family members, relatives or visitors. “If they develop any clinical symptoms like cough, fever and have difficulty in breathing, they are advised to call 104 and if they are advised hospitalisation, travel in the dedicated 108 ambulance escorted by rapid response teams,” said Reddy.

Title: Private cottage sealed in Ooty
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Though the Nilgiris district administration had on March 17 instructed all hotels and guest houses to close till March 31, municipal officials who conducted a surprise check on Saturday found a private cottage in Ooty accommodating guests.

The officials found two families from Chennai staying at Lakshmi Cottage in Church Hill area. “We asked the guests to vacate and sealed the cottage,” Ooty municipal commissioner Saraswathi said.

With more restrictions on vehicles from Karnataka and Kerala entering the Nilgiris, located on the trijunction of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Karnataka, the district is cordoned off from the neighbouring states.

Except for vehicles carrying essential commodities such as milk, oil and ration items, those including light vehicles are not allowed to enter the hill district. However, exceptions are made for people coming to the Nilgiris on emergency purposes such as attending funeral.

According to the district administration, all passengers in the vehicles will be required to undergo the necessary medical scanning at the check posts. “Though there is a restriction on vehicles from Karnataka and Kerala to the Nilgiris, unmindful tourists still try to enter through the border check posts,” said a social activist.

Tourist vehicles are asked to return at Kakkanallah and Nadugani check posts.

Meanwhile, with no tourists in the Nilgiris, merchants and vendors said their business has shrunk at least by 50%. Shops including the 80 shops run by Tibetan refugees located near the Government Botanical Garden in Ooty have downed shutters since the last three days as they depend only on tourists.

“Now the business is based only on the local consumption. With no tourists, the business in markets and other areas in the district has come down by 50%,” said president of the Nilgiris District Merchants’ Association R Parameswaran. “Of course, we can’t complain. It’s the current global trend,” he said.

Title: One held for spreading fake news on Covid-19
Content:
Krishnagiri: Soolagiri police in Krishnagiri district, arrested a man on Saturday for spreading false information about corona virus (covid-19) through social media. The accused, K Shanmugam, 35, is a farmer from Chinnakothur village near Soolagiri.

Krishnagiri district cyber crime sub-inspector S Arul lodged a complaint against Shanmugam for spreading false information about covid-19 and inquiry was initiated, informed a Soolagiri police official. During inquiry, Shanmugam informed police that on Monday, he had posted a message on his WhatsApp mentioning a woman working in the garment unit has covid-19. He went on to say that the virus will spread to more than 1000 workers in the unit. It was revealed that his wife was working in a private garment manufacturing unit in Soolagiri.

The garment unit management came to know about this on Tuesday and contacted the cyber crime SI Arul. After verifying the WhatsApp posts, the SI lodged the complaint with Soolagiri police following which he was arrested.

“Shanmugam wanted the garment unit management to give holidays for all the staff including his wife for which he sent wrong information about covid-19 on WhatsApp,” the police officer said. Shanmugam was lodged at Salem central prison under judicial custody.

Title: Handwash challenge gains momentum in the times of Covid-19
Content: BHOPAL: Experts opine that frequent washing of hands with water and soap plus use of alcohol-based sanitisers are some of the vital preventive measures to contain coronavirus in the community. In this backdrop, UNICEF, Madhya Pradesh, hasstarted a handwash challenge, which is being taken up by many in Bhopal and other parts of the state, including Harda , Gwalior, Indore and Jhabua . Youth organisations, government officials including, Divisional Railway Manager and Divisional Commissioner’s Office have taken up this challenge.“The power of washing hands, plus maintaining respiratory hygiene of covering the mouth and nose with flexed elbow when coughing and sneezing, should be practised by everybody,” said Michael Juma, Chief UNICEF Madhya Pradesh on the importance of handwash challenge. “In the light of the pandemic, it is feared that children are at heightened risk of abuse, neglect, exploitation and violence amidst intensifying containment measures, according to UNICEF. Newly released technical guidance aims to help authorities strengthen the protection measures, especially for children during pandemic,” he added.Divisional Railway Manager of Bhopal, Uday Borwanker, also took the challenge and talked about washing hands with soap for more than 20 seconds to stay safe. People are being urged to tweet their videos on the lines of 2014’s Ice Bucket Challenge that went viral on social media.C S Sankhule, engineer in chief , Public Health Engineering Department and K K Songaria, engineer in chief (adviser), Public Health Engineering Department, also took up the challenge and advocated the cause of washing hands with soap to fight Coronavirus.Handwashing demonstration session at Gwalior division was attended by joint commissioner, deputy commissioner and the staff at division office. Indore divisional commissioner’s Office also took up the challenge.

Title: Police to ensure janata curfew becomes a success
Content: Vadodara: Police department is making all efforts to ensure that nobody in the city steps out of their homes during the ‘janta curfew’ on Sunday. Besides raising awareness through public announcement system, cops also held meetings with auto-rickshaw and taxi owners’ associations on Saturday. “Continuous messages are being passed through public announcement systems installed on our PCR vans so that citizens become aware about the situation,” said commissioner of police Anupam Singh Gahlaut. He added that some cops will be deployed outside all playgrounds and parks by 6.30 am on Sunday morning so that anyone who comes to such places can be requested to go back. “Our staff will also remain at police stations and whenever there will be any emergencies or call from citizens, they will reach out immediately,” Gahlaut said. On Saturday, the traffic branch held meeting with auto-rickshaw and taxi owners’ association. “They were requested to cooperate during the period of ‘janta curfew’ and they have showed readiness to take a break during those hours,” a traffic police official said. tnn

Title: Panic buying sets in as shops run out of masks, sanitizers
Content:
Coimbatore: Most of the pharmacies in the district have run out of masks and sanitizers, the demand for which has shot up with people running from pillar to post to store them in the hope of curbing the spread of Covid-19. Several pharmacies are now forced to turn down their customers, owing to lack of stock.

K Manimozhi, a pharmacist, said, “Masks, sanitizers, alcohol-based handrub and hand wash would be sold out within a few days of procurement. And then we have to wait for the arrival of fresh stock. This has been the situation ever since Covid-19 tension gripped the city in January-end. There is a huge demand for hand sanitizers as well and since stocks aren’t available people are going in for surgical spirit.”

Pointing out that the sale of masks was limited to 50 to 100 a day and that of sanitizers one or two till January, she said the demand has increased manifold since Covid-19 outbreak. “We are now selling more than 500 masks and 100 sanitizers a day.”

She said some people were buying sanitizers and masks in bulk quantities. “There are people who bought all the masks and sanitizers that were available in the shop at a time,” Manimozhi said recalling how she did a business of Rs 10,000 in a few hours.

Earlier, only health workers used to purchase alcohol-based handrub that too only a limited quantity. “I used to stock only five to six pieces. But today almost everyone is asking for handrub.”

Another pharmacist, Meenakshi, said the market was now flooded with several local brands and that a 500ml bottle of handrub was priced at Rs 600. “The high price and local brands are not a deterrent to the public, who continue to buy them.”

Meenakshi said she has been receiving endless phone calls asking for masks and hand sanitizers every day. “The demand might continue for another few weeks until the fear fades away.”

Pharmacist Christy, who owns a shop on Mettupalayam Road, said people were purchasing up to 300 masks and 15 to 20 hand sanitizers at a time. “The demand is for alcohol-based sanitizers. People are after particular varieties of them and are disappointed when they are not available. It takes a lot of lecturing to convince them all varieties of sanitizers and handrubs are equally good and only the percentage of alcohol in them differs,” she said.

Title: Not possible to check every passenger: SCR
Content: Secunderabad: With only two thermal scanners at the Secunderabad railway station, screening of all passengers for coronavirus is a near-impossible task, according to South Central Railway ( SCR officials).“Two main platforms on the railway station, platform 1 and 10, are equipped with thermal scanners since March 20 to randomly check passengers arriving to get onto the trains,” informed an SCR official. Despite the decline in footfall due to the pandemic, the Secunderabad railway station still sees over 1.5 lakh passengers on a daily basis. Railway staff has been directed to screen passengers on a random basis.“Manpower at the station is not enough...We understand that missing out even a single passenger is not right but there is no way we can cover the number of passengers we see every day,” the SCR official said and added that more screening devices and personnel are required on duty.

Title: Cut AC use to stall coronavirus: Maharashtra health minister to government offices
Content:
Health minister Rajesh Tope

MUMBAI: Health minister Rajesh Tope has asked government offices to minimize the use of air-conditioners to prevent the spread of Covid- 19 through air circulation. A circular to the effect has been released in Mantralaya too.

Coronavirus in India live updates

“We have asked all government offices to minimize the use of air-conditioner units as per World Health Organisation (WHO) guidelines and Government of India advisory,” said Tope at his daily press briefing on Saturday. He added the guidelines suggest offices must use fans and keep windows and doors open for ventilation “as a virus’ life increases in low temperature and decreases in sunlight”.

It is said a virus can live longer in low temperatures. “A virus can stay for seven to eight hours in low temperatures but only for an hour to two in normal temperatures,’’ said Tope. “It could stay alive in an AC duct for long and through air circulation infect others,” said the minister as an explanation for asking government offices to use fans.

ACs were considered the main culprit for the quick spread of Covid-19 on Hawaiian cruise liner Diamond Princess where thousands of passengers tested positive.

Dr Shashank Joshi, dean of the Indian College of Physicians, said there has been a debate on whether higher temperatures can kill the virus. “The jury is still out there but there have been outbreaks in Australia and Singapore that have high temperatures,” said Dr Joshi.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Amid scare, Jabalpur families shift to other places
Content: JABALPUR: Amid the scare over Coronavirus , families in the localities where the positive patients from Jabalpur reside are planning to shift to other places and rushing to hospitals in large numbers to get themselves screened. The four patients who were tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday are from two localities of the city.Though the entire city was locked down by state government on Saturday, the scare over the virus has led to few families already shifting to other localities on Friday night itself.“At present there are not male members in our family. So, we thought it would be appropriate to move with kids to the house of our relatives in another part of the city. We moved in the night itself,” said a woman, who had moved with her family from the locality where three of the patients were found to be positive.Besides people shifting to other places, several residents from these two localities rushed to the hospitals in fear of Coronavirus and approached doctors to get themselves screened. However, as a majority of them had no symptoms, they were advised by doctors to take precautions and remain alert. Besides, 25 people who have come into the contact with the positive patients are being screened for Coronavirus, sources said.Meanwhile, official sources said that condition of all the four patients who were tested positive for Coronavirus is stable. One of the patients had reached the hospital by driving his own car, said sources.

Title: Check posts increased on border with Maha
Content: Hyderabad: Hours before chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao decided to temporarily close the border with Maharashtra owing to a spurt in coronavirus cases in the neighbouring state, health officials have set up several check posts to screen passengers who come in by road. On Saturday, officials also increased the number of check posts from four to eight to intensify screening.Three new check posts have been set up at Kandukurti, Salura and Pothangal of Nizamabad district and another three in Asifabad at Venkatapuram, Wankidi and Gudem.Speaking to STOI, Asifabad DMHO Dr Komaram Balu said: “Our check posts are being manned by officials from police, health, transport and revenue department to screen those entering the state. Officials are deputed to check temperature and other symptoms, note down details of people and seek information of their travel history before we give them a clean chit to enter the state.”

Title: ‘Not given work from home option’
Content: Hyderabad: While the government is encouraging companies to offer work from home (WFH) to their staff, many firms in the city, especially multinational corporations (MNC), are yet to extend the option to their employees. Speaking to STOI, techies said that while a majority of them are waiting for allocation of laptops or desktops, in some cases their team leaders are not allowing them to work from home as they need to put in extra effort in managing teams.“Most of us have access to laptops, but even then, our firm is reluctant to give WFH as they are worried that it will have a negative impact on our work,” said an employee, whose office is located in Raheja Mindspace.An employee of an Indian MNC, working in its Manikonda branch, said at least 35% of employees are still forced to come to office every day. “My firm gave WFH option only to those employees, who own a laptop or got one allotted either by the company or client. The rest of us are forced to come to office,” said an employee, adding there are 12,000 employees on two campuses —Manikonda and Gopanapally — of the said firm.The Forum for IT employees said hardly 40% of firms are providing WFH option.Industry heads, meanwhile, said only those employees, who handle data center, security network operations, banking process or those bounded by client restrictions are still working from offices. “There is nothing the firms can do if they are bound by client restriction,” said Srikanth Srinivasan, senior director & head - Membership & Outreach, NASSCOM.

Title: Corpn intensifies efforts to contain Covid-19
Content:
Coimbatore: The city corporation has intensified the drive to create awareness on preventive measures to contain the spread of Covid-19 among the public. It has deployed about 800 workers for the purpose who would also disinfect public gathering places.

A source said the city corporation workers have been on a door-to-door campaign to sensitize people on precautionary measures by distributing pamphlets. “They are also creating awareness at bus stands in Ukkadam, Singanallur, Gandhipuram and on Mettupalayam road, railway station, integrated court premises, airport and corporation office in Town Hall.

Working in three shifts, the source said, the corporation workers have also been spraying disinfectants on bus stand premises, buses and at depots, railway station and other public gathering places. “Earlier, they used to disinfect temples and shopping complexes. Now that they are closed for public till March 31, they have been exempted.”

The source said the city corporation has set up screening centres at the airport, railway station and on court premises. “We are screening everyone for high temperature.”

The corporation workers had on Wednesday disinfected the premises of Nirmala College for Women at Race Course following a request to this effect from the college management. “We were concerned about the students, who were staying on the college premises, and we wanted to ensure their safety,” the source said.

The civic body had also set up a help desk at Ukkadam bus stand on Wednesday. A doctor, who is part of the help desk, said, “We are distributing pamphlets that details steps to be followed to prevent Covid-19 infection and hand washing techniques.”

The doctor said the screening cum help centre was set up at Ukkadam bus stand owing to the presence of buses bound to Kerala, where a large number of people were tested positive for Covid-19. “Since the district administration has sealed all the check posts on Tamil Nadu-Kerala border, a decision on whether to continue the help desk is yet to be taken.”

Meanwhile, villagers of Nathegoundenpudur in Karamadai block sprinkled turmeric power in a government bus, which they also decked up with neem leaves. Pointing out that both turmeric and neem leaves were considered as disinfectants, they justified their act by saying that was a precautionary measure to contain the virus spread.

Title: Corona scare dips crime graph in city
Content:
Nagpur: The coronavirus outbreak seems to be scaring the criminals too, as the crime incidents in city has decreased to some extent.

Speaking to TOI, DCP (crime) Gajanan Rajmane claimed that the crime trend in city has seen a decreasing graph in last few days. “Even the criminals might be fearing the outbreak and that is why they are afraid to leave their home. Also several police officials are regularly patrolling in the sensitive areas, so the crime incidents must have decreased for that reason too,” the DCP said.

As the whole city is under lockdown, the shopkeepers are scared that their establishment might be targeted by anti-social elements.

Sources said, that the closure of bars and wine shops has also helped in decreasing the crime rate in city as alcohol tends to increase aggression among the anti-social elements which can lead to fights or other criminal intents.

In the last few days, other than few burglaries and two robberies no major cases were reported in city.

“At present, police is on high alert due to the Covid-19 outbreak, but we are also keeping our informants active to keep tabs on miscreants in the city. The crime analysis from last few days clearly shows that there has been a decrease in the crimes in city. However, if citizens have any concern or fear about the anti-social elements, we are here to help them,” Rajmane further said.

“We will take stringent action against any person who tries to disturb peace in the city as Section 144 (of CrPC) is also been imposed in city.” he said.

Title: People take to social media to help elderly
Content:
Jaipur: As Covid-19 cases are on the rise across the state, people have taken to social media to offer help to those who are in other cities and are unable to come to Jaipur due to travel advisory.

Netizens have offered to personally check on the families in the state capital and provide basic supplies as well as medicines. Ashish Arora, who runs an automobile workshop, says, “Older people are advised to stay home to prevent catching the virus. There are many old people in the city whose family members are not living with them. We offer them help by shopping groceries from local stores, medicines and other household stuff.”

Soon, it became clear that the need for grocery delivery across the city was widespread, Arora on Saturday posted it on a social networking site in the hopes of expanding his movement. “I am glad, more than 25 people are willing to assist the elderly. If there are people like these in different areas of the city, more people can be helped without much travel,” Arora said.

Purchase of medicines and grocery might seem like routine chores, but it’s a task for many elderly after the advisory was issued in the city. People have to travel distances as all items are not available on one shop.

Rishi Singh, who is on a break from hotel management classes, too, is spearheading a free grocery delivery programme for old and needy who are at risk for contracting the novel virus. “So far, I have helped two people in Jaipur. I read an article on internet and copied the idea from the US, where students took the initiative and helped elderly people in this situation. After I posted it on my Facebook, I received two calls from friends living in different states,” Singh said.

Meanwhile, elderly people who have bought items on their own, requested the government to announce senior citizen hours in the shops to provide safe environment. Urmila Kumari, a resident of Vaishali Nagar says, “In other countries, a time slot for senior citizens was dedicated at stores so that they can buy stuff comfortably and it is the need of the hour for the same to be replicated here.”

Title: BJP MP accuses Kavitha of resort politics, gathering 400
Content: Hyderabad: Nizamabad BJP MP D Arvind sparked a major controversy by alleging that Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s daughter K Kavitha had gathered almost 400 people at a resort in Shamirpet at a time when the state government has banned large gatherings to counter Covid-19 Arvind tweeted a video of the purported gathering on Friday and alleged that it had been organised ahead of the April 7 legislative council election that Kavitha is contenting. All 400 are members of zilla parishads and mandal parishads who will be voting in the elections. TRS reacted sharply by stating that Arvind was circulating a fake video to point fingers at Kavitha.The video made by Armoor councillor Ganga Mohan Chakru shows several ZPTC and MPTC councillors partying in a room at Leonia Resorts in Shamirpet. Chakru later released another video stating that opposition parties were using an old video to make allegations against Kavitha.A video of the gathering that went viral on Saturday shows hundreds of people sitting on tables and having a feast. Arvind tweeted: “Weddings to Public Exams cancelled across the country. The footage is a political campaign organised by Ms.Kalvakuntla Kavitha, daughter of CM of Telangana, for her mere MLC election, risking more than 500 people & their families (exponential if their social contacts are considered). Irresponsibility, thirst for power and No regard to common man’s Life.”Chakru sent out a new video saying: “From yesterday a video is going viral making allegations that councillors from Armoor are partying in a resort. This is far from the truth. Around 20 days ago when I won as councillor, I threw a party for some of the councillors and MPTCs. The opposition party is using the video to tarnish Kavita’s image. There is no need of camp politics. TRS won 90 per cent of local bodies in Nizamabad..”Attempts by STOI to contact Kavitha failed. Her spokesperson said that councillor had said that the video in question was old. He also said that there was no camp conducted.

Title: Merchants sell livestock on road as Tamil Nadu government bans goat shandy
Content:
KRISHNAGIRI: Sheep and goat merchants, who usually sell meat at the goat shandy, have now started selling it on the road.

The goat shandy is held at Gundarapalli village in Krishnagiri district every year, a week before Telugu New year and celebrated on March 25.

However, the district administration has banned the shandy this year as a Covid-19 preventive measure to avoid mass gathering.

Gundarapalli village is situated close to Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka state borders.

“Nearly 75,000 goats and sheep is sold in that shandy and the total business usually crosses Rs 10 crore,” M Jayaraman, one of the merchants told TOI. He also said that, the goat shandy is the biggest and a famous one in the district.

On Friday morning, the goat and sheep owners, merchants started gathering at the shandy place at Gundarapalli. The officials from the district administration who came to know about this, chased all the owners and merchants away with their goats and sheep.

“I have brought 200 goats from Mecheri in Salem district and spent nearly Rs 10,000 for transportation. If I go back, I have to spend another Rs 10,000 which is a loss of Rs 20,000 . “So, I have started selling my goats on the roadside for meagre rate to minimise my loss,” M Kalidoss, a merchant said.

The goat and sheep owners and merchants have come from across the state and were unsuccessful in convincing the officials.

Assistant collector Deivanayaki, who was monitoring the situation said there was no option but to close the shandy due to Covid-19.

Finally, the sellers decided to sell their goats and sheep from outside the shandy ground. One goat which is usually sold for Rs 3,000 in the shandy was sold for Rs 1,800 as the villagers refused to give the demanded money. The merchants who didn’t have any option, sold the goats for meagre rates.

Title: IT sector scrambles for quick fixes to enable extensive WFH
Content: Hyderabad: With rising coronavirus threat necessitating social distancing and isolation, most IT companies are grappling with challenges in rolling out work from home (WFH) policy. Apart from acute shortage of laptops and dongles, other factors like logistics, shifting costs and infrastructure challenges are posing a hurdle.While over the past fortnight companies have been gearing up by conducting VPN load tests and even IT SEZ and STPI authorities have allowed shifting office desktops to employee homes, IT sector officials said it is easier said than done. “This is a humongous magnitude issue that can be sorted out over a period of time but we don’t seem to have that luxury so we are scrambling for solutions,” said an IT major’s top honcho.Cyient Ltd founder chairman BVR Mohan Reddy pointed out that implementing an extensive WFH involves multiple challenges like hardware and software installation as well as infrastructure like power backups and adequate bandwidth in addition to ensuring client security.Agreeing, HYSEA president Murali Bollu said: “Bandwidth and power outages are a major challenge in today’s WFH scenario. Thursday saw a major power outage after heavy rainfall. Many employees do not have power backup to ensure business continuity.”“We have been struggling to shift desktops to employee homes and have been doing it in a staggered manner. Yesterday we got a bill of about Rs 30 lakh for shifting 400 desktops as they can’t be taken in the back seats of cars, they need to be properly packed and installed,” said an IT top gun.Industry sources said nearly 30% of IT employees live in PG hostels, which not only lack necessary space and infrastructure but many are being asked to vacate by owners due to falling occupancies making it unviable to keep them running.

Title: SCR cancels 12 express, all passenger trains to mark ‘janata curfew’ today
Content:
Aurangabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has announced the cancellation of 12 express and 26 passenger trains on Sunday, which will be observed as ‘janata curfew’ as a symbolic gesture to fight the coronavirus across the country.

The cancelled express trains include Nanded-Bengaluru, Nanded-Amritsar, Nanded-Mumbai, Adilabad-Nanded, Nanded-Adilabad, Nagarsol-Narsapur, Nanded-Panvel, Nanded-Visakhapatnam, Jalna-Dadar, Dharmabad-Manmad, Nanded- Sri Ganganagar and Kachiguda-Narkher, an official release said.

In his address to the nation on Thursday night, Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged citizens across the country to observe ‘janata curfew’ by not stepping out of their homes from 7 am to 9 am on Sunday.

Chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh, said, “It is noticed that, in several instances, passengers who have been medically advised to remain in quarantine on the suspicion of Covid-19 symptoms, are travelling by trains instead of staying at home or in quarantine facilities. Such people have been detected on various routes and rushed to the nearest medical institutions en route,”

He said that quarantined people travelling by trains in contravention of medical mandate are creating unsafe conditions for fellow-passengers, railway staff as well as other staff on duty. Rail users are earnestly advised not to travel by trains if they have been advised to remain in quarantine or have any symptoms of the virus, like fever, cough and breathlessness, he said.

“If train travellers come across any such symptomatic co-passenger during the journey, they are requested to immediately bring it to the notice of railway authorities. It is to be understood that the fight against the spread of Covid-19 needs joint efforts,” Rakesh said.

The SCR has appealed to all the rail users to ensure that they act responsibly and support the endeavour of the Indian Railways for ensuring safe travel.

Title: Full police force to be on duty during Janata curfew: Telangana DGP
Content: HYDERABAD: Director-general of police (DGP) M Mahendar Reddy on Saturday said borders of Telangana will be closed for 24 hours due to ‘janata curfew’.Passenger and goods vehicles coming from neighbouring states will not be allowed into Telangana from 6am on Sunday to 6am on Monday.On CM K Chandrasekhar Rao’s directive to take action against those circulating objectionable messages on social media about PM Modi and his call to observe Janata curfew, the DGP told media that gave instructions to all commissioners and superintendents of police (SPs) to identify ‘mischievous’ persons and take action against them.The DGP requested all people to stay indoors except those in emergency services. “For 24 hours, all 63,000 policemen and 19,000 home guards would be performing duty,” he said.“By taking all stakeholders on board, we will make sure there will be no movement of vehicles and establishments will be kept closed. This will be done with the consent. As far as long distance inter-state vehicles are concerned, our state transport department officials had spoken to their counterparts in bordering states to make sure no vehicle enters Telangana. Inter-state borders will be sealed for 24 hours,’’ the DGP added.

Title: Quarantine-stamped caught on public transport in Maharashtra
Content:
MUMBAI: The city witnessed many cases of people with ‘home quarantine stamps’ on hands being caught during travel at railway stations, in trains and on buses from where they were sent to hospitals or handed over to the police or BMC. At CSMT, 16 persons with a home quarantine stamp were found by railway security agencies while they were preparing to board trains to travel to their respective homes.

“On enquiry, it was learnt they had landed from Dubai and had directly come to CSMT from the airport to go home to Madhya Pradesh, Kerala and other states,” said senior inspector Hemant Bavdhankar , CSMT GRP. Medical teams were informed and the 16 were taken away.

In another incident, Railway Protection Force personnel (RPF) at Lokmanya Tilak Terminus did not allow eight Dubai-returned people to board a train to Allahabad. They were instead sent to Andheri’s SevenHills Hospital quarantine centre.

At Kalyan station, RPF constable S N Mundey noticed a 30-year-old man with the home quarantine stamp. He told Mundey that he had a Dubai travel history and had come to the city from Azamgarh district in Uttar Pradesh on March 17. He was sent to a nearby hospital.

In another incident, two passengers, aged 27 and 42 years, who had arrived from Dubai, were forced to get off the Bandra-Surat intercity train at Virar station.

On noticing their ‘home quarantine stamps, fellow passengers pulled the train chain and complained to Western Railway officials. Railway cops told the two passengers to get off the train. The two later left for their destinations in Vadodara and Jamnagar by road.

A man who had returned from Qatar a couple of days ago and had boarded a train from Mumbai to Kalaburagi in Karnataka in Udayan Express was deboarded at Daund station after passengers raised an alarm about his constant sneezing and coughing.

A similar scene panned out in a BEST bus. A foreign national with a home quarantine stamp was found travelling in a BEST bus on route number 309 from Goregaon to Kurla on Staurday. The conductor and driver handed him over to the police near Jari Mari in Kurla.

Title: Ajmer dargah, Brahma temple to remain shut
Content:
Ajmer: The dargah of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishty has been closed down till March 31 to avoid any gathering. The Brahma temple in Pushkar was already closed down early this week. District administration has curtailed the permission to few khadims to perform daily rituals inside the dargah. Similarly, the Arti at Brahma temple will be on loud speaker so that devotees can hear it from their houses.

There are 31 patients suspected in Ajmer, who were quarantine at their houses. This, mostly includes students who have returned from different countries. One patient is in the ICU of JLN Hospital and his test reports have not yet arrived. Looking to the crisis in Bhilwara, Ajmer remained mostly closed. Different market associations have already decided to close their markets for two days so that there will be no public gathering.

Commissioner of Ajmer Municipal Corporation Chinmayee Gopal went for the inspection of dargah bazaar region and directed for spray and fogging in the area to avoid any infection. TNN

Title: Covid-19 threat: Tamil Nadu-Karnataka border closes in Krishnagiri, Erode districts
Content: KRISHNAGIRI/ERODE: The district administration in Krishnagiri and Erode has closed the Tamil Nadu-Karnataka border as directed by the state government to prevent the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19). However, vehicles carrying essential commodities would be allowed to cross the borders.Officials have been deployed at the check posts to screen the people travelling to the state from Karnataka and disinfect the vehicles.Krishnagiri collector S Prabhakar said they were allowing in only goods carriers that too after spraying disinfectants . “TN people will be allowed entry but only after thorough examination. Those having flu, sneezing, cough and temperature will be sent to government hospital for further examination.”He said nearly 50% of public transport between Karnataka and Tamil Nadu had already been cut . “Vehicles that are entering the district border near Jujuwadi will be sprayed with disinfectants.”The district administration has also brought out pamphlets mentioning the dos and don’ts to prevent Covid-19 spread. In Erode, officials are camping at Pulinzalur, a hamlet on TN-Karnataka border. They said only vehicles carrying essential goods will be allowed to enter the state from Karnataka and that too after spraying them with disinfectants. A total of eight check posts have been set up in the two districts .

Title: Breathalyser tests discontinued in attempt to protect traffic cops
Content: Vijayawada: In a move to prevent the spread of coronavirus and protect police personnel from getting infected, Andhra Pradesh police department has suspended the use of breathalysers . The department, however, stated that action will be taken against those caught driving recklessly under the influence of alcohol and will be sent to the nearest hospitals for medical check-up.DGP D Gautam Sawang said they are not suspending the drive against drunk driving. But, traffic police personnel should not conduct breathanalyser tests. The police will adopt alternative methods to register cases against those caught drunk driving.Speaking to TOI, additional deputy commissioner of police, traffic wing, Vijayawada, B Ravichandra said a few motorists have been refusing to take the breathalyser test citing that it could lead to the transmission of the disease. “We regularly conduct checks from 7pm till midnight. Following the outbreak of coronavirus, we have decided to suspend the use of breathalyser, however we will register cases against motorists, who are visibly drunk and are caught driving recklessly,” he added.Use of breathalysers will be discontinued until further orders. “We are trying to take all precautions and for the time keeping human contact to minimal. We have advised our traffic police personnel to use face masks and gloves, a senior police officer said.

Title: 2 swindle Rs 4.80cr, held
Content:
Coimbatore: Former secretary and president of Bellathi Primary Agricultural Cooperative Credit Society have been arrested for swindling Rs 4.80 crore. The city unit of commercial crime investigation wing police identified the accused as R Manoharan, 48 , of Periyathottipalayam near Bellathi, and K Murugaiyan, 69, of Mongampalayam.

An investigation officer said the malpractice was reported between 2015 and 2018 when Manoharan was the secretary of the credit society and Murugaiyan, its president.

In his compliant, J Franklin Thomas, district registrar, cooperative societies, Coimbatore circle, said the two had received deposits from the members of the society by issuing them fake receipts. “The duo swindled a lion’s share of those deposits and credited to the society only a meagre amount. They also misused the provision to provide loan against gold ornaments and misappropriated crores of rupees,” it said.

He said the fraud came to light during the audit, when officials realized Rs 4,80,50,385 was missing. The two were arrested on Friday and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody. “The credit society has already attached their houses and properties,” the officer said.

Title: Rajasthan: Two Covid-19 patients from Bhilwara critical
Content: JAIPUR: A doctor and a nursing staff, who were rushed from Bhilwara two days ago to Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital in Jaipur, are on ventilator support. They were first brought to a private hospital, but later they were shifted to SMS Hospital.They belonged to the same private hospital which has reported 11 Covid-19 cases so far in the past two days. According to SMS Hospital doctors, they have been provided with the same combination of medicines which they had provided to the Italian couple, who were cured of Covid-19. “We are giving them the same combination drugs such as lopinavir and ritonavir, which are useful in HIV treatment, oseltamivir, which is useful in swine flu treatment and chloroquine useful in malaria,” said a doctor of SMS Hospital.SMS Hospital is burdened with Covid-19 patients as it is not only taking care of patients tested positive for the disease in Jaipur but also of other parts of the state such as Jhunjhunu and Bhilwara. Currently, there are 12 patients of Covid-19, in the isolation hospital of Sawai Man Singh medical college.The jhunjhunu couple and their daughter, who were tested positive for the disease on March 18, are also undergoing treatment for Covid-19 in the same Isolation hospital. However, the doctors claimed that their condition is stable. “We are not giving them the combination antiretroviral drugs, which is also useful in HIV treatment. These drugs are given when the patient complaint of pneumonia and when he is critical . In case of Jhunjhunu couple, we have not given them these drugs as they are stable. They are provided with oseltamivir and chloroquine,” said an SMS hospital doctor.A board of doctors has also been constituted at SMS Hospital level which reviews the condition of the patients on daily basis.
