Title: Yavatmal cops resolve mystery of missing girl
Content:
Yavatmal: With the arrest of 40-year-old Gajanan Bhurke, Yavatmal LCB sleuths finally resolved the mystery that shrouded the missing minor girl of Mulava village in Pophali police station on Friday. The police exhumed the decomposed body of the deceased from the jungle near Patharwadi village.

According to LCB chief Pradeep Siraskar, Pophali police received a complaint from the father of the minor girl (8) saying that his daughter went missing from her school on March 12. Her bicycle was at the school. SP M Rajkumar set up a special task force under the leadership of APIs Nilesh Shelke and Shreekant Jindamwar who started the investigation with the help of the Pophali PSO Kailash Bhagat.

The youths of the village have too extended their support to the police. An eye witnesses told the cops that a man took the girl on his bike. Police saw the CCTV footage from which it was confirmed that Gajanan Bhurke was the man. They took Gajanan into custody and during interrogation he confessed to have lured the girl and taken her to a nearby jungle where he committed the heinous crime. He then strangulated the little girl and buried the body in the jungle.

Gajanan is the father of a friend of the deceased girl and took undue advantage of her acquaintance with his daughter. Police took Gajanan to the spot and exhumed the body with the help of doctors from GMCH, Yavatmal, who conducted the post mortem.

The accused has been remanded to police custody by the court. PSO Bhagat is investigating the case.

ends

Title: Covid-19 scare: Buses not to ply in Bihar till March 31
Content: Patna: The state government on Saturday suspended all bus services in the state, including interstate and inter-district buses, till March 31 as a preventive measure against Covid-19 pandemic.The state transport department has decided to stop the operations of city and other private buses as well as the services of interstate buses from Sunday (March 22) till March 31.Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the decision to stop interstate and city buses till March 31 has been taken as preventive measure and to follow the guideline of social distancing. The DMs concerned will take decsion to allow any bus in their respective districts in emergency situation “Buses operated by Bihar State Road Transport Corporation Limited (BSRTC) as well as private operators have been stopped with immediate effect. The interstate buses would also stop plying from Sunday onwards,” he said.“The instruction to ban bus services till March 31 has been issued to all the operators. The suspension order would be revoked only after the situation improves,” he said.On being asked how the department would ensure restriction on bus operators, Agarwal said district magistrates will monitor and take action against violators.“The salary of bus drivers and conductors will not be deducted for this period. Meanwhile, the passengers, who booked the bus tickets in advance from travel websites for interstate buses will get full refund for cancellation,” Agarwal said.There are about 125 city buses of BSRTC and 250 by private operators in Patna. BSRTC operates 20 interstate buses on Delhi and Jharkhand routes and private operators run more than 100 buses on Kolkata, Lucknow, Delhi, Agra and Jharkhand routes.Earlier, an order was issued on March 15 to suspend operation of buses from Patna and Gaya to Kathmandu and Janakpur till March 31.The district transport officers, motor vehicle inspectors and enforcement sub-inspectors of the respective districts have been instructed to ensure that public transport vehicles are being sanitized.

Title: ‘Emulate Kerala govt, give aid to unorganised sector’
Content:
Jaipur: In view of the coronavirus crisis in the state, representatives nine civil society groups, women's organizations and labour unions wrote a letter to chief minister Ashok Gehlot and demanded to make an announcement akin to the decisions taken by the Kerala government and provide immediate financial assistance and food to homeless, daily-wage labourers, construction workers, unorganized sector workers and the poor.

They demanded that elderly people should be next month's pension immediately and all the rural and urban unorganized sector workers should be given Rs 3000 per month as long as this crisis continues.

Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Thursday announced a Rs 20,000-crore financial package to tackle the crisis caused by the novel coronavirus pandemic. The package includes Rs 500 crore for health initiatives, and Rs 2,000 crore for loans, free ration, two month’s pension and payment of water, electricity bills was extended by one month.

They also demanded all prisoners convicted of of petty crimes should be sent home and screening of all the jail inmates must be done. Also, elderly prisoners should be sent home on parole. “If symptoms of coronavirus are seen in any of the prisons and there aren’t enough facilities in that jail, then the patient should be sent to Jaipur or Jodhpur central jail,” they wrote. In a letter to the CM, they have expressed concern over non-availability of works for construction workers and labourers working in mandis over the past one week.

Title: Gates to Tirumala shut, couple ties knot on road
Content:
Police congratulate the newlyweds

Tirupati: A couple tied the knot on the road before the Garuda statue at Alipiri in Tirupati on Saturday after the Lord Venkateswara temple was closed to devotees for a week on Friday.

The couple, from Avanigadda in Krishna district, had decided recently to get married at the Lord Venkateswara in Tirumala . Before getting married, they requested Tirupati urban police wing deputy superintendent of police (DSP) Naga Subbanna who was present there on bandobust duties, to act a ‘pelli-pedda’, an elder under whose dictum a wedding is carried out.

Title: Beed market shut after residents rush to stock up for ‘janata curfew’
Content:
Aurangabad: Citizens gathered in large numbers at the Beed vegetable market on Saturday, a day before the nationwide ‘janata curfew’, sending alarm bells ringing and forcing the district administration to shut the market at 12.30pm.

People thronged the market as soon as it opened at 7.30am. Many were seen strolling around without face mask or covering their faces with handkerchief.

“When we reached the market, there was a heavy rush as people got panicky due to the Sunday lockdown announced by the PM,” said Mohammed Salim Ahmed, a local resident.

Beed district collector Rahul Rekhawar said that the market was shut as soon as the administration found out about the crowding.

“While fruit sellers and grocery shops are open, the district administration has decided to close the vegetable markets as they are witnessing crowds. Street vendors will, however, be allowed to go door-to-door to sell vegetables and there won’t be any problem,” he said.

Rekhawar said that each of 11 taluka hospitals has 50 beds. At the district level, there are 150 beds. Hence, the total number of beds are 700 for quarantine purpose.

“There are 100 government and semi-government hostels vacant now. They are ready to be used as quarantine centres. This adds up to a huge number of quarantine beds in Beed district,” he added.

Title: No local transmission of Covid-19 in Nagpur: Div commr
Content: Nagpur: Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, on Saturday, made it clear that there is no local transmission of Covid-19 in any pocket of Nagpur so far.He rejected the report by a leading news agency in which it was claimed that government has changed testing strategy after 10 samples out of 1,300 tested in some pockets of Nagpur were found positive.“It’s wrong. Only four positive cases were reported in Nagpur at the beginning. Later, even after testing about 250 samples, not even a single positive case has been reported so far,” Kumar said.The divisional commissioner appealed to people not to trust rumours and continue to follow social distancing. He claimed that the government is well-prepared and arrangements for quarantine can be made for 4,000 people in Nagpur alone.As per the data provided by the district collector, 35 samples were received on Saturday which takes the total number of suspects tested in Nagpur till date to 247. Currently, 63 persons are in the quarantine facility at MLA Hostel while 729 persons are in home quarantine.

Title: Coronavirus in Madhya Pradesh: Chhatarpur prohibits entry of buses from outside
Content: BHOPAL: Following reports of four positive cases of coronavirus in Jabalpur, the collector of Chhatarpur has prohibited the entry of passenger buses from Jabalpur, Delhi and the neighbouring districts of Uttar Pradesh . Sheelendra Singh, the district collector, issued the orders in this regard.There are three suspected cases of coronavirus infection in the district and all of them have been quarantined in the district hospital at Chhatarpur. Incidentally, a large number of people travel from Chhatarpur to Jabalpur, about 240 kilometres away for a variety of reasons, including cases related to the high court.Also, a large number of labourers from different districts of Bundelkhand region migrate on a regular basis not only to Delhi, but also to the bigger cities of the neighbouring UP for work. Many of them are now returning home after lockdown in cities such as Agra and Delhi, district administration sources said.Meanwhile, there are three suspected cases of Covid-19 in Chhatarpur, one of them returned from Germany , the other from Dubai, while the third suspected carrier is a labourer by profession.“Those who had returned from abroad were quarantined for 14 days and their test reports were found to be negative. All of them have been discharged,” said civil surgeon Dr R S Tripathi. He said that a labourer from Hinauta village is still undergoing treatment at the hospital.“After he was seen sneezing at a farm field while cutting crops, the villagers beat him up and he was rushed to the hospital. He was sneezing because of inhaling some crop residues, but the villagers insisted that he was suffering from coronavirus,” Dr Tripathi added. “Though he was quarantined, he will be discharged tomorrow”, he said.

Title: Virus scare: Border check posts sealed
Content:
Coimbatore: As many as 14 interstate routes between Kerala and Tamil Nadu, including nine check posts on the border that were sealed off on Saturday, will remain shut for non-essential movement of vehicles and people till March 31.

Coimbatore collector K Rajamani, who visited the Walayar check post on Saturday, said only those vehicles carrying essential commodities such as medicines, milk, vegetables, fuel, and ambulances will be allowed to cross the border after the drivers and other personnel in the vehicles are subjected to Covid-19 screening. The vehicles will also be disinfected.

“People who travel between the states to attend important events such as funerals and those travelling for essential work in public transport will be allowed to cross after proper screening,” Rajamani said.

The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) has been operating very few buses to the neighbouring states due to reduced patronage.

The collector said even pedestrians who come though the border will be tested. “We have 10 medical teams for testing. If need be, we will deploy more teams,” he said.

Along with health officials, police personnel and revenue officials are also manning the border check posts.

Superintendent of police Sujith Kumar said 500 police personnel will be deployed at the check posts. “They will stop tourists and other passengers who come on non-essential travel,” he said.

Title: ‘Isolate kids with cough, fever at children’s homes’
Content:
Jaipur: The Rajasthan State Commission for Protection of Child Rights on Saturday wrote to principal secretary social justice and empowerment department and requested him to isolate those children living in private and state-run children’s homes, who are suffering from fever, cough and cold. It also asked the department to screen every student taking fresh admission.

The decision was taken by the commission’s chairperson Sangeeta Beniwal during a video conference with member Dr Shailendra Pandya, Dr Bijendra Singh and Prahlad Sahay.

In a letter to principal secretary social justice and empowerment Akhil Arora, the commissioner said, “It is requested to ensure that every child staying in the private and state-run child homes are protected from the spread of coronavirus. Therefore, it is expected from the department to isolate those children, living in the children homes, and are suffering from fever, cough and cold. The department should also screen all the students taking fresh admissions.”

Meanwhile, the commission has also taken a decision to ensure that 50% employees of the commission should work from home and not leave the headquarters. They officials have also been directed to work as per the new roster.

“The 50 per cent employees who are working at office must ensure that if they receive any coronavirus-related and other information with regard to children, they must immediately inform the control room and take immediate steps as per the directions of the government,” the order stated.

Title: Hotels need not shut operations: BMC
Content: MUMBAI: Tourist accommodation, including hotels , need not suspend operations, the BMC clarified on Saturday.The BMC has allowed hotels to stay open as long as they abide by social distancing rules. The clarification comes after restaurants and eateries were allowed to function, provided they ensure 50% customer capacity and maintain a three-foot distance between each patron.“Hotels can stay open as long as they follow the mandated procedures like checking body temperature and asking guests to wash hands regularly,” said Kiran Dighavkar, assistant commissioner, G-North Ward. “We have not given orders to shut hotels so far.” G-North covers areas in Mahim and Dadar.

Title: SCR dorms and retiring rooms close till April 15
Content: Vijayawada: In order to contain the spread of coronavirus and minimize travel-related risks, South Central Railway ( SCR ) zone has been continuously undertaking various measures, keeping the interests of rail users in mind.Continuing with a proactive approach, SCR will block or shut down all retiring rooms and dormitories at railway stations on the zone with effect from March 21 to April 15.In view of the same, all old and fresh bookings (online and manual) for allotment of retiring rooms and dormitories will stand cancelled. Passengers who have already made bookings will receive full refund.Authorities of SCR said co-operation of the public and rail users in particular would help the railways prevent the spread of coronavirus.So far, 142 samples have been tested in Andhra Pradesh, of which five samples proved positive, 130 tested negative and the results of seven are awaited.

Title: North Western Railway cancels all trains on Sunday, 1 international flight among 18 affected
Content: JAIPUR: The containment measures for Covid-19 continue to affect the air, road and rail traffic in the state. The North Western Railway , which cancelled 52 of its trains till March 31 on Saturday, declared to cancel all its trains for Sunday. The cancelled trains include 136 passenger trains and 100 mail/superfast trains. Due to poor passenger load, 18 flights — including one international and 17 domestic — remained cancelled.NWR announced that its 100 mail/express trains would remain cancelled from 4am to 10pm on Sunday. This means there would be no train operations between this period.Officials added that 136 passenger trains will stop running from midnight. “These 136 passenger trains plying on smaller distances would not operate from 12.00am to 10.00pm on Sunday,” the officer added.Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation decided to discontinue its bus operations in Pratapgarh and Chittorgarh districts. “Out of our 4,200 buses, which operate on a regular day, we are running only 2,400 buses due to poor passenger load,” Sudhir Bhati, manager, public relations said. Many flights have also been affected. “We had cancellation of 17 domestic flights and one international flight from Jaipur to Bangkok on Saturday,” said J S Balhara, director, Jaipur airport.

Title: Next week critical for Bhopal, says state’s Covid-19 team lead
Content: BHOPAL: “For Bhopal , the next week is critical to break the chain of COVID-19 spread. Everyone should take responsibility and stay at home. No just for a day on Sunday, but for longer duration,” said COVID-19 task force team lead and Gandhi Medical College (GMC) pulmonologist, Dr Parag Sharma , here on Saturday.Report of 17 samples of suspected COVID-19 patients is awaited.Experts like Dr Sharma stress that the contagion chain needs to be broken at the beginning stages. The only way to manage and avoid an outbreak is social distancing. “COVID-19 has entered MP. We need to take drastic measures. The more positive cases, the higher the risk,” he added.As a measure to keep, healthcare workers safe, effective from Sunday, all non-essential elective surgeries stand postponed in tertiary care hospitals from Monday till March 31. The advisory is from the Union government and adopted by state government.Furthermore, in Bhopal about 250 people who have a foreign travel history to COVID-19 impacted nations, are under observation by health department and tracked by police, said Bhopal collector, Tarun Pithode. “All the measures are proactive to keep the city safe from COVID-19,” he said. A non-functional medical college has been taken over by the district administration as a makeshift ‘quarantine and treatment facility’. Located in Kolar area, it has a 300-bed capacity.All hospitals have been instructed to carry out a preparedness drill on Sunday. Guidelines for this drill will be made available by the Union health ministry.Non-essential audits of hospitals by various regulators and accreditation agencies may be postponed. All hospitals must provide treatment free of cost to any medical personnel who pick up infection while treating patients. No suspected COVID 19 patient should be turned away from any hospital and the admission of any such patient should be notified to NCDC or IDSP immediately, it said.

Title: Two dead as car slams into container truck in Erode
Content:
Representational image

ERODE: Two men died when a car in which they were travelling hit a container truck at Nasiyanur in Erode district on Saturday. Two others also suffered injuries in the incident.

Police identified the deceased as K Palanisamy , 45, and his friend S Muthu, 46, both from Guruvareddiyur village.

On Saturday morning, the deceased, along with their friends M Velmurugan , 43, and K Selvam, 46, were heading to Perundurai in a car, a police officer attached with the Chithode police station said.

“Palanisamy, who was at the wheel, tried to overtake a container near Nasiyanur on the Salem-Coimbatore national highway.

The truck driver, however, swerved the vehicle to the left while changing lane. Palanisamy, immediately, applied the brake to avoid hitting the vehicle, but in vain. The car hit the truck from behind,” the officer said.

Palansamy and Muthu succumbed to their injuries on the spot, the officer added.

Passersby took the injured to the government hospital in Perundurai. After being alerted, the Chithode police reached the spot and sent the bodies to the hospital for postmortem. Police are yet to identify the truck.

Police have registered a case and further investigation is on.

Title: Major industries in city to follow ‘Janta Curfew’ protocol
Content:
Aurangabad: More than 90 percent of manufacturing units in Aurangabad will be closed on Sunday as a precautionary measure ahead of the ‘ Janta Curfew ’.

The shutdown directive on Saturday could not be followed as the notification was issued late on Friday night, the industry representatives said.

According to Mukund Kulkarni, the chairman of Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), Marathwada zonal council, there has been no apprehensions from the industry regarding the two-day shut down by the administration. “Close to 75 percent of the industries have shifted their weekly offs to Sunday. The observation of bandh will be seen by more than 90 percent industries,” he said.

He said that any government notification on shut down allows exemption of pharmaceutical industries. “Such industries cannot shut the operations. In addition, there are certain machines that take two days to close down and up to five days to restart. Such companies fall in the less than 10 percent category, which will not be able to participate in the shutdown,” he added.

CP Tripathi, the CSR head of Bajaj Auto on Saturday confirmed that all units in Aurangabad will be closed on Sunday. Being an anchor industry, its closure would lead to the closure of around 150 ancillary units in the city.

Even after receiving a late notification on Friday, most industries had shut their operations by Saturday afternoon.

Ashish Garde, director of Magic, the start-up incubation wing of Chamber of Marathwada Industries and Agriculture (CMIA), said that they would have followed the Saturday the closure had they received an earlier notification. “We made sure that most industries closed down their operations by Saturday afternoon,” he said.

Industry taking precautions

According to Garde, the companies are allowing employees to work from home and for the staff in production, necessary precautions are being taken. “There are thermal screenings being conducted for the workers? Those who are having fever are asked to stay home. Sanitisers are placed at entrances and masks are provided. Visitors entry is restricted and government guidelines on minimum distance between two people are observed,” he added.

Title: No new positive case reported in Vidarbha
Content: Nagpur: Even as Maharashtra recorded 12 new patients of Covid-19 on Saturday, no positive case has been reported in Vidarbha since March 16. As on Saturday, there are seven positive patients — four in Nagpur and three in Yavatmal — from the region.A resident of Yavatmal, having a travel history to Congo, was tested positive in Mumbai on Saturday. This patient has been admitted in Mumbai. Since he is a resident of Yavatmal, his name was added to the list of patients from Yavatmal by the government.Nagpur recorded no new positive patient on Saturday. The four patients being treated in isolation wards of the government hospitals are recovering fast.Eight samples were tested in the first batch at the IGGMCH lab on Saturday. These include two from Gadchiroli, four from Akola, and one each from GMCH and IGGMCH. All eight tested negative.Second batch had 15 samples from across Vidarbha. These included four from GMCH, three from IGGMCH, two from Gadchiroli, three from Sewagram, and one from Bhandara. GMCH Yavatmal also sent samples of two admitted patients for seventh-day test. These 15 samples were being tested on Saturday and results were expected on Sunday.Sources at GMCH informed that four new suspects reported at the hospital on Saturday. They included a 19-year old girl having travel history to London. She returned on March 16 and was experiencing sore throat from last 10 days. One suspect is a 22-year-old man who returned from Thailand on March 5. He is suffering from sore throat, cough and cold.Two male suspects, 38 and 31 years respectively, got themselves admitted to GMCH on Saturday. They are among the close contacts of positive patients admitted to GMCH. Their samples were sent for testing at IGGMCH and reports are awaited.In Yavatmal, two new suspects were admitted to isolation ward in the last two days. According to district collector M Devendar Singh, one suspect was admitted on Saturday, and another on Friday. “Their swab samples have been sent to IGGMCH, Nagpur,” Singh said.In Akola, four students having Bangkok travel history submitted their swab samples on Friday. The samples have been sent to Nagpur and results are awaited.

Title: Pvt school conducts special class, served show-cause notice
Content:
Coimbatore: The district school education department has sent a show-cause notice to a private school in Madukkarai for making Class X students attend special class, ignoring the orders that all schools should remain closed till March 31.

Coimbatore chief education officer P Usha said the school had made 10 students attend the class early this week. “The department will send a communication to all schools in the district to adhere to the safety measures being taken by the state to battle the Covid-19 pandemic. We have asked all schools to send home students residing in hostels, except for those who have to write board exams. Schools should set up proper safety measures. If the homes of hostellers, who have board exams, are within a reasonable distance, we have asked the schools to send them home.”

The department has also asked schools to equip themselves with sanitisers and advise children to use handkerchiefs. “They should not assemble students. Block-level education officials have been ensuring private schools practice the instructions,” the official said.

“If students who write exams have severe symptoms, schools should inform their parents and take the children to doctors,” said the CEO.

To ensure safety, examination halls have been sanitised with the help of municipal workers and health workers, Usha said. “Students and teachers on exam duty have also been instructed to wash hands using sanitisers. There are seven teams on exam duty and a standing squad of two personnel per centre. They ensure that the safety measures are followed.”

Title: Hyderabad: 19-year-old held for kidnap, sexual assault
Content:
Hyderabad: A 19-year-old student was arrested by Chandrayangutta police for allegedly kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 14-year-old victim. The accused, a class 12 student from Mehdipatnam, was known to the victim. On Wednesday, the accused allegedly took the victim to Gulbarga in Karnataka. Following which, the victim’s father lodged a missing complaint with Chandrayangutta police. According to police, two teams were formed and the accused and victim were traced.

The police, during investigation, found that the victim was allegedly sexually assaulted by the accused. Cops arrested the accused and booked him for rape and under POCSO Act. TNN

Title: North Western Railway cancels all trains on Sunday, 1 international flight among 18 affected
Content: JAIPUR: The containment measures for Covid-19 continue to affect the air, road and rail traffic in the state. The North Western Railway , which cancelled 52 of its trains till March 31 on Saturday, declared to cancel all its trains for Sunday. The cancelled trains include 136 passenger trains and 100 mail/superfast trains. Due to poor passenger load, 18 flights — including one international and 17 domestic — remained cancelled.NWR announced that its 100 mail/express trains would remain cancelled from 4am to 10pm on Sunday. This means there would be no train operations between this period.Officials added that 136 passenger trains will stop running from midnight. “These 136 passenger trains plying on smaller distances would not operate from 12.00am to 10.00pm on Sunday,” the officer added.Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation decided to discontinue its bus operations in Pratapgarh and Chittorgarh districts. “Out of our 4,200 buses, which operate on a regular day, we are running only 2,400 buses due to poor passenger load,” Sudhir Bhati, manager, public relations said. Many flights have also been affected. “We had cancellation of 17 domestic flights and one international flight from Jaipur to Bangkok on Saturday,” said J S Balhara, director, Jaipur airport.
