Title: People told to avoid repeated visits to fuel stations, pumps to remain open
Content:
Aurangabad: The Petrol and Diesel Association (PDA), Aurangabad, has appealed to people to get their vehicles filled to the capacity of the fuel tank so as to avoid frequent visits to the petrol pump.

The rush at petrol pumps had slightly increased on Saturday evening, they said.

At a time when the government has issued an advisory asking people to avoid large gatherings and crowding at public places, the sudden rush at petrol pumps in the city is a reason for worry, said PDA authorities.

They said that since fuel is an essential commodity, petrol pumps in the city will continue to work. However, the rush of people not only pose a threat to fellow motorists but also to the staff at fuel stations.

Aqueel Abbas, PDA secretary, said, “The current footfall at petrol pumps puts everybody’s health at risk.”

According to PDA, those having two-wheelers are advised to fill petrol of at least Rs 200 at one go, Rs 300 for three-wheelers and full tank for four-wheelers.

For rickshaws running on diesel, it is recommended that petrol worth Rs 300 should be filled at one go. Transport lorries have been recommended to fill petrol worth Rs 1,000 and full tank for buses and trucks.

This move will restrict frequent visits of people at fuel stations, the association members said.

Petrol pump owners said that practising these recommendations on a usual basis will also ensure reduction in overall fuel costs, time and additional trips to the fuel station.

According to motor mechanic Raees Siddiqui, he has been saving Rs 300 to Rs 500 a month since he has started to fill his motorcycle’s fuel tank to its capacity. “If you fill the tank to its full capacity, there is a reduction in evaporation and less fuel is exhausted,” Siddiqui said.

Meanwhile, petrol pump owners have appealed to the people not to indulge in panic purchasing as fuel stations fall under essential commodities category and the retail outlets will remain open even during the shutdown.

Title: 4-acre defence land to be used as dumpyard
Content:
Secunderabad: A four-acre defence land near dairy farm (abutting to national highway-44) and located at Cantonment outskirts has been allotted to Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) for using as dumpyard. The SCB had been struggling for more than a decade to identify suitable land.

The decision to allot defence land for dumpyard was taken during board meeting on Saturday. “President of cantonment board (PCB), Brigadier Abhijit Chandra, replied to a query on this issue raised during the meeting,” SCB deputy CEO, Vijay Kumar Balan Nair, said.

Nair also said that currently, the open area of Mahatma Gandhi Community Hall at Trimulgherry is being used as dumpyard for more than three years and is likely to be shifted to the newly identified defence land in a month. However, Trimulgherry residents held protests over shifting of dumpyard and SCB ward member Bhagya Shree also raised the issue in board meetings.

About other decisions, Balan Nair said, “The PCB decided to convene a special meeting next week to tackle water problems in ensuing summer and asked SCB ward members to come up with proposals and plan of action. Members of wards III, V and VI had raised the water problem.”

As per the Ministry of Defence (MoD) instructions, new Cantonment Board Account Rules, 2020, will be implemented in SCB from April 1. Till date, we were implementing the Cantonment Account Code, 1924, during process of accounts systems. A software will also be developed for the preparation and maintenance of accounting records under the double entry based accrual method, he added.

Earlier, SCB CEO SVR Chandra Sekhar said the Board has sanctioned a building plan to construct a new building at Karkhana. On March 16, a building collapsed while it was being demolished and led to death of a person. In fact, SCB has imposed a penalty of Rs 2 lakh for flouting the Cantonment Act rules and regulations in demolition of the structure.

Title: Foresters filling ponds in STR to avoid man-animal conflicts
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

ERODE: Forest officials attached to Asanur forest division in the district are filling ponds in the Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve ( STR ) to help wild animals quench thirst and prevent them from straying into human habitats in search of water this summer.

Officials with Thalavadi, Asanur, Kermalam and Jeerahalli forest ranges said they have been taking water from various parts of the district to the ponds in STR through trucks.

Pointing out that all the water bodies in STR had gone dry due to scorching heat in the district, K Sivakumar, forest ranger, Thalavadi forest range, said due to water shortage animals had started entering the villages and hamlets that were close to the tiger reserve.

“Animals like elephants, deer, bears, Indian gaurs and leopards would come out of STR if the ponds don’t have sufficient water for them. If enough water and fodder are available in the forest, they are unlikely to stray into the plains.”

The official said instances of man-animal conflict would intensify if animals were to stray into the plains. “This could be avoided if the water bodies have sufficient water. We will refill the water bodies twice a week.”

He said they were also monitoring the movement of animals using CCTV cameras.

Wild animals are mostly found in T N Palayam, Thalavadi, Bargoor, Asanur, Dhimbam and Bhavanisagar forest ranges in the district.

Title: Aurangabad pharmacist booked for illegally repacking sanitisers
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Kranti Chowk police have booked a city-based pharmacist on late Friday night on the charges of cheating after he was caught red-handed by the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) while repacking and relabelling of sanitisers.

They also slapped relevant sections of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act 1940 on him. The complaint was lodged by Varsha Mahajan (39).

FDA authorities said that the received a tip-off about the repacking of sanitisers in small containers and illegally pasting of fresh stickers on them. Following the tip-off, the team rushed to Samarthnagar-based pharmacy store ‘Sohanda Medicos’ on March 16. They raided the place only to find that sterillium hand disinfectant was being repacked in smaller containers without due permission or knowledge of the appropriate authorities.

FDA team also found that the stickers being labelled on the repacked containers did not have all the mandatory details of the product including license number, date of manufacturing, date of expiry, packing size, manufacturer’s name, address and other relevant details.

The probe that followed the raid revealed that the pharmacist had purchased large quantity of sterillium disinfectant and considering the sudden surge in demand for sanitisers, was allegedly refilling smaller containers of 50 ml each and labelling them for selling them in open market.

Title: Security firm worker kills self after tiff with wife
Content:
Hyderabad: A 30-year-old private security firm employee committed suicide by hanging, reportedly after a tiff with his wife at LB Nagar in the early hours of Saturday. Police registered a suspicious death case.

The deceased was identified as Syed Anwar, a native of Thiruvuru village near Vijayawada in Andhra Pradesh. He was staying along with his wife Syed Nazeema Begum and two children, a 9-year-old daughter and 5-year-old son at LB Nagar .

“On Friday night, Anwar and his wife Nazeema had a tiff over his alcohol addiction. We suspect that after the fight, he was upset and took the extreme step,” LB Nagar inspector Ashok Reddy said. Anwar committed suicide by hanging himself from the ceiling fan on Saturday. His wife noticed the body and alerted police. The body was shifted to Gandhi Hospital for an autopsy and a case was registered under Section 174 of the CrPC.

Title: 3 booked for trying to create communal rift
Content:
Coimbatore: Tamil Nadu Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam founder president B John Pandian was booked for hate speech on Friday.

At a meeting that was jointly organized by Vishwakarma Community and Federation of Tamil Nadu Hindu Organizations on Raja Street here on the night of March 14 in support of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register and National Register of Citizens, John Pandian had targeted the Muslim community.

As his speech was inflammable enough to a create rift between the Hindu and Muslim people, city police commissioner Sumit Sharan had directed the Variety Hall Road police to take action against Pandian, who was subsequently booked under Sections 153(A) and 505 (i) (c) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Two others were also booked on Friday for posting hatred messages on Facebook.

While Chennai-based Kalyan Raman said in his message that communal tension was brewing in Coimbatore and that something was going to be happen in Tamil Nadu, Shajahan Abdhul Kadhar in his FB post said if sangh parivar people attacked Muslims, the victims should stand united and fight back the Hindutva people, instead of approaching police.

Both the Kalyan Raman and Kadhar were booked under Section 505 (2) of the IPC, by the Rathinapuri police and Big Bazaar Street police, respectively.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
Hyderabad: In a suspected case of drunken driving, a car which was travelling at high speed end up hitting a parked ambulance and an electric pole in the wee hours of Saturday at Meerpet. In this incident three persons travelling in the car suffered bleeding injuries.

The car was travelling towards Sagar Ring road from Gurramguda in a drunken state. All the three persons, who got injured were admitted in the hospital, where the accident took place. The damaged ambulance belong to the same hospital. The CCTV footage showed that the car was driven at a high speed.

end//

Title: Rush at markets to stock up on veggies
Content:
CLEARED SKHER

Aurangabad: All businesses, except essential services, across the eight districts of Marathwada downed shutters on Saturday in response to the administration order. City buses too remained off the road and kept a check on the number of people stepping out of their homes.

Despite the assurances from the government agencies, people made a dash to grocery stores , milk centres and vegetable markets for quick purchase ahead of the ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has appealed to citizens to be responsible citizens and stay at home on Sunday through a self imposed curfew.

As citizens crowded vegetable and fruit markets in Shahgunj, Mukundwadi, Jadhavwadi, Gulmandi and Osmanpura in Aurangabad city, the prices were slightly higher than usual.

Aurangabad city police authorities used the public announcement systems on their official vehicles to make announcements and appeal to people to abstain from making rush at public places including markets.

For the motorists stopping at key signals in the city, a large number of traffic policemen ran awareness campaign about the importance of washing hands and taking precautions in dealing with the COVID-19.

In Aurangabad rural, police authorities were found taking extra efforts to put a check on large gathering of people at market places. The police even made the vegetable markets to wind up their operations a bit earlier, to bring a check on heavy rush.

Responding to the district administration’s orders, rural areas in different districts of Nanded, Hingoli, Parbhani, Latur, Jalna, Osmanabad and Beed called off the important weekly markets, including fruit markets on Saturday.

At some places, however, the markets were put off only after the intervention of the local authorities. Majority of the business establishments in these districts positively responded to the orders and kept the hotels, restaurants, joints and other business establishments closed.

Title: Industrial estates disinfected
Content:
Coimbatore: Industrial estates in the district have taken up precautionary measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19 by spraying disinfectants on the premises.

Representatives of the Coimbatore Sidco Industrial Estate Manufacturer’s Welfare Association (Cosiema) on Saturday started an initiative to spray disinfectants in the Sidco Industrial Park in Kurichi.

Along with Nallaram Foundation, a service organization, Cosiema plans to spray 500 litres of disinfectants in and around the estate, president P Nallathambi said. “There are 250 industrial units in the estate. It will take three days to disinfect all of them. On Saturday, we disinfected offices, banks, shops, and other common facilities on the estate and have moved on to disinfecting individual industrial units. We would complete disinfecting the units in a couple of days,” he said. “The association members themselves have been spraying disinfectants.”

The units had undertaken precautionary measures such as providing workers with masks and hand sanitisers over the last two weeks.

Meanwhile, amid the slump due to Covid-19, several MSME associations have requested the Centre to give them a moratorium to pay GST and repay bank loans.

Title: Bhopal: Loudspeakers blare ‘cure of Covid-19’
Content: BHOPAL: Amid the concerns about Coronavirus hitting Madhya Pradesh , factually misleading information about cure of COVID-19 was being announced through public address systems on city roads here on Saturday. The DJ vehicles owners played recorded messages on orders of the local police stations.However, when contacted district health and administration officials said the message was not approved by them.“Three patients with COVID-19 in Rajasthan were treated with anti-HIV drugs and the world is taking notice this achievement’ announced loudspeakers fitted in DJ vehicles. The violation of noise pollutions norms apart, the voice over by a well-known artist, quoted Rajasthan government’s additional chief secretary and stated – ‘the world is taking notice of the cure of COVID-19 in India’.Since the claims by Rajasthan doctors was publicised, the Indian Council Of Medical Research (ICMR) has stated, “There is no current evidence from randomised controlled trial to recommend any specific treatment for COVID-19 patients.”“The message was not from district collector and health department,” said Bhopal CMHO Dr Sudhir Dheriya A DJ vehicles, going by the name, star events, played the message all across CM house, New Market and Jehangirabad through the afternoon. “We have been provided the taped message to play along with diesel,” said the vehicle driver. “Most of the DJ vehicles have been ordered to report to nearby police station,” said another DJ vehicle owner, Rajesh Sahu.

Title: RTO official, 2 others booked for cheating
Content:
Aurangabad: The Vedantnagar police on Friday booked an RTO official and two others on the charges of cheating after they allegedly transferred a car despite the fact that the owner had already died.

A complaint in this regard was lodged by Prashant Dattuprasad Sarosiya (40), a resident of the Kelibazar area of the city.

Sources said that no arrests have been made so far. The process of collecting all official records from the RTO office would begin from Monday, following which role of each suspect named in the case would be ascertained before the process to arrest them is initiated.

According to sources, Sarosiya had given the said car to an acquaintance on rental basis. The vehicle was registered in his father’s name. It was recently after his father’s death that Sarosiya tried to get the vehicle back, but the person who had rented it, began avoiding him.

Suspecting his behaviour, Sarosiya reached out to the RTO office to check for the records of the vehicle. At the time, he found out that the person had allegedly forged Sarosiya’s deceased father’s signatures and got the vehicle transferred in connivance with the RTO official and one more person. Left with no option, the man approached the police.

A couple of months back, an RTO official was booked on the charges of cheating, forgery and criminal conspiracy after he illegally passed several vehicles without being authorised to do so.

Title: SHE Teams in Cyberabad registers 75 cases in Feb
Content:
Hyderabad: The SHE team , Cyberabad, registered 75 cases in February alone, of which 19 were identified as criminal cases. In one case, a 29-year-old teacher of a private school was nabbed for misbehaving with a student.

According to SHE Team, the accused, Errola Prakash, a physics teacher, called the victim, a class X student on the pretext of special classes. The accused allegedly took her to a classroom, touched her inappropriately and misbehaved with her. One of the teachers, who saw the incident on CCTV footage, alerted the police. The accused was booked for sexual harassment and relevant sections of the POCSO Act. In another incident, a 16-year-old juvenile was taken into custody recently for molesting a five-year-old neighbour. The victim, a resident of Dundigal, complained of stomach pain soon after she came back from playing outside. The next day, the girl revealed that the 16-year-old lured her to his house and touched her inappropriately. The victim’s family approached the police and registered a complaint. The accused was nabbed and remanded for judicial custody.

A total of 231 complaints were received from women victims during February. TNN

Title: Centre assesses damage to tourism & hospitality industry
Content:
Aurangabad: The Centre has initiated steps to assess the damage caused to the tourism industry in the region by the Covid-19 outbreak.

The tourism ministry has approached important bodies such as the Federation of Associations in Indian Tourism & Hospitality (FAITH), Indian Association of Tour Operators (IATO), Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) and World Travel and Tourism Council (WTTC) for the survey.

“The relief measures for the tourism and hospitality industry — to overcome the impact of Covid-19 — have been examined by the ministry. Additional information is required to quantify the damage in financial terms,” Meenakshi Mehta, the deputy director general with the tourism ministry, said in a letter to the travel and tourism bodies.

The Centre has sought details on loan exposure of tour operators and travel agents to ascertain and quantify the amounts involved.

It has also sought details on quantification of interest of loans sought for rebuilding tourism and hospitality-related businesses and a doubling of overdraft facility.

These details are expected to be compiled by March 23. In addition, the Centre has also sought clarification on statutory compliances required for tour operators and transport operators. The postponement of these could benefit the industry.

Jaswant Singh, the president of the Tourism Promoters’ Guild, said the Aurangabad Tourism Development Foundation has urged the ministries of tourism and finance to bail out the stakeholders.

“We need an immediate moratorium of 12 months on loans, EMIs and a deferment of statutory taxes such as GST and corporate tax. Aurangabad, known as the tourism capital of Maharashtra, has been hit hard by the Covid-19 outbreak. Many tourist sites are now closed,” he said.

Title: Spectators play a role too in the theatre of cricket
Content:
BENGALURU: It isn’t uncommon to hear of enriched spectator experience at mega sporting events. Media and technology have been augmenting the fan’s engagement with the game not only when he’s at home, but also when he’s at the venue. Elaborate opening and closing ceremonies, giant screens showing highlights and replays or live analyses and statistics on your phones have helped the cricket-lover. After all, everybody, even the TV viewer, loves a packed stadium with exuberant fans because it adds to his thrill.

Long before the cricket buff watched the game on his mobile phone or television set, there was immense joy of seeing the action live or listening to “running commentary” on the radio. The generation that has witnessed many contests at the Central College Grounds – or even from the early 1970s when the matches shifted to Chinnaswamy Stadium – will vouch they got their money’s worth, under the bamboo shades.

The spectator of the 1960s and 70s was more of a student of the game. Everything about his routine was diligent and punctilious: packing his paraphernalia consisting of a cloth cap, a thermos flask filled with coffee, water bottle, pocket transistor and a pair of binoculars; meticulous filling up of score sheets; the laborious shelling of groundnuts; husky shouts mixed with ululations and of course, his awestruck wonderment at the flannelled men. Going to the games was a ritual, a community activity that involved an early morning bath, long waits in queues hours before the first ball was bowled, settling down with friends or family for a quick breakfast as soon as they could grab a place. The older members enjoyed the privilege of the binoculars and the youngsters, ears cocked to the radio commentary, pencilled in the scores. On the return journey home when everyone was tired and brown as a berry, the young ones sportingly lugged the baggage, sometimes freeing their hands to rehearse a Jaisimha drive. The cricket remained for days; an imitation GRV square cut could slice the air frequently. Perhaps more commonly than trying out Dev Anand’s sloping gait or Clint Eastwood’s quiet saunter.

In the gallery where many had to watch the game standing on aching legs, the mood was lifted every time there was good cricket. When a drive came crashing in to the boundary, spoons drummed on tiffin boxes and feet shuffled in excitement, leaving an eddy of dust over fine leg. Yet if you rubbed your eyes, it was also in amazement.

Down history, specifically during the Bombay Quadrangular (1912-1936), cricket was a happening event for privileged class. As Australian historian Richard Cashman wrote in “The Indian Crowd”, it was where social distinctions could be seen. “While the less privileged squatted on the ground, sat on chairs, or on the overhanging branches of trees in Bombay, the elite graced the shamianas or remained in the carriages which lined the eastern boundary having been shunted there the night before,” he said.

Even earlier, in 1895 when the Presidency (the Europeans) played the Parsis, newspaper reports spoke of a clear segregation of the spectators: the military on one side, European and Parsi ladies on another and on yet another, “a motley crowd of natives”. Writing about the carnival-like atmosphere of the Pentagular series, Cashman describes a self-appointed Parsi entertainer called Charlie who amused the crowd when action on the field was dull. Charlie was known to even rush to the ground to garland players, but never disturbed the game.

That was an era when appreciation was largely subdued and discreet. A reminder of village cricket in England where the only occasional cries were that of “Howzat!” from the close-in cordon and a soft chorus of Oohs and Aahs or “Catch it” from the crowd. The most pleasant one was of “Bowlingggg” after a near-miss of the bat.

Decades later, you heard of crowd frenzy that included a couple of incidents in Bangalore too. In February, 1969, the Central College Grounds hosted a semi-final Ranji Trophy match between Mysore and Bengal. Mysore, needing 222 to win, collapsed to 20 for 6, and suddenly after tea, a section of irate spectators, flung missiles, broke chairs and dug up the pitch. What sparked the rioting apart from the pathetic display of batting was the umpire’s decision to give Budhi Kunderan out. Many thought that the Mysore opener, who had shaped defensively at a Subroto Guha outswinger, hadn’t nicked it to the keeper. Play was abandoned.

Old-timers talk of other overwhelming memories of the Central College ground – among them, watching Bill Lawry’s star-studded Aussie team playing South Zone in 1969 or a Central Zone vs South Zone match in 1967 which saw Budhi Kunderan and Salim Durrani blazing away. Newspapers carried an interesting snippet of the first match about an amateur trumpeter in the schools gallery who played pop music and earned Ian Chappell’s admiration.

— Jayanth Kodkani

Title: HC sets aside 1-yr suspension imposed on 2 NIT students
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice T Vinod Kumar of the Telangana high court has set aside the one-year suspension imposed by National Institute of Technology (NIT), Warangal on two of its BTech first-year students their misconduct and directed the authorities to confine the suspension period to one semester instead of the whole academic year. On their part, the two students have to participate in service activities like feeding the poor at Sri Ramakrishna Seva Samithi, Hanamkonda, for two months.

On Oct 26, 2019, the two students consumed ganja and were caught by the security personnel. Subsequently, they were suspended from college for 2019-20. They were barred from attending classes and taking examinations. A penalty of Rs 1 lakh was slapped on each of them as well. Later, the senate confirmed the decision of the officials, which was challenged before the high court by the students and their parents.

While agreeing with the argument of the varsity that discipline is something that cannot be compromised, the judge, however, pointed out certain discrepancies in the varsity’s version of the story. On one hand, NIT said that the two students admitted their guilt, gave an undertaking that they would not commit such a mistake again and even urged the authorities to forgive them. Having said so, the authorities said in their suspension order that they found no remorse in the conduct of the students. The judge, however, rejected the allegation of the students that the authorities were biased against them.

The judge also sent out a stern message to the erring students, by agreeing with NIT to some extent and asked the two students to stay out of the campus.

Title: MIT introduces ‘learn from home’
Content:
Aurangabad: Amid shut down of education sector due to Covid-19 outbreak across the country, MIT group of institutions in the city has introduced a novel ‘ learn from home ’ facility for students .

MIT Director General Munish Sharma said that monetary losses can be replenished, but academic losses were hard to overcome.

“We have already closed our institutions from March 16 till March 31 as per official order, but the academic loss faced by students was a constant reason for worry. The issue has been addressed using a new online home-learning facility made available for students through the enterprise resource planning (ERP), a business process management software,” he said.

Title: Covid-19: Tamil Nadu officials have tough time stopping vehicles from Kerala at border
Content: KANYAKUMARI: Day after chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami announced restricted movement from neighbouring states to Tamil Nadu till March 31 to curb Covid-19 spread, officials from the health department and the Kaliyakkavilai police in Kanyakumari district faced a tough time stopping vehicles from Kerala entering the state through the checkpost on the border at Kaliyakkavilai on Saturday.On Friday evening, the chief minister in a statement said that only ambulances and vehicles carrying essential commodities like milk, petrol, diesel, vegetables, medicines and gas cylinders, other goods carriers and light motor vehicles with commuters for unavoidable circumstances such as death will be allowed to enter Tamil Nadu. He also said that only limited movement of buses will be permitted.But, at the Kaliyakkavilai RTO checkpost, almost all vehicles bearing Kerala registration numbers were allowed. “We had a tough time when we asked all the vehicles with Kerala registration to return. They argued that they are working in bordering areas in Kanyakumari and that they should be allowed after a temperature check,” an official said.Following heated arguments with commuters from Kerala, officials started checking all the TN and Kerala registration vehicles from Kerala and allowed them to enter after checking their temperature. Of the hundreds of vehicles screened, around 10 to 15 were forced to return to Kerala.Those with fever symptoms were requested to be under home quarantine and allowed to enter Tamil Nadu. Two passengers who had landed at the Thiruvananthapuram airport from abroad on Saturday morning and were heading to their homes in Tamil Nadu were referred to the GH.Vehicular movement was limited at the Puliyarai checkpost in Tenkasi district and only goods carriers carrying essential commodities were allowed to cross the border.

Title: NMC transfers 174 surplus teachers to other departments
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has started transferring surplus teachers from the education department to the other departments which are facing shortage of staff.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe transferred 174 surplus teachers from the education department to the property tax, census and advertisement/market departments a couple of days ago. Nearly 134 of the total 174 teachers have been transferred to the property tax department while 20 to census department and the remaining 20 to the advertisement/market department.

The NMC has 366 surplus teachers. Chances of a similar transfer of the remaining surplus teachers in the coming days cannot be ruled out.

The NMC has 3,000 sanctioned teachers. At present, 1,121 teachers are active. As per the state government’s norms, there should be two teachers for 60 students followed by one teacher for the next 30 students.

The NMC is running 131 primary schools, higher primary schools and 29 secondary schools. The strength of students is 18,000. As per the teacher-student ratio, the NMC requires only 755 teachers.

Still, the NMC is maintaining 1,121 teachers for last six years. It means the NMC is maintaining 366 surplus teachers for last six years. Despite cash-strapped conditions, the civic body is bearing salaries of over Rs 22 crore per annum on surplus teachers.

In February, Mundhe came to know about this and directed education department to shortlist surplus teachers and send to state’s education department. But the state’s education department is yet to reply to the NMC’s request to incorporate surplus teachers in their service.

To reduce financial burden, now Mundhe started to transfer surplus teachers in departments facing staff crunch.

NMC teachers union which strongly opposed transfer of surplus teachers to state’s education department has also registered an objection on shifting surplus teachers to other departments in the NMC.

Title: Indian Railways relaxes refund rules till June 21
Content:
Aurangabad: To avoid crowding at public places and to promote social distancing in the view of Covid -19 outbreak, the Indian Railways has relaxed refund rules for passenger reservation system (PRS) counter, an official release said.

Public Relations officer for Nanded division of South Central Railway (SCR) Rajesh Shinde on Saturday said that the relaxation in rules is applicable for journey period up to June 21.

“For train cancelled by Indian Railways for a period up to April 15, refund across the counter can be undertaken on submission of ticket up to 45 days from the date of journey instead of existing rule of three hours to three days,” he said.

The relaxation in rules is also applicable in case the train is not cancelled but the passenger does not want to travel due to COVID-19 scare.

“In such circumstances, passengers can file the ticket deposit receipt (TDR) within 30 days from the date of journey at the station instead of the extant rule of three days,” Shinde said.

Also, TDR can be submitted to the claims office for getting the refund within 60 days of filing the necessary application subject to the verification from the train chart instead of the existing rule of 10 days.

Moreover, passengers who want to cancel their ticket by dialling 139 can get refunds across the counter within 30 days from the date of the journey instead of the extant rule of refund up to scheduled departure of the train.

“Passengers are advised to avail the relaxation in rules for ticket cancellation and avoid coming to the railway station. These measures are taken to promote social distancing,” Shinde said.

Title: Maoist couple surrenders to CP
Content:
Warangal: CPI Maoist communication central regional bureau incharge, Gandrakoti Mallesham alias Mallaiah, alias Kiran and his wife Chinta Srilatha, Dandakaranya special zone committee area member surrendered before the commissioner of police, Dr V Ravinder on Saturday.

According to CP Ravinder, Mallesham was attracted to Maoist party ideology and joined CPI-M in 2003 after encouragement from Bharatakka, the then Narsampet dalam secretary. He was trained in ammunition and worked in the communication wing in 2008 and was promoted to a DCM (Divisional Committee Member) in 2011. He worked with Bharatakka in Odisha, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. He was involved in 9 cases, including a case related to firing on police in Telangana.

Dandakaranya special zone committee area member and Mallesham’s wife, Srilatha, was attracted to Maoist party ideology and went underground after her marriage with Mallesham.She was involved in two murder cases, including an exchange of fire between police and Maoists in Chhattisgarh. The Maoist couple has decided to lead a normal life with financial assistance from the government. CP Ravinder handed over financial assistance to the surrendered couple.

Title: Large crowd at ‘Panguni’ fest despite Covid-19 warning
Content: MADURAI: While bigger temples have been closed as a precautionary measure against Covid-19, smaller temples managed by the HR & CE department and those in villages where thousands gather at a time are continuing to conduct their annual ‘Panguni’ festival, showing that people are still unaware of the lurking danger.On Friday night, over 1,000 people participated in the Panguni festival of Veerakaliamman temple near Melur. The people took out a procession to the temple carrying idols in decorated palanquins. ``We are doing it for the good of the world and the health of the community,’’ said Selvam, a participant, saying that this was an annual festival that no family usually wanted to miss.Pongal was also cooked on the premises and distributed to the people who came there. While the government’s directive to bar devotees is in place for bigger temples, the festivals in smaller temples are going to draw larger crowds. While the district administration and local body administrations are taking many steps to create awareness of hand hygiene in markets, bus stands, stations and other public places, no awareness was created at this specific temple festival.Meanwhile, a small temple at Maravar Chavadi in Madurai conducted a ‘yaga’ seeking protection against the fast-spreading Covid-19 virus. ``A large number of people also gathered there and it was clear that they did not give much thought to social distancing while participating in this puja,’’ said Krishnan of Arapalayam. The Thayamangalam festival in Sivaganga is another temple that draws lakhs of people from various parts of the state for the Panguni festival and the culminating event is to be held on Sunday. Sivaganga district collector J Jayakanthan said that he would look into the issue.Thousands gathered there on Saturday when a large number of goats and chickens were sacrificed. As there is a water scarcity in the temple, thousands entered the village tank simultaneously for bathing after tonsuring their heads. Though the temple is under the control of the HR & CE department, there was no effort to control the crowds on Saturday. If not closed, the temple could draw a larger crowd on Sunday during the Janta curfew and lead to the failure of the attempt to combat the deadly virus.

Title: Covid-19 threat: Madurai flower market to shut after 50 years
Content: MADURAI: The Madurai flower market will down shutters for the first time in 50 years as part of precautionary measure for Covid-19 and to observe Janata Curfew on March 22.President of the Madurai Meenakshi flower market association, Pookadai S Ramachandran, said that to the best of his memory, this was the first time that the market was going to be shut in the last 50 years. “Even during bandhs, we were given exemption because our product is perishable, but now because we fear for our lives and that of others, we will be closing shops on March 22,” he said.Ramachandran added that the flower market was witnessing a considerable dip in the sales for the past one week. “The price of flowers has hit an all-time low because temples are closed and celebrations and festivals have been cancelled or postponed,” he said.Even when leaders like Indira Gandhi, MGR, Kalaignar and Jayalaliathaa died, the flower market only closed temporarily for a few hours to pay homage to the leaders. “We play an important role during any sort of social event and cannot afford to close down completely,” said Ramachandran.On Saturday, over five tonnes of jasmine that arrived in the market sold for just Rs 120 per kg, which was very low. “If not for Covid-19, it would have been selling for nearly Rs 800 on a Saturday, because Sunday would generally be a busy day,” said Chellam, a vendor.Ramachandran said that almost all the flowers, which were used for decorations and garlands, sold for less than Rs 20 per kg. Pitchi was the only flower that sold for Rs 200 as the supply was low on Saturday. Samangi, Arali and Chendupoo sold for as less as Rs 20 per kg.Flower farmers, traders and vendors, too, come under the agrarian community, like their counterparts, who cultivate paddy, pulses and other condiments. “While, their produce would stay for some time, our products become dry and withered in a day. It has hit farmers and traders because the banks that loaned us will start pressuring us by March 31, this is the first time that we are facing uncertainty of this magnitude,” he said.

Title: 34 more quarantined at Kallikudi, four isolated at MGM
Content:
Trichy: Thirty-four passengers who arrived from Sharjah, Dubai and Singapore have been quarantined at the makeshift facility in the Central market at Kallikudi while another four were admitted at the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) government hospital isolation centre on Saturday. Seven people who were admitted earlier at MGM have tested negative for Covid-19 on Saturday. Collector S Sivarasu has hinted that MGM may soon have a Covid-19 testing facility.

Out of 458 passengers who landed at the Trichy international airport on five flights from Sharjah, Dubai and Singapore, 34 passengers including 25 men and nine women have been diagnosed with mild cough and cold. As a precaution, the public health and preventive medicine department sent them to the quarantine facility at Kallikudi.

In a press meet, collector S Sivarasu said that medical officers will check and decide if they should be kept at the quarantine facility or sent back home with an advice to self-quarantine. They will also be provided with an essential toiletry kit and food during their accommodation.

“If the doctors find them fit, they will be advised to stay at home for 14 days. I have spoken to nine passengers quarantined and sent from the centre. They are all doing well and have no symptoms,” he added.

The public health and preventive medicine department has so far quarantined 191 passengers including the 34 on Saturday. The passengers quarantined in the last few days have been let off.

The results of the four people, admitted in the isolation wards at MGM on Saturday, is expected to be out from the lab at the government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur on Sunday. “All of them are from local areas. One of them had vomiting after taking biryani from a restaurant in the city. Three others stayed in a single room in West Bengal. Their swabs have been taken for tests,” said the collector.

Deputy director of health services Dr A Subramani has advised people to avoid consuming bottled drinks from outside and instead opt for homemade buttermilk, porridge and other fluids to stay safe.

Title: Indore to get new parking protocol with help from UK
Content:
Indore: Don’t be surprised if down the years, Indore’s traffic and parking management system becomes like London. Giving a videshi touch to city streets, civic body is preparing a ‘parking management policy’ in association with United Kingdom government under UK-India ‘Strategic Partnership’ for Smart Urban Development in Indian States (SmUDI).

The initiative aims at effective utilization of parking spaces, reducing dependency on private vehicles and increase ridership of public transport. “The parking management policy focuses on five broad guiding principles. Under each guiding principle, several initiatives will be taken to increase parking turnover, allocate appropriate space for road users, reduce demand for parking, increase ridership of public transport and reduce traffic congestion,” Indore civic body commissioner Asheesh Singh told TOI.

Under the new policy, people might soon have to pay for parking their vehicles at public places like open grounds, gardens or even on roads in front of their houses.

“These initiatives will be implemented in phases as it will require understanding of citizens’ acceptability and modifications in strategy if needed,” he said, adding that provision regarding collection of charges from citizens if they use public spaces such as roads, public ground or garden for parking vehicles have also been made in the policy.

“A final decision in this regard is yet to be taken as it also requires permission from state government,” commissioner said.

He said that corporation plans to implement the system on trial in certain areas of city and if all goes well IMC would pitch for making provisions to incorporate the plan in its bylaws. “The main idea is to encourage people to shun use of private vehicles and opt for public transport, especially in areas with heavy traffic pressure,” he said.

Officials said that they are identifying potential areas in city for implementation and enforcement of the parking management system.

“Areas with maximum parking demand and presence of commercial establishments will be given priority for successful implementation of the plan,” said Ashwani Lamba, an official associated with the project.

On-street parking and no parking zones would also be introduced in certain areas for proper implementation of the plan, he added.

Title: One in isolation ward, another sent home in Thanjavur
Content:
Trichy: One foreign returnee has been admitted to the isolation ward of the government medical college hospital while another has been sent home for self-quarantine in Thanjavur. A 32-year-old resident of Cholapuram in Kumbakonam, who returned from Saudi Arabia a week ago, approached Kumbakonam government hospital on Friday evening saying he has been having cough with fever for the last two days.

Doctors immediately sent him to the isolation ward for medical examination. Subsequently, his blood sample was sent to Chennai for a lab test. However, after the initial medical examination, he was sent home as there was no sign of coronavirus. In the other case, a 45-year-old resident of Kumbakonam who arrived at Thanjavur from Dubai on March 12 said he has been having fever along with cough and cold for a few days. He was also sent to the isolation ward at Kumbakonam government hospital. His blood sample was sent to Chennai for test and he was referred to Government medical college hospital in Thanjavur for further observation as he experienced difficulties on Friday night. Hospital sources said his condition is stable now.

Title: Man kills wife with a spade in front of son
Content:
Indore: A man killed his wife with a spade at Bajrangpur in Banganga following a dispute on Saturday.

The accused was selling off his property and his wife was opposing it. The dispute escalated to such an extent that accused Dinesh Sahu chased his wife with a spade and attacked her in front of their 11-year-old son.

The incident took place at 10.30 am when the woman identified as Draupadi, 30, was working inside the house. She had a dispute with her husband over selling off the property. The fight escalated and the accused brought the spade kept outside, ran behind the woman and attacked her. The woman fell unconscious and was rushed to the hospital by the family members but was declared brought dead by the doctors.

Her mother Sadhurani, a resident of Ram Nagar, said that the dispute had been going on for a long time.

Banganga police station in charge Indramani Patel said that a case has been registered and the accused was arrested. TNN

Title: Covid-19 scare: 58 inmates given bail to decongest Madurai jail
Content: MADURAI: As many as 58 inmates of Madurai Central Prison were released on bail on Saturday in order to bring down congestion in the jail in the wake of Covid-19 scare. These inmates include two women, who were lodged in special prison for women, where 105 have been lodged.The decision was taken at a special camp that took place on the prison premises, which was chaired by justice P N Prakash from Madurai bench of Madras high court. Madurai city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham, south zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaran, and Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan took part in the camp. A panel of judges from Madurai district court and officials from prison department also took part.The 35-acre Madurai Central Prison, located in the heart of the city, has a capacity to accommodate around 1,300 inmates, but more than 1,550 inmates were lodged in the prison.Deputy inspector-general of prisons D Pazhani told TOI that it was an initiative by the prison department and the judicial department. The inmates considered for release on bail was based on a report prepared by the police department. It was held in order to bring down the strength in the prison in the wake of Covid-19, he said.There are around 960 convict prisoners and 630 remand prisoners in Madurai Central Prison. Out of the 630, the authorities released 58 inmates, DIG said.Sources from the prisons department said that a camp will be held on Monday too in order to further bring down the numbers. The list of prisoners to be released was carefully selected based on the eligibility norms laid down under the law. It was scrutinized in such a way that these people will not create any unrest in society.Meanwhile, various measures are being taken in the prisons department in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19 among inmates and one such measure was suspension of interview with their family members and lawyers for two weeks.

Title: Janta Curfew: Railway staff told to stay at home on Sunday
Content: BHOPAL: DRM Bhopal Uday Borwanker on Saturday issued fresh guidelines to counter the coronavirus scare. Borwankar said that on the day of Janata Curfew on March 22, all personnel of railway operations, safety and health management have been asked to stay at home.Apart from the main entrance of the DRM office at Habibganj , all other gates have been closed. “Any passengers on train showing symptoms of coronavirus are being deboarded and examined by doctors. Such coaches are being sanitized,” said Borwanker.DRM said that the RPF, medical and sanitation workers’ team is working round the clock. A total of 110 beds have been arranged for quarantining people in railway hospitals and training centers. Arrangements have also been made for catering, cleaning and testing.The DRM said that passengers who are cancelling their tickets are being given full refund. The railway department has also simplified the refund rules, so that there is no need to come to the station to get a refund immediately. This rule will be applicable for tickets issued for the period from 21 March to 15 April.Passengers, who cancel their tickets through phone numbers 1 & 9, can get their tickets refunded from the railway reservation counter for 0 days from the journey date. If the train is cancelled during this period, passengers can withdraw the entire amount by depositing ticket at the railway reservation counter within 45 days of the date of journey.If the train is not cancelled and the passenger does not want to travel, then the passenger can collect his refund by depositing his ticket through ticket deposit receipt within 0 days from the date of journey.Apart from this, the passenger can collect the refund within 60 days from the date of his travel to the office of the Chief Commercial Manager or Chief Claims Officer by depositing the Ticket Deposit Receipt.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Madurai cops use public address system to check crowding
Content:
Police officials said that they will continue to take up the sensitisation activity until Covid-19 scare comes... Read More

MADURAI: The Madurai city police are reaching out to the public in crowded areas asking them to confine themselves to houses at a time when Covid-19 scare is looming large throughout the country.

Police teams from concerned stations started creating awareness using public address system in commercial streets, recreational places, business establishments where crowds throng.

They said that although people are aware of the present situation, their (police) response varies from people to people. For those who take it lightly, they keep telling them with intensity about the virus against which the whole world is battling. Since mortality rate among elderly people is higher, they are advised to leave crowded places at once. They are also advised not to venture out of their houses, police officials said.

A police team led by the Teppakulam police inspector Ganesan sensitized public gathered at the Vandiyur Mariamman Teppakulam on Friday night. The team reminded them of the virus scare and the higher possibility of getting infected in crowded places. After their intervention, people started to leave.

All the police stations are involved in a similar activity to discourage gatherings based on instruction from the city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham. Police officials said that they will continue to take up the sensitisation activity until Covid-19 scare comes to an end.

Title: Bizman kidnapped on his way home
Content:
Mhow: Businessman Yogesh Sharda, 42, was kidnapped while he was on his way home from his warehouse at Manpur on Friday night. His family came to know only when he called up his father Murli Sharda and told him that the kidnappers were demanding a ransom. Murli, family members and other businessmen of the area reached Manpur police station to report the matter. Manpur police informed senior officials at Mhow and Indore.

Indore DIG Ruchi Vardhan Mishra and ASP (crime) Rajesh Dandotiya along with other officials reached Manpur late night and five separate teams including officials from Mhow, Badgonda and Kishanganj were formed.

As per sources, CCTV footage from a petrol pump and two houses were checked that are close to the warehouse of Yogesh. Two locals have been identified in the footage, in which an SUV is seen which was used to kidnap Yogesh at gunpoint.

Mhow SDO (police) Vinod Sharma told TOI that the police were waiting for the second call of kidnappers but haven’t received the call yet. He said that police have received a clue that locals were involved in the kidnapping and police are close to solving the case. All precautions are being taken to ensure Yogesh’s safety, he said. TNN

Title: Couple who robbed rly passengers held
Content:
Hyderabad: A couple who have been involved in stealing valuables of passengers at railway stations and on platforms were arrested on Saturday.

Railway police said 42 tolas of gold worth Rs 16.80 lakh was recovered from the couple — M Kumar and his wife M Gowri, who are residents of Jeedimetla. Police said the couple were involved in 10 cases this year alone.

They would secretly open passengers’ bags on platforms. Most of the offences were committed at Secunderabad station. Kumar was arrested earlier too for stealing valuables in Balanagar and Jagathgiri Gutta police. The accused were produced before a magistrate. TNN

Title: Janata Curfew: Southern Railway cancels mail, express and intercity trains
Content:
This story is from March 22, 2020

Janata Curfew: Southern Railway cancels mail, express and intercity trains

Image used for representational purpose only MADURAI: Southern Railway has announced cancellation of several trains on Sunday (March 22) due to ‘Janata Curfew’.

TNo 12638/12637 Madurai - Chennai Egmore – Madurai Pandian Express. TNo 22671/22672 Chennai Egmore – Madurai – Chennai Egmore Tejas Express. TNo 16525 Kanyakumari – KSR Bengaluru Exp. TNo 16605 Mangaluru – Nagercoil Ernad Exp. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Bhopal: Hotels & restaurants shut, business worth crores hit
Content:
BHOPAL: Hotels and restaurants in Bhopal were shut down because of coronavirus scare. Following an order passed by the district collector, many restaurants stayed shut while many were asked to shut down by cops.

Many people have already stopped visiting restaurants. Besides, bookings for social gatherings, kitty and birthday parties have also been cancelled.

The industry has been hit hard, restaurant owners claimed, adding, business worth about Rs 2 to 3 crore per day has been affected, a restaurant owner said.

On Friday, the district administration decided to close down all eateries including pubs.

President of the hotel restaurant association of Bhopal Tejkulpal Singh Pali said, “This is an emergency and restaurant owners are willingly closing down theor units. Safety of people and our families is paramount concern.”

Despite administration’s orders, many small restaurants shopkeepers were running their business. Besides, ice cream parlours were also opened.

On Saturday afternoon, police made announcements in various markets and forcibly got the restaurants shut down.

Meanwhile, In view of the Sunday bandh , many sweet makers in Bairagarh and some other places of Bhopal offered 50% off on sweets. People joined queue to avail the offers.

“All my sweets was sold out by afternoon,” said a famous sweet shop owner in Bairagarh as he closed down his shop for the day.

Title: Chain snatched from snack vendor
Content:
Trichy: A 53-year-old woman was robbed of her gold chain by an unidentified man on VOC Road in Trichy on Friday.

The culprit riding a bike got close to N Revathi of Thiruverumbur, a street snacks vendor in Trichy, and snatched her 1.75 sovereigns of gold chain in the afternoon on Friday. The woman screamed for help but the criminal escaped with the valuable.

Acting on her complaint, the Cantonment police launched an investigation.

The incident happened behind the Central bus stand where police claimed to have installed CCTV cameras to prevent crimes.

Title: Garment trader abducted and robbed of Rs 6000 at knifepoint
Content:
Indore: A cloth trader was abducted and robbed of Rs 6000 at knifepoint by a man, who owed him Rs 450, along with a woman at Annapurna on Saturday. The accused took the woman’s help to falsely accuse the complainant of harassing her.

Police received a complaint from one Shivnarayan Porwal, a readymade garments trader at Rajwada, that accused Balram owed him Rs 450 and had called him near the gurdwara at around 4 pm to return the money. When Shivnarayan reached the gurdwara on Friday evening, the accused said that he was to get money from a man near Harsiddhi temple and would pay him back from the cash received.

He took him to a temple on his two wheeler and stopped the vehicle near a bridge. After some time, a woman came there and while asking him the address of the police station intentionally fell on him and blamed him of harassing her.

Accused Balram knew the woman Aarti and asked her to sit behind the vehicle. Aarti and Balram abducted Shivnarayan and took him to the secluded spot near Lal Bagh where Balram brandished a knife at him and threatened to kill him if he did not give him money.

The woman Aarti also threatened to tear her own tshirt and falsely implicate him in a molestation case. They snatched Rs 6000 from the accused along with his Aadhaar card. When the accused demanded more money, the complainant took him to Labriya Bheru at his friend’s shop from where the accused fled.

Annapurna police station in charge Satish Dwivedi said that a case was registered and a team was formed to arrest the accused. Acting on the information, the location of the accused was traced and they were arrested within an hour from the area. Balram Chandak, 31 and Aarti Verma, 42, both residents of Sudama Nagar, were arrested and booked under relevant sections of the IPC. The two-wheeler used to commit the crime was also seized. TNN

Title: Collector warns action against disobeying Janata Curfew
Content:
Trichy: Asking people to strictly adhere to the Janata Curfew appeal by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, district collector S Sivarasu has warned of action in case of any gatherings in public places from 7am to 9pm on Sunday.

“We are making an appeal to the people to stay indoors as a preventive measure to contain the spread of the virus. Those in need of medical emergency can travel. In case of any unnecessary group meetings, they will be subjected to action,” he said.

Police will patrol the streets to monitor the situation apart from revenue and medical professionals who will remain on duty, he added. “There will not be any restrictions on people involved in essential service as essential commodities like milk, vegetables etc will be made available to avoid inconvenience to people. There won’t be shortage of milk in the market. Aavin has enough quantity of milk to meet the demand for three days,” said the collector.

In Trichy district, 96 marriage halls have been booked by various people for various functions including marriage. The district administration has advised them to complete most of the rituals on Saturday night itself and finish the Sunday function as early as 8am in the presence of a small gathering.

On Saturday, 16% of the 973 Tamil Nadu state transport corporation (TNSTC) buses were off the roads as the passenger traffic came down to 5.5 lakh. “One third of the bus services will be suspended. The trips of city buses will also be reduced,” said the collector.

The collector also said that migrant labourers residing in Chinna kammala street and Big kammal street have returned back to their state. “Some of them are staying back due to suspension of train services,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus: Didi against trains entering West Bengal
Content: KOLKATA: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee has called for an immediate stop to inter-state trains entering Bengal as there is no mechanism on trains to screen passengers for coronavirus infection.Banerjee instructed state chief secretary to get in touch with railway officials after getting news of two special trains bringing home thousands of migrants working in Maharashtra , the most severely affected state in the country.“Why can’t these states take responsibility for these people’s health when they make them work? But they ( railways ) are not listening. We will not allow (inter-state) trains to enter the state if they (railways) keep sending them here” the CM said.“All three positive cases here are people who have come from abroad. Some of them landed elsewhere in the country and then reached Kolkata. Railways does not have any screening mechanism in place,” she said.

Title: Covid-19 in Tamil Nadu: It’s their call to quell panic from going viral
Content: Hunched over a computer, Muruganandam looked drawn and tired. His headphones firmly over his ears, he wearily takes a 108 call from Tirupur.The hosiery hub has a high number of labourers from across the country. Muruganandam straightens in his chair at the Emergency Management Response Centre (108 ambulance service) in Chennai to quickly fill up an online form on the screen even as he talks reassuringly to the caller. She’s a staff nurse of a public health centre (PHC) in Tirupur asking for an ambulance.A 25-year-old woman, who was taking care of a relative, a textile mill worker from Jharkhand suffering flu-like symptoms and admitted to the Tirupur PHC, is showing similar symptoms and needs to be shifted to the local government hospital.Muruganandam tells the nurse an ambulance is on the way, and hangs up. The next call is from Theni.The 108 helplines never stop ringing, keeping the pressure on the 60 people cooped up in cubicles with red tack boards who field calls from across Tamil Nadu "It’s a massive task," GVK EMRI Tamil Nadu head M Selva Kumar tells TOI."We get around 450 calls every day. Most of them suspected Covid-19 cases. At least 25 seek counselling and another 20 calls are from Indians abroad seeking information on whether they can fly in," he says.As the country prepares to lockdown on Sunday, the 108 ambulance service and the Covid-19 emergency operation control room at the Directorate of Medical Services campus in Chennai are in battle mode.In the Covid-19 control room, more than 200 health workers, delegated to eight desks, and administrative staff work in tandem with authorities and police in the districts to identify potential virus carriers.They coordinate with airports, seaports, other states, collate information from other countries, monitor patients on ventilators, patients in isolation wards and in quarantine.Those on the home quarantine desk work hard to keep conversations going with people to ensure they complete the two weeks compulsory ‘home stay’."We bond with them. Clarify their doubts and ensure they stay home for two weeks without exposing themselves to the very young and the old and vulnerable," says Dr Esakki Prasad, a member of the desk.In the nearby 24/7 call centre at the DMS, 15 doctors man phones that ring constantly. "There is no respite. Every minute we get a new call. People ask about symptoms, causes, precautions and preventive measure. They ask if their neighbour, who may have returned from travel abroad, has been screened," says Dr Praveen Shankar, during a brief break.Emergency management technician Prabhu has an unenviable task. He’s the one who sits beside the 108 ambulance drivers as they careen across city roads in response to calls for help from suspected Covid-19 cases."Every day, we are called to transport at least five people with suspected Covid-19 symptoms to isolation wards in hospitals across Chennai," says Prabhu.There are now 54 people with Covid-19-like symptoms who are in isolation wards in hospitals across the state. At least 895 are home quarantined and 229 quarantined in hospitals in Tamil Nadu.But for these health warriors, the vigil continues.

Title: 164kg processed sea cucumber seized in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

MADURAI: Combined efforts by the marine police and the forest department in Tuticorin led to the seizure of 164kg processed sea cucumber in different incidents on Saturday. Forester S Arun Kumar said the stock was about two to three months old and suspected to be left over that could not be smuggled due to the Covid-19 crisis.

He said that sea cucumber does not have a big consumption market in India as the species is protected under the The Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 . It is smuggled to Sri Lanka, from where it used to be sent to China and Thailand . Marine police raided a godown at K V K Nagar in Tuticorin based on a tip off. Police seized 70kg of the processed sea cucumber that was stored in four bags and also seized a gas cylinder used in the process.

Meanwhile, the team received information about processed sea cucumber being smuggled in a car and a combined operation was launched by the marine police and the forest department. The car had 94kg processed sea cucumber in four gunny bags. Efforts are on to trace the vehicle owner.

The forest department registered a case.

Title: Coronavirus in Bhopal: Restaurants face music for flouting orders
Content: BHOPAL: MP Nagar police on Saturday booked the directors of a bar and restaurant under Section 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) for organising a party of around 100 people on their premises. The accused had organised the party at their restaurant despite the district collector having issued an order against all such events to check the spread of Covid-19 pandemic.SHO MP Nagar said, district collector had issued an order under Disaster Management Act on March 17, in which a ban was imposed on the operation of restaurants in view of Coronavirus spread. He said that on Saturday, SDM MP Nagar, sent a letter to police and informed that the directors of a bar and restaurant located in MP Nagar Zone-2 were violating the order and organising programmes at their venue.A case under section 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 270 (Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) and 188 of IPC has been registered against the restaurant directors, including Vinod Kushwah , Gaurav Shivhare, Ajay Bhargava, DJ Shibu and other party organisers.

Title: Three booked for spreading rumours in Pudukottai
Content:
Pudukottai: Three people were arrested for spreading rumours on social media that two people were infected with Covid-19, in separate incidents on Friday.

In the first case, the Viralimalai police arrested C Ayyappan, 26, of Lanchamedu in Pudukottai, and his colleague C Rajkumar, 21, of Agarapatti in Pudukottai, for spreading false news that Alagarsamy from Lanchamedu was a Covid-19 patient and admitted to government headquarters hospital in Manapparai. All the three work in the same company and are colleagues.

When A Muthukumar, a resident of his village, forwarded Alagarsamy the message on WhatsApp, he was taken aback. Muthukumar told him that Ayyappan posted the message in a WhatsApp group. When Alagarsamy confronted Ayyappan, he passed the buck on Rajkumar.

Alagarsamy lodged a complaint with the Viralimalai police stating that he was healthy and also stated that the rumour caused him mental agony.

In another case, the Aranthangi police in Pudukottai district arrested A Palanivel, 32, of Koothadivayal near Aranthangi in Pudukottai, on Friday for spreading rumours on WhatsApp that R Vadivel from Kalapakadu near Aranthangi was a Covid-19 patient. Vadivel and Palanivel are private ambulance drivers.

The police said that they had previous enmity with each other. Vadivel lodged a complaint with the police on Friday.

The police have booked all the three under the Information Technology Act and Disaster Management Act for spreading rumours and creating panic among the general public.

Title: Mother-son dead in car crash, 3 injured
Content:
Barwani: A 22-year-old youth and his mother died while three others were injured when the car they were travelling in crashed on Agra-Bombay National Highway under Julwania police station in Barwani.

According to Julwania police station sources, the car collided with the railing near Bakwadi Phata, 50 km from Barwani district headquarters. Due to the collision, 22-year-old Hitesh Joshi and his mother Lakshmi Bai, 45, died on the spot.

Hitesh’s elder sister Priya, 25, her daughter Himani, 6 and driver Santosh were injured in the incident. They were referred to Barwani district hospital after being brought to the primary health centre at Julwania.

They were returning from Udaipur in Rajasthan to their home village in Khuldabad, Maharashtra. Police sources said on the basis of a preliminary investigation that the incident took place because the driver had dozed off. One of their kin Kuber Joshi, who came from Khargone, claimed before reporters that after the postmortem the bodies were kept in the open in front of the locked mortuary for almost four hours.

Julwania PHC Dr Manoj Kadam told TOI that he handed over the bodies to kin after the postmortem and went to OPD. The kin must have kept the bodies there itself and standing at a distance due to the sun. TNN

Title: Big rush at vegetable markets, Uzhavar Santhai ahead of Janata Curfew
Content:
Trichy: Following Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call for observing a ‘Janata curfew’ on Sunday, residents in city flocked the vegetable markets including the Uzhavar Santhai, Gandhi Market to buy vegetables and essentials. Meanwhile, most of the eateries in Trichy have declared holiday till March 31.

Except for essentials, the government has ordered to close down all commercial establishments. Traders and vegetable vendors have promised to observe the curfew on Sunday. Agriculture marketing officials also announced that Uzhavar Santhai would down shutters on Sunday.

In order to avert scarcity of essentials, people thronged all the Uzhavar Santhai located in seven places in the district, Gandhi Market as well as various local vegetable markets to stock vegetables, greens and fruits.

To cater to the needs of customers, all the Uzhavar Santhai in the city were kept open till afternoon, skipping evening sales. A large number of people gathered at the markets in Tennur Anna Nagar, KK Nagar, Lalgudi to purchase things.

According to Gandhi Market vendors, around 2,000 wholesale mandis are there exclusively for vegetables, onion, potato, fruits and banana. As per the call made by the PM, they have decided to close down all the mandis and retail shops in the market. Several customers from the city and from the outskirts of the city arrived at the market till late in the evening.

“I have never seen such a huge crowd even during festivals in the recent past,” S Ramesh, a vegetable vendor in Gandhi Market, said.

Title: Cuddalore collector’s house in Thanjavur burgled
Content:
Thanjavur: Unidentified miscreants broke into the house of Cuddalore district collector V Anbuselvan at his native village near Peravurani taluk in Thanjavur district and decamped with gold jewellery worth several lakhs of rupees on Friday. The incident came to light only on Saturday and police are investigating.

According to police, Anbuselvan is a native of Nadiyam village and has been residing at the collector's camp office in Cuddalore along with his family. He had hired Selvam, 62, a native of the village, to guard his house during the night.

On Friday night, Selvam was guarding the front gate of the house when some miscreants managed to break open the back door and get inside. They looted gold jewellery weighing about 55 sovereigns from a bureau in the bedroom. Before stealing the valuables, the burglars damaged five CCTV cameras fixed in and around the house as well as the recorder and dumped them in the water tub in the backyard, police said.

Selvam noticed the robbery on Saturday morning only and subsequently informed the police. Pattukottai deputy superintendent of police Subramanian and Sethubavachathiram inspector V Annathurai along with their police team rushed to the spot and conducted an inquiry. Forensic experts and sniffer dog were pressed into action. The collector’s relatives arrived there and confirmed the theft to the police.

Title: Railways relaxes reservation refund rules
Content:
Trichy: As per the government advisory in the wake of Covid-19 to avoid crowding and practice social distancing, Railways has relaxed refund rules for tickets generated through passenger reservation system (PRS) counters.

All rules for e-ticket are remaining the same, as a passenger does not need to come to the station for a refund of the ticket. The relaxation is for journey period between March 21 and April 15.

In case, trains were cancelled by Railways during the journey period, refund across the counter can be taken on submission of the ticket up to 45 days from date of journey, instead of extant rule of 3 hours or 72 hours, a release from Trichy Railway Division said.

If the train is not cancelled and the passenger does not want to travel, ticket deposit receipt can be filed within 30 days from date of the journey at the station, instead of the extant rule of 3 days.

Ticket deposit receipt can be submitted to claims office for getting the refund with 60 days of the filing of ticket deposit receipt subject to verification from train chart, (instead of the extant rule of 10 days). For passengers who want to cancel ticket through 139 can get refund across the counter within 30 days from the date of journey. (Instead of the extant rule of up to scheduled departure of the train), the release said.

Railway authorities have asked passenger to avail the facility by avoiding coming to the railway station during the spread of the virus, the release added.

Title: Panic on ‘suspects’ sends officials into a tizzy
Content:
Shopkeepers keep shutters down in Mangalbazaar area as a precautionary measure on Saturday

Vadodara: If you thought panic was limited to buying of essential commodities, hand sanitizers and masks, think again. For trigger factors also include the foreign returned people in Bayan City, who are now at the receiving end of people’s heightened worries.

So much so, that the virus-wary Barodians have been keeping authorities on their toes with phones buzzing constantly with information about people whom they find suspicious in their neighbourhood!

On Saturday morning itself, major drama ensued at Sukhdham Residency on Waghodia-Dabhoi ring road where a youth from Bhavnagar put himself under self quarantine after returning from Spain. The youth, a student in Spain, had landed at Mumbai airport a few days back and had kept himself in self-quarantine at his relative’s vacant home in the society. When the residents of the society learnt about him, they forcefully sent him to a government quarantine centre at Ajwa Road.

“On Friday evening we learnt about the youth staying here and enquired from the owner about his details. When he told us we became alert as the youth, although in self-quarantine, had been staying in society which could affect all of us,” said the president of the society, Jagdish Sharma.

Sharma added that the man had been ordering food through online services and disposing garbage along with waste from other houses of the society. “He had not got himself tested and doesn’t know whether he has any symptoms or not. So, we called an ambulance on Saturday morning,” said Sharma, a retired Indian Railways employee.

When the ambulance arrived, the youth hid himself in the house, but after much deliberation, was taken away forcefully to an isolation centre.

A businessman living in Harni alerted Vadodara Municipal Corporation on Twitter when he learnt through hearsay that a daughter of his neighbour was planning to come to the city from Ahmedabad. The businessman Pankaj Gupta told TOI: “She is under self-isolation at her relative’s house in Ahmedabad after returning from Dubai. Her mother and a cousin went to Ahmedabad and they are all planning to return to Vadodara on Monday.”

Such hoax alarms are sending VMC officials in a tizzy.

On Friday, deputy mayor Jivraj Chauhan said that a call was received from eastern part of city which informed the officials that a couple in a residential apartment has returned from abroad and has come out of the house for two days. When health officials reached the house, they came to know that they had voluntarily decided to stay in isolation nor had travelled to any foreign country.

Not only VMC, but the police control room too has been flooded with alarm calls from different parts of the city with reports about people violating guidelines of self-quarantine. “We ask people to call the government helpline 104 in case they find any suspicious violation because we can hardly do anything regarding these complaints,” said assistant commissioner of police (control room) Vimal Gamit. On Saturday too, police control room received several calls from Waghodia Road and Bhayli areas.

Title: Poorly built stretch at EC Road causing inconvenience, say locals
Content:
The residents say that many people who own cars are forced to park their vehicles on the road as the stretch d... Read More

Dehradun: Just six months after a cemented stretch was built at the EC Road by Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority (MDDA), it has started causing inconvenience to the locals of the area. Those who live in the locality say that drainage arrangements were neglected while laying of the road.

“After much requests, the road was built in October, last year. However, its design is faulty and the quality is sub-standard. Rain water gets stagnated and doesn’t trickle down due to lack of sewage provisions. The leveling of the road isn’t proper. Also, only 550 metre-long road was built despite the sanction for a 630 metre-long road,” said DC Chandola, president of residents welfare association.

The locals allege that the survey before construction of the road was not done properly, as a consequence of which, water and other waste does not flow in the direction of main drainage.

RK Agarwal, a local, told TOI, “Around 3-foot-deep water got collected outside our homes after rain spells earlier this month. The water logging makes it difficult for us to even move out of our homes.”

Another resident of the area Kaushal Madan said, “The quality of the road can be ascertained from the fact that the gravels have started coming out of the road making it slippery for commuters and causing accidents.”

The residents say that many people who own cars are forced to park their vehicles on the road as the stretch doesn’t reach their home. “Had the MDDA constructed a road of the sanctioned length, such problems would not exist,” said a local.

Meanwhile, Abhishek Bhardwaj, assistant engineer of MDDA, said “The road ensures that rain water flows in the direction of the drainage. The stretch was built with the sanctioned budget of Rs 51.23 lakh and the contractor was paid only after verifying the quality of the road.”

Title: Women SHG members to make hand sanitizers
Content:
Trichy: With the requirement of sanitizers on the rise in government hospitals, primary health centres and everywhere, self-help groups (SHGs) in Trichy have been roped in to make them. Public health and preventive medicine department organised a training programme at the district collector office on Sunday at which 70 members of women self-help groups (SHGs) of Magalir Thittam learnt how to produce hand sanitizer.

Head of the microbiology department at K A P Viswanatham government medical college, Dr S Dhanapal, taught them the formula of mixing isoprophyl alcohol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide and distilled water at the prescribed ratio to make the hand sanitizers. The formula for preparing one litre to 25 litres of sanitizers, procedures and safety measures to be followed were imparted to the attendees. The microbiology chief also listed out the containers required for the mixing.

“Since masks and sanitizers are required in abundance, the SHGs have been trained to make them on their own,” said collector S Sivarasu after inaugurating the training session. Assistant project officer of Magalir Thittam Julius Theodar said the SHG members will prepare 20 litres of sanitizer at the district supply and marketing society office in Trichy from Monday. It will be supplied to the health centres according to the directions of the district collector.

To start with, Magalir Thittam will help SHG members with funds and raw materials. Later, the SHG members will be taking care of the project on their own.
