Julius said the hand sanitizer-making project will help the members financially and make the item available in the market at a reasonable price also. “Not everyone is required to wear a mask and use hand sanitizers. Proper hand washing using soaps will do,” he told reporters at a press meet. While urban people were sensitized about hand washing by the corporation officials, block development officers (BDO) have been asked to meet the rural people in the evening and sensitize them about hand washing before going for work and after returning home, said the collector. Public health and preventive medicine department also got the head of the department of microbiology at MGMGH to provide training to the SHG women at the collector office on Saturday.

Title: Three booked for cheating in Madurai
Content:
Representational image

MADURAI: The Ramanathapuram district crime branch police have booked three people for cheating a government job aspirant from Madurai of Rs 27 lakh by promising him to get a job.

The candidate’s father, S Shanmuga Sundaram from Sammattipuram near Kalavasal lodged a complaint on Friday stating that his son applied for group II job and appeared for the TNPSC examination in 2018.

The accused, Siva, Naganthira Rao and Rajendran alias Vengadachalam approached the candidate through email mentioning that he did not clear the exam. But, they can arrange for the job if money is paid. They demanded Rs 30 lakh. As the amount was beyon his reach, he decided not to proceed further. But the scamsters started threatening him saying that his son will be blacklisted in all future examinations. Left with no other option, Sundaram agreed to pay Rs 27 lakh. He met them in Rameswaram and paid the amount in 2018 itself. But, they did not send any appointment letter as promised by them, nor did they return the money.

Title: Quarantined family of four gives tough time to Nashik district admin
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A family of four who have returned from Australia and advised home quarantine started frequenting between their Nashik city residence and parents’ home in Khambale village of Igatpuri taluka, leaving the authorities in a tizzy.

The family has finally been given strict instructions to stay self-quarantined at their residence in Nashik city, said officials of the district health department.

“None of the family members is suffering from any illness, but all of them are under strict watch because of rising number of coronavirus cases in the state.”

According to health officials, the man, aged 36, his wife and children aged eight years and one year returned from Australia on March 11. After spending a few days in a hotel and at their residence in Nashik, they went to their parents house in Khambale village on March 17.

“Soon after the health department got information about the travel history of the family, they rushed to their residence in Khambale on March 18 and asked the family to remain confined to their house,” said the officials.

“However, on the same day in the afternoon, they returned to their residence in Pathardi Phata . After that, they once against went to Khambale on March 19.”

Given the frequent travelling of the family from Khambale to Pathardi Phata, the district administration decided to keep them in isolation. An ambulance was rushed to Khambale to pick them.

District collector Suraj Mandhare said the family has been warned of strict action if they are found leaving their house in the city again.

He has appealed to people to dial 104 and 100 and alert the officials if people with travel history are found mingling in crowds or moving about freely.

Title: Private hospitals to keep their OPDs shut
Content:
Nagpur: To avoid rush in the hospitals and visits of healthy patients for regular check-ups, Vidarbha Hospitals Association (VHA) has appealed all private hospitals, nursing homes, and clinics in Nagpur to keep their Outpatient departments (OPDs) closed from March 21 onwards. Dr Ashok Arbat, president of VHA said that emergency services will continue in all hospitals.

“Hospitals attached to VHA have stopped regular health check-up visits and also postponed the planned surgeries for the time being. Now, we have appealed all hospitals and nursing homes to keep their OPDs closed and ask patients not to come for regular check-ups,” he said. Most corporate private hospitals in city are attached to VHA.

“Private hospitals are committed to provide their services to the government authorities to fight the coronavirus outbreak. We are constantly in touch with the government authorities,” he said.

Dr Arbat also advised patients those who want to visit hospitals or clinics from March 21 onwards for their regular check-ups to avoid if it’s not very necessary. “In case it becomes necessity, you should call the doctor and ensure whether the OPD is functioning or not,” he added.

The VHA has ensured that they are ready to cooperate with the government authorities by providing any technical or human resource support at the quarantine facilities. VHA has already given a proposal to hand over one entire hospital with less occupancy to government and develop it as ‘Quarantine hospital’.

Meanwhile, the Indian Medical Association (IMA) has started ‘Talk to Doctor’ 24X7 helpline for patients. “Patients may call 9999672238 & 9999672239 and speak to doctor round the clock. They will get all the scientific information about coronavirus,” said Dr Kush Jhunjhunwala, President of Nagpur IMA.

IMA has also launched a WhatsApp number dedicated fully to defuse all the irrational information being spread on social media platforms. This number is 9823087561.

“Anyone can send anything which is irrational regarding corona viral infection on this WhatsApp no. and person will get a scientific reply in couple of hours. This WhatsApp facility is only for residents of Maharashtra,” Dr Manjusha Giri, Honorary Secretary of IMA Nagpur, said. IMA has also supported the Janata Curfew call and appealed people to participate in it as it has a scientific base.

Title: Two oil units sealed in Roorkee
Content:
Roorkee: The Roorkee administration, on Saturday, conducted raids at two mustard oil expeller units in connection with adulteration and misbranding. The administration team collected samples of mustard oils from both units for lab testing and sealed the units.

According to deputy collector Prateek Jain, who led the administration team for the raid, they had been receiving complaints of adulterated mustard oil being manufactured by two small-sized mustard oil manufacturing units in BT-Ganj market. "The owners of both oil units had stocks of mustard oil of other brands and we took up samples of oil from there for lab examination," said Jain.

Title: Students coming back for an early & forced vacation
Content:
A hoarding requesting people to participate in janata curfew being put up at Badkas Chowk on Saturday

Nagpur: As various cities in Maharashtra as well as the country start shutting down, those enrolled in colleges there have started coming back for an early vacation.

A student, who returned from Vellore (Tamil Nadu), said, “It was difficult to book tickets from a small town at the eleventh hour. I wasn’t really scared about getting infected but the friends I travelled with were. We were informed on March 15 evening that the institute will shut down from the next day, so there was panic among students.”

A student who returned from Dharwad (Karnatake) said his return journey was a long one. “I had to first travel all the way to Belgaum. From there, I took a flight to Mumbai and then another flight to Nagpur. I wasn’t scared of getting infected because panicking in such situations won’t work. You simply need to take preventive measures,” said the student.

Another student who came back from Pune said she was lucky as travelling was not a hassle at all. “My sister and I returned early by train, so getting a ticket was not an issue. But throughout the journey we kept our faces covered because in the train, it’s very easy to catch any infection,” she said.

A student, who returned from Mumbai, said that though she is back, it’s shocking to see how casually people are taking the situation.

“People are extremely careless regarding the issue which is why I was a bit scared about getting infected while travelling. We must take precautions while travelling,” she said.

Another student from Pune said the college is still communicating with them. “We are keeping in touch through the college’s web site as all the information is being updated there,” she said.

A Bengaluru college student said that technology is helping them to keep in touch. “My college is commuting via texts and e-mails. But looking at the brighter side, I’m spending a lot of quality time with my parents,” he said.

A student from Pune said their college is now providing every support possible through mobile apps. “Our college is constantly in touch with us through whatsapp. We are even appearing for our exams online,” said the student.

Another student from Bengaluru said that they are making up for the academic loss by doing multiple home assignments. “Academic loss is something everyone is worried about, but all of us are making the maximum use of this leave by studying and preparing for the exams. There are chances that the college might start online classes, but for now, they are updating us with a separate college application,” said the student.

Title: T Students Storm London High Commission
Content:
Hyderabad/London: Around 60 Indian students -- most of them from Telangana -- created a ruckus at the High Commission of India (HCI) in London on Friday night, demanding that they be sent back to India in the wake of escalation in novel coronavirus fear. On Saturday, some of them had left. However, 28 students stayed put at the HCI building.

The students, who stood outside the HCI building all day on Friday carrying their suitcases, refused to leave the premises and spent the night on the floor in the passport and visa section. They insisted they did not have any place to go.

“We contacted some hotels and found them accommodation in two and three-star hotels at £10 per night. Most of them belong to Telangana and south India,” a senior Indian diplomat told STOI. “Despite that, they stayed put and entered the premises. They want to be repatriated to India. Since no flight can land in India, it is not possible to send them,” he said.

The protesting students claimed their hostels had closed and they did not have money to stay in London. “We offered them alternative accommodation, but they want to stay put in the High Commission. We have got no evidence that hostels have closed,” the diplomat said.

“The visa section has a huge floor where they are sleeping,” the diplomat said. The staff had already sealed access to the rest of the HCI building. “We do not want to evict them because they are Indian nationals. The canteen is closed over the weekend, so they will have to fend for themselves,” he said.

In a video message sent to STOI, the agitated students said London was already in a shutdown mode and there was no facility to conduct a coronavirus test on them. Mirza, a student from Hyderabad, said: “Please rescue us.”

Another student said if the government of India could arrange a special flight to airlift students from Rome, it could as well airlift them from the UK. “We are readyto cooperate with the authorities for self-quarantine once we land in India. Please fly us back,” they said in a letter to Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao.

Meanwhile, the Indian diplomat said the students could leave the building and come back later. He said they were worried about health scare. “There are no showers. This is not sustainable in the long run. They could be spreading coronavirus. I hope in a few days, they will move on. There are not many visas we are handling now but this undermines the security of the building,” he said.

He said some of them were student leaders who “seem to be getting assistance from a political side.”

Title: Covid-19: Traders’ outfits extend support to Janata Curfew in Madurai
Content: MADURAI: Various trade organisations in Madurai and southern districts who have offered to extend their support to Prime Minister’s call for people’s curfew on March 22, have sought relief from the government.President of the Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce and Industry , N Jegatheesan has said that the chamber fully endorses the clarion call and would extend their support to the all-out initiatives taken by the central and various state governments to contain the spread of deadly virus Covid-19 in our country.But, the decelerating take off of many goods including essential food items and medicines have taken a heavy toll on the financial health of the business community especially in the MSME sector, he said.Various countries like UK and France has offered incentives and tax reliefs for businesses and have postponed payment of tax. Most of the MSMEs in our country have been keeping large tax paid on inventory. Steep fall in sales turnover with a sizeable portion on credit basis due to lack of demand has created a severe dent in the cash flow of the units in the MSME sector, resulting in their inability to make GST payments on time.He added that, the central government should postpone the tax payment due to be remitted by the taxpayers in the MSME sector with less than Rs10 crore annual turnover, for the months of March, April and May 2020 to July 20th 2020. They may be permitted to file GSTR 3B returns every month without payment of tax till such time.Collection of loan repayment, interest and penalties payable by them for the year 2018-19 may be suspended till coranovirus threat withers away. Instalments and interest payable by such units on short term and long term bank loans may also be kept in abeyance at least for six months or such loan schemes may be rescheduled, he said.President of the Madurai District Tiny and Small Scale Industries Association (Maditssia), B Muruganantham has also said that they would extend full cooperation to Prime Minister’s move to control the pandemic. The Tamil Nadu Fireworks and Amorces Association (TANFARMA) have also extended its support.

Title: Uttarakhand: Landslide kills engineer, 2 others, working on all-weather road
Content:
The incident took place in Chada area on the Bardinath highway route in the wee hours of Saturday

DEHRADUN: Three persons, including an engineer involved in construction of the all-weather road for the central government’s Char Dham project, were killed after boulders fell on them. The incident took place in Chada area on the Bardinath highway route in the early hours of Saturday. According to police, all three bodies have been retrieved from the debris and there is minimal possibility of more casualties.

Mountain and rock cutting work is currently underway for broadening of the Badrinath road. With the Char Dham yatra scheduled to start around April-end, authorities are ensuring round-the-clock work on the route. The boulders fell on the Pokland machine being used in the construction work, damaging it badly. Machines had to be used to remove the debris and pull out the bodies. The deceased have been identified as Himanshu Singh (junior engineer), Pankaj Singh and Rakesh Kumar. While Himanshu and Pankaj are from Chamoli district, Kumar was a resident of Himachal Pradesh.

Following the accident , traffic was diverted on the Kothyalsain-Nandprayag road. Officials said that the debris would soon be removed and route would open in a short time.

Notably, this is not the first accident during the ongoing all-weather road project in the state. In the past too, deaths have been reported due to works on the project which aims to widen the highways leading to the Char Dham shrines. In a major accident in December 2018, seven labourers were killed and four others sustained injuries after they were trapped in the landslides while working on the project. The accident was reported in Rudraprayag district of Garhwal .

In March 2019, two persons were killed in a landslide while they were working on the all-weather Road project in Tehri district of Garhwal.

The accident occurred near Nagni on Chamba-Rishikesh stretch of the all-weather project when an operator and a helper were using the Pokland machine on the road construction site and a sudden landslide brought down silt and boulders on the machine.

Title: 3 years of Uttarakhand government: How has tourism minister fared?
Content:
DEHRADUN: One of the senior-most ministers in the Trivendra Singh Rawat cabinet, tourism minister Satpal Maharaj’s tenure has seen an increase in tourist inflow in the state but at the same time, many of his announcements meant to bolster the tourism scenario — like introducing submarines and seaplanes in Tehri lake, starting over half a dozen ropeway projects as well as developing a new destination in each of the 13 districts — have either remained non-starters or have moved at a snail’s pace.

Defending the initiatives taken and work done by him, Maharaj told TOI, “It takes time for a project to be completed, especially in the hills. The work is on for several projects like Tehri lake development, ropeways and homestays. The change will definitely be visible in the next two years.”

He added that “ever since BJP came to power in March 2017, there has been a substantial increase in the number of tourists visiting the state with the Char Dham Yatra last year registering a record turnout of 32 lakh pilgrims.” “Encouraged by the positive response, the state government has given tourism the status of an industry in the state. From planning and preparation stage, we have now moved towards implementation stage where a number of tenders have been awarded and work on many projects have been started,” the minister said, adding that the tourism department has set a target to have 5,000 homestays in the state — up from the present 2,100 — by this year-end.

Meanwhile, tourism industry professionals had mixed views on the initiatives taken by the tourism department. Chain Singh Rawat, trekking and mountaineering operator at Sankri village in Uttarkashi said that while the government had initiated some good schemes, which helped increase the number of tourists in the hill state, there had been no concurrent attempt to bolster infrastructure facilities like road, electricity and communication which were erratic in many tourist places.

As for the homestay scheme, he said that “most people, particularly villagers of remote villages, are not getting the benefit of homestays and other subsidised schemes of government, due to the difficult documentation process and non-cooperation of concerned departments.” “The tourism department should frame a proper tourism policy maybe on the lines of Himachal Pradesh so that the benefits are able to reach those for whom they are intended,” Rawat said.

In a similar vein, Dinesh Bhatt, president of rafting and camping association of Rishikesh, said, “The tourism department has taken steps to boost the sector but there are several key issues pending. In Rishikesh for instance, the camping and rafting business has declined, simply because there is no clear rafting policy drafted by the government — even though NGT, while banning riverside camping along the Ganga, had asked for a policy to be drafted. The result is that tourists are now moving to other states for camping. This could have been avoided."

Title: Hyderabad: Residents take up social media campaign on staying home
Content:
People post pics on Instagram

HYDERABAD: In an attempt to spread awareness on importance of social distancing, a few residents started a social media campaign. “Sometimes, all it takes is a little nudge for people to actually follow instructions. This was the idea behind starting #HydCoronaStopKaroNa challenge,” said Namrata Sadhvani, who along with fellow instagrammer Sunpreet N Sinha, started the campaign.

Inspired by Instagram posts by @dudewithsign to help fight the pandemic, Sinha said, “When the PM made his speech, he mentioned how each one of us can help create awareness about Janata Curfew. This is us doing our bit.”

She said ever since she put up a photo asking people to be cautious and practice social distancing, she received multiple requests from residents in her community wanting to participate in the challenge. The challenge is easy: Just post a photo of yourself with a placard “Ghar Pe Ich Baitho Na”, a fun Hyderabadi twist to what is being said all over the world — “Please Stay Indoors”.

Till now 35 people have participated in the challenge that began on Friday. “We in India have ‘sab chalta hai’ (everything will go on) attitude. This must change. I see people behave as if they are on a summer vacation. They continue to organise birthday parties and events. I wanted to be part of this challenge to let them know that the current situation is a serious one,” said Nandita Bhardwaj, a CA and mother.

Stressing on how important it is to “flatten the curve”, Richa Mundhra, an analyst with Google, said: “Symptoms can show up till 14 days. If people can stay at home during this period, it will make a huge difference. Those who are working, the ‘work from home’ option is a welcome relief.”

Among those who accepted the challenge was Priyanka Mallik, a resident of Lingampally. Mallik tried to catch people’s attention by turning to music. In a video uploaded on Instagram, she raps: “Listen up world, what we gotta say/We can fight together, there is a way/It’s not for you, it’s not for me/But home is where you gotta be.”

Cautioning again panicking, she says, “Don’t hoard stuff and don’t hoard cash/Don’t attend your bff’s bday bash/No sleepovers, no pyjama parties now/No salon visits, not the time for brow/Stay safe and stay back at home/Now is not the time to roam.”

Title: Paan outlets shut, no curbs on shops selling essentials
Content:
Ahmedabad: The district magistrate of Gandhinagar issued a notification on Friday curtailing certain activities and closing shops selling paan masala, from March 20 to March 31. Ahmedabad police also issued an advisory to cops to act according to the notification issued by the commissioner and help the municipal authorities close paan shops.

According to the Gandhinagar notification more than 121 cases of Covid-19 have been registered and it is thus necessary to take certain steps to stop the spread.

The notification bans processions, large meetings, melas, and orders the closing of malls, multiplexes, cinema halls, paan shops, gyms, sports clubs, swimming pools and educational institutes.

The notifications says eateries and restaurants should provide hygienic food and not allow customers to dine in. A top Gandhinagar police official said that they are using force to close shops if needed but are acting according to the notification.

“No shops of essential commodities are being closed. We have beefed up patrolling across the district,” said the official.

Title: Madurai: Burglars beat up man, 72, rob jewellery and cash
Content:
Representational image

MADURAI: Burglars attacked a 72-year-old man and took away 65 sovereigns of gold jewellery and Rs 1 lakh cash from his house. The incident took place in Palkulam village near Srivaikuntam in Tuticorin district on Saturday.

Police said that Balasubramanian, a fuel station owner was residing alone in his house ever since his wife passed away four years. His daughters, who are married, were living in Valliyoor , Tirunelveli district .

At around 5am on Saturday, two unidentified people gained entry into the house by breaking open the back door. The duo tied Balasubramanian with ropes and taped his mouth.

The accused then stole the gold jewellery and cash from the locker and left the place. Electrician Sakthikumar who went to the house later in the day was shocked to see Balasubramanian tied up, and rescued him.

Suspecting the hand of people known to the victim, the Srivaikuntam police quizzed his relatives and those working in his house and fuel station.

Title: Rush for vegetables causes price rise in Madurai markets
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

Anticipating uncertain times, all vegetable markets in the city witnessed a huge turnout of customers on Saturday as they made bulk purchases. The increase in the crowd also saw vegetable prices rising by at least 30%.

Central vegetable market, Paravai market, farmers market at Anna Nagar and Bibikulam, K Pudur market, Thayir market as well as roadside markets on Bypass Road witnessed a sudden throng of men and women. Most of them purchased vegetables to stock up to 15 days instead of their usual one week. “Janata curfew has been called on Sunday. But we do not know what lies ahead and if it all it is a pandemic, how long will it last. What if markets are also shut like parks and large commercial establishments. I have purchased double the quantity of vegetables than my usual weekly quota,” said K Vijayalakshmi from Surya Nagar .

J Velavan from Ponmeni said there is panic among the public because of rumours that markets too will be closed as a preventive measure. With the public transport system also curtailed, the price of vegetables may increase further, he said. “The increased demand for vegetables has resulted in price rise. It is only 9 am, but more than half of the vegetables I purchased today has been sold out. Though it is only a one-day voluntary curfew, panic among the public is quite evident through the way they purchase,” R Selvam, a vegetable seller said.

Prices of all vegetables including onion, tomato, carrot, beans, coconut, brinjal, ladies finger and cabbage have gone up. While already they have witnessed an increase of up to 30%, it may rise further depending on how people react to the situation, he added.

Many residents said they have already purchased essentials required for the next one month from grocery stores and medical stores. It has resulted in the increased crowd in grocery stores, be it at the ones next door or wholesale grocery stores.

Title: Agency shuts itself to outside world
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Major tourist destinations in the Agency in Visakhapatnam district have closed as part of measures by Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) authorities to ensure no tourists enter the area.

The entry of tourists from the Ghat road entry points (S Kota-Araku road, Vaddadi-Paderu road, Narsipatnam-Ghat road and the road that connects to Odisha) will be blocked and guards placed at all four Ghat road points that lead to Araku, Paderu, Tajangi, Lammasinghi, Chaprai and Kothapalli waterfalls.

“We are going for a complete shutdown, right from the tribal museum in Araku, the Padmanabha Gardens and waterfalls at all tourist hotspots have been closed.

This step was taken to ensure that nobody passes through the Agency, which is a vast area, spread over 11 mandals and almost 6,500 square km,” said DK Balaji, project officer, ITDA, Paderu. Integrated Tribal Development Agency PO has also issued instructions ordering people running homestays to list the number of non-locals in the Agency, banning village fairs and shutting down all tourist spots. Balaji added, “This measure was taken out of fear that some people might try to come to the Agency just to escape the self-quarantine in the urban areas. In such a scenario, we cannot control the flow of tourists and are forbidding everybody who is a tourist not to enter the Agency.”

Sources in the tourism department added that quarantining the Agency area was the only way to control the flow of traffic and added that mass gatherings at all major religious places have also been banned.

Title: COVID-19: Madurai Kamaraj University to hold online classes
Content: MADURAI: The Madurai Kamaraj University MKU ) has urged its students to make use of the digital education platform being provided by the consortium for educational communication (CEC) to study university course subjects from their homes. The university, following the government’s orders for COVID-19 prevention, has been shut down from March 16 till March 31.In a formal notification issued on Friday, the university said that e-content courseware for 87 under graduate subjects are available on the CEC website (http://cec.nic.in/). “Two weeks is a long time, so we, of course, want to keep students engaged. We told our students to consider as if still they were at the university and spend at least a minimum of four to five hours studying or doing assignments,” said Dr R Sudha, director, educational multimedia research centre (EMMRC) at MKU. The EMMRC, Madurai has so far hosted 1,570 e-contents in CEC website.The notification further mentioned that students can make use of study webs of active learning for young aspiring minds (SWAYAM) platform, a programme by the Ministry of human resource development that enables professors and faculties of centrally funded institutions like IITs, IIMs, etc., to offer massive open online courses (MOOCs). In the current semester, CEC is also delivering more than 150 SWAYAM MOOCs for under graduate and post graduate courses. Students can also study from CEC-UGC YouTube channel and make use of the educational curriculum-based lectures for free. Some MKU departments have also prepared timetables for online seminars and assignments and sent them via email for students to follow and learn from home.`Meanwhile, on the TV platform, 11-subject based SWAYAM Prabha DTH channels are available on DD free dish, Dish TV and Reliance Jio mobile App.

Title: Hospital manager duped with lure of cheap masks
Content:
Ahmedabad: A deputy manager of a private hospital, who also runs a business in surgical supplies, lost Rs 1.56 lakh to cheats who snared him with the promise of providing face masks at cheap rates. The cheats had promised to supply 1.35 lakh masks for Rs 19,84,000 and took an advance of Rs 1.56 lakh, after which they stopped communicating with the victim.

Chandlodia resident Abhishek Jain, 31, the complainant who works in a hospital in Sola, stated in his FIR at Sola police station on Friday that on February 23, while browsing Facebook, he came upon an advertisement for sale of masks put up by one Gautam Patel.

Jain then called up Patel’s Facebook manager, said inspector J P Jadeja of Sola police station. The manager said the masks were available and sent images of the masks to Jain’s phone. Initially, Jain turned down Patel’s manager’s demand for a token payment in advance. The next day, the manager again called up Jain and convinced him to pay the advance and complete the deal. He sent the bank details of his company, Nvalkaran Health Care Private Ltd, and the photo of the Aadhaar card of one Makrubia Gautam Patel of Surat.

“Jain placed an order for 1.35 lakh masks and transferred Rs 1.56 lakh as advance payment to the bank account given to him,” Jadeja said.

On February 25, the manager called up Jain and said that his consignment has been sent and he will receive it by evening. “However, the consignment of masks never arrived. Later the manager also switched off his phone and went underground. Jain waited for a few days and tried to find the company himself. On realizing that he had been cheated he approached police,” Jadeja said.

Jadeja added that they suspect a company located in Rajkot and a team is verifying the account.

Title: After two more cases turn positive in city, 24 close contacts put in quarantine
Content:
Facility for rail passengers to wash hands at the entrance of the station

Surat: Total number of COVID-19 cases in the diamond city has reached to three after two male patients, a 67-year-old and another 23-year-old, tested positive of the virus on Saturday. The condition of the 67-year-old patient is stated to be critical and has is on ventilator at the Mahavir hospital located in Athwalines.

Official sources said that both the COVID-19 positive patients have foreign travel history. The 67-year-old patient is a diamond trader operating from Mahidharpura diamond market and is a resident of Nanpura area. He had recently gone to Jaipur and Delhi on business tours where he is believed to have come in the contact with coronavirus positive patient. He was admitted in the Mahavir hospital after his health deteriorated from suspected coronavirus symptoms on March 17.

“The condition of the 67-year-old patient admitted in Mahavir hospital is very critical. We are in the constant touch with the Mahavir hospital authorities to get updates on his health. He has been kept on ventilator after he stopped responding to the treatment,” said deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), Dr Ashish Naik.

According to Dr Naik, another patient, a 23-year-old male from Athwa zone who visited Sri Lanka and Dubai and returned from a foreign study tour on March 15 has tested positive on Saturday. He was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil hospital for suspected symptoms of coronavirus on March 19. His samples were sent for laboratory testing at Ahmedabad.

Earlier, a 23-year-old woman having foreign travel history to London had tested positive of the virus on Thursday. The patient, who is studying in London, had landed in Mumbai on March 13 and reached Surat on March 14. She was admitted in the New Civil hospital’s isolation ward March 16. “The coronavirus positive cases in the city has gone up to three. A total of 24 close contacts of the two positive patients were shifted to the quarantine facility at VNSGU’s Samras hostel for 14 days,” said deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), Dr Ashish Naik.

Title: Five suspected COVID-19 cases in Kanyakumari, one dies
Content: MADURAI: A 59-year-old woman admitted as a suspected case of COVID-19 died in the Kanyakumari government medical college hospital on Saturday night. She was one of the five new suspected COVID-19 patients who were admitted in Kanyakumari hospital on Saturday.“The woman had no travel history. The patient came in an already critical condition from a private hospital and was suffering from multiple illnesses. She had suffered a left-ventricular heart failure. Only as a precaution, we are keeping her in the mortuary as for any severe infectious cases,” said Kanyakumari GH Dean, Dr R Suganthy, speaking to TOI. The body is to be kept in the mortuary till results for the COVID-19 investigations are received. Samples taken from the woman and the four other cases have been sent to the Tirunelveli medical college hospital for testing and results are expected to arrive by Sunday.The four other patients admitted in the Kanyakumari hospital on Saturday are an eight-month-old baby who returned from abroad, a 49-year-old man who returned from abroad, a 26-year-old man from Kerala and a 52-year-old woman with no travel history abroad.

Title: Over 500 Indian medical students stuck at Kazakhstan due to Covid-19 threat
Content: Dehradun: More than 500 Indian students — who had been studying MBBS and medical-related courses at universities in Kazakhstan — are unable to return home due to travel services being disrupted on account of the Covid-19 threat. One of the students who is stuck at Almaty, one of the largest cities in Kazakhstan, told TOI over phone, “There are more than 5000 Indian students enrolled in different medical universities of Kazakhstan with a large chunk of them being from Rajasthan. Around 2000 Indian students have decided that they will be staying in their hostels in Kazakhstan until the Covid-19 threat passes over. Some had already left but there are over 500 students who wish to return but can’t because travel services have been disrupted.”The student added that flights to India are being suspended from March 22 and on the same day, Kazakhstan is also stopping inter-state travel.Zain Khan, a medical student, added, “Our college is in Semey and from there, coming to Almaty takes almost 24 hours by train. Many of us had booked our flights between March 22 to 28 but due to restriction on foreign flights to India in that period, all of them got cancelled. We can’t go back to our hostel in Semey as inter-state travel is banned from Sunday and even if we reach our hostel somehow, the management won’t allow us to enter the campus as they will send us to the medical centre where we will be put in self-isolation for at least two weeks.”Shahrukh, another medical student, further said that most students are hard-pressed for funds and “not much help has also been forthcoming from the Indian embassy.”

Title: Officials use tom-toms to sensitise villagers
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Paderu ITDA officials have fallen back on the age old method of using tom-toms to spread awareness on coronavirus.

The lack of modern communication methods and poor cell phone network in remote villages has forced officials to turn to the time-tested communication method with the local populace. “The problem is with cell phone network. We do not have connectivity in much of the agency and the only way to make public announcements is through tom-toms. This is a very effective method of communicating with the people and educating them on the new threat,” ITDA-PO DK Balaji said. Sources in ITDA added that instructions have been given to volunteers to spread the message among people in the agency. However, officials claim that raising awareness is becoming an issue in the agency, where people are not acquainted with sanitisers or hand washes, considering the fact that in many households even running water is not available.

“One of our key instructions to volunteers is to alert authorities in-case outsiders come to a particular village and reside with friends or relatives,” Balaji said.

Title: Kalajathas to spread awareness
Content:
Visakhapatnam: NGOs, health workers and the tribal welfare department are raising awareness among tribals in Visakhapatnam agency about coronavirus and the precautionary measures to be taken.

Nature— an organisation based out of Araku Valley has taken up a week-long sensitisation programme about symptoms and spread of coronavirus through Kalajatha (folk theatre) in Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) areas of Paderu. They are also spreading awareness on janata curfew. TNN

Title: Ballygunge condo women test -ve
Content:
Kolkata: The three residents of a prominent highrise on Ballygunge Circular Road, who had been taken for tests twice on Friday since two of them had returned from abroad and the third being mother of one of the returnees, have all tested negative. They have returned home but have been advised home isolation.

There was much drama at the high rise for the last two days over one of the returnees, who is studying in the UK, being unwilling to isolate herself. Residents complained that she was also driving in and out of the complex at will, despite repeated requests from them. The other returnee, who has come from San Francisco after visiting her son, had initially not put herself in self-isolation but had done so when residents requested her.

When they couldn’t convince the women, the residents first complained to the Ballygunge police station. “When we found that this kept the girl home but her maid was all over the complex, we had no choice but to take our plea to the chief minister,” said a resident. The two returnees and the mother of the young girl were first taken to the Beliaghata ID for tests but they came back home. Later, they were taken back again to the quarantine centre at CNCI’s new complex at New Town where they were kept for the night.

“They returned this morning. Police assured us that they have tested negative but have been made to sign a bond where they have assured the administration that they will remain indoors for the next 15 days,” a resident said. The residents’ committee has decided to keep a vigil on them.

Title: Covid-19 concerns: Parents complain as private school in Madurai tries to hold special classes
Content: MADURAI: A private school at Nagamalai-Pudukottai area in Madurai district has allegedly been attempting to hold special classes for Class XI students during last few days despite the state government’s closure order except for board exams. On Saturday, state board exams for Class X, which were to begin on March 27, were also postponed to April 15. Pandiarajan B, member, Child Welfare Committee (CWC), Madurai said “Parents came to us saying that during the past few days, the school authorities have been telling Class XI students that special classes will happen. Even school buses came to pick up students as usual. However, a few hours later, the students were sent back home. Some students were dropped off by school buses creating distress for parents.” He added that despite informing an official at the office of the chief educational officer (CEO), Madurai on Thursday, students were still forced to come to school till at least Saturday.Many parents, especially those who live or work in areas far from the school were unable to immediately to pick up their children either. “On Friday, my child was forced to come to school but was later dropped off by the school bus much earlier than the usual time putting me in a fix to pick up from the usual drop off spot. My child was alone and had to get an auto-rickshaw to come home. We are all worried about our child’s safety,” said a parent, on condition of anonymity.Further, the parents claimed that students were even sent to teachers’ houses for classes. “On Saturday, the school told us that the students were at their teacher’s house and gave us an address to pick up our child from. We were shocked,” added the parent. Speaking to TOI, Madurai district CEO R Swaminathan said that he will immediately look into the matter. “I will definitely call up and warn the school. Anyone with information that a particular school is holding special classes can immediately inform us. We will take strict action,” he said.

Title: Plan to map areas having people with flu symptoms
Content: KOLKATA: The latest coronavirus case reported from Salt Lake with no travel history abroad has prompted the state administration start working on an alternative plan to stop the virus from spreading further.The state government has already asked the Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) and different municipalities and corporations to conduct a detailed survey in their respective areas and map those areas where people have been suffering from fever and other symptoms like cough and sneezing. “This survey will take some time because we need to go from door to door for the study,” a state health official said.Civic bodies have been asked to expedite the household survey and map the areas having considerable number of patients. KMC will then put to use its available health infrastructure (malaria clinics) and its pool of doctors to screen patients from these areas and refer a few, if necessary, to government hospitals for tests. “The primary screening is necessary. Otherwise, people will crowd Beliaghata ID Hospital for with common flu symptoms,” a KMC doctor said.The survey will also help the state take into consideration the lockdown plan in case of an emergency. “Lockdown is a possibility but it will have a wider impact and the state and the health department will have to be prepared to meet the possible consequences. We will have to ensure the basic amenities to people because their movement will be restricted. So lot of administrative works need to be done before this is implemented,” the official said, adding that the government will explore the option only after more than 10% of citizens in a particular area gets affected.According to health officials, Bengal has just entered the second week and it will take a couple of weeks more to assess the extent of the virus spread. “So far, all but one detected with coronavirus came from outside. If we reach the next level, where the spread is within the state, we will be able to decide on the next course of action,” a senior health department official said. Given the state’s high population density, the government is also keeping plans of a “partial lockdown” ready. “We are not ruling out the possibility. We are keeping a close tab on the situation,” the official said.The state government has been heading for the lockdown plan in phases. The education department has put the ongoing HS examinations on hold after calling off the Public Service Examination. The health department has enforced a lockdown on restaurants, pubs, nightclubs and has also suspended shooting till March 31. The state transport department has cancelled inter-state bus services from the city. Kolkata Police is reaching out to households following complaints from the neighbourhood against people ignoring the self-isolation advisory and stepping out of their homes after returning from abroad.

Title: 10k throng Guntur market yard as officials throw caution to winds
Content:
Guntur: Farmers are thronging the agriculture market yard in Guntur with huge stocks of chilli . The market yard has been flooded with over 1.5 lakh bags each day for the past few days. Farmers are believed to be rushing to sell their stocks for fear of the state government regulating the transactions as part of measures to contain the spread of covid-19 virus in the coming days. The rush of stocks has dipped the price by Rs 1,000 to Rs 1,500 per quintal on Friday.

However, market committee officials took no steps to follow protocol set by the state government. The market committee neither kept sanitisers and face masks ready nor made merchants follow guidelines.

The market yard is heavily crowded with the massive arrival of stock as nearly 4,000 to 5,000 farmers are coming from different parts of Telugu states including Khammam, Nalgonda (Telangana), Krishna, Kurnool, Anantapur, Prakasam and Nellore districts besides the local farmers.

The market yard is witnessing near stampede like environment due to the presence of huge number of farmers.

In addition to the farmers, about 2,000 hamalis (daily wagers) and another 1,000-1,500 workers are also spending almost 20 hours in the market yard. About 400-500 traders and market committee staff were also working over-time in the yard keeping in view the peak season arrivals. This is making the market yard premises heavily crowded with over 8,000-10,000 people moving in very close proximity.

According to information, about 400-500 chilli exporters from different states including Maharashtra, West Bengal, New Delhi, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh are visiting the market yard to supervise the purchases.

Although, farmers coming from rural areas might not be carriers of the virus, travelling in buses and trains might put them in danger, said a trader in the market yard. Similarly, the presence of exporters from other states is creating fears in the yard as they might just leave everyone in trouble, he noted. In fact, marketing commissioner PS Pradyumna had directed the market yard officials to follow all covid-19 protocols to prevent the spread of virus. He asked officials to keep the sanitisers ready for the staff and make the commission agents supply sufficient number of masks and sanitisers to the weighmen, hamalis, farmers and their staff. Surprisingly, the officials have not followed even a single instruction issued by the commissioner as well as the district collector.

“We have asked the merchants to provide masks, hand sanitisers and napkins to the farmers and staff,” said market committee secretary M Venkateswara Reddy. However, the market committee had not initiated measures to check whether anyone is following the instructions. In fact, district collector Samuel Anand Kumar had issued detailed guidelines on crowd management in market places to contain the spread of viruses.

Commission merchants Association secretary Suresh Reddy alleged that the market yard secretary is least bothered about the situation and not taking any inputs from the traders. Meanwhile, the average prices have come down to Rs 8,000-Rs 10,000 per quintal from the previous Rs 10,000-Rs 12,000 per quintal.

Title: Life in rural areas of western Maha comes to standstill
Content:
Kolhapur: The coronavirus scare has gripped the rural parts of western Maharashtra resulting in an undeclared curfew.

Several youths and students, who have moved to Pune — a city that has recorded a high number of Covid-19 cases — for education and work, are planning to return to their native places.

Private bus operators have already stopped their services to western Maharashtra. A huge rush of commuters was seen at Swargate bus depot in Pune, from where buses leave for Satara, Sangli, Solapur and Kolhapur.

As a precautionary measure, the administrations of all four districts are planning to start passenger screening at all entry points. Kolhapur already has 20 checkpoints while Sangli on Saturday started a similar activity in four places. Sangli district collector Abhijit Chowdhari issued an order on Saturday declaring the four screening spots at Peth, Ankali, Peth Wadgaon and Nagaj.

A team of health officials, accompanied by police, have been deputed at four places to check on people showing symptoms. Any suspected commuter is immediately transported to the nearest government hospital for further medical investigation. Satara and Solapur administration are also thinking to start similar screening points at various junctures in the city, sources said.

Life in rural parts has been badly affected as people are strictly preferring to stay indoors. Locals are seen making food arrangement in the first half of the day, as the roads are deserted post noon.

Maharashtra and Karnataka state road transport corporations have suspended their several services to stop people from travelling. Hence, buses are seen parked at ST stands in the border areas of both the states.

Government officials and organizations have requested the citizens to observe a strict bandh on Sunday as appealed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Collectors, superintends of police, Zilla Parishad chief executive officers and municipal commissioners have issued a joint press statement, appealing people to observe the janata curfew. Meanwhile, a 34-year-old youth, who had returned from Chile, was kept in Satara civil hospital after he showed some symptoms of Covid-19. District civil surgeon Amol Gadikar said that swab sample has been sent to Pune based National Institute of Virology .

Title: Fever helpline records 10-fold rise in calls
Content: Ahmedabad: At EMRI’s headquarters in Kathwada, on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, time melts under artificial lights for the 30-odd call centre executives handling the 104 fever helpline round the clock. They face a barrage of calls, primarily related to COVID-19.“The average daily calls before Monday were close to 100. From Monday, the first day of the unofficial lockdown, the calls started escalating and our average calls reached 800,” said a senior 104 coordinator. “From Thursday – when we recorded our first positive case — it has reached 8,000.”Jashvant Prajapati, the COO of EMRI Gujarat, said that the service works with the state health department to disseminate the right information. “Citizens want to know about the new viral infection and how to safeguard against it,” he said. “Of the total calls, about 60% are to inquire about the helpline itself. A few also call to ascertain whether the symptoms they have are associated with COVID-19.”Alpa Parmar, one of the executives, said: “A woman asked whether people can get infection from the auto driver stationed outside their society.” The woman said the driver often takes passengers from the international airport. “We commended her concern and told her to follow good hygiene practices and also impart those habits to the driver if possible,” Parmar said.The majority of the calls are from four major cities, topped by Ahmedabad, which accounts for about 40% of the calls. “Our task is not only to provide answers to queries but also to assure people that if needed, they can get help including hospitalization,” said Pooja Patel, another executive.

Title: TTD gives 2.8 lakh free laddus to employees
Content:
TTD has distributed nearly 2.8 lakh laddus free of cost to its employees.

TIRUPATI: The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams has distributed nearly 2.8 lakh laddus free of cost to its employees on Saturday.

Considering its high demand, Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams prepares nearly 4 lakh laddus, each weighing 175 grams, every day.

Besides, it keeps a stock of nearly three lakh laddus. But following the closure of the Lord Venkateswara temple to pilgrims, TTD has been left with nearly 2.8 lakh laddus and approximately 1,000 Kalyanotsavam large laddus. The temple administration in order to prevent the prasadam from going waste distributed them among its employees on Saturday, ahead of the Telugu new year Ugadi.

Title: Kolhapur: People throng shops ahead of ‘janata curfew’
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

KOLHAPUR: The markets in the city witnessed a large number of people buying essential goods ahead of the ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday.

There were queues in shops, since early in the morning till late evening though the district administration said the essential supply will be available. Due to panic purchase, essentials like milk was in short supply on Saturday afternoon. People also thronged meat markets.

One customer said: “We eat mutton or fish every Sunday so we decided to stock up incase shops remain shut. Also, the mutton sellers said they are unsure of opening their shops on Monday as well.”

Apart from the essential supply shops, everything else was shut in malls. At one of the malls in Tarabai Park, only 20 people were allowed at a time and the next batch of 20 was allowed after 10 minutes of the previous batch coming out.

The mall operators ensured that only one person from a family is allowed to enter at a time. This was done to ensure that people does not hoard the essentials.

Requests were made to the buyers not to buy in excess.

The railway stations and the central bus stand saw a surge in the number of people travelling back to their home town. Many of them depend on the hotels and the roadside eateries which too will remain shut on Sunday.

The passengers had to wait for hours as the state transport department has cut down the number of buses.

There was no check on the number of people entering the buses even after the state government’s directions to allow 50% of the total occupancy of the bus.

The shops started closing down from Saturday afternoon. The shop owners said they have been told by the administration to shut down the shops. Similarly, roadside eateries and tea-stalls were shut.

Title: People queue up at retail stores to stock supplies
Content:
People at a city retail outlet waiting for their turn to buy groceries. There is an increased demand for items... Read More

Hyderabad: A day before Janata Curfew, denizens were seen queueing up at retail shops to stock up on food supplies, bottled water, medicines, and other household necessities. A number of malls and shops in the city will remain closed on Sunday.

“Products such as rice, atta, pulses, edible oil, sugar, instant noodles, butter, frozen food, soaps, handwashes, and floor cleaners are now difficult to get at malls and supermarkets with most shelves empty,” said Saira Ahmed, a resident of Begumpet.

Unwilling to go out for grocery shopping amid coronavirus scare, many are opting to order products online. There is an increased demand for items such as frozen foods, ready to eat packets, milk products, and beverages and so most of the products are already out of stock.

“As much as it is convenient to get grocery products right in front of our door in a time like this, most of the delivery slots provided to us are delayed. We are getting our order two-three days later which isn’t helpful given most of us are in self-isolation,” Salva Rai, a resident of Somajiguda, told TOI.

Most in-demand items like handwash, soaps, and sanitisers have been off shelves for a long time now, while kitchen supplies like onions, potatoes, rice, and wheat, are stocked out across platforms, say customers.

“The fact that shops are going to be closed for a day should not alarm people as most of them have already bought food items that should last them till the end of the month. Hoarding products is not the solution as many who are in need might not even get to buy them,” said a customer at a local kirana store.

Meanwhile, people were seen going around in many localities in the city asking the residents not to venture out on Sunday.

Title: Covid-19: Rajasthan locks down till March 31
Content: JAIPUR: All government and private offices, malls, transport operations barring essential services will remain shut across the state till March 31 as chief minister Ashok Gehlot directed a complete lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19.The order states all factories, public transport, shops and private and government offices will remain closed from March 22 till March 31. Governor Kalraj Mishra had recently issued a notification declaring coronavirus as a pandemic while making it mandatory for doctors to report each and every case to the health authorities.Gehlot has also directed the labour department to make sure that no employee working in factories is sacked during the period. “Factory owners should give holidays to their employees till the lockdown is over,” said Gehlot. To ensure that no family faces shortage of food, he said families registered under NFSA will get the two months of food supplies in advance for free.Similar arrangements have been made for street vendors, daily wage earners and those in need living in urban areas.“The local administration will provide them two months’ ration on or from April 1,” said Gehlot.The chief minister has formed a high-level committee to take important decisions and to ensure its strict implementation. The committee is headed by additional chief secretary (home) Rajiv Swaroop.The government has also decided to release pensions under social welfare schemes early-April.

Title: Unseasonal rains damage crops, 8 dists worst-hit
Content:
Hyderabad: Notwithstanding the massive impact the closure of commercial establishments due to Covid-19 will have on revenues of the state, unseasonal rains and hailstorms have dealt another blow on standing crops.

Paddy, mango, lime, maize and vegetables in various districts were damaged in the rains and hailstorms. Officials involved in assessing the extent of damage said the impact on the crops was severe in Suryapet, Nalgonda, Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri, Jangaon, Warangal, Suryapet, Rangareddy and Khammam.

“Farmers should intimate the loss within 72 hours to the insurance firm on toll-free numbers 18005992594 or 18001035499,” said an official. The firm will appoint a loss assessor within 48 hours from receipt of intimation. The civil supplies department is also making arrangements to procure wet and damaged paddy from the farmers. tnn

Title: TDB closes all major temples till March 31
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Travancore Devaswom Board TDB ) has announced several restrictions, including barring entry of devotees at major temples and special work arrangements for its staff, as precautions to curb the spread of Covid-19 cases. The self-imposed restrictions will be in place till March 31."The board decided to maintain vigil against the spread of Covid-19. One of the major decisions is to bar entry of devotees till March 31 at administrative office grade and special grade temples," said TDB president N Vasu on Saturday.Temples like Sabarimala fall under administrative office grade temples and temples such as Thiruvallam Parasurama temple that sees large gathering of devotees on a daily basis comes under the special grade temple. As a result, there would be no entry for pilgrims at Sabarimala temple that opens for Uthram festival on March 28.Falling in line with government decision, Saturdays will be holidays for TDB employees till March 31. Employees in the rank of assistant commissioner and below would need to report for work on alternative days during the period. Officials in the rank of commissioner and administrative officer will work as usual.As per the changes which came into effect on Saturday, pujas will be held in administrative and special grade temples on schedule. Temple fests should be restricted within its compounds. No elephant should be paraded as part of festival during this period. All advance bookings for offerings should be rescheduled at a later date.Temple employees would be given masks and gloves. Hand sanitizer would be made available at every temple.

Title: Sirens to blow at 5 pm today; buses, autos to remain off roads
Content:
Kolhapur: All six fire stations in the city will blow sirens at 5 pm on Sunday to inform people to spare a few minutes and applaud the efforts of all those working for emergency/essential services across the country.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in his address to the nation on Thursday, said that everyone must respect and appreciate the endless efforts of health workers in trying to contain the spread of coronavirus.

All the government agencies have pledged to observe the janata curfew. The PM has advised people to stay indoors as much as possible, adding that they should observe the janata curfew from 7 am to 9 pm. He said that the moment sirens are blown, citizens should come to their balconies/terraces and clap as a token of appreciation for those working in the essential/emergency services sector.

Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti held several meetings with the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) staff on Saturday. “We have appealed to the citizens to observe the janata curfew. We have six fire stations located at various places in the city. The fire staff will blow sirens at 5 pm.”

In addition, the Kolhapur Municipal Transport (KMT) bus service as well as autorickshaws will remain off the roads on Sunday. However, water and power supply services will continue as usual. The sanitation staff has been asked to pick up garbage from roads and open spaces on Saturday night. Over 2,500 staff will be deployed to clean the city streets and gardens.

District administration has said that all essential services such as chemist stores and milk shops will remain open. The janata curfew is a voluntary initiative; however, the administration is making all efforts to make it a successful one.

Content: JAIPUR: All government and private offices, malls, transport operations barring essential services will remain shut across the state till March 31 as chief minister Ashok Gehlot directed a complete lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19.The order states all factories, public transport, shops and private and government offices will remain closed from March 22 till March 31. Governor Kalraj Mishra had recently issued a notification declaring coronavirus as a pandemic while making it mandatory for doctors to report each and every case to the health authorities.Gehlot has also directed the labour department to make sure that no employee working in factories is sacked during the period. “Factory owners should give holidays to their employees till the lockdown is over,” said Gehlot. To ensure that no family faces shortage of food, he said families registered under NFSA will get the two months of food supplies in advance for free.Similar arrangements have been made for street vendors, daily wage earners and those in need living in urban areas.“The local administration will provide them two months’ ration on or from April 1,” said Gehlot.The chief minister has formed a high-level committee to take important decisions and to ensure its strict implementation. The committee is headed by additional chief secretary (home) Rajiv Swaroop.The government has also decided to release pensions under social welfare schemes early-April.

The committee is headed by additional chief secretary (home) Rajiv Swaroop.The government has also decided to release pensions under social welfare schemes early-April.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Goa seals borders, to allow only essential items, residents
Content: PANAJI: Goa braced itself to contain the spread of Covid-19 by sealing its borders with neighbouring Maharashtra and Karnataka from midnight. All passenger vehicles will be denied entry and only essential goods, other cargo and bonafide residents of Goa would be permitted to enter the state.“Even though there has not been a single positive case in Goa, considering the critical phase the country is going through, it is necessary to be more vigilant and take all preventive measures that are required to prevent the community transmission of the virus,” chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Saturday.The order was issued a day after the Karnataka government banned entry of passenger vehicles from Goa and Maharashtra.“We don't want tourists coming to Goa until the situation settles,” health minister Vishwajit Rane said. He also said interstate movement of private vehicles will be restricted.“We will use thermal screening to check occupants of private vehicles. We do not want people coming from neighbouring states to Goa. Families travelling in their personal vehicles will be allowed only after they are screened with thermal guns,” Rane said.Inspector general of police Jaspal Singh told TOI that additional personnel will be deployed to strengthen existing teams at the borders and ensure passenger vehicles from Karnataka and Maharashtra don’t find their way here.The orders have been issued by both district magistrates, R Menaka and Ajit Roy, under section 144 of the CrPC.“Certain stringent measures are required to ban the movement of passenger vehicles viz maxicabs (12+1 seater), heavy passenger vehicles such as contract carriages, stage carriages and all-India tourist buses (tourist omni buses) plying from Karnataka and Maharashtra into North and South Goa districts and vice-versa with immediate effect until further orders,” states the order by the collectors.Any person contravening this order shall be punishable under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).“With Karnataka banning entry of vehicles from Goa and Maharashtra and vice-versa, passenger flow into the state has reduced,” said Singh.On Friday, the state government imposed a ban on assembly of four or more persons and holding of any processions. The district collectors have also banned demonstrations and public meetings on streets. Those violating the order will be penalised under section 188 of the IPC.

Title: Chothi aayo corona?: Gujarati artists belt out topical viral tunes
Content:
Divya Chaudhari

AHMEDABAD: Amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, Gujarati singers are trying to cash in on the Covid-19 virus to go viral, and also spread awareness against at the local level.

A song by Gujarati singer Hitesh Rawal ‘Chothi aayo corona’ deals with the pandemic. It goes: ‘Corona no virus chothi aayo aaje, loko ne kashu na hamjashe, cheti ne rehjo virus valgi jashe. Virus ni charcha charekor aaje, Virus valgi jashe’. (Where did the corona virus come from, people won’t understand anything. They should remain alert or the virus will catch them. The virus has become the talk of the town, stay alert or it will catch you.)

Another song on Covid-19, by folk artist and singer Kiran Patel, ‘Corona thi chetore’ talks about how the virus spread and about social distancing. The lyrics say, ‘Cheen na malak thi farto aayo corona. Timli tane kahu chhe corona thi chetore, hello hi bolo re hath na milavo re. Door-door thi bhaibandho ne namaste bolo re’. (The virus has come all the way from China. I am telling you to be alert about corona. Just say hello-hi, don’t shake hands. Say namaste to your friends from a distance.)

Mehsana-based singer Divya Chaudhari’s new release “Karo namaste Corona ena raste” deals with the awareness aspect. The lyrics says, ‘Hath jodine karo namaste, corona virus halyo jashe ena raste’. (Say namaste with palms together and the virus corona will be on its way.)

About her song, Chaudhari says her stage performances were cancelled due to the pandemic so she thought about reaching out to people during the crisis by releasing a Gujarati song on the virus itself.

“I have been in the Gujarati music industry for two decades and this is the first time I’ve sung a song to make people aware of a disease. I wanted to convey my concern in an entertaining way, so people develop certain habits to prevent the virus spreading in Gujarat,” said Chaudhari.

Another singer, Kiran Patel, says his friends advised him to compose a song to raise awareness which can also be used by youths in their TikTok videos.

“For the last few days, people are talking about the coronavirus. Many of my friends used to talk only about this and they advised me to produce a song. I composed this song using a tribal tune from Panchmahal in such a way that youths can make TikTok videos using it and it will go viral and spread awareness about the coronavirus,” said Patel.

A Gujarati film producer, Narendrasinh Bapu, said some artists have also made a proposal to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) authorities offering help in making an audio and video awareness campaign. “As the coronavirus spreads like a wild fire, Gujarati musicians and even folk singers such as Kirtidan Gadhvi are making their best efforts to make people aware of it,” said Bapu.

Title: Direct pvt hosps to treat patients: Bhatti
Content: Hyderabad: Congress floor leader in the assembly Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka on Saturday demanded that the state government should issue directions to private hospitals to treat the poor for coronavirus (Covid-19), the expenditure of which would be borne by the state government. He also appealed to the people to make the fight against Covid-19 a success by observing ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday. tnn

Title: Breaking quarantine rule to attract police charge: Desai
Content:
Kolhapur: The district administration has threatened to file the police complaints against individuals, who have been instructed to quarantine themselves at home for 14 days, if they violate the quarantine norms.

In the city, around 25,000 persons have been screened for Covid-19 symptoms. The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has found one person with a travel history and he has been put in the quarantine ward.

District collector Daulat Desai has ordered the health staff to keep a watch on the other home-quarantined people. The officials have been asked to visit them thrice every day for follow-ups. Moreover, people completing the home quarantine period must be referred to the CPR Hospital for a final check-up before they are given the go-ahead to move around freely.

“To stop coronavirus transmission, home quarantine has been made compulsory. Those violating the rules will have to face police charges. The health authorities have been asked to forcefully take them into custody and keep them in the quarantine wards,” said Desai.

He added that violators will be charged under various sections of the Indian Penal Code and Communicable Disease Control Act.

So far, the district has had 523 people with symptoms akin to coronavirus infection. Of them, the authorities have identified 495 people who have come to India from abroad. Currently, 384 persons are under home quarantine. There are at least 24 local residents, who do not have any foreign travel history, in home quarantine. No confirmed coronavirus case has been reported in the district yet. The number of swab samples sent for the testing at the Pune-based NIV has increased to 12, which, according to the health officials, is much lower than the number of persons with symptoms.

The number of people completing the 14-day home quarantine period is 138. Collector Desai said these persons have to report the district health authorities time and again for their health check-up. Each such person is given a card stating the suggestions by the doctors.

Satej Patil, district guardian minister, said: “Checkpoints have been set up at several locations. We are tracing the persons coming from abroad. They will be compulsorily brought to the quarantine centres. Those who have come from cities like Pune and Mumbai, will be asked to quarantine themselves.”

Title: Telnades barred from civic council
Content:
Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai late on Friday night issued an order disqualifying two Ichalkaranji municipal council members – Sanjay Telnade and Sunil Telnade. The action has been taken as both of them were absent for six consecutive council meeting without any notice.

Ichalkaranji chief executive officer Deepak Patil had sent the proposal a few days back to disqualify Telnade brothers. Desai approved the proposal. However, Telnade brothers have been given period of 15 days to appeal before the state government.

Telnade brothers are wanted under under Maharashtra Control of Organized Crime Act (MCOCA) and are absconding for the past few months. The MCOCA court in Pune had set the deadline of March 16 for them to surrender before the court but they did not appear. Police are expected to initiate procedure to confiscate all the properties of Telnade brothers as per provisions of MCOCA.

The general body of Ichalkaranji municipal council was expected to pass a resolution on disqualifying Telnade brothers the last month. However, the general body did not take any decision, forcing the administration to send the proposal to disqualify them to the district collector. Sanjay Telnade was elected unopposed.

Telnade brothers are absconding since May last year after police raided a gambling den, being run by them. Police have arrested several of their accomplices, including a lawyer, but both of them continue to give a slip. Police have invoked MCOCA against Telnade gang.

Police have passed all information to Income Tax department and Directorate of Economics to initiate further action. Sanjay Telnade has 17 offences registered against him and his brother Sunil has seven offences registered against him.

Title: Cases filed as temples, mosques & church organize gatherings
Content: Thiruvananthapuram/Kannur: As more Covid-19 cases were reported in Kerala, authorities also cracked the whip on persons disobeying the social distancing and no crowd rule enforced to contain the disease. On Saturday, police booked the office-bearers of Malayinkeezhu Sree Krishna Swami Temple and Vellayani Devi Temple.At Malayinkeezhu, police recorded the arrest of 28 members of the temple committee for organizing a huge procession that saw the participation of hundreds of devotees. Malayinkeezhu SI AB Saiju said the temple committee had gone ahead with the event, disregarding police directive.“We had served them a couple of notices in this regard. But they just went ahead with conducting the event,” he said, adding that the persons, who were booked, were later granted bail after their arrests were recorded. At Vellayani, police booked over 100 persons including the members of the temple trust committee for taking out a procession on the road. They were charged under Sections 51(b) of Disaster Management Act and 118e of Kerala Police Act. Those booked include devotees who took part in the procession.The 70day Vellayani Devi Temple fest will conclude on April 23. Police registered the case on Saturday evening. In the morning, the temple committee members convened a meeting and decided to cancel all public events that are part of the festival.Six cases in Kannur: In Kannur, police registered cases against six places of worship, including Trichambaram temple in Taliparamba and five mosques, for organizing rituals, violating restrictions. Taliparamba deputy SP TK Rathnakumar said a case was registered against authorities of the temple for organizing a mass event.

Title: HC takes up PIL on insanitary conditions at quarantine facilities
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana high court has taken up the insanitary conditions at the quarantine facilities created by the state as a public interest plea. HC is likely to take up the matter on Monday.

Following media reports that the conditions prevailing at these quarantine facilities are not in tune with the hygiene expected at such centres, Justice P Naveen Rao wrote to the judicial registrar on the need to take up the cause. The same was brought to the notice of the Chief Justice and senior judges all of whom agreed to take up the matter as a PIL asking the authorities concerned as to why two to three international passengers are being housed in one room.

Passengers arriving at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) from foreign countries are sent to the designated quarantine facilities. However, the rooms lack even the basic amenities. There is not enough water supply in the washrooms and so all efforts to maintain cleanliness goes in vain.

“While the state’s objective of assessing the health of all international air passengers, the place they chose for isolation wards is not fit for the purpose,” said the PIL, which made the state’s top medical and revenue authorities as respondents. The facilities should be improved immediately, it added.

Title: Minus the festivals, traditional artists stare at uncertain future
Content: Kochi: Sahadevan has been sitting on the portico of his home, for most part of the day, in Thrissur waiting for a booking or a call from his drummers’ group for the past two weeks. He checks his WhatsApp group once more if someone has put a ‘thumbs up’ to join a festival in some remote corner of the state. Unfortunately, these days, there are only posts about precautions to be taken against Covid-19 , he said.As the summer season peaks in Kerala, it is hectic time for drummers and Theyyam artists as two of the state’s popular obsession Melam and Theyyam begin again. These artists get work for only 100 days every year and the three months starting in February are their peak season. They have more than one performance every day and the ensemble travels from one temple to another, earning just enough to survive the entire year.“Covid-19 is like a death sentence to all micro-traditions of Kerala. All of us are going to get severely impacted as all performances and gatherings have been banned. Most artists, who work like daily wage-earners, now find it difficult to make both ends meet,” said Peruvanam Kuttan Marar, who is at the helm of major Melams in state.There are around 5,000 traditional artists in Kerala who subsist on festivals . If Theyyam is a popular art form in north Kerala, central and south Kerala revel on Melams and Panchavadyams, the three-hour orchestra, which has 50-100 participants, that include drummers trumpet blowers and cymbal clangers.The festival circuit also earns good tourism revenue with around 40% of the state’s tourism earnings coming in the first quarter of the year, but as state has clamped down on all large gatherings, there is bound to be a huge dip in the revenue this year.The life of an average drummer, to begin with, is far from easy. He is exposed to the sun, dust and heat for the entire day, standing shirtless and drumming for 10-12 hours every day during the season.Over the years, Melams began got a cult following and its popularity grew, especially among youngsters and thankfully the drummer’s family was slowly lifted from poverty.
