This year, life seems to have come a full circle again.For hundreds of Theyyam artists like Rajesh Peruvannan, a Kannur resident, whose entire family subsist on the 100-odd performances he gives during a season, it can never get worse. "Theyyam is supposed to be the incarnation of god who gives blessings to devotees, but here even God is at the mercy of a largely man-made pandemic," he said.Temple authorities, though they sympathise with this miserable state of artists, cannot do much. "We can only hope that this calamity doesn’t spread to a longer period, then stricter measures may have to be taken. Festivals have already become a pious affair now," said Cochin Devaswom Board Mohanan chairman AB.

Title: Maharashtra businessman duped of Rs 4 lakh in bid to buy machine
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police booked a couple on Friday for duping a businessman from Raigad of Rs4 lakh in 2018 on the pretext of selling him a used earth-moving machine.

Businessman Ajay Rajaram Sapkal (43) has lodged an FIR of criminal breach of trust and cheating under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code.

Sapkal came across an advertisement on an e-commerce website that mentioned that an earth-moving machine had been put up for sale posted by the couple. He wanted to buy it for farming and conducting his construction business.

Senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad from the Kondhwa police said, “Sapkal contacted the couple and expressed interest in buying the machine. On August 18, 2018, Sapkal visited their office in a society building on the Katraj-Kondhwa bypass and the couple shown the machine.”

Gaikwad said, “Sapkal liked the machine and struck a deal with the suspects for buying it for Rs15 lakh. He paid a token amount of Rs50,000 in cash and Rs3.5 lakh by cheque to the couple on September 18, 2018. Sapkal assured the suspects that he would take a loan of Rs11 lakh to buy the machine.”

Sub-inspector Nilesh Chavan from the Khadi Machine Chowkey under the Kondhwa police said, “The couple contacted Sapkal on numerous occasions and asked him to pay the balance amount but he asked for the delivery before he made the payment.”

He said, “The couple failed to deliver the machine and gave vague replies whenever Sapkal tried to contact them. Eventually Sapkal realized that he had been cheated and asked the suspects to return Rs4 lakh to him but in vain.”

On December 18, 2019, Sapkal filed a complaint application with the office of deputy commissioner of police, Zone V.

Later the application was transferred to the Kondhwa police and a preliminary inquiry was conducted before a complaint was registered against the suspects, Chavan added.

Title: Covid-19 in Telangana: Anganwadi centres will continue supplying food to pregnant women
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Even as the Covid-19 threat looms large, anganwadi centres in state will continue to function until further orders. These centres supply cooked food to pregnant women and kids aged below six.

Though almost all commercial and other establishments which witness public gatherings have been ordered to be closed until further orders, the state government has decided to keep the anganwadi centres open so that poor pregnant women, lactating mothers and children have access to nutritious food under the Arogya Laxmi scheme.

Women and child development minister Satyavathi Rathod has directed the officials concerned to make all arrangements for sanitisation of anganwadi centres and ensure that personal hygiene of highest standards is maintained by the staff. “Pregnant women and children from poor background should continue to get cooked food from anganwadi centres as per chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s orders,” said the minister.

Pregnant and lactating women get one full meal under Arogya Laxmi with one egg, 200 ml of milk, rice, dal and vegetable every day. Children in the age group of seven months to three years receive fortified ‘Balamrutham’ packet of 2½ kg and 16 eggs in a month. Those in 3-6 age group, as part of pre-school, get a hot meal of rice, dal, vegetables, egg, and nutri snacks/chana dal daily.

In view of the coronavirus scare, nursdery classes have been put off until further orders and only food is being supplied to the children.

Title: The internet is critical to navigating this pandemic
Content:
We are at a critical point in history. The entire world is being affected by the novel coronavirus COVID-19. Leaders from all walks of life are being tested, as we face an unprecedented situation. From governments to businesses, from societies to families, this pandemic is causing a shift in our way of life – a paradigm shift that puts us all in uncharted territory. The best way to tackle this problem is to ensure that we practice social distancing and good personal hygiene, to ensure that we minimise the chances of community transmission. This implies taking potentially aggressive measures to reduce footfall in places of congregation.

A few decades ago, shuttering shops in this manner would spell disaster for businesses. Today, however, digital business models, the cloud, and new-age technology minimise the erstwhile disruption with the help of high-speed internet. Globally, and especially in India today, broadband is a critical part of the infrastructure needed to realise seamless delivery of essential services. High-speed internet is the prerequisite for uninterrupted life and business today.

Even now, as individuals and families quarantine themselves in their homes, people are already turning to the internet to access not just business solutions to help them outlast the pandemic but to seek solace, entertainment and information on the state of the world. Suddenly, people are trying to establish, “What is essential?” In fact, the interest in the search term, “essential commodities” on Google, has more than doubled in the past three weeks. High-speed internet is needed simply for people to know what is essential and what is not in the coming weeks. People’s social media accounts are starting to turn into mini news outlets while their couch and their laptop become their home office.

For businesses, digitally enabled online operations in the areas of sales, communication, and fulfilment can reduce the impact in today’s disruptive “COVID times”. High-speed data connectivity provides a virtual office-like working environment to all businesses without compromising on safety. As the market shifts, the speed with which businesses act is of the essence. One cannot afford to lose clients due to slow service and other technicalities. A high speed fiber broadband connection ensures that nothing about a business suffers due to the lack of speed or infrastructure, be it while you are having video conferences with the rest of the team or while you are providing services to your clients.

In a crisis, humans have looked to society and their contacts for support. Suddenly, people are being separated from their families, friends, neighbours and social circles as entire cities are entering quarantine. When students and workers are stranded in their college dormitories or in airports abroad, trying to come home or quarantined abroad, being able to pick up a phone and video call them over the internet offers support virtually where distance is an insurmountable factor.

In time, restricted movements, social distancing and the same walls around us, doing the same time, perhaps at home alone, may lead to boredom. To stave off boredom, we turn to the world that the internet offers us. When speed is not restricting someone, the possibilities are endless. It becomes very easy to just pick up that show you’ve been meaning to catch up on and binge it in HD. We may not be able to visit movie theatres, but can stream movies and tv shows that ensures that we have a near endless library of entertainment at hand. Between streaming and gaming, there is enough to keep many people occupied for a long time. If there is a language that you have wanted to learn for a while, now is the time. If you haven’t played the guitar for a while, YouTube lessons are but a click away. There’s a unique opportunity to spend time with and connect with your loved ones. Even if you just run out of groceries, or just want to order take out, you do not need to brave the pandemic and go out, when you can just order things over the internet. Social distancing and working from home have given rise to new ways of working including emergence of concepts like telemedicine and online virtual classes.

I believe that we will emerge from COVID-19 stronger, more united, and wiser. An connected society, thanks to the internet, provides the fulcrum to the combined strength of humanity, for the country’s machinery to continue running in the face of unprecedented headwinds. We have better information, swifter access to emergency services, quality availability of entertainment, instant connectivity to family and friends, uninterrupted and innovative education practices, and access to business solutions and more.

Decades from now, this time will be looked upon as a critical juncture in human history. This will be a trying time, but we will emerge better for it, and it wouldn’t happen if we weren’t as connected as we are today. High-speed internet connectivity has brought us all together, and it will be critical to braving the storm we are in today.

— The author Bala Malladi is the CEO of ACT Internet

Title: In 4 weeks, faux lungs turn grey in less polluted area
Content:
Nagpur: Corroborating air pollution in the city, the faux lungs installed outside KRIMS Hospital on Central Bazaar Road, Ramdaspeth, have changed colour — from pristine white to grey in a span of nearly four weeks. This, despite the area being one of the least polluted ones in the city and the frequent weather changes, including several spells of rain, in the last one month.

Mimicking actual functioning of human lungs, these artificial lungs also capture pollutants, which leads to change in its colour. Called ‘The billboard that breathes’, the lungs are fitted with HEPA (High Efficiency Particulate Air) filters. A pair of fans fitted at the back of the billboard sucks in air to mimic the functioning of lungs while breathing.

In the city, the lungs have been installed under a joint initiative by Jhatkaa.org, Waatavaran, Centre For Sustainable Development (CFSD) and KRIMS Hospitals.

In the second phase of the initiative, the organizations plan to install a couple of artificial lungs at highly polluted places, including traffic junctions. “Ramdaspeth is not one of the most polluted areas in the city. In the first phase, our priority was to sensitize citizens on air pollution. We will now focus on more polluted areas in the next phase,” said Leena Buddhe, founder of CFSD.

Similar lungs installed in Mumbai in January this year turned black in just two weeks. The lungs installed in New Delhi in November last year turned black in just six days while it took 25 days for the ones put up in Bengaluru to change colour.

Activists stressed that just because the faux lungs have not completely turned black yet, doesn’t mean Nagpur is not polluted. “The air quality index being displayed is still way above permissible limits. All cities have areas that are more polluted than others, and weather conditions play a huge role in how quickly the lungs change colour — especially in Nagpur where the installation is at a relatively low pollution spot,” said Shikha Kumar, campaigns manager at Jhatkaa.org.

She added that the several cloudy and windy days along with intermittent rains in the city also played an important role in further delaying the lungs from turning black.

Pulmonologist from KRIMS Hospital, Dr Sameer Arbat, said, “Ramdaspeth is a residential-cum-commercial area that has been regularly showing an AQI above 130. We need to understand that pollution is not limited to industrial areas and need not wait for the faux lungs to turn black to understand the impact of air pollution.”

Bhagwan Kesbhat, founder of Waatavaran Foundation, stated that it was for everyone to see that the HEPAfilter lungs have become dark in four weeks in one of the lesser polluted areas despite unseasonal rain last month. “This is enough indication that Nagpur needs a strong Clean Air Action Plan and citizens need to demand their right to clean air for themselves and the future generation,” he said.

Title: Eight conmen booked for investment fraud of Rs 4.7cr
Content:
Pune: Eight persons were booked on Friday for cheating 32 people to the tune of Rs4.78 crore, by urging them to invest in their startup and promising them handsome returns.

The victims are from Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad and other parts of the district.

Rajashri Wani (43) of Junnar lodged a complaint with the police on Friday stating she and the others had invested money in the company in July last year.

Wani runs a small vehicle service centre in Junnar. The FIR stated, two of the eight suspects approached her in July last year and claimed they had recently started a company and were looking for investors. The suspects claimed the startup had been initiated under the Make In India and Digital India programmes of the Centre.

The suspects told her to visit their office in Baner.

Assistant inspector Shashikant Dhendge of Hinjewadi police station said, where six other persons conducted a presentation for all the investors in the Baner office. The digital firm was involved in marketing, blogging and advertising.

They promised handsome returns on investment. They also gave them the option to secure the firm’s franchise. The suspects said there would be no GST on the investment.

They accepted the investment from the people and gave them a note stating the same, Dhendge said.

The suspects, who said they were from Junnar, Pimpri Chinchwad and Indore in Madhya Pradesh, had promised the returns in a few months.

“Gradually, the suspects stopped answering calls of the investors and they recently shut their office, without returning the invested money of the victims,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Gujarat man escapes twice to avoid quarantine
Content:
Representative image

RAJKOT: A 35-year-old Jamnagar man, who had returned recently from Dubai, gave the local health officials and police a tough time before he was quarantined on Saturday. Police have begun criminal proceeding against him and will be filing FIR against him for violation of government order.

Health officials of the Jamnagar Municipal Corproation (JMC) and local police had to chase Mustafa Hala to Morbi district, after he managed to give the authorities a slip, not once but twice, to attend a marriage function.

According to JMC officials, Hala had returned from Dubai on March 10 and landed in Ahmedabad, where he stayed for a week. As soon as Hala arrived in Jamnagar on March 17, a team from district administration contacted him took him to quarantine centre set up in the city. But Hala gave them a slip and ran away.

Talking to TOI Jamnagar district collector Ravi Shankar said, “We came to know that Hala escaped to attend a marriage function in Morbi district. We informed Morbi collector and superintendent of police to locate this person and also sent our team there.”

According to district officials, when Hala came to know that police and health officials were searching for him, he slipped away from the marriage venue in Malia Miyana town of Morbi.

Hala reached the Gujarat State Road Transport Corporation’s (GSRTC) bus depot, where he saw the health officials chasing him. He boarded the first bus he saw.

The health officials chased the bus and nabbed Hala from the hotel where all bus took a halt. The Morbi police has initiated the process to lodge FIR against Hala.

Title: Three book for violation of govt prohibitory orders
Content:
Palanpur: Three men were booked for violation of prohibitory orders banning gathering of four or more persons in public places.

Police booked Vijay Thakor, Hitesh Solanki and Trikm Solanki for violation of order issued under section 144 of Indian Penal Code.

According to police, the complaint was lodged by constable Yogesh Kumar Parmar stated that Vijay had organised Bhajan programme late on Friday where more than 60 people had gathered near Becharaji Temple in Bhopanagar. He had also hired music system from Hitesh while bhajans were sung by Trikam.

Meanwhile, five people suspected cases were admitted in Patan hospital, said the chief district health officer Bharat Goswami.

Those admitted include a couple that returned from UAE, one woman from Saudi Arabia and one male each from Australia and Malaysia.

Title: Albert Camus and the time of the infodemic
Content:
BENGALURU: As we begin the day to observe Janata Curfew, we continue to be swamped by news and messages about Covid-19. It’s still coming to us, wave after wave, through every channel – comments and notes about the possible origin of the virus , Do’s and Don’ts, country-wise data, the benefits of “regulating” our daily routine, of social distancing, hand-washing and so on. Some useful, some useless and the rest, needless. But we carry on regardless, lapping up everything because after all, very few know enough.

All of which prompted WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus to say, “We’re not just fighting an epidemic; we’re fighting an infodemic.” The organisation’s communication team hunkered down to bust myths: spraying alcohol or chlorine over your body will not kill viruses that have already entered; taking a hot bath does not prevent the disease; ultraviolent lamps should not be used to sterilize hands or that cold weather can’t kill the virus.

News portals have been putting together pandemic reading lists for those who are “stuck at home” and want to pore over apocalyptic fiction and non-fiction. Among the choices are Daniel Defoe’s “A Journal of the Plague Year”, Emily St John Mandel’s “Station Eleven”, Stephen King’s “The Stand”, Ling Ma’s “Severance” and topping them all, Albert Camus’s 1947 masterpiece “The Plague”, whose sales have spiked in recent weeks. Camus’s deeply-philosophical novel set in the plague-hit Algerian town of Oran, looks at human responses to calamities; how death and suffering come unannounced and render everything meaningless. It is this vulnerability that makes life absurd. At the centre of this fight against the epidemic are two strong characters representing duty and faith – Dr Bernard Rieuxo, a physician who’s an atheist, and Father Paneloux, priest and scholar.

But let’s stick to how the novel sees media handling this contagion. Parisian journalist Raymond Rambert meets Dr Rieux in his clinic one afternoon to get details for a story he’s doing on the sanitary conditions of the Arab population. The physician tells him he would share details only if he’s prepared to write an “unqualified condemnation of the present state of things”. Rambert gives up the idea and prepares to leave. Seeing him off, Rieux suggests another development that could make a curious story: the number of dead rats found all over town. At first, there’s disbelief or indifference in the town, but the mood changes.

As days pass, the local newspaper begins to devote its pages exclusively to a campaign against the authorities. Things get worse and the epidemic enters another phase. The radio stops announcing the weekly toll and switches to daily death stats, which the narrator feels lessens the gravity of the crisis. Even amidst paper scarcity that has forced the dailies to cut the number of pages, a new newspaper called “The Plague Chronicle” is launched to inform the townspeople “with scrupulous veracity, of the daily progress or recession of the disease”. For all its noble intentions, the Chronicle ends up devoting space to advertisements about “infallible” antidotes to the disease and the queues outside shops selling these.

Some of these insights came from the intense research Camus did on epidemics down the ages. But even a casual look at reportage in India in 1899 shows an almost gazette-style recording of statistics: “The following is the plague statement for the week ending January 13: Bangalore city – 8 attacks and 13 deaths; Bangalore Cantonment – 84 attacks and 58 deaths; Mysore city – 104 attacks and 79 deaths; Kolar district – 185 attacks and 114 deaths…” About three decades later, reports spoke of health authorities adopting new measures to prevent the spread of plague. They organised a “Rat Week” in 1932 to check the rodent population which included a rat-catching competition, film shows and awareness parades by school children.

Another character in Camus’s novel who is also grappling with communication – or rather, expression – is the kind-hearted Joseph Grand who wants to be an author and spends his time rewriting the opening sentence of his book – sometimes whole weeks on a “mere conjunction”. He once catches hold of Dr Rieux to say: “I grant you, it’s easy enough to choose between a ‘but’ and an ‘and.’ It’s a bit more difficult to decide between ‘and’ and ‘then.’ But definitely the hardest thing may be to know whether one should put an ‘and’ or leave it out.” As absurd as the café in the town which decides to boost its sales with the sign: “The best protection against infection is a bottle of good wine.” Did we hear something similar recently?

At the very end, Camus does allude to the cyclical turn in history. The plague bacillus, he says, “never dies or disappears for good”. The day would come “when it would rouse up its rats again and send them forth to die in a happy city.”

— Jayanth Kodkani

Title: Senior citizen held in Pune for outraging modesty of two women
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Kothrud police on Friday arrested a farmer under the charge of outraging the modesty of a woman and her sister.

The police have invoked provisions of the Maharashtra Prevention and Eradication of Human Sacrifice and other Inhumane, Evil and Aghori Practices and Black Magic Act and Section 354 of IPC.

The complainant (45) runs private coaching classes, while her sister is a medical practitioner. There was a drop in the number of students attending her coaching classes.

In January this year, the sister’s domestic help told the complainant about the suspect — Bharat Ganapati Kemdarane (70) of Osmanabad — whom she claimed practised exorcism. The complainant then contacted Kemdarane.

On February 11, Kemdarane arrived in Pune and went to the complainant’s house. He suggested a nightlong ritual to solve her issues, senior inspector Pratibha Joshi said.

He asked the two sisters to disrobe and used a lemon to perform a “ritual”, Joshi said. He then charged them Rs 7,000. The two women were uncomfortable and suspected that Kemdarane took advantage of them. After mulling this over for a month, the complainant approached the police, who arrested the suspect from Paranda.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Maharashtra: Covid-19 threat looms over census, NPR exercise
Content: PUNE: The state government will explore the option of deferring the implementation of the National Population Register (NPR) and census updates in Maharashtra during a meeting of a cabinet sub-committee March 26.Top government officials said the Centre was likely to postpone census and updating of the NPR, scheduled to kick off in all states between April and September. Officials said the postponement could be attributed to the health ministry’s guidelines limiting mass contact on account of coronavirus. The state government was to undertake the exercise between May 1 and June 15 this year.A minister and a member of the state-government appointed committee told TOI that a final decision on the matter would be taken on March 26. “As the state nears lockdown on account of coronavirus, the execution of the exercise in the predetermined time frame would have to be reviewed,” he said.The government had appointed the sub-committee after protests over the implementation of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and NPR in the state.“The enumerators would be required to go to door-to-door to collect information for the exercise. This would pose a great risk for field functionaries in the wake of coronavirus spread. I think a decision to postpone the two exercises should be taken immediately,” a senior government official said.

Title: Former district vice-president of NCP arrested in extortion case
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch on Saturday night arrested the expelled district vice-president of NCP, Mangaldas Bandal, in the Rs50-crore extortion case lodged by a jewellery firm owner.

ACP (crime) Shivaji Pawar confirmed that the police had arrested Bandal. According to police, Bandal had meetings with the three suspects arrested earlier in restaurants in Camp, Deccan and Market Yard to discuss the plan.

After Bandal’s role popped up in the crime, the NCP expelled him from the party.

Title: Passengers spot man with ‘home quarantine’ stamp, bring train to halt, force him to disembark
Content:
AGRA: New Delhi-Varanasi Shiv Ganga Express was delayed for nearly 30 minutes and brought to an unscheduled halt on Friday night at Etawah junction after passengers raised an alarm when they spotted a fellow passenger with ‘home quarantine’ stamp on his hand.

According to railway sources, the passengers panicked and pulled the chain multiple times. They asked the railway authorities to deboard the passenger with the stamp and sanitize the entire 22-coach train.

The passenger had landed at New Delhi’s IGI airport from Muscat (Oman), where he was stamped for ‘home quarantine’. He boarded the train from New Delhi railway station.

“He had boarded a sleeper coach of the train and later walked into the AC coach. Some passenger noticed a stamp on his hand and tweeted about this to @RailwaySeva. As soon we received the information, we traced the passenger. He looked scared, possibly due to other passenger’s aggressive stance of deboarding him. He had attempted to hide himself in the coach lavatory and also tried to erase the stamp. After help from the GRP squad, we calmed him down and then alighted him at Etawah junction,” said a railway source.

At 9:58 pm, Shiv Ganga Express was brought to an unscheduled halt at Etawah junction. At 10:02 pm, the passenger was taken off the train and sent to Etawah district hospital. Six coaches, including the pantry car, of the train were sanitised.

Multiple sources claimed that the passenger was humiliated by his fellow travellers. He was made to stand in a corner in the train as well as at the Etawah junction, until the medical team arrived.

Etawah CMO Dr Naresh Singh Tomar said, “The passenger was in deep distress. He was thirsty and hungry when he was brought to the hospital. After a thorough check-up, we found him normal.”

Dr Amarnath Tiwari, who inspected the passenger’s health, said, “Though he is normal, we have kept him in the isolation ward of the district hospital as a precautionary measure. After 72 hours, if shows any symptoms of Covid-19 infection, we will send his sample to KGMU.”

Earlier on Thursday night, Old Delhi-bound Kalindi Express was delayed for nearly an hour at Tundla junction after a woman passenger made distress call about a 64-year-old passenger, who had coughed in the AC1 coach while interacting with his relative over the phone. The passenger has returned from Dubai on February 29 and was heading back to Delhi for his medical check-up, as he was not screened at IGI airport when he landed.

Ajit Singh, chief public relations officer of North Central Railway, said, “The passenger was attended by a railway doctor who found him fit to continue his journey.”

According to railway sources, the senior citizen was secluded in a coupe on the demand of other passengers for the rest of the journey.

Title: DK gears up for Janata Curfew
Content: Mangaluru: Dakshina Kannada is getting ready for a total shutdown on Sunday, following a request from Prime Minister Narendra Modi to observe Janata Curfew Organisations of bus owners, merchants and other establishments have agreed to close down their premises on Sunday. Temples, masjids and churches too will be closed. Meanwhile, all hospitals will be open for emergency cases.Though no positive cases were reported in the district, the district administration is leaving no stone unturned to prevent the spread of the disease. As a precautionary measure, the district administration has closed 16 out of 17 roads that connect Dakshina Kannada with Kasaragod district of Kerala, where six Covid-19 positive cases were reported. However, in Dakshina Kannada, all 89 samples tested for Covid-19 have come out negative.District minister Kota Shrinivas Poojari appealed to the people to strictly follow the guidelines and cooperate with the district administration to prevent the spread of the disease. “The 16 roads on the Karnataka-Kerala border in Dakshina Kannada will be closed till midnight on March 31. However, vehicles will be allowed in case of emergencies, under the Essential Commodities Act, to transport essential commodities mentioned in the act. Meanwhile, passengers in all coaches of trains that arrive in railway stations in the city will be thoroughly screened. Ships will not be allowed to dock at the Old Port in the city till midnight on March 31,” Kota said.The minister also appealed to the people to either impose restrictions or cancel festivals and rituals in temples, mosques and churches.“The entire nation is prepared to shut down on Sunday, with people cutting across political parties and religions readily agreeing to heed the call given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Chief minister B S Yediyurappa has appealed to the people to stay at home on Sunday. People should postpone all programmes, including marriages,” he added.Mosque shuts down Al Khaleel Masjid at Nellikai Road in the city has closed its gates as a preventive measure to check the spread of Covid-19. The managing committee of the masjid has put up a banner, informing community members that as a precautionary measure, there will be no entry into the masjid till the next order.Dakshina Kannada khazi Twaqa Ahmed Al Azhari said, “The world is in a very critical phase. We have already entered stage 2 of the Covid-19 outbreak, and we cannot imagine the consequences if it crosses this stage. The situation in Kasaragod district is very distressing. A situation is prevailing where congregations are not possible in mosques. Hence, no one should question if they are asked to offer namaz at homes. As per Islam, one will get heaven if he saves others’ lives by staying at home. Let us pray to Allah who is supreme.”Meanwhile, Christians in the district decided to participate in the obligatory Sunday mass online or through television. Temples have restricted the entry of devotees and cancelled all festivals. Some temples, including the Kudroli Sri Gokarnanatha Temple, have requested devotees not to visit the shrines till further notice.

Title: Three AMU students leave university’s isolation facility, traced to Kashmir
Content:
Aligarh Muslim University

AGRA: Three research scholars with a travel history to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) who left the isolation facility at the Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) were traced by police to their homes in Jammu & Kashmir. They are now quarantined in Baramulla district hospital in the valley, AMU spokesperson Shafey Kidwai has confirmed.

The research scholars claimed that they had informed their research supervisors and taken a train home.

Officials at AMU health centre — where the trio were housed — initially claimed the trio had absconded on March 19. But chief medical officer of AMU’s health centre Dr Shariq Aquil confirmed to TOI that the confusion arose because students had informed their research supervisors that they were leaving but not the health centre.

One of the research scholars told TOI they had arrived in Aligarh on March 9 and had been in self-isolation for four days. He said that after VC Tariq Mansoor’s notice that those with travel history to foreign countries should report to the health centre, all three of them had gone for a check up and were sent back to the hostel since they didn’t have any symptoms.

On March 18, provost of the hostel visited their rooms and asked them to get admitted to the health centre. “We were admitted there but instead of isolation wards, we were kept together in cubicles in one large room and not even given masks. One more student who had returned from Taiwan joined us and he was coughing and sneezing which is why we got scared and asked for separate isolation wards,” said the student. He said they left for home since they were not shifted to another ward.

AMU spokesperson, however, said proper precautions were taken. “The isolation ward has five cubicles, each separated by a six-feet wall. All students were kept in separate cubicles,” he said.

Title: Agra to observe complete shutdown during ‘Janata Curfew”
Content:
Agra: Following Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s clarion call to the nation to participate in the ‘Janata Curfew’ against Covid -19, all major business and market associations of Agra district have decided to observe a complete shutdown on Sunday.

Petrol pumps will remain closed from 7 am to 9 pm. Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) buses will not operate from 6 am to 10 pm. Agra- Mathura city bus services will also remain suspended. Major transporters have declared that their trucks will ply on Sunday.

On Saturday, shopping malls around the city remained close following the orders of the district magistrate. Shopkeepers downed their shutters early in the evening.

Agra Vyapar Mandal president TN Agarwal said, “Agra will be observing complete shutdown on Sunday. Except for pharmacies and other essential item shops, all businesses across the district will remain closed. It is the responsibility of every citizen to participate in the war against coronavirus.”

Heeren Agarwal, secretary of Sanjay Place Market Association, said, “We have asked all the members not to open their shops and showrooms on Sunday and avoid stepping out of the house if it is not necessary. It is the duty of each citizen to stop the virus from spreading and contribute in the efforts to so by the government.”

President of the Agra Shoe Factors Federation Gagandas Ramani said, “We welcome the Prime Minister’s call for Janata Curfew and will be observing complete shutdown on Sunday. Shoe factory owners have decided to keep operations suspended on Monday and Tuesday as well. We also should cooperate with the government in every possible way to check the spread of the the deadly virus.”

District president of the Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh Bhupendra Rana said, “The PM’s call for Janata Curfew is to benefit the entire nation. We have communicated the message to observe complete shutdown and social isolation on Sunday to our workers and members. Autorickshaws and e-rickshaw drivers’ leaders have been informed not to operate on Sunday.”

So far, eight positive cases have surfaced in Agra. Out of these, seven people have been cured and quarantined at home. One woman Covid-19 positive patient is being treated at SN Medical College.

Title: Petrol stations to stay closed
Content: Rajkot: Across Saurashtra, 1,500 petrol and gas station to remain closed from 7am to 7pm on Sunday in purview of the janata curfew. Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) will not run city buses on Sunday and made a helpline number public to seek transportation facility in case of emergency. The supply of milk in the morning is expected to be disrupted with most dairies in the city asking customers to stock their quota.

Title: Covid-19 pandemic: Pets bearing brunt of fake news forwards
Content: HYDERABAD: While coronavirus is spreading across the globe, fake news and misconceptions are spreading even faster. One such news is that of dogs and other domestic animals being carriers of this virus. In recent days, the state has seen a spike in abandonment of pets over such misconceptions. Animal activists said that in many cases, healthy dogs are being left on the streets by their owners.“I have been receiving 10 to 15 calls a day from people willing to give up their dogs. When I ask them why do they want to do so, some say they are scared they might get infected,” said Pravallika N, founder of Compassionate Society for Animals (CSA).Despite the World Health Organisation (WHO) denying rumours of dogs being carriers of the virus, many have been rushing to veterinary clinics to get their pets vaccinated. Veterinarians, at both private and government clinics, have been receiving an increasing number of calls for vaccination. “It is important to understand that coronavirus in dogs and novel coronavirus (Covid-19) are completely different. We are counselling people who are enquiring about the vaccine but still many insist on getting their pets vaccinated with the coronavirus injection,” said Dr M Nivedita who works for Blue Cross and also runs a private clinic.Coronavirus in dogs causes mild gastroenteritis along with diarrhoea and usually happens to older dogs while the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) is a respiratory disease which spreads only through human transmission. When asked about the crisis, GHMC chief veterinary officer Dr Abdul Vakil said: “It is illegal to abandon pets. We have already spread word among doctors and volunteers to explain and spread awareness about the fact that Covid-19 doesn’t spread from dogs and the coronavirus vaccine for dogs is optional.” He also added that strict action will be taken against those who abandon their pets.

Title: Shops selling non-essential items to be closed till Tuesday
Content:
Kolkata: All shops selling non-essential commodities will be shut till Tuesday, Confederation of West Bengal Traders’ Association president Sushil Poddar said on Saturday. The association will review the situation on Tuesday evening and decide whether to open on Wednesday or extend the closure.

The announcement triggered panic buying across markets, leading to shortage of essential commodities. Though the traders’ body claimed that shops selling foodgrains, staples and groceries were exempt from the purview of closure, people rushed to the markets to buy rice, wheat, pulses and potatoes in bulk. The shutdown will include trading and retail hubs in Burrabazar and New Market. Grocery, medicine and milk booths will open for a few hours.

While some traders said the panic buying was a result of consumer speculation of a long-term shutdown following the PM’s call for ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday, many also blamed a section of wholesalers and mahajans for hiking prices to take advantage of the Covid-19 scare.

Enforcement agencies and market task forces swung into action and carried out raids at the markets in Posta, Koley, Maniktala, Jadu Babur Bazaar to dissuade traders from adopting any dishonest means to maximize profits. Chief minister Mamata Banerjee has assured there will be no shortage of essential commodities in the state.

Panic purchase has been going on for three days now. Rice was the first staple commodity to fly off the shelves, followed by flour, edible oils and pulses. Potato, too , saw record sale in last few days.

Potato — which was selling at Rs13-14/kg on Thursday and Friday — cost Rs 25-30/kg on Saturday. In many markets, goods vehicles carrying potatoes reached late or did not reach at all — a typical ploy of hindering free flow of supply to jack up prices. “For the last three-four days, rumours were doing rounds that the government may go for long-term lockdown, necessitating the stocking of non-perishable essentials.

Kolkata mayor Firhad Hakim also assured that there will be no shortage of commodities. Citizens must not indulge in panic buying that will only encourage hoarders. “We are keeping some municipal markets open so that people can still buy essentials even on Sunday. I appeal to citizens not to venture out of their homes except in case of emergency.”

Sri Krishna Bhandar, a retail shop in Khidderpore, exhausted its sizeable stock of rice and pulses in two hours on Friday. “On Saturday, when I tried to book an order to replenish my stock, I found prices of all essential commodities had gone up by nearly Rs30/kg. My customers will think that I am hiking the price taking an advantage of their distress,” owner Jatin Ghosh said.

Title: How Racing Came to Bengaluru
Content:
BENGALURU: Somewhere on the border of what are now Austin Town and Domlur once stood an open plain. In the earlier half of the 19th century, this was once an animal fighting arena – where spectators watched battles with cheetahs, and between other big cats. According to historian BN Sundarrao, the author of Bengalurina Ithihasa (Bengaluru’s History), first published in 1983, describes the arena – complete with wooden galleries for the audience. Tigers and leopards that were captured from the wild were brought to the arena and grand events where men fought these wild beasts were arranged for the Bengaluru people. “Sundarrao records two incidents at the location when large crowds gathered to watch a group of British military men, named Lieutenant Audrey, Captain Sapper and Captain Cole fought tigers using spears and guns,” says Vemagal Somashekar, historian and author.

1857 changed everything for Bangalore. The first war of independence led to large scale deployment of British troops in the cantonment area. And with them came a passion for thoroughbreds and therefore, horseracing.

Ancient History

Horse racing has been around almost from the beginning, from when humans domesticated horses, in what is present day Kazakhstan, about 5,000 years ago. Chariot racing was part of the ancient Greek tradition of funeral games – sporting contests held to honour the recently deceased. They also became one of the biggest sports – and attractions – at the ancient Olympic games, when they were introduced in 680 BC.

These old racetracks were called hippodromes, dangerous tracks with hairpin turns at either end. In a tradition that continues to this day, the prizes and acclaim were given to the owners of the horse teams, not to the driver of the chariot or the horse’s jockey. A 2000-year-old tablet, part of the Lukuyanus monument in Turkey, contains details of the rules of racing at the time. Among the rules – a horse that won one race could not participate in other races, and its owner could not run a horse in any other race.

Horse races feature in Nordic myth as well. The Prose Edda by Snorri Sturluson describes a race between the god Odin and the giant Hrungnir, a race run because of Odin’s boast that his horse Sleipnir was faster than the giant’s steed Gullfaxi. Odin wins the close-fought race and invites the giant to Valhalla – setting of a chain of events that led to Hrungnir’s death.

British Institution

Horse racing as a professional sport in the UK can be traced back to the 12th Century after the English knights returned from the Crusades with Arab horses. These horses were bred with English horses to produce the thoroughbred horse. Later, during the reign of Charles II from 1660 to 1685 the king held horse races between two horses on private courses or open fields with prizes awarded to the winners and Newmarket was the venue for the first horse racing meetings in Britain. Racing as a spectator sport – with betting – took off in the early 1700s, and racecourses were built all over England. In 1750 horse racing’s elite met at Newmarket to form the Jockey Club to oversee and control English horse racing. The Jockey Club wrote a comprehensive set of rules for horse racing, and these rules were the basis of racing rules in their colonies – and therefore in India as well.

Colonial Heritage

The first racecourse in India was set up in Madras, back in 1777. From there, other turf clubs took hold. In Bangalore, the old animal fight arena was slowly converted to a racecourse.

Training for Courses

According to Captain Horace M Hayes, a British racing aficionado and expert on racing who lived in India in the nineteenth century, there were 74 racecourses in India in 1890. The Bangalore racecourse was a mile and two furlongs in length, and was one of the shorter courses in the country, but it made up for it by being on uneven ground. “I believe that the Bangalore Course, for one and a half miles, is six seconds slower than that of Madras,” Hayes wrote in his 1892 book, Training and Horse Management in India.

Not all races were run by the British, and they trained local men – preferably young teens to ride their horses, both during the training as well as the race. These boys were usually paid from Rs 6 to Rs 10 a month with a Rs 5 bonus every time their horse won. (An English jockey in India, on the other hand, was paid Rs 150 a month and Rs 100 for winning.

The New Club

This year, the Bangalore Turf Club celebrates its centenary. But racing in Bengaluru was much older than the club. The presence of the British soldiery in the city also saw the import of horses from the Middle East – most notably by Ali Asghar and others. The Mysore cavalry had rows of stables outside the city’s fort – in what is now Kalasipalayam. And as for Bengaluru’s original race course? The only remnant is in the name of a thoroughfare in Austin Town: Old Race Course Road.

The fire tragedy of 1970

On October 23, 1970, Bengaluru witnessed a fire tragedy when a horse stable on Palace Grounds went up in flames killing 35 animals. Allegedly set fire by some men, the incident drew much sympathy and anger among denizens then.

With the horse racing frenzy in its peak in the 70s, Bengaluru had a dedicated stable in Munireddy Palya (now JC Nagar) were the horses owned by various racing enthusiasts were kept. Over 50 people worked in the sheds which had a thatched roof and many horses including some famous ones were breed. According to old media reports and historian accounts, there was rift brewing between the workers in the sheds and the owners over money. It ended in a shockingly cruel twist, when some men allegedly set fire to the roof of the stables. 35 horses died. Media reports and images had half burnt bodies of the animals which had made a desperate attempt to escape the blaze.

A police investigation followed into the matter then and horse stables were permanently removed from the location.

— A photograph from 1952 of horse racing in Bangalore. Photo Courtesy: Rohit Hangal

Title: Electric bus depot will be developed at Etmadpur
Content:
Agra: The state government, under the Agra smart city project, has approved a plan to develop an electric bus depot and charging center on 1.94 hectare land in village Madra under Etmadpur sub-division. Besides, the process to purchase 100 battery-run buses, proposed to be operated by the Agra-Mathura city transport service limited, has been initiated.

According to city transport service officials, the land acquisition process will be started in April.

Managing director of Agra-Mathura city transport service RBL Sharma said, “The plan to develop a modern electric bus depot and charging centre at village Madra has been approved by the state government. The 1.94 hectare land on which the depot will be developed belongs to the Agra development authority (ADA). Registration process of the land will be completed in the next month.”

He said, “Hundred electric buses are proposed to be operated in Agra and Mathura city. Currently, 170 CNG buses operate in Agra and 60 diesel buses operate in Mathura. Majority of these buses are old and require replacement. The state government has taken the decision to replace old CNG and diesel buses with modern electricity buses. The process to purchase these buses has been initiated.”

The state government has planned to operate 580 electric buses on contract basis in nine major cities. Out of these, 100 buses will be operated in two cities under the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ).

Besides Agra and Mathura, other cities where electric buses will be operated include Kanpur, Prayagraj, Ghaziabad, Varanasi, Gorakhpur and Saharanpur. The urban transport directorate has planned to start operation of at least 10 buses in each city within the next three months.

According to officials of the urban transport directorate, the electric buses will have a travelling range of 150km on single charge. The buses will have maximum speed of 75 kilometer per hour. The lithium-ion batteries of these buses will not take more than 30 minutes to charge completely.

Title: Delhi: Buses at half strength, daily items available
Content:
The PM’s call has struck a chord with Delhiites, who have prepared for the daylong isolation.

NEW DELHI: For Shilpi Mukherjee, a 30-year-old Laxmi Nagar resident, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s call for ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday is not only a welcome initiative but also a breather. Mukherjee, who is employed in the development sector, hasn’t started working from home yet and now can’t decide how to spend this Sunday — by reading a book she bought last year or watching a new series.

“Self-isolation is extremely important because we don’t know when there could be a sudden spike in the number of Covid-19 cases. I would have preferred if the curfew was for four to five days,” she said. “Hopefully I would be able to work on alternate days from next week,” she added.

The PM’s call has struck a chord with Delhiites, who have prepared for the daylong isolation. Many have asked their domestic helps to take the day off and also cancelled visits to friends or relatives.

On Saturday, most people stocked up on food items such as bread, milk and vegetables, with the result that many shops had run out of milk by Saturday afternoon. “I don’t intend to get out of my house at all on Sunday and that’s why have thought of stocking up on some milk and noodles. However, local shops had run out of both by evening,” said Akash Sharma, a Malviya Nagar resident. “It is good move by the PM and I’m looking forward to showing my appreciation for those who are at the frontline of this battle at 5pm from my balcony.” Many people bought basic medicines, too.

“I plan to use the Sunday by starting to work on a novel that I have been planning for a long time. I will also spend time with my family,” said Prakash Kumar, of Ashok Vihar. “I’m missing my brother who is stranded in Australia,” he added.

“The move will prepare citizens for some kind of isolation and social distancing,” felt Pankaj Agarwal, general secretary of Delhi RWAs Joint Front. “Safdarjung Enclave, where I live, is already in ‘janata curfew’ mode and most shops are closed. At 5pm on Sunday, all residents of our block will come out and clap or clang utensils,” he said.

S R Sangar, general secretary of Federation of IP Extension II Housing Societies, said he had asked all RWAs of the area to cooperate with the initiative. “This will help instil discipline and stop the spread of the disease.”

B S Vohra, of East Delhi RWAs Joint Front, said it should have been a 15-day curfew. “Everyone is supportive of the initiative but I believe more awareness is needed for those who are not less educated.” In east Delhi, residents will come out at 5pm to express their support for the fight against novel coronavirus, he added.

S P Mudgal, general secretary of RWA of Maya Vihar in west Delhi, said even the temple in the area would be closed to make the move a success. “As the PM himself have requested people, everyone is prepared to do this,” he said.

Title: AMU to lodge FIR for confidential document leak
Content:
Representative image

AGRA: Stung by the recent “leak” of certain “confidential” documents pertaining to the fleeing of three Kashmiri students from the isolation ward of the varsity hospital and the notice served on a professor on charges of sexual harassment, the AMU authorities are considering to lodge an FIR.

According to a statement issued by the university , it has been brought to the notice of vice- chancellor Tariq Mansoor that certain confidential documents are being leaked.

These include documents which contain personal information of employees and students. The university is considering lodging an FIR in the matter, so that the persons responsible for the leak can be identified.

Sources said the VC had taken a serious note of the recent leak of these documents in particular.

Title: Hosps shun OP visit, take telemedicine route
Content:
Kochi: The new coronavirus is about to reshape the manner in which doctors and patients interact in the state. With the majority of hospitals discouraging OP consultations for routine or existing ailments, many hospitals and even healthcare providers have taken to telemedicine services.

Patients can now reach out to doctors over the phone, email or WhatsApp for medical advice in some clinics and hospitals, while in others, hospital staff is now reaching the patient’s doorstep.

“It is really a difficult time. Even as hospitals get ready to treat Covid-19 patients, we can’t forget our patients with existing illnesses as well as those who need medical help,” said Indian Medical Association ( IMA ) state president Dr Abraham Varghese.

“Many small clinics in Kochi have now started telemedicine services. The doctor interacts with a patient either through video call or by mail and advice patients on medicines and tests. Consultation fees are paid online,” said Varghese. This, despite the fact that several doctors had stopped responding to messages or emails in the wake of increasing cases of medical negligence.

On the other hand, Sunrise Hospital has initiated home services, in which a team will visit patients and prescribe medicines or tests. The team will dispense medicine and collect blood samples for further tests, if any. This facility will initially be available only within Thrikkakara municipal limits.

Meanwhile, various medical associations have decided to set up helpline numbers to provide voluntary consultations. People can clear doubts about medication, symptoms and issues related to lung health. “If there is Covid-19 outbreak in the community, the most vulnerable are those with respiratory problems such as COPD and asthma. To help such patients, we pulmonologists will be available on call,” said Academy of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine president-elect Dr P S Shajahan.

Even IMA has asked for a list of doctors in each district who are willing to provide voluntary free consultation over the phone.

Title: Unidentified man bludgeoned to death
Content:
Visakhapatnam: A 40-year-old man was found bludgeoned to death by unidentified persons near a roadside temple close to the Fourth Town police station on Saturday.

Police said his head was smashed with a big stone by the miscreants. The identity of the deceased is yet to be established.

K Rama Rao, the in-charge station house officer of Fourth Town PS, said the body was found at Navadurga peetham near Green Park colony in Balayya Sastry layout. The body was spotted by a devotee who had gone to the temple offer prayers in the early hours of Saturday. She informed her husband who immediately alerted the police. A big stone with blood marks was found near the body. Cops also found the business card of a Sriharipuram catering company from his trouser pockets. TNN

Title: Petrol stations to stay closed
Content: Rajkot: Across Saurashtra , 1 ,500 petrol and gas station to remain closed from 7am to 7pm on Sunday in purview of the janata curfew. Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) will not run city buses on Sunday and made a helpline number public to seek transportation facility in case of emergency. The supply of milk in the morning is expected to be disrupted with most dairies in the city asking customers to stock their quota.

Title: Why you need to clap for India’s healthcare workers
Content:
Doctors, nurses and

are fighting sweat, stigma, fear and frustration to save lives

DOCTOR’S ADVICE: This image of Amarinder Singh Malhi, senior resident at AIIMS Delhi, holding a placard has gone viral, with even PM Modi retweeting it. But the 37-year-old is worried. “Only 10-20% are following the advice to self-isolate. We need to amplify the message a lot more,” he says

No hugs, lonely meals

Landlord throws out nurses

Double workload for lab staff

*Name changed on request

Reporting by Himanshi Dhawan & Durgesh Nandan Jha in Delhi, Shailvee Sharda in Lucknow, Sunitha Rao in Bengaluru, Sajimon PS in Alappuzha, Malathy Iyer & Sumitra Deb Roy in Mumbai

Dr Preeti’s* day starts with donning a hazmat suit before she enters the virology lab in Delhi’s AIIMS . It could be 12-14 hours before she can think of leaving. Since the beginning of March, lunch and dinner often merge into one, sleep is less than three hours as she and her colleagues examine petri dishes of nasal and measles swabs. About 192 samples are tested in 24 hours and the work requires extreme caution and accuracy. “As doctors we are used to working under pressure but this is different. The hazmat suit is suffocating and sweaty, and then there is a fear that engulfs you. The sample shouldn’t spill, it shouldn’t get contaminated, the results should be accurate….so much is at stake,” says the 29-year-old senior resident. Healthcare workers in government hospitals and labs have always dealt with less pay and heavy workloads but now there’s sweat (from the hazmat suits if they’re lucky to get one), fear (of getting infected, especially with a face mask shortage lurking), frustration (at not knowing how to stop the march of this virus).DOCTOR’S ADVICE: This image of Amarinder Singh Malhi, senior resident at AIIMS Delhi, holding a placard has gone viral, with even PM Modi retweeting it. But the 37-year-old is worried. “Only 10-20% are following the advice to self-isolate. We need to amplify the message a lot more,” he says.While others get more family time during quarantines, doctors are scared to touch, let alone hug their wives and kids. Dr D Himanshu Reddy, in charge of the infectious disease unit at Lucknow’s King George’s Medical University (KGMU), moved out of home and into the hospital guest house five days earlier. “I distanced myself as soon as the first positive case in Lucknow was reported. I have not seen my father and children for about 10 days,” he says. To add to the tension, a doctor in the hospital tested positive for Covid-19 earlier this week. Some stay at home, but with strict isolation protocols. “Just like patients in the isolation ward, we lead restricted lives at home,” says KGMU’s Dr Mohd Ansari, who got the entire first floor of his house converted into an isolation zone to quarantine himself after duty. He eats alone and washes his own clothes to protect his family.Like many of her colleagues, Dr Preeti has shifted into the AIIMS hostel, and speaks to her parents on the phone to allay their concerns. “I know that the phone can also be a source of contamination so I don’t use it in the lab. I try and catch up with them when I am off-duty,” she says in a tired voice.Despite the hard slog, doctors have to often deal with hostile patients who want to leave. “Quarantined people whose test results are yet to arrive make irrational demands. Some of them fight with us to let them go home. It is very frustrating,” says a doctor posted at Delhi’s Safdarjung hospital.For nurses, the job profile now includes monitoring patients in quarantine and even keeping guard. At the entrance to the isolation ward no 27 in BMC-run Kasturba Hospital sits an alert nurse, covered in a green protection suit and an N95 mask. Nothing misses her eye — or ears. “Don’t allow anyone to linger here,’’ she shouts at the guards while rushing out to shoo away people hanging around. “It is for your own good,’’ she tells the hangers-on. In times of Covid-19, it is perhaps the sanest piece of advice, but these women and men manning the wards of Mumbai’s only infectious diseases hospital can do anything but “stay home’’. Doctors working here say nurses (“You will find only senior, well-trained nurses in Kasturba Hospital,’’ said a senior doctor) are the main backbone of a hospital with a minimal workforce that comprises PG students on rotation from a nearby civic medical school.Like doctors, nurses too are tense. A nurse in Bengaluru’s Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases self-isolated for a whole month till she tested negative for Covid. “I went to meet my parents in my hometown only after the results,” he says.The four Covid-19 patients stuck in the isolation ward of the Medical College Hospital (MCH), Kottayam, often chat with the nursing staff who attend to them. However, the three male nurses who voluntarily opted to do this duty which many colleagues avoided, are not battling just a pandemic but also social stigma. Last week, their landlord told them to vacate the house they were renting since he feared infection. Though the trio, all in their early 30s, got temporary accommodation in the hospital, they doubt that anybody will give them a house. Indira P G, a nursing officer at MCH, says nursing staff needs more support. “Society should realise what the world would be like if no nurse wanted to work in such situations,” she said.In the last two months, laboratories too that have come under huge pressure. At the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Alappuzha, tests have seen a spike from 70-80 samples a day to 250 in March, forcing the team of 20 to stretch their working hours. What keeps them going? Officer-in-charge A P Sugunan (Scientist-G) says each negative result is a shot in the arm. Jijo Koshi, a lab technician, from Thiruvananthapuram, has been living away from home since the beginning of March. He says, “Though I want to see them, there is no time. I spend most of my day in the lab and manage with food from outside.”But still India’s healthcare staff goes on. “People at home say take leave and come for back after two months. But though it sounds dramatic I have told them that this is war, and I am a soldier and soldier’s families don’t talk like that,” says a 29-year-old senior resident at Safdarjung hospital.

Title: Section 144 imposed in five districts of south Gujarat
Content:
Corona sample testing laboratory has started functioning at NCH

Surat: After Surat’s Diamond City, authorities have imposed Section 144 of The Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) in Valsad, Navsari, Dang, Tapi and Bharuch districts in south Gujarat also to prohibit large gatherings to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

The prohibitory orders issued in these districts ask all cinema halls, shopping malls, trade fairs, auditoriums, dance classes, tuition classes and educational institutions to shut down till March 31. Jan Seva Kendras in these districts too will remain shut. Entry of visitors at government offices in these districts have been banned till March 31, sources said.

Dr MD Modiya, district collector of Bharuch, said, “Section 144 has been imposed in the entire Bharuch district to contain the spread of COVID-19. We have shutdown shopping malls, restaurants, hotels etc. as a precautionary measure. Also, people in industrial estates in Ankleshwar and Dahej have been asked to voluntarily shutdown their units till March 31.”

Dr Modiya said about 1,000 bed quarantine facility has been set up in government hospitals and hostels in Bharuch district. About 132 people having travel history to foreign countries are under home quarantine and that samples of four suspected patients have tested negative.

Navsari district collector Ardra Agarwal said, “Section 144 has been imposed in the entire district and we have appealed to residents to stay indoors to stop the spread of COVID-19. At present, we have about 200 people under home quarantine and no positive case has been reported. Eateries and restaurants have been shut in Navsari to prevent people from coming out of their houses.”

Title: Section 144 in Bharuch, malls, tuition classes forcibly closed
Content:
Bharuch/Surat: District administration in an advisory issued on Friday had asked all shopping malls , gymnasiums and tuition classes to close with immediate effect as a preventive measure against the spread of COVID-19. “A number of mega malls, gymnasiums and tuition classes found open in violation of the orders were forcibly closed on Saturday. We also appeal to citizens to stay at home on Sunday to break the chain of the virus. Only essential services will be operational,” Bharuch district collector Dr. M D Modiya said.

He informed that Section 144 of The Code Of Criminal Procedure has been imposed in Bharuch district prohibiting assembly of four or more people in an area.

Meanwhile, samples of three persons, who were kept in isolation ward of Bharuch Civil Hospital, have tested negative for coronavirus. The administration has set up 455-bed facilities at various hospitals in the district to treat coronavirus patients. People can contact local helpline number 02642 252472 in case of any emergency, he added.

Title: Pune, Tamil Nadu cases spur contact-tracing efforts
Content: NEW DELHI: Amid fear that Covid-19 positive cases – one each in Tamil Nadu and Pune could be the first cases of community transmission, the government is vigorously pursuing contact tracing in these cases to identify sources and break the chain of transmission.A 20-year-old Delhi resident in Tamil Nadu and a woman in Pune who tested positive this week had, unlike other “positive cases”, not travelled to any foreign country and have denied coming into contact with a known Covid-19 patient.Authorities are yet to establish the source of infection in these cases and if further investigation confirms their account, then the two cases will mark the worrying evidence that the virus might have spread in the community— a threshold at which a huge surge of incidence may become unavoidable. The health ministry on Saturday maintained there was no evidence of community transmission in the country, and that the two particular cases were still being investigated. Official sources said there are indications that the individuals don’t have adequate recollection of events involving them— essentially, who all they came in contact with— and a firm conclusion can be reached about the source of their infection once the “missing links have been established”.The government and health agencies in multiple states are carrying out an aggressive drive to trace the contacts of these two cases and locate people they have met, events attended by them, places they have visited, transports used by them, even co-passengers and various other minute details to establish the source of infection.

Title: Assam reports first coronavirus positive case in Jorhat
Content: A four and a half-year-old girl tested positive for coronavirus at Jorhat Medical College and Hospital (JMCH) on Saturday, reports Anup Dutta . The girl along with her family came to Assam from Bihar on March 19 and was staying at Pulibor area on the outskirts of the town. “The family has been shifted to JMCH isolation ward,” said deputy commissioner (Jorhat) Roshni Aparanji Korati. “The child’s sample has tested positive at Jorhat lab but we want to confirm for Covid-19 and so we have sent for a second test to Lahowal ICMR lab,” said health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma She added, the girl, her sister and mother came from Bihar to Jorhat on March 19. Health officials visited the family on the next day and brought them to JMCH as the girl exhibited symptoms. Sample was taken, tested and found positive this evening.”Korati also that they have sent the sample to Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) for recheck and waiting for reports.Korati further said that district administration officials started contact tracing and everybody is being placed under isolation including ASHA worker. The family has also been shifted to JMCH isolation ward.

Title: Colleges allow teachers to work from home in S Guj
Content:
Surat: Several colleges affiliated to Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) on Saturday decided to allow their teachers to work from home for the next few days in view of outbreak of coronavirus in parts of the world, including India. The time period differs from college to college for the teachers, but majority of administrative staff will have to go to their offices. Teaching has been suspended and examinations postponed in the colleges affiliated to the university.

Teaching on the university campus on UM Road has been discontinued, but no directives have been issued till Saturday evening regarding allowing VNSGU teachers to work from home. On Saturday, senator Ganpat Dhameliya submitted a written application to university authorities requesting that teachers be allowed to stay at home for a few days. Associations of college teachers and university teachers followed up on his demand and wrote to the VNSGU authorities too.

Title: Covid-19: Establishments advised to blow sirens at 5pm
Content:
NEW DELHI: In view of Prime Minister’s appeal to countrymen to observe a 14-hour ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday and applaud all those in the forefront of fighting Covid-19 at 5 pm.

Union home secretary Ajay Bhalla has written to chief secretaries and administrators of all states/Union Territories asking them to widely disseminate the PM’s message to the community at large.

He also asked the state governments and UT administrations to advice urban local bodies, panchayats, fire services, police, civil defence and industrial establishments etc to ring a siren at 5pm for intimation of all citizens. “All should ackno-wledge the work being done by medical staff, police, government servants, airline staff, mediapersons, bus/train/auto operators and home delivery guys,” he said.

Title: His creative technology truly prevention better than cure
Content:
It’s one of the oldest and often used adage — prevention is better than cure — and probably that’s why its importance is lost. But 28-year-old entrepreneur Shubhendra Singh Thakur has designed his entire life’s philosophy around it. Having conceptualized and made early detection kits for kidney disease and oral cancer, Thakur is hoping that ‘nipping it in the bud’ will help to stem the rot.

A B.Sc (biology) student, Thakur has always been fascinated with creating new gadgets which can help make people’s lives easier. He won an innovation award for start-ups in 2017 which was organized by Bootstrap track of FbStart, a Facebook platform. That award was for a college campus networking app.

Later, for safety of women, he developed a glove which gave an electric shock to the perpetrator.

But his shift towards medical devices started due to a personal reason. Thakur said, “In 2017, doctors said that my mother’s kidneys have shrunk. The options were a kidney transplant or to continue dialysis.”

He started researching on both options and for dialysis, he found that the mental trauma to the patient is more dangerous. “The patient already feels he’s a burden to others around him and lying in bed for hours during dialysis pushes him more into depression,” said Thakur.

The exceedingly long paperwork for kidney transplant, even if coming from a family member, and costs associated with it were beyond what a middle class family can manage. “I realized that had early detection happened, my mother’s kidneys would never have reached this stage. It’s then that I started working on the device that would help give out those signals early,” said Thakur, whose mother’s help is now slowly improving.

Around the same time, as Thakur’s trips to various hospitals increased, he came across patients of oral cancer. “Their level of pain is unbearable. Patients come there at a stage when cancer has taken control and operating is the only option. I decided that this is something which also needs to be detected early through simple home-based tests,” said Thakur.

By early 2019, he had completed both his liver disease and oral cancer detecting kits, which work in non-invasive way. “People just have to use either their urine or saliva samples. These devices basically tell you whether or not you are at risk of a kidney disease or oral cancer. This helps people take an early and informed decision about seeking professional medical help,” said Thakur.

He strongly believes that such early interventions will not only help save people’s lives, but also lessen the burden on the health care system.

xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Title: Amid exodus from cities, PM says avoid crowding stations
Content: NEW DELHI: With reports of people leaving cities in droves by taking crowded trains because of the coronavirus scare, PM Narendra Modi on Saturday took to twitter to put out a strong “stay put” appeal saying that it would increase the risk of infections. Modi also exhorted quarantined people to heed doctor’s advice not to venture out. He said: “I pray that the city you are in, please stay there for a few days. With this, all of us can stop the disease from spreading. We are playing with our health by crowding railway stations and bus stands. Please worry about yourself and your family, do not leave your house if it is not necessary.He also asked those quarrantined to abide by the advice by doctors. Using the hashtag #IndiaFightsCorona and sharing videos on precautions that can be taken against the infection, he said on Twitter: “This is the time we should all listen to the advise given by doctors and authorities. All those who have been told to stay in home quarantine, I urge you to please follow the instructions. This will protect you and others.” In line with his address to the nation on Thursday where he announced a voluntary 14-hour citizens’ “curfew”, the PM sought cooperation of people in staying home and avoiding unnecessary travel.In a move to provide credible information and bust myths, the PM announced the launch of a government of India collaboration with WhatsApp for a ‘Corona Helpdesk’ which would help disseminate authentic information on Covid-19. He also appreciated Twitter for its effort to provide credible updates on the situation in India.

Title: Most flights cancelled from city due to fall in passenger traffic
Content:
Surat: Airlines operating from Surat airport have started cancelling flights due to sharp drop in number of passengers amid virus scare.

Air India announced cancellation of its evening flight between Delhi and Surat for a week from March 22 to 27. The AI has also cancelled its morning flight every Wednesday and Saturday and evening flight every Saturday during the summer schedule.

SpiceJet had cancelled its flights from Surat to Goa, Jaisalmer, Jaipur and Udaipur on Friday. Majority of flights operating from Surat remained cancelled on Saturday.

Sources said passenger footfall at the airport has gone down drastically as the airport is also facing huge drop in passenger traffic. Airport director Aman Saini said, “After the travel advisory people are avoiding travelling in flights. Screening of passengers at the airport is going on. Till now, we have not found any suspected case. Sharjah-Surat international flight had already been suspended.”

tnn

Title: No Public Transport To Run Today, 4,000 Isolation Wards Ready in City
Content:
Visakhapatnam: For the first time in history, public transport services including buses and trains will be completely shut down on Sunday. While some of these services will be shut for just one day, many will remain closed till the end of the month. Owing to the announcement of Janata Curfew on March 22, people have been advised to stay at home.

Executive director for the AP public transport department, Ravi Kumar said that all 12,000 buses across the state, including 3,000 in Vizianagaram zone would go off the roads from zero hour on Sunday. Buses to Hyderabad from Visakhapatnam have been cancelled on Saturday, he added. “The shutdown of bus service in the Vizianagaram zone will cause a loss of Rs 3.3 crore,” Kumar said.

Railway officials too said that all train services from Visakhapatnam will remain suspended on Sunday. “Nearly 40 trains pass between the two Telugu states daily. All trains will stop running from late evening Saturday till late evening Sunday,” a railway official informed. Some of the major trains to have been cancelled are the Visakhapatnam to Secunderabad Duronto Express and the Secunderabad to Visakhapatnam AC Weekly Express.

Meanwhile, Visakhapatnam district collector V Vinay Chand said on Saturday that 20 teams have been formed to track suspected Covid-19 cases in the district. The collector reviewed the situation with allied departments.

Speaking on the occasion, the collector said that foreign returnees must be tracked and quarantined. He further said that medical drills will be conducted at hospitals where isolation wards have been set up. Nearly 4,000 isolation wards would be kept ready in Visakhapatnam, the collector informed.

The collector said that 20 committees will inspect the isolation wards and that ambulances should prioritise facilitation of Covid-19 positive cases.

Every hospital must follow a protocol in handling such cases and 10,000 beds should be ready by Monday in Visakhapatnam, the collector said. He added that a containment zone should be formed in every 3km radius and a buffer zone should be formed in every 2km radius. Lab surveillance committees have been asked to send reports by 5pm every day.

Tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao inspected the arrangements being made at the airport. He asked the airport staff to examine all domestic and international travellers and take a self-declaration from domestic travellers as well. He asked the West zone ACP to deploy more police personnel at the airport.

Title: Vizagites throng rythu bazaars to stock up on essentials
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Rythu bazaars in Visakhapatnam saw large crowds come in on Saturday to stock up on essentials ahead of the ‘Janata curfew’ on Sunday. At around 8am on Saturday, a long and serpentine queue could be spotted in front of the MVP Colony rythu bazaar .

People had come in to stock supplies for a week. Among essential commodities featured rice, pulses, and vegetables with relatively long shelf lives as well as eggs, which had become unpopular among residents for some time now.

Speaking to TOI, a shopkeeper from Kommadi rythu bazaar said, “There has been a great demand for vegetables like potatoes, onions, drumsticks and tomatoes. People are actually buying in bulk. Whatever I sold on Saturday was around four times of what I sell on usual Sundays.”

This rush to stock up on essential commodities happened in context of the Janata curfew to be observed on Friday. All 13 rythu bazaars in Visakhapatnam will remain closed on Sunday.

K Prabhakar, who was busy buying vegetables at MVP Colony said, “We do our weekly shopping on Sundays. But since my office has been closed for a week and I don’t want to take any chances I am here today. I don’t know what will happen if the government announces a lockdown.” tnn

Title: Coaches disinfected for ‘2 suspect cases’
Content:
Screening at railway platform

Surat: About three coaches of the Mumbai Central-Surat Intercity express were disinfected twice — at Vapi and at Valsad railway stations — after two passengers stamped ‘home quarantine’ were deboarded from S-2 coach of the train at Virar station in Mumbai.
